Author: Mariena Mercer
About: At The Chandelier bar at The Cosmopolitan hotel in Las Vegas, chief mixologist Mariena Mercer has been experimenting with Szechuan buttons for years, and this cocktail is one of the bar’s most popular signature drinks.
Instructions:
Combine the lemon verbena leaves and ginger syrup in a cocktail shaker and muddle.

Add the remaining ingredients and ice and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a double rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a Szechuan button.

*Yuzu-calamansi sour mix: Combine 1 cup water and 1 cup sugar in a saucepan. Heat slowly, stirring until sugar dissolves. Remove from heat and let cool. Combine with 1 cup freshly squeezed yuzu juice and 1 cup freshly squeezed calamansi juice.

**Ginger syrup: Combine 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar and ¼ pound ginger, peeled and thinly sliced, in a saucepan. Heat slowly, stirring until sugar dissolves. Simmer for 30 minutes. Remove from heat, let cool and strain out solids.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The coconut, key lime and cilantro in this vodka cocktail can immediately send you somewhere warm and sunny with sparkling waters.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled rocks glass, and garnish with 2 sprigs of cilantro.

About: Enjoy the once-illicit absinthe in an old-fashioned Absinthe Drip.
Instructions:
Fill an absinthe fountain with ice water.

Pour the absinthe into an absinthe glass and place an absinthe spoon topped with the sugar cube across the rim. Position the glass under a spigot of the fountain and slowly drip water over the sugar cube until the sugar dissolves and the absinthe turns completely opaque.

(You will need roughly 5 ounces of water per ounce of absinthe).

Stir briefly before serving.

About: This bright and refreshing spin on the Martini trades in olives for raspberries. It strikes the perfect balance between sweet and tart. Grab your muddler and a little mint to make it yourself.
Ingred: .5 oz St Germaine Elderflower Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Muddle raspberries, simple syrup, and mint in a shaker.

Add remaining ingredients with ice and shake.

Strain into a martini glass.

Garnish with two raspberries.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Get a taste of summer with this citrusy gin drink.
Ingred: Bitter lemon soda or lemon-flavored club soda
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with bitter lemon soda or lemon-flavored club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Phillip Ricafort, American Oak
About: The Wabash Avenue Sour updates the Whiskey Sour by adding Chicago’s own FEW bourbon or rye. And that’s not the only ingredient shaking up the classic recipe.
Ingred: .5 oz Cherry liqueur (Cherry Heering or Luxardo Sangue Morlacco).5 oz
.5 oz Small Hand Foods pineapple gum syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients and dry-shake (without ice), then add ice, and shake again.

Strain into coupe and garnish with rhubarb bitters.

Author: Mount Gay
About: Prefer rum to whiskey? This twist on the old timey classic will cure all your ailments.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Mount Gay Extra Old Rum
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, lightly muddle the orange peel with the rum and sugar.

Remove the peel and add bitters and ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with the orange slice and cherry.

Author: Andrew Olsen
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except the curaçao in mixing glass, and add ice.

Stir to standard dilution.

Rinse a coupe with the curaçao.

Strain into a chilled and rinsed coupe.

Garnish with one Fabbri amarena cherry and manicured orange swath.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: Liz Taylor once said that this unlikely combination of ingredients was her favorite cocktail.
Instructions:
Heat the chocolate syrup until warm.

Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir.

Fill with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. .

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: Rye whiskey, Campari and sweet port join forces in this delicious sipper.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Graham's Six Grapes Port 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir briefly and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice or a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a dusting of ground cinnamon.

Author: Tristan Willey
About: For this white version of the classic Americano, bartender Tristan Willey mixes Suze, a gentian-based herbal apéritif from Switzerland, with Carpano Bianco, a lightly sweet, round white Italian vermouth. The resulting drink is fragrant and low-alcohol, perfect for day drinking.
Instructions:
Add the Suze and Carpano Bianco to a Collins glass filled with ice and stir.

Top with soda water, and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

About: No, it’s not a dance. But it just might spark some killer moves. To prepare a Rum Swizzle, it’s best to use an authentic swizzle stick. Real swizzle sticks are long stems snapped off a tree native to the Caribbean, and feature multiple prongs that stick out horizontally. When spun rapidly between your hands inside a cold cocktail, the swizzle stick will create a thick layer of frost on the outside of a glass—the sign of a perfect swizzle.
Instructions:
Fill a pitcher a third of the way with crushed ice, and add all the ingredients.

Churn vigorously until frothing (or shake in a large shaker), and strain into 4 rocks glasses filled with fresh ice.

Garnish each with an orange slice, a pineapple cube and a cherry.

Author: Naren Young
About: This fall-forward combination of pear brandy, applejack and sherry is versatile enough to be served cold or as a warm Toddy.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Clear Creek Pear Brandy 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain over one large hand-carved ice cube.

Spray with allspice tincture, garnish with pear crisp and serve on a burning maple leaf.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About:
Hot Buttered Rum is a warm, soothing cocktail that hits the spot when a chill is in the air. Adding butter to a cocktail may seem a little out of the ordinary, but the pat of butter imparts a richness to the Hot Buttered Rum that would otherwise be missing. While many recipes call for a simple pat of butter to be added to the cocktail, this version instead calls for butter batter, which tends to make it creamier and avoids the oil slick that generally forms on top.
While the Hot Buttered Rum dates back to colonial times, it was Kenneth Roberts’ 1937 best-seller, “Northwest Passage,” that reignited the passion for Hot Buttered Rum. The passion warmed the hearts and hands of many a drinker on frosty nights and continues unabated to this date.
Instructions:
Add the rum and batter to a mug.

Fill with boiling water and stir.

Author: Tori Bender
About:
No mini umbrella is required for this remarkably refreshing Tiki cocktail. All you need are fresh, natural island flavors and some premium dark rum.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tiki Grows Up: Three Drinks That Will Win You Over.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker, and dry-shake (no ice) until well-blended.

Strain into a Napoli or Hurricane glass over fresh pebble ice.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

About: A lot of people like a little something bubbly with their brunch. Move past the Mimosa and the rosé, and satisfy that craving with an Aperol Spritz. An Aperol Spritz is bubbly and low-proof, making it the perfect cocktail for daytime drinking. This is one of the most popular cocktails in Italy. Soon enough, it will be a favorite for your customers, too.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a wine glass with ice and stir.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: George Costa
About: This vodka-and-grapefruit concoction is pure old-school.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with salt and fill with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This cocktail, which appears in Kat Odell’s Day Drinking: 50 Cocktails for a Mellow Buzz
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a shaker, and muddle to break down the orange.

Add ice cubes to fill the shaker three-quarters full, cover, and shake to chill for about 15 seconds.

Strain over ice into a rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange slice.

About: Think of this as a refined Italian alternative to a Screwdriver. The orange juice makes it a natural fit in the family of brunch cocktails, while the Campari gives it Italian authenticity. The Campari Orange isn’t the most famous use of Campari—that distinction goes to the Negroni—but this aperitivo should really, truly be a brunch staple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Highball glass filled with ice and stir.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: No offense to whiskey, but the most delicious, inspired take on the Old Fashioned might just be the one that includes dark rum. Judge for yourself by making the BACARDÍ® Rum Old Fashioned today.
Ingred: 2 oz BACARDÍ Gran Reserva eight-year-old rum
Instructions:
Place 1 large ice cube into an Old Fashioned glass.

Add all the ingredients, and stir for about 5 seconds.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Kaitlyn Goalen
About: For the cocktail lover on hiatus, the Waiting Room offers a sophisticated mocktail inspired by the soda fountain. Pineapple gomme syrup delivers a silky mouthfeel similar to that of booze, and acid phosphate provides all the acidic punch of citrus with none of the sugar.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker filled with ice, add the syrup, acid phosphate and bitters.

Shake well until chilled.

Add the cream and more ice and shake again for about 20 seconds.

Strain into a Collins glass and top with the seltzer. .

Author: Tony Abou-Ganim
About: Try this modern San Francisco classic.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Marie Brizard Orange Curaçao 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Stir together the cinnamon and sugar in a wide-mouthed bowl or on a saucer.

Rub the rim of a chilled cocktail glass with the lemon wedge and dip in the cinnamon-sugar mixture to coat.

Set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass and garnish with an orange spiral.

About: Named for a character in Game of Thrones, this Sazerac update is full of warm masala spices.
Instructions:
Rinse a coupe with absinthe.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir well.

Strain the cocktail into the coupe.

Garnish with an orange peel.

*Masala spice syrup: Steep equal parts water and sugar with a combination of cinnamon, cardamom, clove, anise, sumac and pepper.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Subtle sweetness and refreshing coolness make this a perfect warm-weather cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Cucumber, peeled and roughly chopped
1.5 oz Grey Goose La Poire flavored vodka
Garnish: 1 Mint, cucumber slices and lemon zest
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cucumber.

Add the vodka, St-Germain, lemon juice and simple syrup, and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with mint, cucumber slices and lemon zest and top with lemonade or club soda.

About: The spicy notes of rye whiskey and ginger pair beautifully in the simple and classic Ginger Ale Highball.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with ice and add the whiskey.

Fill with ginger ale.

Author: Helen Diaz
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“The original 49ers were gold seekers that came through California in 1849 during the Gold Rush,” says bartender Helen Diaz of Bloodhound and Churchill in San Francisco. “When I think about the 49ers, I think Gold Rush, and then I think of the Gold Rush cocktail. This is the Gold Rusher! What better way to represent this team but to add a little fernet to the drink?” she says, calling on the fact that San Francisco consumes more fernet than any other place in the country.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until cold.

Double-strain over a large handcut chunk of ice into a rocks glass, and garnish with a mint sprig.

*Ginger solution: Heat 1 part water in a small pot over medium heat. Add 1 part sugar and 1 part ginger juice, and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved. Remove from heat and let cool before using.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Believed to have originated in the 1970 by a bartender and fan of the iconic band, the B-52 is classic guilty pleasure armed with three liqueurs. Make this layered shooter in seconds and impress all your friends.
Ingred: 1⁄3 oz Baileys Irish cream liqueur 1⁄3 oz
Instructions: Layer the three spirits in a shot glass in the order that they're listed.

Author: Eric Alperin
About: This rum punch plays off cold-brew coffee’s bright orange-peel and spice flavors.
Ingred: 4 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
In a large bowl or pitcher, muddle the sugar and orange peel.

Let stand for an hour or so to extract the oils.

Add the remaining ingredients and a little cracked ice.

Stir, and strain into a punch bowl filled with a large ice block.

Top with a sprinkling of ground cinnamon.

Serve in teacups, garnished with cinnamon sticks cracked in half the long way.

About:
Think the Margarita is the ultimate Mexican cocktail? Think again. The Paloma is a quick and easy classic that can be made right in the glass. Whether drinking solo or with company, this drink will fulfill all your tequila  needs.
Make it a meal with this taco soup recipe.
Ingred: Grapefruit soda (Jarritos or Squirt work best)
Instructions:
Combine the tequila, lime juice and salt in a highball glass.

Add ice and top off with the grapefruit soda.

Stir gently and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Zacapa Rum
About: Rum and honey syrup make an unusual but delicious version of the classic.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Jim Kearns
About: This tantalizing cocktail is a smoky and frothy twist on the traditional Whiskey Sour.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Lapsang souchong tea syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds until drink is frothy, and strain into a coupe glass.

About: We got the recipe for this modern classic from Beachbum Berry’s Latitude 29 in New Orleans.
Ingred: 2 oz Caña Brava 7-year-old grand reserve añeja rum
4 whole lychee nuts, shelled (drained if canned)
1⁄4 oz Rhum Clément Mahina Coco liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1 dash Fee Brothers Aztec chocolate bitters
Instructions:
Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1.5 cups crushed ice for up to 20 seconds until frappéd.

Pour unstrained into a Cocktail Kingdom Pearl Diver glass, and garnish with an edible orchid, pineapple wedge and straw.

Author: Martin Cate
About: This modern Tiki cocktail takes the Zombie, a fairly complex drink, cuts down the number of ingredients and puts it in a coupe.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Blended aged rum (Appleton Estate Reserve or The Real McCoy 5-Year-Old)
.5 oz John D. Taylor’s Velvet falernum.5 oz
.5 oz Fresh grapefruit juice (white or pink).5 oz
Intertwined lime and grapefruit twists, for garnish
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled cocktail coupe with absinthe blanc. Add the remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker with cracked or cubed ice.

Shake and double-strain into the coupe and add the garnish.

*SC cinnamon syrup: Put 2 cups of water in a saucepan.

Add 3 halved 6-inch pieces of cinnamon stick to the water, and bring to a boil over high heat.

Add 4 cups of granulated sugar and stir with a whisk (or an immersion blender) until dissolved for about 1 minute.

The liquid should become clear such that you can see the bottom of the pot.

Immediately remove from the heat. Cover and let sit at room temperature for 12 hours.

Strain through cheesecloth into a bowl, and then use a funnel to pour into a lidded bottle or other sealable container.

The syrup will keep, refrigerated, for several weeks. Makes 4 cups (32 oz).

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The Grasshopper cocktail is a minty classic that is better than your traditional dessert.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Grate fresh nutmeg directly over the center of the drink.

Author: Aida Mollenkamp
About: This sparkling pear-and-cardamom elixir is the official cocktail of the 2014 Golden Globes.
Ingred: 20 Cardamom pods, crushed with the side of a knife or a mortar and pestle
Moët & Chandon Imperial Brut Champagne, chilled
Instructions:
In a small saucepan, bring the sugar, water and cardamom to a simmer over medium heat.

Simmer for 5 minutes, remove from the heat and let cool for 20 minutes.

Strain, and stir in the pear brandy.

(This mixture can be made up to 2 days ahead of time.) Add half an ounce of the pear-cardamom mixture to each of 6 white wine or coupe glasses.

Top each glass with 4 ounces of Champagne.

To garnish, core 2 Forelle or Seckel pears and cut into eighth-inch slices.

Garnish each glass with 3 pear slices spread into a fan shape.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Add a light Mexican beer to get a super-refreshing Margarita.
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a highball glass with salt, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the tequila, Cointreau and lime juice to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with the beer and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Pyrat Rum
About: This drink will make you passionate about rum.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a bucket glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a peach wedge if desired.

Author: John O’Connell
About: John O’Connell of West Cork Distillers in Cork, Ireland, recommends this Irish version of a Manhattan
Ingred: 1 oz West Cork Distillers 10-year-old single-malt Irish whiskey
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

About: This Irish Coffee from The Dawson is both soothing and luxurious. It’s an upscale cocktail you can make at home.
Ingred: .5 oz Kronan Swedish Punsch liqueur.5 oz
Metric Le Corbusier French roast coffee Metric Le Corbusier French roast coffee
Instructions:
Add the whiskey, liqueur and syrup to an Irish Coffee glass, and top with the coffee.

Whip the cream in a sealed container, and slowly pour over the top of the cocktail.

Garnish with a dusting of chai masala powder.

Author: Beau du Bois
About: Improve on the classic Hot Buttered Rum with sherry and mulled cider.
Ingred: 4 oz Mulled cider, hot (use your favorite recipe or packaged mix)
Instructions:
Add the rum and butter to a mug and slowly pour in the mulled cider.

Sprinkle the five-spice powder on top.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Every day is a holiday with this fizzy, fruity vodka punch.
Instructions:
In a large bowl, muddle the orange peels and sugar to form a paste.

Add the lemon juice, syrup and both vodkas, and stir to combine.

Place a large block of ice in a punch bowl and add the vodka mixture.

Top with the sparkling wine and water.

Stir, and garnish with thinly cut lemon wheels and thin slices of fig.

About: Forget the whiskey. This warming Toddy replaces the brown spirit with cachaça laced with chai and spicy ginger liqueur.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Garnish: Lemon wheel stuffed with cloves and cinnamon stick
Instructions:
Soak one tea bag in a half mug of hot water for 30 seconds.

Remove the tea bag, add the rest of the ingredients and top with more hot water.

Garnish with lemon wheel stuffed with four to five cloves and a cinnamon stick.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: You’ll want this simple tipple to roll in even on sunny days.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) or agave nectar.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Surf and turf shouldn’t just be on a plate. It goes equally with inside a corn tortilla for a smart taco take on your favorite steakhouse meal. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: .5 cup Lightly packed chopped cilantro, plus more for garnish.5 cup
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Combine the olive oil, lime juice, orange juice, shallot, garlic, crushed red pepper and 1/2 cup cilantro in a mixing bowl. Divide the mixture evenly into 2 large zip-top bags. Seal one of the bags and refrigerate for use later. Add the skirt steak to the remaining bag, seal and refrigerate. Let marinate for at least 2 hours and up to 4 hours.

Once the steak has about half an hour left to marinate, remove the shrimp from the fridge and skewer onto two side-by-side skewers to prevent the shrimp spinning when flipped on the grill.

Brush the reserved marinade onto both sides of the skewers with a pastry brush, and place the skewered shrimp onto a plate. Refrigerate for 15 minutes.

Bring your grill or grill pan to high heat. Remove the shrimp and steak from the fridge and use tongs to transfer the steak from the marinade.

Sprinkle both sides of the shrimp and steak with a pinch of salt and place onto the grill. Cook both for about 4 minutes on each side, until the steak has started to char and the shrimp have cooked through. You may find the steak needs a minute or so longer than the shrimp, depending on how thick the cut of steak is. Remove both from the grill, and let rest for 10 minutes.

Make the pico de gallo.

Cut the steak into several 4”-long cross-section along the grain. Then cut each cross-section into 3 to 4 strips against the grain, severing the long muscle fibers and making the steak easy to chew.

Assemble the tacos by starting with steak, followed by the shrimp, pico de gallo, sour cream and cilantro.

*Pico de gallo: Combine 1 medium tomato, 1 small finely chopped red onion, kernels from 1 cob sweet corn, 1/4 cup lightly packed cilantro and 1 tbsp lime juice. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: The crispness and spice of this tasty elixir will help stimulate your appetite.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the ginger, cranberries and sugar.

Add the remaining ingredients and enough ice to fill a rocks glass.

Shake hard but briefly and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with grated cinnamon.

Author: Harvest Spirits
About: Mix up this spiced concoction after a decadent Thanksgiving meal.
Instructions:
Add the applejack and simple syrup to a snifter and stir.

Season to taste with grated cinnamon and nutmeg, and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: The Cocktail Collective
About: Try the first First Lady’s famous rum-and-citrus drink.
Ingred: 9 oz Flor de Caña 4-Year-Old Gold Rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a pitcher or other container and stir to combine.

Refrigerate until cold.

Place a large ice block into a punch bowl (or fill halfway with large ice cubes).

Add the prepared mixture and the club soda, and stir.

Garnish with lemon and orange half-wheels and grated nutmeg.

Author: Jason Percival
About: Nodding to the classic Blood & Sand, this drink by Jason Percival, the bar manager at Boston’s Post 390, relies on beets for its dramatic rosy hue and a hint of sweetness.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Sweet vermouth (Vya, Dolin or Carpano) 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Beet puree (cooked and peeled beets, pureed) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

Author: Jerry Slater
About:
Jerry Slater, a bartender and forthcoming owner of The Expat in Athens, Ga., and co-author of “The Southern Foodways Alliance Guide to Cocktails”—has created a Southern take on the Irish Coffee that’s a much more grain-forward, slightly richer version of the drink.  
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Irish Coffee: 3 Delicious Ways to Reconsider the Famed Cocktail.”
Ingred: 2 oz High Wire New Southern Revival sorghum whiskey
Instructions:
Pour the whiskey and simple syrup into a coffee mug.

Top with the coﬀee, and stir to combine.

Place the heavy cream in a pint-size Mason jar, and seal tightly with the lid.

Shake the jar until the cream gets thick and pourable but not yet ﬁrm.

Pour the soft whipped cream on top to form a layer about 1/2-inch thick.

Author: Alex Valencia
About: A few drops of habanero tincture transform this sotol-and-pineapple cocktail—for the better.
Ingred: .5 oz Rich agave syrup (2 parts agave nectar, 1 part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
About: This Irish-whiskey Manhattan has a subtle anise note.
Ingred: 2 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: The citrusy, bubbly Boat House Punch is both gorgeous and delicious.
Instructions:
In a large pitcher, muddle the lemon peel and sugar.

Let stand for at least 30 minutes.

Add the remaining ingredients, fill with ice and stir briefly.

Garnish with orange wheels.

Author: Sebastian Degens
Ingred: 1.5 oz Stone Barn Brandyworks Pear Brandy
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice. Shake well, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: RumChata
About: Get your morning fix with a kick.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: Fiery jalapeño syrup kicks up this sweet and fruity tequila cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a long slice of jalapeño.

About: Remember the old-timey hard lemon candy found in homes around the country? This cocktail is the adult equivalent of that childhood favorite. It combines citrus, orange liqueur and vodka for the perfect blend of tart and sweet.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a cocktail glass with sugar and set aside. (Do this a few minutes ahead of time so the sugar can dry and adhere well to the glass.).

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist..

Author: Daniel Guess
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
For the Tampa Buccaneers, bartender Daniel Guess of Tampa’s Fly says he decided to tap into Tampa’s rich centuries-old rum history by swapping the Port of Call
Ingred: 1 3⁄4 oz Foursquare Port Cask Finish rum
.5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the wine to a shaker filled with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice, and float the wine over the back of a barspoon on top of the drink.

Garnish with a lemon wheel dusted with Chinese five-spice powder.

*Cinnamon syrup: Add 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water and 2 cinnamon sticks to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is fully dissolved. Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. Remove the cinnamon sticks, and store in the refrigerator until ready to use.

Author: Bryan Gall
About:
Bryan Gall of Portland, Ore.’s Bacchus Bar at Kimpton Hotel Vintage uses a bright bunch of smashed basil to give this Yoda-inspired drink its requisite gasp of green, reminiscent of the Jedi master’s lovely skin tone. Sage simple syrup is a natural nod to Yoda’s wisdom, and a couple of those leaves make a nice, perky Yoda ear garnish too. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Celebrate the Release of ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ with These Great ‘Stars Wars’ Cocktail Recipes.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into Martini glass.

Garnish with 2 fresh sage leaves.

*Sage simple syrup: Heat 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water together over medium-low heat, stirring often, until dissolved. Allow to cool. Transfer to an airtight container, add 8 sage leaves, cut in half, and steep overnight. Remove in the morning.

Author: Jason Kosmas
About:
The alchemy of the ultimate Daiquiri lies in keeping it simple: two parts rum to lime juice, with just enough sugar to take the edge off. Using a rich simple syrup made of demerara sugar gives the drink necessary sweetness and balance without turning the drink into the sugary mess that many associate with the Daiquiri.
The original Daiquiri was invented in the early 1900s but didn’t become popular until the 1940s. World War II rationing made whiskey and vodka hard to come by, but President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s Good Neighbor policy made relations with Latin America better and thus rum easily accessible. It was one of six classic cocktails that was later featured in David A. Embury’s 1948 seminal book on cocktails, “The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks.”
Ingred: 2 oz White rum (Kosmas prefers Caña Brava)
.5 oz Rich simple syrup (2 parts Demerara sugar to 1 part water).5 oz
Instructions: In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients with large ice cubes. Shake vigorously and strain into a coupe glass.

Author: David Petro
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
AMER bartender David Petro’s Atlanta Falcons–inspired cocktail is made with rye whiskey and is served up, as he says, “to represent the Falcons high-flying offense.” The deep red color evokes the team’s color. Petro uses lemon sherbet to deepen the flavors of the drink and egg white to give it a nice rich texture.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Cappelletti Amaro Sfumato Rabarbaro 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Cane sugar simple syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until frothy and very cold.

Strain into a coupe, and garnish with a cherry and grating of orange zest.

Author: Liquor.com
About: When in Rome? How about when in New Orleans? The Hurricane powerful tropical drink will transport you to French Quarter during the first sip. Created in the 1940s, this super boozy rum-based concoction that will get the party started no matter where you are.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a large Hurricane glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a cherry..

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: An instant-party-in-a-punchbowl for six, dreamed up by cocktail legend Dale DeGroff.
Ingred: .5 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram.5 oz
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a large pitcher or bowl.

Before serving, shake individual drinks in a shaker with ice and strain into punch cups or large goblets filled three-quarters of the way with ice.

Garnish each drink with pineapple, orange, and lime slices.

Author: Steve Carrow
About: It’s sparkly and sweet, and packs a rum punch.
Instructions:
Add the rum, sugar cube and bitters to a Champagne flute.

Fill with Cava.

Author: John Stanton
About: This autumnal cocktail from Chicago’s Sable Kitchen & Bar head bartender John Stanton pairs bourbon with black walnut–rosemary syrup.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Jess Goldfarb
About: Concord grapes give this cocktail a clean, crisp autumn flavor while Cocchi Americano and dry vermouth balance out the sweetness of the grape and rosemary syrup.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Concord grape rosemary syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except club soda to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a Collins glass filled with ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with Concord grapes and rosemary sprig.

About: The Mudslide is a decadent mix of vodka, Kahlua and Bailey’s Irish Cream. Perfect for sipping in warm weather, this frozen cocktail is rich, sweet and very, very cold. This summer, ditch your cocktail shaker, bust out the blender and knock back this creamy concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth.

Pour the Mudslide into a Martini or Hurricane glass.

If desired, drizzle with chocolate syrup.

Author: Andrew Schloss
About: Love savory flavors? Four different smoky ingredients combine in a tasty liqueur that’s the base for this Bloody Mary variation.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pint glass filled with ice and stir to combine.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: You’ll be begging for this Maker’s Mark, maple syrup and beer cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients, except the beer, to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with beer and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

Author: Baileys
About: You won’t find this caffeinated drink at Starbucks.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Baileys Original Irish Cream 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Fill a rocks glass with ice and add all the ingredients.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Ingred: 2 oz BACARDÍ GRAN RESERVA MAESTRO DE RON®
Club soda or sparkling water, to top
Instructions:
Pour the rum, lemon juice and sugar into a cocktail shaker with ice, and give it a good shake.

Fine-strain the mixture into a serving glass, and top it up with the club soda or sparkling water.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Ruben Hernandez
About:
Ruben Hernandez, the head bartender at New York City’s Miss Ada, was inspired to create a salad stand-in that stems from the Mediterranean tradition of mixing arak with water, mint and citrus over ice. Beets provided the perfect base—not to mention a gorgeous, intense color—and purple, pink and even rainbow ones work equally well. To add savory tanginess, feel free to garnish with a sprinkle of goat cheese.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Right Drink. For Every Bit of the Thanksgiving Meal.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with 1 mint sprig and crumbled goat cheese (optional).

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Rich añejo tequila stands in for whiskey in this hot classic.
Instructions:
Coat the bottom of a mug with honey and add the tequila and lemon juice.

Stir in the hot tea.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick and lemon wheel.

Author: Brian Miller
About: Painted face not required.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Press mixture with a muddling stick.

Fill with crushed ice.

Garnish with thyme and mint sprigs and dust with grated nutmeg.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Owl's Brew
About: This base of freshly brewed Darjeeling tea spiked with hibiscus, strawberry and lemon peel is a bright match for vodka and cranberry bitters.
Ingred: 2 oz Owl’s Brew Pink and Black
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: No need to be delicate with this recipe. Grab your muddler, NOLET’S Silver Gin, fresh mint and cucumber. Then smash your way to a mouthwatering cocktail. This is how you make a Cucumber Smash.
Instructions:
Muddle the cucumber and mint with simple syrup and lemon juice in a pint glass or mixing tin.

Add NOLET'S Silver Gin, ice and shake well.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Garnish with a sprig of mint and a cucumber slice.

About:
A Gin & Juice might be as easy to make as the name implies, but there’s a reason this classic cocktail has a Snoop Dogg song named after it. It’s simple, fruity and refreshing, and the exact recipe is up to you. Grab your favorite fruit juice and whatever gin you have on hand, and you’re set. 
Mix up this Gin & Juice recipe when you have your mind on your money and your money on your mind.
Ingred: Juice (choose your favorite juice or combination of juices — half orange and half grapefruit works well)
Instructions:
Fill a Collins glass with ice and add the gin.

Fill with juice and stir.

Sip that Gin & Juice.

Author: Frank Torres, Del Frisco’s Double Eagle Steakhouse
About: This cocktail was created by Frank Torres at Del Frisco’s Double Eagle Steakhouse for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled Martini glass with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the cognac, simple syrup and bitters to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with the lemon peel.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: You’ll wish that it was always tea time.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a pitcher and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with lemon wheels.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: This twist on the classic Vodka Martini recipe will transport you to the City of Light.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Martini & Rossi Rosso Vermouth 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Martini glass with sugar and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a blood orange wheel and a pinch of grated nutmeg.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: The classic Collins gets a black-cherry makeover.
Ingred: 2 oz Grey Goose Cherry Noir Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add the vodka, lemon juice and simple syrup to a highball glass filled with ice.

Fill with club soda and garnish with a cherry.

Author: Dubonnet
About: Simple but elegant.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a Champagne flute.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Dushan Zaric
About: Pear brandy and absinthe combine to make this a truly unique tipple.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Rich simple syrup (two parts sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the absinthe to a coupe glass, swirl to coat the inside, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake vigorously for 30 seconds.

Strain into the prepared glass and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a drop of Peychaud's Bitters.

Author: Jason Littrell
About: Prepare for Olympic glory with this multinational cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Prat Dry Vermouth (France).5 oz
.5 oz Martini & Rossi Rosso Vermouth (Italy).5 oz
2 dashes The Bitter Truth Orange Bitters (Germany)
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange half-wheel.

Author: Johnnie Walker Scotch Whisky
About: What happens when you add Scotch to apple cider?
Ingred: 1 oz Johnnie Walker Gold Label Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add the Johnnie Walker, apple cider and apple bitters to a Collins glass filled with ice and stir.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

About: If you treat Scotch like a religion, try this simple and classic cocktail. Be sure to use a spicy ginger ale so you get the most out of the three-part combo. Not a fan of Scotch? The Presbyterian is also delicious with a measure of bourbon.
Ingred: 2 oz Scotch (may substitute bourbon or rye whiskey)
Instructions:
Add the Scotch to a Collins glass and fill with ice.

Fill with equal amounts of ginger ale and soda.

Author: Joaquín Simó
About: With tea-infused vermouth and tequila, this fizzy concoction is a cocktail-party champion.
Ingred: 1.5 tbsp MarketSpice Cinnamon-Orange Black Tea or other spiced black tea
Centinela Reposado Tequila or other reposado tequila, chilled
12 oz Fresh apple juice or cider, chilled
4 oz Demerara syrup (2 parts Demerara sugar, 1 part water), chilled
16 dashes Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Aged Bitters, Fee Brothers Old Fashion Bitters or The Bitter Truth Old Time Aromatic Bitters
Instructions:
At least 24 hours prior to kickoff, fill a plastic container (1-pint or 1-quart, depending on the size of your punch bowl) with water and add apple slices and cinnamon sticks if desired.

Freeze until solid.

Combine the tea and vermouth in a jar or other container and let stand for 90 minutes.

Strain, and refrigerate. On game day, combine the tea-infused vermouth and the remaining ingredients in a punch bowl, adding the soda last.

Carefully add the prepared ice block and garnish lavishly with apple slices and freshly grated cinnamon and nutmeg.

Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Express the essential oils in the mint and rub them inside the glass.

To the same glass, add simple syrup, bourbon, and crushed ice.

Stir.

Garnish with more ice and fresh mint.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Adapted from the 1939 classic cocktail book The Gentleman’s Companion by Charles H. Baker, the original cocktail nods to the drink’s Navy roots, suggesting that the excess bitters “go back in the bottle, on the floor or out the porthole or window, depending upon who, where and what we are.”
Ingred: 2 oz London dry or Old Tom gin
Instructions:
Dash the bitters into a chilled coupe. Gently tip the glass and rotate it to coat the inside of the glass. Pour out the excess bitters.

Stir the gin in a mixing glass with ice, then strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a curl of lime peel.

Author: David Wondrich
About: All hands on deck for the historic quadruple-liquor USS Richmond Punch.
Ingred: 2 cup Strong-brewed black tea (use 2 teabags, 16 oz water)
2 cup Dark Jamaican rum (Smith & Cross or Myers’s, 16 oz)
2 cup VS or VSOP-grade Cognac (16 oz)
2 cup Ruby port (Graham’s Six Grapes, 16 oz)
Garnish: 1 Thin lemon slices and grated nutmeg
Instructions:
Place a 2- or 3-quart bowl of water in the freezer and let freeze overnight.

Peel 6 lemons with a swivel-bladed vegetable peeler, trying not to get any of the white pith.

In bowl, muddle the peels with 1.5 cups of superfine sugar and let stand for an hour for the lemon oil to leach out.

Juice the peeled lemons and add the juice to the sugar mixture, along with the tea.

Strain out the peels and pour into a 1-gallon container.

Add the rum, cognac, port and Grand Marnier, and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.

To serve, unmold the block of ice into a 2-gallon punch bowl.

Add the chilled punch stock and top off with the club soda (or, if feeling dangerous, Champagne).

Garnish with grated numeg and 1 seeded lemon sliced thinly.

Serves 20.

Author: Phill Watts
About: Challenge your palate with this complex Italian cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
Ingred: 2 cup Blanched almonds (If prefer to use bitter almonds, find them online or at a Mediterranean grocery store)
Instructions:
Pulse almonds in a food processor until finely ground. Combine the sugar and water in a pot over medium heat and stir until sugar dissolves completely. Boil the syrup for three minutes, then add in the ground almonds. Turn the heat down to low and simmer for another three minutes, then slowly increase the temperature to medium high. Just before it starts to boil, remove it from the heat and cover with a lid.

Allow the covered nut mixture to infuse for at least 3 hours or up to 8 hours. Then, strain it through two layers of cheesecloth, discarding the ground almonds for another use. Stir the orange flower water and brandy into the nutty syrup. Use a small funnel to portion the orgeat into bottles or a jar. Store in refrigerator for up to two weeks.

Author: Alex Frane
About:
This mezcal- and amaro-based coffee cocktail was cooked up as a brunch drink for Esters Wine Shop & Bar in Santa Monica, Calif. This Mexican-themed drink packs a zing from agave and mole bitters and can be mellowed with a bit of cream. While the recipe calls for Foro amaro, other amari can be easily substituted, such as Ramazzotti, Cynar or Averna.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Coffee Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir lightly.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.

About: Three French spirits combine for one elegant cocktail.
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Mike Bohn
About:
Although the full recipe takes a couple of hours, this classic drink is accomplished in a crockpot, so it’s basically a set-it-and-forget-it type of recipe. Get a batch started before friends arrive, then spoon into coffee mugs.
“We use an IPA as the beer base,” says Mike Bohn of New York City’s Olmsted, “which gives the drink a contrasting freshness from the hops and citrus, plus a little porter thrown in to add some coffee richness.”
Instructions:
Serves 10�"12 (6 oz pours).

Place the mace, allspice berries, cloves and cinnamon on top of a square of cheesecloth, and use kitchen twine to tie tightly into a spice sachet.

Turn a crockpot on high. Add the cream and eggs, and whisk until homogenized. Once warm, whisk in the sugar until dissolved, then add the beers, liquors and spice sachet. Continue to cook on high for 2 hours, until the mixture forms what is essentially a cooked layer of egg and curd on top. Turn temperature down to warm until you’re ready to serve.

To serve, whisk into fine curds, then spoon into coffee mugs. Grate fresh nutmeg on top to garnish.

Author: Jamie Gordon
About: Gin, lemon juice and honey create a buzz-worthy cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: Love citrus? Try this sweet-and-sour recipe.
Ingred: 1 oz Grey Goose Le Citron Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and simple syrup or sugar.

Add the vodka and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Top with a splash of club soda and add additional ice if needed.

Author: Willy Shine
About: This tart whiskey cocktail combines orange, lemon and pomegranate flavors.
Ingred: 2 oz Gentleman Jack Rare Tennessee Whiskey
3⁄4 oz Pomegranate grenadine (one part Pom Wonderful Pomegranate Juice, one part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon half-wheel.

Author: Bryan Galligos
About:
“There’s something so comforting about a good ol’ Hot Buttered Rum—the spices, the rich mouthfeel and a good barrel-aged rum,” says lead bartender Bryan Galligos. He adds Plantation five-year-old rum, lemon juice, hot water and a syrup made from apple tea and demerara sugar. But the pièce de résistance? A pat of butter filled with cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, ginger, star anise, cardamom, cayenne pepper, salt, pepper and brown sugar, floated so the spices melt into the drink and the flavor develops as you drink it down. “You can’t beat butter,” he says. Um, nope.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “7 Hot Buttered Rum Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Spiced apple demerara sugar 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into an Irish Coffee mug.

Top with a pat of spiced butter.

*Spiced apple demerara syrup: Combine brewed spiced apple tea (your choice of tea bag) and demerara sugar in a 1:2 ratio in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer on the stove until sugar dissolves, then remove from heat. Store syrup in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

**Spiced butter: Mix 1 room-temperature stick of butter with 2 tsp cinnamon, 2 tsp nutmeg, 2 tsp ground cloves, 2 tsp ground ginger, 1 ground star anise pod, 4 ground cardamom pods, 2 tbsp brown sugar and 1 heavy pinch each of cayenne pepper, salt and pepper. Mix well, then form into a log, wrap in plastic wrap, and freeze until ready to use.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About: This mezcal
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with a pineapple leaf.

*Pineapple-cinnamon syrup: Bring 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water to a boil, and simmer until sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat, add 1 cup fresh pineapple chunks and 4 cinnamon sticks, and steep for 30 minutes. Remove solids, and store in the refrigerator.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Stronger than a mere Mimosa.
Ingred: 1 oz Van Gogh Pomegranate Vodka, chilled
Instructions: Pour the vodka into a Champagne flute. Top with the sparkling wine and garnish with a strawberry.

About: This twist on the classic Margarita recipe uses a delicious sugar snap pea puree.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: St-Germain Liqueur
About: Thankfully, the partridges aren’t included.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Hangar One Spiced Pear Vodka (may substitute another pear vodka)
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or Martini glass.

Garnish with a pear slice.

About: Try an elegant, tangy Martini for your next aperitif.
Instructions:
Rim a cocktail glass in sugar.

Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime twist.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Red pepper and chile pepper powder make this Margarita almost too hot to handle.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup or agave nectar.5 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with salt, fill with ice and set aside.

In a shaker, muddle the agave nectar or simple syrup, red pepper flakes and chile powder.

Add the remaining ingredients, fill with ice and shake vigorously.

Strain through a tea strainer into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a jalapeño or red chile pepper.

Author: Killian Lee
About: Jameson
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Ciaran Wiese
About: This cocktail by Ciaran Wiese, the bar manager at Tucson, Ariz.’s Agustin Kitchen, is an updated version of a Picon Punch.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Wolfberger Wolfamer Liqueur A L'Orange
.5 oz “Brandy” (3:1 split of cognac and Jamaican rum).5 oz
Instructions:
Add the amer and syrup into a highball glass with ice, top with the soda, and lightly stir.

Float the cognac/rum split on top.

Squeeze a lemon twist, add it to garnish, and serve with a straw.

Author: Scott Kennedy, Distilled
About: This cocktail was created by Scott Kennedy at Distilled for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the cognac, grenadine and orange juice to a shaking tin.

Fill with ice and shake well to chill.

Double-strain into the prepared coupe, and garnish with the orange peel.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: Top bartenders Jason Kosmas and Dushan Zaric of Employees Only created this complex tequila Smash that melds the bittersweet qualities of kumquats with the inherent spiciness of ginger.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the ginger, kumquats and sugar.

Add remaining ingredients and fill the shaker with ice.

Shake vigorously, and pour, unstrained, into an Old Fashioned glass.

About: A twist on the classic, a little mezcal and ancho chile liqueur gives the Negroni a smoky and spicy finish.
Ingred: .5 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned or rocks glass over fresh ice.

Author: Gary Regan
About: With cream, crème de cacao and brandy,  classic is a creamy, indulgent delight. With many details of its origin unknown, the Brandy Alexander became popular in the early 20th century. Try this cocktail as a decadent after-dinner sipper.
Ingred: 2 oz Cognac or other fine aged brandy
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

About:
Make a batch for your next party. Or just spend the weekend sitting on the porch, rocking your cares away.
Makes about 1 gallon (16 glasses)
Ingred: 3 cup Crushed ice, plus more for serving
Instructions:
Combine the boiling water and sugar in a heatproof container. Stir until sugar is dissolved.

Add the tea bags and steep for 5 minutes. Remove tea bags and discard.

Pour the tea base into a heatproof pitcher or serving jar. Add the cold water, ice and bourbon. Stir well, and refrigerate until serving.

To serve, pour into an ice-filled highball glass or Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with mint and lemon slices.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The classic Coffee Cocktail is actually caffeine-free.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a port glass.

Dust with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: Looking to get a little fruity? Try this blackberry-and-gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Drizzle the crème de mûre on top and garnish with a blackberry and a lemon wedge.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
“The Mularkey’s Secret Playbook is named after the new head coach [Mike Mularkey] in hopes that he has the secret playbook to bring us a winning season,” says Etch bartender Mark Kremper. “The main components of the drink are Tennessee whiskey and Chartreuse. It wouldn’t be a cocktail celebrating our Tennessee Titans if it wasn’t made with Mr. Tennessee Whiskey himself, Jack Daniel’s. I chose to use its new single-barrel rye whiskey for its heat and spicy notes, to give our team the kick it needs to beat the competition, and paired it with Chartreuse, for which the secret recipe is known only by a select few (hence the playbook). This cocktail embodies our hopes for the season.”
Ingred: 2 oz Jack Daniel’s single-barrel rye whiskey
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.

Strain into a coupe, and garnish with maraschino cherries skewered with bamboo in the shape of an X (making Xs with the skewer and Os with the cherries).

Author: Jon Santer
About: Arm yourself with this bourbon  and coffee liqueur cocktail. Introduced by San Francisco bartender Jon Santer in the early 2000s, the Revolver is locked and loaded with the spicy bite of rye-heavy Bulleit bourbon and a slug of coffee liqueur. Orange bitters lend subtle brightness to that dark and mysterious duo. Go ahead and pull the trigger.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with a wide strip of orange peel.

Author: Lukas B .Smith
About:
This riff on a classic Daiquiri, by herbalist and cocktail specialist Lukas B. Smith at Washington, D.C.’s Cotton & Reed, incorporates Cotton & Reed’s white rum and its allspice dram, which has rum as a base, resulting in a complex and spicy new take.
This recipe originally appeared as part of The Pioneering Return of the All-Important Allspice Dram.
Ingred: .5 oz Cotton & Reed allspice dram.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Allen Katz
About: She may look delicate, but this is one strong woman.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

About: Spice up the Old Fashioned by bringing in smoke and single malt. This spin on the traditional recipe will make you fall in love with the classic all over again.
Ingred: 2 oz Aberlour 12 Year-Old Single Malt Scotch
.5 oz Demerara syrup (1:1 water and sugar).5 oz
Choose your smoke: Hickory, Applewood, Mesquite or Cherrywood
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to mixing glass filled with ice and stir until cold.

Smoke is added to the wine glass after the cocktail is strained into the glass.

Smoke is added via a smoke gun such as this.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Replace the vermouth in a classic Martini with scotch and you get something altogether different.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Zachary Faden
About: It has been a long time since the first Bamboo
Ingred: 2 oz Brisson Pineau des Charentes apéritif
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: This variation on the Screwdriver is packed with citrus flavor.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a tall glass and fill with ice.

Fill with club soda and stir.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Ezra Pattek
About: Featuring a delicious grapefruit-lavender cordial, this drink highlights gin’s floral character.
Ingred: 3 dashes Bar Code Lavender Spice Bitters
Instructions:
Mist a frozen cocktail glass with pastis and set aside.

Add the gin, Grapefruit-Lavender Cordial, Lillet and bitters to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Twist the lemon peel over the drink to extract its oils and discard.

Garnish with a swatch of lemon peel and a lavender sprig on a cocktail pick.

Author: Gary Regan
About: A dressed-up tequila shot that’s ready to go out.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Green Chartreuse, chilled in the freezer 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Don Julio blanco tequila 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the Green Chartreuse to a sherry copita glass.

Float the tequila on top and garnish with a pinch of cayenne pepper.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: Subtle hints of lemon and absinthe accentuate this bourbon cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the absinthe to a pint glass and swirl to thoroughly coat the glass.

Discard any excess absinthe and add the bourbon and bitters.

Squeeze the lemon wedge into the glass and drop it in.

Fill three-quarters of the way with ice and stir swiftly for 20 seconds.

Top with soda.

Author: Abigail Gullo
About: Pre-batch this fizzy cocktail in a soda siphon and serve at a fall party.
Garnish: 1 Grapefruit twists, star anise pods, cinnamon sticks
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to an ice-cold one-quart soda siphon.

Charge the siphon with a CO2 charger, shake then pour into a rocks glass filled with cracked ice.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist, a star anise pod and a cinnamon stick.Note: Keep all ingredients cold as it helps with the fizz.

Author: Wild Turkey Bourbon
About: An ideal summer punch for your next backyard barbecue.
Ingred: 8 Red herbal tea bags (lemon zinger or hibiscus)
Instructions:
In a large saucepan, boil 2 cups of the water.

Remove from the heat and add the tea bags.

Steep for 10 minutes and then discard the tea bags.

Add the remaining 2 cups of water.

Stir in the Wild Turkey American Honey, transfer to a pitcher and chill.

Just before serving, add the lemon juice and club soda.

Pour the drink into tall glasses filled with ice.

Garnish each glass with a couple cherries.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This drink recipe first appeared in Jerry Thomas’ seminal 1862 The Bon Vivant’s Companion.
Ingred: 8 oz Smith & Cross Traditional Jamaica Rum
half Pineapple, peeled, cored and cut into half-inch rings
1 Quart-sized ice block (fill a quart bowl with water and freeze overnight)
Instructions:
Combine the whiskey, rum, lemon and pineapple in a punch bowl and let stand for at least 3 hours (overnight is best).

Dissolve the sugar in the water and stir into the whiskey mixture.

Refrigerate for at least an hour before serving.

To serve, slide the ice block into the bowl and grate about a quarter of a whole nutmeg over the top.

Ladle out 3-ounce servings into punch cups.

(This recipe makes about 24 servings).

Author: Vincenzo Marianella
About: The smallest state in the union is the namesake for this big-time tequila cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with crushed ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with a splash of ginger beer and garnish with lemon and lime zest.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: A unique potato vodka makes this version of the classic Moscow Mule distinctive.
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a Collins glass filled with ice and stir to combine.

Author: Herradura Tequila
About: A quick and easy version of the Margarita with a refreshing lemon-lime flavor.
Instructions:
In a rocks glass, muddle the lime and lemon wedges.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Author: Jack Hubbard
About: This picturesque pineapple and vodka concoction is served at Edition Hotels.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a copper pineapple glass or Collins glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with dried pineapple and a sprig of torched rosemary.

Author: Liquor.com
About: Turn your cotton-tailed confection into the perfect shot glass with this seasonal treat that will have you rethinking your next Easter basket.
Instructions:
Gently remove the ears from the chocolate bunny and set aside.

In a mixing tin, muddle the strawberries.

Add the vodka, Irish cream, heavy cream and syrup, and shake with ice until well-chilled.

Strain into the chocolate bunny.

Garnish with shavings from the amputated ears.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Actress Mary Pickford was known as America’s Sweetheart in the 1920s, when she landed in Cuba to shoot a film with husband Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin. As the story goes, Fred Kaufman, one of the many American bartenders who relocated to the island during Prohibition, dreamed up this BACARDÍ® rum-based concoction special for the silent-film star. Some recipes call for prepackaged juice only, but according to Basil Woon’s 1928 book, “When It’s Cocktail Time in Cuba,” it’s not a Mary Pickford without the addition of freshly squeezed pineapple juice. We tend to agree.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker, gently muddle the pineapple chunks.

Add the remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a preserved cherry.

Author: Ryan Te
About: This riff on the Negroni is made with jasmine-infused soju, Korea’s white spirit usually distilled from rice or sweet potatoes.
Ingred: 1 dash Fee Brothers West Indian orange bitters
Instructions:
Stir all ingredients with ice, strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with an orange peel.

*Jasmine Hwayo: Pour 1 cup of hot water over 8 grams of jasmine tea leaves.

After five minutes, discard the tea, reserving the “washed” tea leaves.

Steep the tea leaves in 1 cup of Hwayo Soju 41 for 25 minutes, fine-strain, and discard the leaves.

Strain a second time through cheesecloth to catch any remaining particles.

Makes enough jasmine-infused soju for several drinks.

Author: Brittney Olsen
About: This Los Angeles–inspired cocktails has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker, and dry-shake (without ice) to froth the egg white.

Add ice to the shaker, and shake.

Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a dehydrated peach slice.

*Chamomile-infused Chilean pisco: Add 1/4 cups loose chamomile tea to 750 mL Chilean pisco, and let rest at room temperature for 20 minutes or until desired strength.

**Blueberry-honey syrup: Thaw 12 oz frozen wild blueberries, purée and fine-strain. Combine equal amounts purée and honey syrup (honey diluted with water for cocktail use). Add 1/8 tsp high-quality vanilla extract for every 2 cups syrup. Stir to combine.

Author: Giuseppe González, Suffolk Arms
About: This cocktail was created by Giuseppe González at Suffolk Arms for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the cognac, bitters and syrup to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish by twisting the lemon peel over the surface of the drink to express its oils, then discard.

Author: Christy Pope
About: Those who seek comfort from slowly slurping a bowl of chicken soup can enjoy the savory flavors of chicken broth paired with autumnal apple in any season. This elegant chilled chicken cocktail by Christy Pope of consulting and catering company Cuffs & Buttons and Dallas’ Midnight Rambler Bar turns your sick day into a party in the best way possible.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Swanson organic free-range chicken stock
1⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a shaker with add ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Grate fresh nutmeg on top of the drink for garnish.

Author: Matt Merkin
About: The Dana Scully is a smoky, spirit-forward sipper. Like its namesake agent, the Mezcal, Cynar, Cointreau and raspberry liqueur creation is a striking burnt vermillion. It’s a no-nonsense recipe for a no-nonsense agent.
Ingred: .5 oz St. George Raspberry Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass over ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Eben Freeman
About: The liqueur pairs beautifully with Hendrick’s Gin.
Instructions:
Add the gin and Pimm's to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a half-pint glass.

Top with the Sprite and crown with cucumber foam.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Mango, pomegranate and sage for a nice autumn note.
Garnish: 1 Spanked sage leaf and cucumber wheel
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a spanked sage leaf and a cucumber wheel.

Author: Zak Kittle
About: This simple but delicious drink was inspired by the Southern tradition of adding peanuts to a can of Coke.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and orgeat to a rocks glass and stir until well combined.

Fill with ice and top with the Coca-Cola.

Garnish with a small handful of salted peanuts.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: A teacup is the unusual vessel for this Champagne-topped rum drink.
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (two parts honey, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled teacup filled with one large ice cube.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Maegan Delgrande
About: The secret ingredient behind this new age Negroni? Concord grape–infused vermouth.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Concord grape–infused Dolin Blanc Vermouth
1 dash Bar Keep Organic Lavender Bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except bitters to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir 45 turns for proper dilution.

Strain contents into a rocks glass and add one large ice cube.

Finish with one dash of lavender bitters.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: High-class meets working-class.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass halfway with beer.

Pouring over a spoon into the glass, fill to the top with Champagne.

Author: Shannon Mustipher
About:
This twist on the Bijou cocktail was created by Shannon Mustipher, the head bartender at Glady’s in Brooklyn. She pairs Haitian rhum agricole and London dry gin for a drink that’s equal parts earthy, bracing and herbaceous.  
This recipe originally appeared as part of “This New York Bartender Thinks You Should Drink More Rum.”
Ingred: Absinthe, to rinse Absinthe, to rinse
1 oz Boukman botanical rhum agricole (or Barbancourt blanc)
Instructions:
Rinse a rocks glass with absinthe, empty, then add 1 large ice cube, and stir until chilled.

Pour the remaining ingredients into the glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

*Chamomile tea syrup: Place 2 cups water in a pot over high heat. Add 2 cups sugar, bring to a boil, and stir until it dissolves. Add 2 chamomile tea bags, turn off heat, and let syrup cool. Strain into a container and refrigerate.

About: Together they make 14 and a sweet, sparkling whiskey drink.
Instructions: Add the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice and stir gently.

Author: Brendan F. Casey
About: This drink proves that rye and tequila belong together.
Ingred: 2 oz Michter's Single Barrel Rye Whiskey
2 dashes Fee Brothers Old Fashion Bitters
Instructions:
Add the maple syrup, rye and tequila to a mixing glass and stir until combined.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: A little fizz goes great with the distinct floral flavors of El Gobernador pisco. Pamela Wiznitzer’s bright and refreshing recipe is an amazing introduction to the world of pisco cocktails.
Instructions:
Rim half of a highball glass with a mix of salt, sugar and paprika, and set aside.

Add all the ingredients except the soda water to a shaker with ice, and short-shake.

Strain into a highball glass over ice.

Top with the soda water.

Author: Nicola Anderson
About: Lavender, peach and gin makes this cocktail perfect for any sunny day.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake.

Add ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with a sprig of dried lavender.

Author: Meaghan Dorman
About: You’ll be thoroughly delighted after one sip of this autumnal vodka tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a red apple slice.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Warm up with this tasty Scotch cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Glenfiddich 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Solerno Blood Orange Liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cherries.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: This chilly and refreshing drink calls for both gin and genever.
Ingred: .5 oz Rich simple syrup (two parts sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
In a Julep cup, muddle the simple syrup and mint.

Fill with crushed or pellet ice and add the genever and gin.

Top with the club soda and stir until combined.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Jonah Flicker
About: This citrus-infused cocktail takes the idea of a Manhattan and builds upon the classic. Grenadine, citrus and orange bitters combine with bourbon for a slightly sweet, slightly sour concoction.
Ingred: 1.5 oz I.W. Harper Kentucky straight bourbon whiskey
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker, and strain over ice in an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Flatiron Lounge
About: Whether you’re a saint or a sinner, you’ll like this spicy concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: Don’t fear: This crimson cocktail gets its bite from bold blanco tequila, not venom. Agave nectar and muddled blackberries soften that bite with a hint of sweetness, and give the Black Widow its signature spooky hue. Don’t forget the fresh basil and blackberry garnish for the full effect. Its bite brings pleasure, not pain.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blackberries and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a stemless Martini glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a blackberry and basil leaf on a toothpick.

Author: Marcus Jernmark
About: Let this Scandinavian Glögg warm you to the core.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a large saucepan over medium heat.

Heat to a simmer, remove from the heat and let stand for 2 hours.

Strain, and reheat.

Serve in mugs, garnished with raisins and sliced blanched almonds.

About: You’ll go bananas for this tropical swizzle.
Garnish: Mint sprig, Lemon wheel, Sliced bananas
Instructions:
Add the mint leaves to a Collins glass and lightly muddle.

Add the cognac, liqueur, syrup, lemon juice and 3 dashes of the bitters, and swizzle until diluted.

Fill the rest of the glass with crushed ice.

Add the 3 remaining dashes of bitters, then garnish with a mint sprig, lemon wheel and sliced bananas.

*Demerara syrup: Combine 2 parts demerara sugar to 1 part water in a saucepan over low heat. Heat until the sugar dissolves. Cool before using.

Author: Cody Goldstein
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“The perennial losing ways of the New York Jets have inspired me to create a cocktail around the last time they were actually winners,” says bartender Cody Goldstein of Mathews in Jersey City, N.J. “The Broadway Joe era was both flamboyant and fabulous. I combined joe (coffee) flavors with herbaceous mint and alpine herbs to wake the team up along with coconut cream rum because they are always on vacation come playoff time.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Brinley Gold Shipwreck coconut rum cream 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Dolin Génépy des Alpes liqueur.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker filled halfway with ice, and shake for 5 seconds.

Strain into a stemmed Collins glass filled with crushed ice, and garnish with edible green glitter, 3 mint sprigs and 3 chocolate-covered coffee beans.

*Coffee-infused tequila: Combine 1 tsp whole coffee beans and 750 mL blanco tequila. Let sit for 1 hour, then strain out the beans.

**Vanilla simple syrup: Slice 2 vanilla beans down the middle with a paring knife. With a spoon, scrape the vanilla into to a medium pot filled with 4 cups water. Bring to a boil and add 4 cups superfine sugar. Bring to a simmer and stir until the sugar dissolves. Remove from heat and allow to cool to room temperature, then strain out the vanilla bean through a fine-mesh strainer. Keeps in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Think a Greyhound is just grapefruit juice and gin? Think again.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a sprig of rosemary.

Author: Patrick Natola
About: Bartender Patrick Natola of Sable Kitchen & Bar
Ingred: 2 oz The 86 Co. Cabeza blanco tequila
3⁄4 oz Pineau des Charentes apéritif 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled Georgian glass.

Express the oil from a lime peel over top, and drop in for garnish.

About: You won’t find this grown-up chai latte at Starbucks.
Instructions:
Shake all with ice for a minute.

Serve long without ice and top with soda.

Garnish with lemon swath.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: This bourbon drink is a lot more enjoyable than trying to read Crime and Punishment.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Myles Worrell
About: The bar team at Downstairs at The Esquire Tavern
Ingred: 2 oz Pierre Ferrand Pineau des Charentes apéritif
.5 oz El Maestro Sierra amontillado sherry.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Express the oil from a grapefruit peel over top.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: A drink that tricks the eye and the palate.
Garnish: 1 Thin apple slice or maraschino cherry
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the simple syrup and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled martini glass.

Garnish with a thin apple slice or a maraschino cherry.

About: Bring elegance to any brunch.
Instructions:
Add the orange juice to a Champagne flute.

Fill with sparkling wine.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: A simple, minty classic, the South Side is the perfect introduction to gin cocktails.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint and simple syrup.

Add the lemon juice and gin, and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

About: This cocktail from Shari Sushi Lounge in Orlando, Fla. mixes gin, mint and cucumber for an extra-refreshing libation.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part water, one part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with three cucumber slices.

Author: Godiva Vodka
About: Indulge with this chocolate-raspberry vodka and Champagne treat.
Ingred: 1 oz Godiva Chocolate Raspberry Infused Vodka
Instructions:
Add the vodka and crème de cassis to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with chilled Champagne.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Raspberry, lemonade, vodka: the ultimate summer trifecta.
Ingred: .5 oz Chambord or premium raspberry liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Fill a chilled highball glass with crushed ice and add the vodka.

Top with lemonade to just below the rim and then add the Chambord.

Garnish with honeydew melon balls.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: The best Daiquiris aren’t made in machines and garnished with mini umbrellas. This elegant take on the tropical classic combines freshly squeezed lime juice, real sugar and world-class rum.
Instructions:
Add the sugar and lime juice into a shaker, and stir until the sugar has dissolved.

Add the rum, fill the shaker with half cubed ice and half crushed ice, and shake vigorously until thoroughly chilled.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a mint leaf.

Author: Nonna Titulauri
About:
Purists, keep walking! When the mercury climbs and the dog days of summer start barking at your heels, the only proper cocktail is the one that keeps you cool and happy. This super simple Frozen Margarita recipe will have you bonding with your blender all season long. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of Sensational Frozen Cocktails: The 11 You Should Be Drinking in American Bars Now.
Instructions:
Salt the rim of a chilled Margarita glass and put aside.

Add all the ingredients into a blender, and top with 1 cup of ice. Blend until the mixture is smooth and frothy.

Pour the contents into the salted Margarita glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Give the classic Collins cocktail an update with a measure of VEEV Spirit.
Instructions:
Add VEEV, lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass.
