Fill glass with ice and top with the soda.

Garnish with a lemon wedge and mint sprig.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: Bourbon, apples and bubbles. Oh my!
Instructions:
Add the bourbon to a Champagne flute and fill with sparkling apple juice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Mount Gay
About: We’ll bet you never expected this tasty twist on the traditional New Orleans recipe.
Ingred: 2 oz Mount Gay Black Barrel Rum
.5 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Rinse a rocks glass with absinthe and discard the extra liquid, leaving a light coating in the glass.

Add remaining ingredients to a separate mixing glass filled with ice.

Stir, and strain into the absinthe-rinsed rocks glass (no ice).

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Zacapa Rum
About: If you’re feeling under-the-weather, this toasty beverage will perk you right up.
Instructions:
Pour the water into a footed Irish coffee mug.

Add the remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker.

Shake well, pour into the mug and stir.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: This refreshing vodka drink is the official cocktail of the Kentucky Oaks races—but you can’t go wrong with it any day of the year.
Instructions: Fill glass to slightly above rim with cubed ice. Add all ingredients to the glass and stir slowly. Garnish with a fresh blackberry and a slice of lemon.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: All that fruit is good for you; have another glass of this delicious White Sangria.
Ingred: 2 Ripe peaches, pitted and cut into eight wedges
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pitcher and refrigerate for 2 to 4 hours before serving.

Serve in wine glasses.

Author: Reid Lewis
About: This savory cocktail by bartender Reid Lewis at Dallas’ Bowen House
Ingred: .5 oz Don Ciccio & Figli finocchietto liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except for the olive oil in a mixing glass and stir.

Pour into a Nick & Nora glass, and top with the olive oil.

Garnish with a lemon peel speared with a rosemary sprig.

*Rosemary-infused Spanish olive oil: Take a large handful of fresh rosemary stems, split them into 2 equal parts, then moderately roast 1 part with a brulee torch. The other half remains fresh. Simmer 2 cups Spanish olive oil, add all of the rosemary, and simmer at low heat for 20 minutes. Strain through a cheesecloth into an eyedropper.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“With 2.5 ounces of liquor, this is the perfect cocktail for an Oakland Raiders fan,” says bartender Martin Delgado of Prizefighter in Emeryville, Calif. “Bold and strong while pleasantly refreshing, that is always my take away from a Raiders tailgate and a Raiders win. And as we are the Raiders, rum was without question the base spirit! Go, Raiders!”
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the tequila, falernum and lime juice to a double rocks glass with crushed ice and stir.

Top with the rum, fill with more crushed ice, and garnish with a lime wheel.

About:
The beauty of the Screwdriver lies in the cocktail’s simplicity. Combining orange juice and vodka in a highball glass is about as easy as a cocktail gets and creates a base that’s ripe for experimentation.
The Screwdriver is a classic drink that has been designated an International Bartender Association official cocktail. The history of the Screwdriver is somewhat debatable, even though mention of it in literature goes back to 1949. Some claim that the drink was first made popular by American aviators. Another origin story claims that it was made popular by American oil workers who dubbed the drink the Screwdriver because they mixed it first with a screwdriver when a spoon was not on hand. 
Make this version of the classic Screwdriver next time you’re hosting a brunch or just need a pick-me-up, and rediscover why this is an essential part of any cocktail toolbelt.
Instructions:
Add the vodka to a highball glass filled with ice.

Top with orange juice.

Author: Phil Ward
About: The unexpected pairing of mezcal and Irish whiskey stars in this clever concoction.
Ingred: 1 oz Redbreast 12 Year Old Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: Three different herb-infused spirits flavor this easy-to-make cocktail with complex flavors.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled large cocktail glass.

Author: Willy Shine
About: Take your boozy lemonade to the next level.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fresh lemon juice (juice of 2 wedges) 3⁄4 oz
Garnish: 1 Skewered ginger candy or lemon wedge
Instructions:
Muddle ginger in cocktail shaker.

Add all other ingredients and fill shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass.

Fill glass with fresh ice and garnish with ginger candy or lemon wedge.

Author: Giovanni Denigris
About: Start celebrating the holidays early with this prosecco cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an ice-cold flute.

Garnish with raspberries, orange and fresh mint on a toothpick.

Author: Leo DeGroff
About: Irish whiskey is the backbone of this sweet-and-tart cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: Sweet-and-tart apple vodka is a great addition to the classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pitcher and fill with ice (For extra flavor, muddle the fruit before adding the remaining ingredients).

Stir, and pour into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: This cocktail, aka the Brandy Old Fashioned, is practically the official Wisconsin state drink and takes brandy instead of whiskey.
Ingred: 1 dash 7Up/Sprite, seltzer or sour soda (sour mix and soda water)
Garnish: Skewered brandied or maraschino cherry and orange slice
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except for the brandy to an Old Fashioned glass and muddle.

Add ice to fill the glass, add the brandy, then top with the 7Up/Sprite (or seltzer or sour soda).

Garnish with a skewered brandied or maraschino cherry and an orange slice.

About: The classic Mexican Michelada recipe kicks up the flavor of a cold beer. We break down the steps to the Michelada to make it easy.
Ingred: Mexican lager beer (such as Tecate, chilled)
Instructions:
Rub the lime wedge along half the rim of the pint glass and dip into a mix of equal parts salt and cayenne pepper.

Add the remaining ingredients except the beer.

Fill with beer and garnish with a fresh lime wedge.

Author: Leslie Pariseau
About: This fresh, summery punch could have cooled the flames of the French Revolution.
Instructions:
In a punch bowl, crush the blueberries and a splash of simple syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients except the pomegranate soda, plus plenty of ice.

Stir well and top gently with the pomegranate soda.

Garnish with lemon and lime wheels.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Two ingredients, many flavors.
Instructions: Add the vodka to a rocks glass filled with ice. Top with lemonade and garnish with blueberries.

Author: Tullamore Dew Irish Whiskey
About: Salute the Emerald Isle with this spirited cup of joe.
Instructions:
Fill a coffee mug or heat-proof glass with very hot water to warm it and then discard the water.

Fill the mug or glass about three-quarters of the way with coffee.

Drop in the sugar cubes and stir until thoroughly dissolved.

Add the whiskey and top with lightly whipped cream.

About: Put a Margarita-ish spin on your next cognac cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a piece of honeycomb and 3 jalapeño wheels.

Author: Gardner Dunn
About: Celebrate the season with this whisky-and-cider cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Yamazaki 12-Year-Old Japanese Single Malt Whisky
Instructions:
Add the whisky and cider to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Dust with ground cinnamon and garnish with 2 apple slices and a cinnamon stick.

Author: Somer Perez
About: You’ll be smiling after a taste of this gin and citrus cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Clementine or orange wedge or twist
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the prosecco or Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with prosecco or Champagne and garnish with a clementine or orange wedge or twist.

Author: The Cookie Rookie
About: This three-ingredient celebration cocktail from The Cookie Rookie couldn’t be simpler. It’s perfect for every winter holiday, from Thanksgiving straight through to Valentine’s Day.
Ingred: 2 oz Ginger ale or ginger beer
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a Champagne flute.

Garnish with sugared granberries.

Author: Juan Coronado
About: When temperatures drop and you’re looking for a sipper to warm your bones, check out this tropical twist on a classic Hot Buttered Rum from bartender Juan Coronado. The secret ingredient? Guava paste, a popular ingredient in the Spanish Caribbean.
Ingred: .5 cup Unsalted butter, room temperature.5 cup
Instructions:
Serves 4 - 6.

In a mixing bowl, whisk all the ingredients except the rum until smooth.

Add the rum and 2 cups boiling water, and stir.

Serve in coffee mugs.

Garnish with cinnamon sticks.

Author: Thomas Thompson
About: This take on a Shandy is the French version of the classic Radler.
Instructions:
Combine the beer and syrup in a pilsner glass and enjoy.

*Demi Peche syrup: Peel, pit and slice 4 ripe peaches and lightly salt with a pinch of kosher salt.

Heat in a saucepan over medium high heat, allowing the peaches to lightly caramelize.

Add 2 cups of refined sugar and 2 cups of water and stir.

Bring to a simmer, stirring frequently, for 2 minutes, remove from heat, and allow to cool to room temperature.

Strain (preferably through a cheesecloth) and refrigerate.

Author: Pyrat Rum
About: Hoist one to the skull and bones. Arrr!
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake gently and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the soda and garnish with grated nutmeg and cherries.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: You don’t need to be in the five boroughs to enjoy this sophisticated tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

(If you prefer a dry Manhattan, use dry vermouth instead of sweet and garnish with a lemon twist.).

Author: Charles Joly
About: Fortify yourself with the Irish-whiskey-and-egg Gaelic Flip cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and dry shake (without ice) to emulsify.

Fill with ice and shake again.

Strain into an Irish coffee mug or rocks glass and garnish with grated nutmeg.

Author: Colleen Healy, Pops for Champagne
About: This cocktail was created by Colleen Healy at Pops for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Place the sugar cube in a chilled coupe glass and saturate with the bitters.

Add the cognac to the glass and top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Xavier Padovani
About: This fruity punch will keep a large group warm and happy.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a large saucepan and simmer over low heat for about 20 minutes.

To serve, pour the hot mixture into a punch bowl or teapot and garnish with orange slices studded with cloves.

Pair with gingerbread.

Author: Michael Dietsch
About: In this cocktail from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails
Ingred: 2 oz Canadian rye whiskey (Alberta Dark Batch)
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, and add the rye, Fernet-Branca, simple syrup and bitters.

Stir for 15 seconds, until chilled and diluted, strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Clayton MacGregor
About: “When it’s hot out—and it’s always hot in Arizona—I want something light, refreshing and sessionable,” says Clayton MacGregor, who created the Junior Buffalo GDE cocktail at Phoenix’s Pig & Pickle
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Highball glass filled with ice and stir.

Garnish with an orange slice.

*Orange blossom soda water: Add 24 oz water, 6 oz orange simple syrup** and 2 oz orange blossom water

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Celebrate the Fourth of July year-round with this ruby-red punch.
Garnish: 3 Blueberries or black raspberries (coated in powdered sugar)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strin into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with 3 blueberries or black raspberries coated in powdered sugar.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Remember the glamorous days of old Hollywood with this creation of ’40s gossip columnist Hedda Hopper.
Ingred: .5 oz Apricot brandy (Marie Brizard Apry).5 oz
Instructions:
Add both the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass or tall shot glass.

Twist a swatch of thin-cut lemon peel over the top.

Author: Yellowtail
About: A chardonnay twist on a cocktail classic.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the orange, basil and agave nectar.

Add the wine and brandy, and fill with ice.

Shake well and double-strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Add a splash of Grand Marnier and garnish with an orange twist and an orange slice.

Author: Tippling Bros.
About: This tequila-and-mezcal drink with apple cider and ginger beer is a delicious tipple for the fall or winter.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Collins glass with Spice Sugar, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the tequila, mezcal cider and lemon juice to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Fill with ginger beer and garnish with diced red apple.

Author: Jayce Kadyschuk
About: Canadian whisky meets Italian aperitivo in this rich and creamy cocktail by Jayce Kadyschuk, the head bartender at Clive’s in Victoria, British Columbia. “The higher rye content works really well here,” he says.
Ingred: The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas’ Own Decanter bitters The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas’ Own Decanter bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain and serve in a coupe.

*Clove simple syrup: Bring cloves [to taste] to simmer in water. Turn off heat, and mix in sugar at 1:1 ratio to water.

About: This bourbon-and-amaro drink pairs well with holiday spices and can be served warmed up or chilled.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir for 15 seconds and strain into a coupe glass.

Express the oils of the lemon twist over the drink, and gently drop the twist into the cocktail.

About: The Old Pal Negroni is an authentic and savory spin on the Italian cocktail. Dry gin gets replaced by whiskey while the vermouth is dry rather than sweet. This tinkering with the classic recipe creates a cocktail that feels both familiar and fresh.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Liquor.com
About: This pre-Prohibition classic is one of Philadelphia’s contributions to mixological history.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with three speared raspberries.

* If you donÂ''t have raspberry syrup, you can muddle together 3 or 4 fresh raspberries and .5 oz simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) instead.

Author: Vena Edmonds
About: With aged Dominican rum and coconut, banana, peanut and pineapple flavors, it’s about as tropical as you can get.
Ingred: .5 oz Castries Peanut Rum Crème Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a pineapple slice.

Author: Tom Macy
About: Celebrate in style with this fizzy aperitif.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the sparkling wine to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with sparkling wine and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Jose Pereiro
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a pilsner glass, add crushed ice, and swizzle with a swizzle stick.

Top with more crushed ice, and pour grenadine on top.

Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel and tarragon sprig.

About: Fresh citrus, sparkling wine and premium cognac bring out the best in one another in this refreshing new cocktail.
Ingred: Dry sparkling wine or cava, to top
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with dry sparkling wine, and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Martin Cate
About: Forget tea and crumpets. This drink is named for the mythical dark companion to St. Nicholas.
Ingred: .5 oz Coruba Original Blend Rum.5 oz
.5 oz Leopold Bros. Rocky Mountain Blackberry Liqueur.5 oz
1⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 1⁄4 oz
.5 oz B.G. Reynolds' Vanilla Syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a pint glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Willy Shine
About: The simplest pairings are often the most satisfying. A perfect showcase for Gentleman Jack Rare Tennessee Whiskey, The Gentleman’s Press melds naturally with the bubbly freshness of ginger beer and a hint of lime.
Ingred: 2 oz Gentleman Jack Rare Tennessee Whiskey
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Stir briefly and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Gin, rose petals and exotic lychee team up to make this tasty, summery tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a teacup filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wedge or an orange wheel.

Author: Liquor.com
About: The Big Daddy of high-octane Tiki
Ingred: 1 oz Gold demerara rum, such as El Dorado
1 oz Dark Jamaican rum, such as Appleton Estate
1 oz White Cuban or Puerto Rican rum, such Bacardí Superior
1 oz Honey syrup (equal parts honey and water)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker filled with crushed ice and shake until well-chilled (about 30 seconds).

Strain into a chilled rocks glass with fresh crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Matt Grippo
About: Fresh celery juice adds bright, earthy undertones to this tequila-based cocktail made with elderflower liqueur and Fino sherry.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.

Garnish with lime wheel and celery leaf.

Author: Brooke Arthur
About: Possibly named for a World War I field gun, this classic drink packs a wallop.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and fine-strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a long ribbon of lemon peel.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
“Before Prohibition, WWI and WWII, Maryland was one of the largest producers of rye
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously for 25 seconds.

Double-strain into a highball glass filled with ice, and top off with the ginger beer.

Garnish with a mint sprig and three blackberries.

*Blackberry mint syrup: Add 1 cup of sugar and 1 cup of water to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Add 1.5 cups of blackberries, and muddle the berries into the syrup. Add 2 cups of mint leaves and stir. Place in the refrigerator for 24 hours, and strain into a jar. Keeps in the refrigerator for 1 month.

Author: Allen Katz
About: This Michael Collins Irish Whiskey cocktail has some spunk.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Wild Turkey Bourbon
About: Feel free to share this bourbon-lemonade punch with your friends.
Ingred: 1.5 cup Wild Turkey American Honey Liqueur
Instructions:
In a large saucepan, bring 2 cups of the water to a boil.

Remove from heat and add the tea bags.

Steep for 8 minutes and then discard the bags.

Add the lemonade and the remaining 2 cups of water.

Transfer the mixture to a pitcher and chill.

Stir in the basil and crush with a spoon until fragrant.

Stir in the bourbon and liqueur.

Pour into tall glasses filled with ice and garnish each glass with a lemon wheel.

Author: Dukes Hotel
About: This classic cocktail is the house Martini at London’s Dukes Hotel, where James Bond creator Ian Fleming was a regular.
Instructions:
Chill the gin, vermouth and a Martini glass in the freezer.

Add both ingredients to the glass and stir gently.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: The black-pepper-and-onion garnish makes this classic drink a savory delight.
Instructions:
Rinse a Martini glass with vermouth and set aside.

Add the vodka to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with cocktail onions and freshly cracked black pepper.

Author: Ashtin Berry
About:
Tokyo Record Bar beverage director Ashtin Berry was inspired to create this Dark ’N’ Stormy riff by the izakaya cuisine at this New York City lounge where vinyl rules. She loves the way heat coaxes out white miso’s butterscotch notes. “The Dark ’N’ Stormy has this perfect blend of baking spiced fruit and ginger spice,” says Berry. “I decided to use the white miso and sweet potato notes of the sochu along with the bitterness of the Cynar liqueur to create a more savory version.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The 5 Recipe Variations Every Dark ’N’ Stormy Lover Should Know.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Cynar liqueur, to float 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the shōchū, syrup and yuzu juice to a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Top with the soda.

Float Cynar on top.

*Miso syrup: Combine 2 cups white sugar and 2 cups water in a saucepan. Simmer on medium until the sugar is dissolved. Whisk in 1/2 cup white miso until incorporated, then remove the syrup from the heat and let cool. Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Lucinda Sterling
About: This Rocky Mountain variation on the traditional Brown Derby recipe combines TINCUP Whiskey and grapefruit juice.
Ingred: .5 oz Grade A maple syrup.5 oz
2 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Maxime Belfand
About: Maxine Belfand’s irresistible Pisco Punch brings together high-quality pisco, white wine, pineapple and lemon juice. The relatively simple recipe allows the floral notes of El Gobernador pisco to really shine.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into a punch cup over ice.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf, a star anise and freshly grated nutmeg on top.

About: This classic recipe first appeared in O.H. Byron’s 1884 Modern Bartenders’ Guide.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until chilled, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: Ancho Reyes
About: Try this intriguing cocktail featuring an ancho chile liqueur from central Mexico.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: No need to feel guilty for mixing up this sweet and sour whiskey concoction.
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Simon Ogden
About: A dash of fernet spices up this 416-style Manhattan by Simon Ogden of Veneto in Victoria, British Columbia.
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin and stir.

Pour into a coupe.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: This combination of Irish whiskey, vermouth and sherry will get you going.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Redbreast 12 Year Old Irish Whiskey
4 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Twist a piece of orange peel over the drink to express the oils and discard.

Author: Naren Young
About: Two of springtime’s most delicious ingredients combine in this tart and refreshing tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a pickled rhubarb stalk and a lemon wheel.

About:
Think the Margarita is the ultimate Mexican cocktail? Think again. The Paloma is a quick and easy classic that can be made right in the glass. Whether drinking solo or with company, this drink will fulfill all your tequila  needs.
Make it a meal with this taco soup recipe.
Ingred: Grapefruit soda (Jarritos or Squirt work best)
Instructions:
Combine the tequila, lime juice and salt in a highball glass.

Add ice and top off with the grapefruit soda.

Stir gently and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: This elegant mixture of Champagne and passion fruit was inspired by award-winning actress Ingrid Bergman.
Instructions:
Add the passion fruit puree to a mixing glass.

Stir, and add in simple syrup, then ice.

Still stirring, slowly add in the Champagne.

Strain into a flute and float the Alizé on top.

About: The Manhattan cocktail is what the Manhattan Project should’ve been about.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with a cherry.

About: White whiskey and rum join forces in this simple sour cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Both Chile and Peru claim the classic Pisco Sour as their own.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a highball glass or Champagne flute.

Garnish with a lime wheel and 3 gentle drops of Angostura Bitters, which will settle in the foam of the cocktail.

Using a straw, swirl the bitters into a simple design.

Author: Creative Culinary
About:
Deep, dark chocolate is every so slightly accented with pinot noir in this decadent adults-only dessert.
These Pinot Noir Chocolate Brownies originally appeared in our DrinkWire channel.
Ingred: 3⁄4 cup Ghirardelli sweet ground cocoa 3⁄4 cup
.5 cup Walnuts, toasted and chopped.5 cup
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.

In a mixing bowl, combine the eggs with the sugar and vanilla, then add the butter and wine.

In a separate mixing bowl, stir the cocoa with the flour, baking powder and salt.

Combine the two mixtures together, and add the walnuts.

Spread onto a greased 8-inch-by-8-inch pan.

Bake 25 to 30 minutes.

*Chocolate glaze: Melt 4 tbsp unsalted butter over medium heat. Reduce heat to low, and add 1 oz unsweetened chocolate, 4 1/2 tbsp granulated sugar and 3 tbsp pinot noir wine. Continue heating over low heat, stirring often, until mixture is smooth (don't let it boil). Spoon the hot glaze over the brownies, and let stand for at least 1 hour; 12 hours is best.

Author: Danny Misch
About: A happy marriage of Italy and Mexico.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Margarita glass.

Author: Cindy Augustine
About: This take on a Frozen Margarita at Coccoloba Bar & Grill
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to blender with a cup of ice and blend.

Pour into a rocks glass.

Dust with cayenne pepper.

*Spiced honeydew syrup: Add 1 cup diced honeydew, 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water to a saucepan, muddle then stir for 3 minutes over medium heat. Let cool, and add ground cayenne pepper to taste.

Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: This citrus and honey elixir is a perfectly refreshing way to kick off a party.
Ingred: .5 oz Triple sec or Grand Marnier.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the honey and hot water to a shaker and stir to dissolve.

Add the remaining ingredients, shake vigorously and strain into a Martini glass.

Author: Somer Perez
About: No reason vodka should have a monopoly on tomato-juice cocktails.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass, fill with ice and stir.

Garnish with any of the following: a celery stalk, pickled okra, a dill pickle spear, an asparagus spear, a skewer with 3 olives, a skewer with 3 cherry tomatoes or a carrot stick.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This raspberry-and-mint tipple is delicious all year round.
Ingred: 2 oz Peach brandy (not peach liqueur; may substitute 1.5 oz bonded applejack and .5 oz peach liqueur)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a small goblet filled with fresh cracked ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and a raspberry or two.

Author: Vikram Hegde
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
For the New England Patriots, “this cocktail is a little taste of humble pie, with the strength and resolve of some local navy-strength rum
Ingred: .5 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker, and shake without ice until emulsified for about a slow 5 count.

Add ice and shake vigorously for a slow 10 count or until the shaker frosts over.

Fine-strain into a lowball glass without ice, and garnish with a few dots of Angostura bitters in the shape of the Patriots’ Flying Elvis logo (to the best of your artistic ability).

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Our classic Caipirinha recipe instantly transports you to a beach in Rio.
Instructions:
To make a Caipirinha first, in a double Old Fashioned glass, muddle the sugar and lime.

Fill with ice and add the cachaça.

Stir briefly and garnish with a lime wheel if desired.

About: This play on the Mint Julep that’s named after Cyndi Lauper’s first album is guaranteed to be interesting.
Instructions:
Muddle the bitters, shiso leaves and sugar cube in a goblet.

Add crushed ice.

Add the cognac and whiskey, and top with more ice.

Garnish with a shiso leaf.

Author: Amy Zavatto
About: This classic cocktail from the 1920s and ’30s takes its name from its main ingredient of applejack and the resulting color from grenadine.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lime or lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Fine-strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a lime or lemon twist.

Author: Jason Seele
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
Garnish: Orange diamond, with brandy cherries on the side
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into a coupe.

Express oils from an orange diamond, and wipe the rim with it.

Hang the orange diamond on the rim of the glass for garnish.

Author: Brooke Arthur
About: Possibly named for a World War I field gun, this classic drink packs a wallop.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and fine-strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a long ribbon of lemon peel.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: A simple addition to the classic recipe yields huge flavor.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: This bubbly tipple will light up your night.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Cherry Noir Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Fill a rocks glass with ice and add the vodka.

Add the soda and top with the grenadine.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: Make the classic gin cocktail better by replacing orange juice with tangerine.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Tanqueray No. TEN Gin 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: David Kurka
About: Punny name. Serious drink.
Instructions:
Add the tequila, orgeat and lime juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the bitters.

Twist a piece of orange peel over the glass, rub it around the rim and drop it into the drink.

About: You could say this is the Irish version of a Manhattan.
Instructions: Stir the whiskey, vermouth and bitters with cracked ice for 30 seconds, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: Take flight with this gin classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist or maraschino cherry.

Author: Liquor.com
About: The signature drink at Havana’s historic Hotel Nacional
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake for 30 seconds.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: This riff on the classic Manhattan will make you feel like you’re up to no good.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: Inspired by Italian apéritifs, this crisp cocktail pairs well with handmade pasta.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until properly diluted.

Strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Express an orange peel over the top before placing it inside the cocktail.

Author: Jonah Flicker
About: This whisky cocktail is pretty simple—sort of like an alcoholic version of Ocean Spray Cran-Apple.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Crown Royal Regal Apple whisky
Instructions:
Add the whisky to a rocks glass over ice.

Top with cranberry juice and stir.

Garnish with an apple wheel.

Author: Sam Ross
About: A riff on The Last Word  cocktail, the Paper Plane is pleasantly easy to remember thanks to its equal parts.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
A Frozen Margarita is a beautiful, refreshing cocktail. But throw a little Campari in there, and a good thing gets even better—and pinker. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Serves 6
Ingred: 8 oz Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients with 2 cups crushed ice in a blender, and blend on high speed for 30 seconds, until there are no longer chunks of ice.

Pour into six Highball glasses.

Garnish with lime slices, and serve immediately.

Author: Kara Anderson
About: In this riff on the Bramble, the honeyed fruits and floral notes of Dewar’s 12-year-old scotch play well with the Briottet crème de mûre liqueur while taking the drink in an entirely different direction.
Instructions:
Combine the scotch, lemon juice and syrup in a shaker with ice, and shake.

Fine-strain into a hurricane glass over crushed ice, and drizzle with the liqueur.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Eden Laurin
About:
Eden Laurin, the head of spirits programs at Dove’s Luncheonette, Publican Anker and The Violet Hour in Chicago, subs out standard white rum for a duo of more complex bottles for a winter version of the classic Daiquiri.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Can the Classic Drinks of Summer Be Transformed for Winter? Yes. And This Is How.”
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

About: This classic three-ingredient cocktail is the rye whiskey version of a Negroni.
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass with ice, add all of the ingredients, and stir until diluted and chilled for about 30 stirs.

Strain and serve up or on the rocks in an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

About: Bubbly and berries are cognac’s BFFs in this bright sparkling rosé cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the rosé to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Add the rosé, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Garnish with a lemon peel-wrapped blackberry.

*Berry and pepper syrup: Muddle 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar, 6 strawberries, 10 blackberries and 2 jalapeño peppers in a saucepan. Bring to a boil and cook for 14 to 18 minutes. Let cool before using.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: Bongo drums, black beret and Jack Kerouac paperback not included.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Brian Nixon
About:
This drink by owner and bartender Brian Nixon of Washington D.C.’s McClellan’s Retreat has a big dose of fall in the form of a house-made liqueur of vodka and toasted pie spices that’s the liquid equivalent of pumpkin pie. He starts with Scarlet Ibis Trinidad rum, a spirit originally commissioned for New York cocktail bar Death & Co, and mixes it with warm apple cider and the liqueur. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “These Are the Only 3 Mulled Rum Cocktails You’ll Ever Need.”
Instructions:
In a saucepan, heat the cider.

Pour the cider into a mug, and top with the rum and liqueur.

Garnish with 2 cinnamon sticks.

*Pie spice liqueur: In a small skillet, toast 1 tsp whole cloves, 1 tsp whole allspice berries, 3/4 tsp white peppercorns, 4 cinnamon sticks and 1 whole nutmeg pod over medium heat for 2 minutes, until fragrant. Transfer to a sealable quart jar and add 2 1/2 cups vodka, then seal and steep for 2 days, shaking the jar twice a day. Strain out the solids and transfer them to a small saucepan. Add 2 cups sugar and 1 cup water, bring to a simmer, and cook until the sugar dissolves. Let the mixture cool completely, then strain the syrup into the jar with the infused vodka, and shake to combine. Refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: This luscious drink looks as beautiful as it tastes.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake gently for 30 seconds.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a few lavender blossoms.

About: This cocktail combines spring flavors like lemon thyme, verjus and sugar snap peas.
Ingred: 1 pinch Maldon salt or other sea salt
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the pea pods.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a large coupe glass.

Garnish with a sprig of lemon thyme resting across the rim.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: Just as pretty as the holiday plant, and this one sparkles too.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and cranberry juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with raspberries.

Author: Matthew Linzmeier
About: At New York’s County Restaurant, this spicy serrano-infused cocktail can be made with interchangeable base spirits like tequila or rye whiskey.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe.

Author: Pusser's Rum
About: A twist on the Piña Colada, the Painkiller cocktail is a rich and fruity tropical drink that’s a specialty of the British Virgin Islands. Coconut cream, orange juice and pineapple juice join rum  in this drink that brings the tropics right to your glass.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a hurricane glass or snifter filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a pineapple wedge.

Author: Jacob Briars
About: This chile pepper, lime and cachaça cocktail captures the spirit of Brazilian Carnaval.
Garnish: 1 Chile pepper slices or lime wedge
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the agave nectar, chile pepper slices and lime wedges.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with crushed ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with additional chile pepper slices or a lime wedge.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Upgrade this tropical rum cocktail with a scoop of coconut sorbet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe glass or coconut shell.

Garnish with dried coconut flakes.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: A bourbon Bloody Mary? Try this unusual concoction for brunch.
Garnish: Celery stalk, lime wedge and blue cheese-stuffed olives
Instructions:
Rub the lime wedge around the rim of a pint glass and coat with celery salt.

Fill with ice and add 2 dashes of celery salt and the remaining ingredients except the tomato juice.

Fill with tomato juice and stir well.

Garnish with a celery stalk, lime wedge and blue cheese-stuffed olives.

Author: Charles Joly
About: This cocktail has so much flavor you won’t miss the alcohol.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker.

Fill with ice and shake.

Add the club soda and gently roll the shaker back and forth to mix.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Whip up a batch of clover honey syrup for this fruity Caipirinha-inspired tipple.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the kumquats and lime.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake lightly and pour (unstrained) into a double Old Fashioned glass.

Author: Martin Cate
About:
Black rum was touted after Prohibition as a great base for punch. It works especially well in the classic Hurricane, where its richness is offset by tangy lemon and passion fruit. This version is from famed San Francisco Tiki bar Smuggler’s Cove. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Everything You Need to Know About Black Strap Rum.”
Ingred: 4 oz Black blended or black pot-still rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with 12 oz of crushed ice and 4-6 small pieces of cubed ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Pour into a Hurricane glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and cocktail umbrella.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: Pineapple, tequila and rosemary collide in this fresh, complex drink.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the rosemary.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass.

Garnish with a sprig of fresh rosemary.

Author: Adam Bernbach
About: With a little bit of care and thought, the old-school Whisky Mac can be reimagined and turned into something worthy of our more particular modern cocktailing palates, the Whisky Contardo, from bartender Adam Bernbach at Washington, D.C.’s 2 Birds 1 Stone.
Ingred: 2 oz The Famous Grouse Smoky Black scotch
1 oz Spiced Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a mixing tin with ice and stir.

Strain into a coupe glass, express a lemon peel, and garnish with the peel.

*Spiced Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine: Blend 8 oz Stone’s Original Green Ginger Wine, 1 15-gram piece of fresh ginger and 1 gram white pepper and strain.

Author: Chad Solomon & Christy Pope
About: A glass of this spiced-apple-cider-and-cognac concoction is just the thing for a chilly or warm afternoon.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Louis Royer Force 53° VSOP cognac
4 oz Wassail, hot (or 3 oz wassail, chilled, if serving cold)
Instructions:
To serve hot, add the cognac and rum to a Toddy glass and top with the wassail.

Garnish with apple slices or fresh cranberries.

To serve cold, add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Beckaly Franks
About: Smoky Scotch is tempered with a hint of bitter amaro and a slick of spicy ginger syrup in this straightforward glass.
Garnish: Orange peel oil or candied ginger
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.

Garnish with oils expressed from an orange peel.

Author: Manny Hinojosa
About: A refreshing Campari-and-vodka drink with a tangy grapefruit twist.
Ingred: 2 oz Fresh ruby red grapefruit juice
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist and a fresh basil leaf.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: A French name and an exotic flavor.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fresh ruby red grapefruit juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Muddle the peppercorns in a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a few more peppercorns.

Author: Dushan Zaric
About: The bubbly French 75 is perfect for celebrating a large or a small occasion.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Fill with Champagne and garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: Get introduced to French apple brandy with this simple variation on a classic.
Instructions:
Combine equal amounts of cinnamon and sugar on a small saucer.

Rub the rim of a cocktail glass with the lime or lemon wedge and dip carefully into the sugar mixture so that only the very top of the rim is coated evenly.

Place the glass into the freezer to let the sugar rim harden.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Sother Teague
About: Who couldn’t use a nice getaway? This Jäger and rum cocktail will take you to faraway lands.
Ingred: 1 oz Flor de Caña 4-Year-Old Gold Rum
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with pebble ice. Mound more ice on top like a snow cone and garnish with a few heavy dashes of Peychaud's Bitters.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Tropical fruit, crème de cacao and fine tequila will please your palate.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Unsweetened passion fruit purée 1⁄4 oz
.5 oz Dark crème de cacao.5 oz
Instructions:
Fill a double shot glass three-quarters of the way with crushed ice.

Add all the ingredients in the order listed above.

If you're going to sip the drink, stir to combine.

Otherwise, shoot it and let it mix in your mouth.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: This tasty and simple recipe will never go out of style.
Instructions:
In an Old Fashioned glass, lightly muddle the agave nectar, bitters and orange peel.

Fill with ice and add the tequila.

Stir, and garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Willy Shine
About: Jamaica meets Italy in this powerful combination of rum, vermouth and Aperol.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir till very cold and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

About: The simple two-ingredient French Connection is one of the best ways to enjoy a young cognac.
Instructions: Fill an Old Fashioned glass with ice, add both ingredients and stir briefly.

About: Swap out the lemon juice for rum in this boozy update on the Sidecar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel set aflame.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: For unexpected guests, throw together the classic Last-Minute Mulled Wine with ingredients you probably have in the pantry. When unexpected guests arrive at the door, there’s no easier party punch than Last-Minute Mulled Wine. Got a bottle of red wine lying around? Spike it with warm pantry spices like cinnamon and star anise, then amp up the flavor even further with a splash of bourbon or brandy. That’s how you capture the holidays in a mug.
Ingred: .5 bottle Fruity red wine (such as Beaujolais or syrah).5 bottle
1 Long strip of lemon or orange peel
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a small saucepan.

Cook over low heat until warm (do not boil), remove from the heat and let stand for 5 to 10 minutes.

Serve in mugs or punch cups, garnished with cinnamon sticks.

Author: Jake Roberts, Harper & Rye
About: This shaken cocktail has just enough citrus to brighten up the sweet flavor profile. It’s precisely what the doctor ordered.
Ingred: .5 oz Tempus Fugit crème de cacao.5 oz
Garnish: 6 Mint sprigs; 4 dashes of Angostura bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker, and dry-shake (without ice), then shake with ice.

Double-strain into a sherbet glass.

Garnish with 6 mint sprigs and 4 dashes of Angostura bitters.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Throw on some Skynyrd and mix up the SoCo, sloe gin, amaretto and orange juice Alabama Slammer. No one knows who invented the Alabama Slammer, but legend has it that the colorful cocktail was first shaken at the University of Alabama in 1975. The sweet mix of SoCo, sloe gin, amaretto and orange juice is supposedly the signature drink of the Alabama Crimson Tide football team.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange wheel and a cherry.

Author: Kaitlyn Goalen
About: Ernest Hemingway is inspiration, not author, of the Hemingway Daiquiri. His request for a Daiquiri made with half the sugar and double the booze created an unbalanced drink: one that bartenders couldn’t help but right through the eventual addition of maraschino liqueur and grapefruit juice. To reinstate some of Hemingway’s influence, this recipe uses key lime juice and goes for a whir in the blender, as the earliest Daiquiris were served over crushed ice.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a blender and fill with ice.

Cover and pulse the blender until the drink has a slushy consistency.

Divide the contents of the blender between 8 wine glasses and garnish each with a lime wheel.

About: This house cocktail at Scotland’s Glenmorangie House
Instructions:
Add the scotch and bitters into a rocks glass over ice, and stir.

Top with the ginger ale, flame an orange peel to express the oils, then add as a garnish.

Author: Allison Widdecombe
About: Port, Fernet Branca and cardamom-infused bitter liqueur take a bourbon cocktail to uncharted territory.
Ingred: .5 oz Oolong teainfused ruby port.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients, except the lemon peel, to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.

Express lemon oils over cocktail and discard the peel.

Garnish with a cherry.%Oolong teainfused ruby port:I steeped loose tea (Wuyi Oolong tea and a small amount of rooibos tea) into Graham's 6 grapes port.For every 20 ounces of port, I added 8 ounces of dry oolong tea and 1 ounce of rooibos (measured out by my jigger, I am not sure how the conversion of wet to dry ounces are).

I let this steep for about 18 minutes.

The oolong flavor is definitely prominent by the end.%Cardamom-infused Amèr Nouvelle:For this I added a crushed (green) pod to each ounce of liqueur and let it steep about 25 minutes.

I would taste as I infuse though, as cardamom pods can vary in strength.

One infusion timing test I did went only 19 minutes.

The flavor added is very light and gentle.

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About: The shocking color belies a classy Champagne-and-tequila concoction.
Garnish: 1 Orange slice, mint leaf and cherry
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a Collins glass and fill with ice.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an orange slice, mint leaf and cherry.

Author: Matt Armato
Instructions:
Combine the sugar and black pepper in a shallow dish. Wet the rim of the glass with the slice of lime, and gently rotate the rim into the sugar and pepper mix to coat the edge of the glass evenly.

Add the triple sec, pineapple chunk and jalapeño round into a mixing tin and gently muddle.

Add the tequila, lime juice and pineapple juice. Add ice and shake.

Double-strain over fresh ice into the rimmed glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge, pineapple chunk and jalapeño round.

About: A dash of olive brine brings a salty, savory note to the all-time classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with 2 olives.

Author: Nate Dumas
About: A few dashes of pear brandy and Fernet-Branca make this gin cocktail recipe unique.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Perry's Tot Navy Strength Gin
.5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the prosecco to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with chilled prosecco and garnish with a lemon half-wheel.

About: This dessert-y sipper has rich, chocolaty underpinnings, so “the drink will pair best with a New-World corn-based or wheat-based vodka rich in vanilla or cocoa elements,” according to bartender Tony Abou-Ganim.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, and shake vigorously until blended (long enough to dissolve the cocoa powder).

Strain into a chilled Nick &  Nora glass, and dust with the grated chocolate.

Author: Fredo Ceraso
About: With Polish vodka and French and Italian liqueurs, this aperitif is a grand European tour in a glass.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Brett Esler
About: Brett Esler of Whisler’s in Austin created this intricate take on the Hot Toddy. It gets a nice spice from ginger liqueur, a round sweetness from house-made honey syrup and plenty of spice from cinnamon and allspice. Keep in mind this tipple proves strong, so it’s best to sip slowly.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Elijah Craig small-batch bourbon 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Lustau Solera Reserva brandy de Jerez.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except for the cinnamon-lemon-infused hot water into a small Toddy mug.

Top with the infused hot water.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and grated nutmeg.

*Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use, the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

**Cinnamon-lemon-infused hot water: Boil 1 cup water, 1 lemon peel and 1 cinnamon stick for 5 minutes, discard the peel and stick, and let cool.

Author: Jonah Flicker
About: Bourbon and orange don’t usually go together, unless it’s a slice dropped into an Old Fashioned, but this cocktail adds a splash of orange liqueur to bourbon and tops it off with ginger ale to counter the sweetness.
Instructions:
Fill rocks glass with ice.

Add the bourbon, orange curaçao liqueur and a squeeze of fresh orange and stir.

Top off with ginger ale, and garnish with an orange wedge.

About: This cocktail is an eight-ingredient, highly amplified riff on an Old Fashioned, incorporating five Don Ciccio & Figli bottles and several additional ingredients.
Instructions:
Pour all of the ingredients in mixing glass and stir.

Pour into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Shawn Chen
About: Inspired by the harvest season in late September, this cocktail embodies fall’s coziest flavors.
Ingred: 3 Concord grapes soaked in pomegranate molasses brandy and toasted almond
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir vigorously until the mixing glass becomes frosty.

Strain into a rocks glass over two-inch ice cube.

Author: Mandy Landefeld
About: This two-ingredient take on the classic Martini is named for the fashion icon.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Author: Richard Woods
About: This inventive cocktail could only come from the mind of Richard Woods at Sushisamba London, where he puts a richly-flavored spin on the Old Fashioned with wagyu-beef-fat–washed Japanese whisky.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and lightly mix.

Add ice to the shaker and stir to chill.

Strain, and pour into rocks glass over ice.

Author: Brian Bartels
About: With some tomato but also other ingredients to tone it down and chill it out, this cocktail by Brian Bartels, of New York City’s Fedora
Ingred: 3 dashes Hella Bitters ginger lemon bitters
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with the dill salt.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and roll the mixture back and forth with another shaker 3 times.

Strain the cocktail into the rimmed glass over ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

*Cucumber juice: Either use a juicer or purée cucumber in a high-powered blender, then strain through a fine-mesh sieve.

**Dill salt: Stir together 1 sprig of dill and 1/4 cup salt in a bowl, and let sit for at least 2 hours before using. Makes 1/4 cup, enough to rim 12 glasses.

Author: Martin Cate
About: This Tiki drink is what an exotic cocktail is all about, with citrus, sweeteners, spice and, of course, rums.
Ingred: 1.5 oz AOC Martinique rhum agricole vieux
1⁄4 oz John D. Taylor’s Velvet falernum 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 1⁄4 oz
3 maraschino cherries on a cocktail pick and 1 pineapple frond (representing Morse Code—three cherries as the three dots and the frond as the dash), for garnish
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a drink mixer tin.

Fill with 12 oz of crushed ice and 4 to 6 small “agitator” cubes.

Flash-blend, then open pour with gated finish into a footed pilsner glass and add the garnish.

Drink Name: Tippy Cow Halloween Layered Shooters: Toot Toot Tootsie
Instructions:
Layering trick: Pour first flavor into shot glass.

Shake second flavor vigorously for 10 seconds with ice then pour over spoon into glass.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Cool down with this refreshing mix of vodka, watermelon and ginger.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the basil, ginger, watermelon and simple syrup.

Add the vodka and lime juice, and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with ginger ale and garnish with a watermelon chunk and basil leaf.

Author: Simon Difford
About: The fizzy elderflower-and-wine cocktail has become a modern classic. You simply need a measure St-Germain elderflower liqueur, some Champagne to cut the sweetness and soda to make it ultra-refreshing.
Ingred: 2 oz Dry white wine or Champagne
Instructions:
Add the St-Germain and wine to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Stir well and top with club soda.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: This Negroni takes a delicious detour to Poland. You have to taste this cocktail to appreciate how unfiltered vodka can elevate the classic cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Noah Small
About: Concord grapes are perfect for cocktails thanks to their sweetness and pleasantly dry finish. Paired with clean agave flavor from the tequila, Concord grapes create your new favorite flavored Margarita.
Ingred: 1 oz R.W. Knudsen Organic Concord Grape Juice
1 barspoon Barspoon Smuckers Concord Grape Jelly
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice.

Author: Chilled Magazine
About: If you love popsicles and love cocktails, there’s nothing better than these easy-to-make treats. Have these on hand at your next summer gathering!
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Add the sorbet, limoncello and 2 oz of the whiskey into a blender and blend until smooth.

Set aside.

Add the raspberries, lemonade and 1/2 oz of the whiskey into a blender and blend until smooth.

Pour the raspberry mixture into a liquid measuring cup or a cup with a spout for easy pouring.

Fill popsicle molds wells 3/4 of the way up with the limoncello mixture.

Slowly and carefully pour raspberry mixture against the sides of the molds for a layered effect.

Cover the molds with foil and cut a tiny hole in the center of each mold.

Place a popsicle stick through each hole.

Place in the freezer until frozen.

Author: Juan Coronado
About:
This black-rum-based cocktail is sweet, bitter and herbal, with a bit of brightness from lime juice and an orange peel garnish.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Everything You Need to Know About Black Strap Rum.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Named after Cuban president Gerardo Machado, the El Presidente #1 is a drier version of the original and described as “the aristocrat of cocktails.” It was created by American bartender Eddie Woelke at Jockey Club.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir thoroughly.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a preserved cherry.

Author: Martin Cate
About: You don’t need a pegleg, a parrot or a tri-cornered hat to enjoy this drink.
Ingred: .5 oz Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with a lemon slice.

Author: Shannon Ponche
About: Lower alcohol than most Bloody Marys
Ingred: Negra Modelo beer, to top Negra Modelo beer, to top
Instructions:
Coat half of the rim of a chilled beer mug with salt.

Combine the sangrita and lime juice in the glass.

Top off with the beer.

Garnish with 2 skewered lime wedges.

*Carrot-papaya sangrita: Combine 9 oz Perfect Puree papaya puree, 9 oz carrot juice, 1 ¼ oz lime juice, 1 1/4 oz orange juice, 1 tsp ground guajillo chile powder, 1/2 tsp ground chipotle chile powder and 3/4 tsp salt, and let sit for 1 hour. Pass through a fine-mesh strainer lined with cheesecloth or a coffee filter. Transfer to a pitcher if serving immediately, or store in a sealed container and refrigerate for up to 2 days. Makes 2 1/2 cups, enough for 10 drinks.

Author: Lucid Absinthe
About: Expand your mind with this absinthe cocktail.
Instructions:
Muddle the mint leaves in the bottom of a frappe style glass.

Add the absinthe, simple syrup and fill with crushed ice.

Pour the mixture into a shaker and shake vigorously.

Pour the contents back into the glass.

Author: Noreen Ryan
About: Rum and rye play nicely with rosehip liqueur and pineapple juice in this drink from Atwood Restaurant in Chicago.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Juice from brandied cherries 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with mint sprig.

Author: Jonah Flicker
About: This beer cocktail adds a hoppy IPA to 100-proof bourbon, some citrus and the kicker: muddled fresh marjoram, resulting in a variety of summery flavors that blend together nicely.
Instructions:
Dry-muddle the marjoram.

Add all of the other ingredients except the beer, and give it a quick stir.

Strain into a pint glass, and add ice.

Top with the beer, and garnish with the grapefruit peel.

Author: Ryan Te
About: Lapsang tea lends its signature smokiness to this cocktail through an infused gin, which is balanced with bittersweet Cynar and Chartreuse.
Instructions:
Add ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a glass.

Garnish with orange peel.

Author: Robb Jones
About: Bellecour
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the bitters into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice).

Add 1 large ice cube, and shake well.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and top with a few dashes of Angostura bitters.

Garnish with a lemon pigtail twist.

Author: Emil Areng
About: This rum cocktail by Emil Åreng of Umeå, Sweden’s Open/Closed was created for the Bacardi Legacy competition.
Ingred: 1 Ear of microplaned dried sweetened corn, for garnish
Instructions:
Shake all of the ingredients, strain, and top with the corn foam.

*Corn foam: Make 8 cups of simple syrup, add two pre-boiled corn cobs, and let it rest at medium heat for about 1 hour. Strain and add two leaves of gelatin.

Pour into a cream siphon, and add 2 cream chargers.

Let it sit in the fridge for 1 hour.

Author: Rusted Mule
About: The strong coffee flavor in this cocktail from Rusted Mule
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz St. George NOLA coffee liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda water to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into mixing tin and dry-shake for 1 minute.

Strain into chilled Old Fashioned glass.

Slowly add soda water until foam goes beyond the lip of the glass.

Garnish with fresh coffee grounds and an orange twist.

Author: Liquor.com
About: To think that a little more than a year ago, frozen rosé, aka frosé, was on the fringes of summer refreshers. After all, its very existence seemed more sorority house dare than sound cocktail concept. Wine was something to be sniffed, swirled and studied, not dumped mindlessly into a blender. America begged to differ. Today, the adult slushie sensation appears on bar lists (and Instagram feeds) from coast to coast, proving that sometimes the best rule to good imbibing is to just chill out and drink.
Ingred: 1 bottle Rosé (750mL, something full-bodied and dark in color, such as a pinot noir– or merlot-based rosé)
Instructions:
Serves 4.

Pour the rosé into a 13 x 9” baking pan, and place in the freezer for up to 6 hours or until almost solid.

Remove the mixture and scrape into a blender, chopping up the larger icy bits.

Add the remaining ingredients along with 3/4 cup crushed ice to the blender, and puree until thickened.

Divide evenly into coupe glasses.

Garnish with lemon twists.

Author: Will Duncan
About: This sparkling cognac and rum punch bursts with citrus flavor.
Instructions:
In a large punch bowl, prepare an oleo saccharum by muddling the sugar and citrus peels gently for a few minutes every 10 minutes over the course of an hour.

Meanwhile, prepare the hot tea, timing the tea steeping to complete just as the oleo saccharum is ready.

Strain the tea into the punch bowl to melt the oleo into a rich, aromatic syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients except the Champagne to the punch bowl.

Add the Champagne and an ice block just before service.

Garnish with 3 orange wheels and fresh mint sprigs.

*Darjeeling tea: Brew 1 tbsp of loose tea per cup of hot water and let steep for 5 minutes.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Bacardí brand ambassador Jacob Briars created this drink as a joke, but it’s become a popular order, so he gets the last laugh. It is similar to the Corpse Reviver No. 2, but swaps Cointreau for blue curaçao.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe or Martini glass with absinthe and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Fine-strain into the prepared glass, and garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: This sophisticated sherry-and-tequila cocktail proves that the agave spirit can be elegant.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Flor de Caña Rum
About: This rum drink is up-to-date.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini or coupe glass.

Garnish with 2 raspberries.

About: Scotch as complex and rich as Aberlour can elevate almost drink. The Robert Baratheon shows how single malt and vermouth can bring out one another’s strengths.
Ingred: 2 oz Aberlour 12 Year-Old Single Malt Scotch
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.

Stir until cold and strain into a chilled coup.

Author: Nick Mautone
About:
The Bloody Mary is a vodka-soaked nutritional breakfast and hangover cure all in one. What else could you ask for?
The tomato-based cocktail has hundreds of variations, from heavy on the hot sauce to a splash of Guinness on top. It’s best to start with the classic recipe and work toward the way you like it, even if it’s topped with a shrimp skewer, a slice of bacon and a tiny cheeseburger. Crazy garnishes aside, there’s a reason this iconic beverage is a classic.
While the origin of this popular brunch cocktail is debatable, the Bloody Mary’s staying power leaves no question.
Instructions:
Pour some celery salt onto a small plate.

Rub the juicy side of the lemon or lime wedge along the lip of a pint glass.

Roll the outer edge of the glass in celery salt until fully coated.

Fill with ice and set aside.

Squeeze the lemon and lime wedges into a shaker and drop them in.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake gently and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a celery stalk and a lime wedge.

Author: Danny Sawyer
About:
Danny Sawyer, a bartender at Chicago’s Sable Kitchen & Bar, describes this glögg riff as warm, rich and spicy.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “These Are the Only 3 Mulled Rum Cocktails You’ll Ever Need.”
Ingred: 1⁄4 dropper The Bitter End Memphis Barbeque bitters 1⁄4 dropper
Instructions:
Warm all ingredients in a cappuccino cup and serve it in a teacup with a saucer and spoon.

Garnish with an orange peel studded with 3 cloves.

Author: Casa Noble Tequila
About: This sweet-and-fizzy pitcher cocktail is a great excuse to throw a party.
Instructions:
In a small bowl, stir together the agave nectar and lime juice until the agave nectar dissolves.

Add to a pitcher, along with the tequila and ginger beer, and stir well.

Add the ice and stir until cold.

Serve in highball glasses garnished with lime wheels.

Author: Ketel One Vodka
About: It’ll be the Invisible Man after you taste this cool cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the simple syrup, cucumber and mint.

Add the vodka and lime juice, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Drambuie
About: One sip of this hot apple-and-Drambuie cocktail will warm you to the core.
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a mug and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Garrett Smith
About: For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. Every Friday of football season, in honor of the Colts, Indianapolis’ Spoke & Steele serves these electric-blue drinks from a slushie machine alongside its spicy “famous nug” meatballs during happy hour.
Ingred: 2 dashes Plum bitters (or Angostura orange bitters)
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a blender, blend until smooth, and serve in a rocks glass.

*Spiced simple syrup: Add 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar, 1 cinnamon stick, 4 whole cloves, freshly grated nutmeg and a couple of pieces of lemon peel to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is completely dissolved, and bring to a gentle simmer. Remove from heat, allow to cool to room temperature, and strain.

Author: David Slape
About: Named for the marmalade-loving bear, this drink gets a jolt of fruit flavor from orange preserves.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe glass with absinthe.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Jeff Bell
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ancho Reyes chile liqueur 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Pok Pok Pineapple Som 3⁄4 oz
3 oz Victory Prima Pils pilsner beer
Garnish: Rim of one part La Bôite NYC Izak N.37 and four parts kosher salt
Instructions: Shake the tequila, liqueur, Pok Pok Som and lime juice with ice, top with the pilsner, and strain into a chilled ice-filled Pilsner glass rimmed with a blend of one part La Bôite NYC Izak N.37 and four parts kosher salt.

About: Wine, fruit and booze—what’s not to love?
Instructions:
Add all the Ingredients to a blender, and blend until smooth.

Garnish with skewered berries and a basil sprig.

Author: Patrón Tequila
About: Tired of Margaritas? Try this simple tequila and pineapples juice cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Patrón Citrónge Orange Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Pour Patrón Silver Tequila and Patrón Citrónge into a rocks glass full of ice.

Fill with pineapple juice and finish with a squeeze of lime.

Garnish the drink with a lime wheel.

Author: Dimitris Kiakos
About: Created by Dimitris Kiakos of the Gin Joint in Athens, Greece, the Kumquat Smash muddles the small yet flavor-rich citrus fruit into a refreshing gin base.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the kumquats.

Add remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with two kumquats.

Author: Phil Ward
About: With gin, cointreau and a touch of absinthe, this pleasure won’t remain unknown for long.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jack McGarry
About: Try this twist on the classic Coffee Cocktail, which calls for a pair of Irish spirits.
Ingred: 1 oz Graham's Late Bottled Vintage Port
2 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a small, chilled wine goblet.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Paul Tanguay
About: Sake isn’t just for sipping. Try this spicy cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Grapefruit slice and fresh mint sprig
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the grapefruit and Tabasco.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a grapefruit slice and a fresh mint sprig.

About: This traditional drink from Barbados uses dark, oil-like blackstrap rum.
Ingred: 2 oz Black strap or aged Barbados rum
Instructions:
Combine rum, falernum, and lime juice in a rocks glass.

Top with crushed or cracked ice.

Add the bitters and stir ingredients until well chilled. The glass should be frosty.

Top with bitters and serve with a lime wedge.

About: This take on the Sidecar is just peachy.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe.

Author: Jared Schubert
About: You don’t need a crowbar to fix this tasty bourbon cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, lightly muddle the orange, mint and simple syrup.

Add the bourbon and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and double-strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Forget pancakes! Use your maple syrup in cocktails.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

About: So popular they named a glass after it, this whiskey cocktail is a classic go-to.
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass with ice, and add all of the ingredients.

Stir until chilled and diluted, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass with fresh ice.

Garnish with an expressed orange peel and 2 cherries.

Author: Allen Katz
About: This classic cocktail was invented in a British social club in Burma.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Cameron Dale
About: Every home bar should have a bottle of Lillet Blanc. And a glass of Lillet on the rocks makes for a perfect afternoon.
Instructions:
In a rocks glass, add the Lillet Blanc and fill with ice.

Garnish with a speared orange peel.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: You don’t need to be an oil tycoon to enjoy this cocktail.
Instructions:
Pour the vodka into a rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with black pepper.

Author: RumChata
About: You’ll savor every flavorful sip of this Martini.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Jessica Lambert
About: Sherry, pineapple juice and a rummy homemade mix are the stars of this cocktail from Sable Kitchen & Bar in Chicago.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the pilsner to a hurricane glass filled with crushed ice.

Mix well, and top with pilsner.

Garnish with a mint sprig and 3 dashes of Angostura Bitters.

Author: Karin Stanley
About: Canadian whisky teams up with earthy Cynar to create this burly coupe with a hint of smoked salt.
Ingred: 1 oz Forty Creek Barrel Select Canadian whisky
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe.

Author: Knob Creek Bourbon
About: This potent bourbon cocktail is surprisingly sweet.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Rich simple syrup (two parts sugar, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
1 dash Fee Brothers Old Fashion Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Mix up this distant cousin of the Manhattan.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry on a cocktail pick.

Author: Gary Regan
About: With cream, crème de cacao and brandy,  classic is a creamy, indulgent delight. With many details of its origin unknown, the Brandy Alexander became popular in the early 20th century. Try this cocktail as a decadent after-dinner sipper.
Ingred: 2 oz Cognac or other fine aged brandy
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

About: Cognac, sherry and peach tea make this summery punch a year-round crowd-pleaser.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the lemon halves to a large punch bowl.

Squeeze the juice from the lemon halves into the punch.

Chill with a large block of ice.

Serve in rocks glasses over solid cubes of ice or shaved ice.

Garnish with lemon and peach slices.

*Honey syrup: Combine 3 parts honey to 1 part hot water, and stir until the honey has dissolved.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: A pair of famed bartenders created this subtle variation on the classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: This calvados cocktail was created in honor of Princess Mary’s 1922  wedding.
Instructions:
