Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Baileys
About: South of the borderIrish-style.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Baileys with a Hint of Coffee
3⁄4 oz Don Julio Añejo Tequila 3⁄4 oz
Generous scoop of vanilla ice cream (softened)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and fill with ice.

Blend until smooth and pour into a highball glass.

About: This melon pineapple inspired drink is easy to make for those warm Summer days.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with Maraschino cherry and pineapple slice.

Author: Rachel Bahman
About: Created by a star Los Angeles bartender, this unusual cocktail will transport you to Southern California.
Ingred: 3 dashes Dr. Adam Elmegirab's Dandelion & Burdock Bitters
Instructions:
Coat the tarragon sprigs in Chartreuse and heat carefully over an open flame for about 15 seconds each.

Set one Â"smokedÂ" tarragon sprig aside and muddle the second in a shaker with the Honeydew Honey Syrup.

Add the gin, lemon juice, bitters and 2 tsp.

Yellow Chartreuse, and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and fine-strain into a fluted pilsner glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with the reserved Â"smokedÂ" tarragon sprig.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: Spice up your next cup of cocoa with this cayenne-spiked recipe mixed with nutty walnut liqueur and bourbon.
Instructions:
Preheat mug by filling it with hot water.

Discard water after 30 seconds.

Add bourbon and walnut liqueur to the heated mug.

Add the spicy hot cocoa and gently mix together.

Garnish with chile peppers.

About: Bitter amaro bites through this otherwise “spritzy” drink, made with gin, Aperol and silky gum syrup.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with lemon peel.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Throw some lamb on the grill and the next thing you know you’ve got tacos! This taco recipe is simple and full of big outdoor weather–friendly flavors.
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great hot-weather tequila drinks.
Ingred: 3 lb bone-in leg of lamb roast (or 2 pounds boneless), butterflied by the butcher
2⁄3 cup cup olive oil, divided 2⁄3 cup
4 cloves garlic, smashed plus 2 cloves garlic, minced
1⁄3 cup lightly packed cilantro leaves 1⁄3 cup
6 oz crumbled cotija or feta cheese
Instructions:
Make the marinade: In a large zip-top bag, combine 1/3 cup olive oil, 4 cloves smashed garlic, jalapeño, one chopped shallot and salt and pepper. Add the lamb and marinate for four hours at room temperature, or refrigerated overnight. If refrigerated, let come to room temperature before grilling.

Once the lamb has marinated, bring your grill to very high heat. Charcoal grill is best here, but any hot grill will do. Place lamb on the grill, making sure the meat isn’t bunched up in places and is completely flat. Cook for about 8 minutes, at which point there should be a lot of charring, then flip the meat over and cook for another 8 minutes. If the lamb is particularly thin (less than 2-inches thick) you may only need 5 minutes on each side. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the lamb to make sure the temperature has reached 145 degrees fahrenheit. Transfer lamb from the grill to a cutting board, cover with foil and let rest for ten minutes. When the lamb is nearly finished resting, cut it into strips against the grain.

While the lamb rests, make the salsa: In a medium mixing bowl, combine the remaining 1/3 cup olive oil, minced garlic, remaining chopped shallot, red wine vinegar, cilantro, parsley, oregano, red pepper flakes, squeeze of lime, salt and pepper and whisk together.

To serve, warm your tortillas on the grill and assemble tacos by filling with lamb, salsa, cotija, and radish.

Author: Jay Zimmerman
About: Made from gin, applejack and apricot liqueur, this cocktail is fruity but powerful.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a slice of orange peel.

Author: Brian Means
About: Combine ZU Bison Grass Vodka with hard apple cider for a seasonal vodka cocktail that is citrusy, crisp and ultra refreshing.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the cider to a pilsner glass.

Add pebbled ice and stir until the outside of the glass frosts.

Top with more ice and the cider.

Garnish with a sprig of mint and seasonal berries.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Mix up this tequila, cassis and grapefruit cocktail.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Fresh ruby red grapefruit juice
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cassis to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Dribble the .5 oz of French Cassis down the inside of the glass so it settles at the bottom.

Author: Tara Wright
About: It’s a seriously stressful job to sit in the captain’s chair (and wear those tight pants, too) on Star Trek’s Enterprise—be it Pike, Kirk, Picard, Sisco, Janeway, Archer or any of the others who’ve helmed that position, briefly or not. So here’s a much-deserved absinthe and Chartreuse sipper for an otherworldly vacation from the deck.
Instructions:
Blend the absinthe, Chartreuse, juices, Bénédictine and Angostura in a blender with ice on high for 7 seconds or until slushy.

Add 4 dashes of Peychaud's bitters, and swirl with a straw until pretty.

Garnish with a paper umbrella.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: There’s still time to make this seasonal cocktail before the beginning of fall.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a tall glass filled with ice.

Stir and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Garrick Club Punch tasted as good in 1835 as it does today.
Instructions:
Peel the lemons with a vegetable peeler, avoiding the white pith.

Muddle the peels with the sugar in a 3-quart pitcher or punch bowl and let stand for 30 minutes.

Add the lemon juice and stir until the sugar has dissolved.

Add the gin and Luxardo Maraschino Liqueur or Grand Marnier, and stir.

Fill the pitcher or bowl halfway with ice and add the seltzer or club soda.

Stir again and serve in individual punch or highball glasses.

Author: Galliano
About: You don’t need to be Audubon to appreciate this tasty cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel or a slice of lime peel.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: Pam Wiznitzer’s bubbly New Orleans: #RAD was inspired by her favorite moment during the annual Tales of the Cocktail convention. Following the last Tales event on Sunday night, the industry takes over a local bar and breaks out the sparkling rosé to the chant of “rosé all day.” Wiznitzer captured the energy of this moment with her specialty cocktail, made with cognac, St-Germain, strawberry puree and absinthe and topped with a float of sparkling rosé.
Instructions:
Shake all ingredients except for the sparkling rosé.

Pour into a white wine glass.

Top with sparkling rosé.

Garnish with mini tiny rubber duckie.

Author: Erick Castro
About: Love bourbon? Don’t miss the simple and delicious Bulleit Bourbon Kentucky Buck cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon juice and strawberry.

Add the bourbon, simple syrup and bitters, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with ginger beer and garnish with a lemon wheel and a thinly sliced strawberry.

Author: Jonathan Webb
About:
Get everyone congregating around the punch bowl instead of the water cooler with this convivial sip from Jonathan Webb, the bar manager at Fine & Dandy in Jackson, Miss. Feel free to temper the amounts if it seems too boozy for your crowd by upping the amount of juice or beer and cutting back on the rye whiskey and rum. And prep the syrup in advance so you can easily mix the punch before the party. You can serve it in a large punch bowl garnished with a round Jell-O mold ice block filled with sliced fruit.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tired of Boring Bartender Staff Parties? These Tips Will Change How You Celebrate.”
Ingred: 2 12-oz cans of ale (such as Lucky Town pub ale)
Instructions:
Makes 8-10 servings.

Combine all the ingredients except the beer in a large punch bowl and stir well.

Top with the beer, and add several large ice cubes.

Garnish with orange and lemon wheels.

*Cinnamon pear syrup: Combine 1 cup demerara sugar and 1 1/2 cups water in a saucepan, and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce it to a simmer, add 1 pear (thinly sliced), and let it simmer for 45 minutes. Remove it from the heat, add 2 cinnamon sticks, 5 cloves and 2 pieces of star anise, and let steep for 1 hour. Strain out solids, allow it to cool, and store in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

Author: Moon Mountain Vodka
About: This sweet drink makes a strong case for using grape juice in cocktails.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and two grapes on a cocktail pick or skewer.

Author: Brian Means
About: Anchor’s Christmas Spirit is the merry result of distilling Anchor Brewing’s Christmas ale, which creates a smooth, winter-spiced spirit that’s ideal for holiday cocktails like this one, mixed with maraschino, cognac and bitters.
Ingred: .5 oz Chateau Montifaud Pineau de Charentes Rosso.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a Luxardo cherry.

Author: Tony Devencenzi
About: This complex cocktail will set your heart aflame.
Ingred: 1.5 oz George Dickel Barrel Select Tennessee Whisky
2 dashes The Bitter Truth chocolate bitters
1 tsp Ardbeg Uigeadail Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled small cocktail glass.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Sweet has never tasted so hot.
Instructions:
Add all of the  ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine-strain into a Martini glass or tumbler filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a jalapeño slice.

Author: Demi Moore & Madonna
About: The South American cocktail endorsed by Demi Moore and Madonna.
Instructions:
Fill an Old Fashioned glass with ice.

Squeeze the lime wedges into the glass and then add the wedges and sugar.

Fill the glass a third of the way with cachaca.

Fill with Vita Coco Tangerine and stir gently.

Author: Eric Alperin
About: Ketel One Vodka with grapefruit juice and orange liqueur. Hold the adding machine.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit peel.

Author: Dan Warner
About: Load up on vitamin C.
Ingred: 1 oz Tonic water (such as Q Tonic)
Garnish: 1 Lemon wheel, lime wheel and orange wheel
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a Collins or highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel, lime wheel and orange wheel.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: This version of a Shandy served at Boston’s Coppa
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients, except for the beer, in a mixing glass and stir.

Strain over fresh ice in a tall beer mug (or pilsner glass), and top with beer.

Author: BÃ©nÃ©dictine
About: This easy-to-make drink will take you to the Promised Land.
Instructions:
Add the BÃ©nÃ©dictine to a mug.

Fill with ice, top with cold milk and garnish with an orange slice and a cinnamon stick.

This cocktail can also be served hot. Simply Â-warm up the milk and leave out the ice.).

Author: McLain Hedges
About:
Bartender McLain Hedges created this cocktail at RiNo Yacht Club in The Source hotel to celebrate the city’s ethnic diversity. The clean, well-balanced cocktail comes off as both familiar and exotic, and, as Hedges says, “It’s a cocktail that feels good to drink.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “13 Healthy Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into a highball glass, fill halfway with crushed ice, and swizzle for 10 seconds.

Top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and lime zest.

*Eastern medicine syrup: Stir together 1 qt water, 1 qt sugar, 1 chopped 2-inch piece of fresh ginger, 2 makrut lime leaves, 1 tsp rosewater, 10 Korean chili threads, 6 cracked cardamom pods, 2 cracked lemongrass stalks and 10 mint leaves in a pot over medium heat, bring to a simmer, and steep for 1 hour. Chill the syrup, then strain through a cheesecloth or fine-mesh strainer, and store in the refrigerator. Makes 1 qt.

About: Most popular in western Europe, especially Germany, this two-ingredient beer cocktail is easy to make and refreshing.
Instructions: In a pint glass, combine the lager and Sprite (or 7Up).
Pour over ice.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Romantic Summer Winter

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Despite its name, there are no geographical limitations for this gin cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, gently muddle the mint and lemon juice.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig or lemon twist.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: The spicy kick of ginger is a welcome addition to this update of the Margarita.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ginger Root Simple Syrup% 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a highball glass with salt, fill with ice and set aside.

Add  the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Kara Newman
About:
If you’re looking for a pick-me-up post-dinner, the Espresso Martini is here to jolt you awake with its boozy magical powers. The cold coffee-flavored cocktail mixes vodka with espresso coffee, coffee liqueur (usually Kahlúa) and simple syrup. Garnish with a few coffee beans, and it’s picture perfect.
British bartender Dick Bradsell invented this now-classic drink, a.k.a. the Vodka Espresso, at Fred’s Club in London in the late ’80s. Legend has it that Kate Moss asked for a drink that would “wake me up and then fuck me up” at the same time, and the Espresso Martini was the result.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with 3 coffee beans.

Author: Franky Marshall
About: This simple bourbon drink is pure old-school.
Ingred: 1 tsp Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with lemon and orange twists.

Author: Patrón Tequila
About: Grapefruit is a great match for tequila and orange liqueur.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Patrón Citrónge Orange Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the tequila and liqueur to a highball glass full of ice.

Top with grapefruit juice.

Add a splash of club soda and garnish with lemon and lime slices.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: Start your day with this delicious orange-marmalade Margarita.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Agave syrup (one part Partida agave nectar, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: No need to overthink it when you’re working with a spirit as good as Jack Daniel’s Tennessee rye. Here’s how to let it shine in a Highball.
Instructions:
Add the rye, juice, syrup and bitters to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Highball glass with fresh ice.

Top with soda water.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: You’ll fall in love with this creamy, chocolaty and chile pepper-spiked vodka cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the chile slices.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Author: Alyssa Sartor
About: A few unexpected ingredients and artisanal touches separate this cocktail by Alyssa Sartor of August Laura in New York City from your average Irish Coffee.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the whiskey, allspice dram and syrup to an Irish Coffee mug and fill with the coffee.

Top with the cream and dust with ground cinnamon.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: This bourbon, orange and cranberry cocktail will get your juices flowing.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Sarah Smith, Putnam’s Pub & Cooker
About: This cocktail was created by Sarah Smith at Putnam’s Pub for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rinse an Old Fashioned glass with the Chartreuse, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the cognac, molasses syrup and bitters to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into the prepared glass.

Flame the lemon peel over the surface of the drink, then drop into the glass.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
Molly Wellmann of Japp’s Since 1879
Ingred: 2 oz The Kraken black spiced rum
3 oz Left Hand Brewing milk stout
Garnish: 4 orange peels, cut long and thin
Instructions:
Cut 4 long and thin orange peels, and press them firmly onto the inside of a coupe.

Add the rum, syrup and mint to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into the coupe carefully, trying not to disturb the peels, though some will undoubtedly float in the glass.

Gently top with the stout, and yell “Who Dey!”.

*Vanilla simple syrup: Combine 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar and 2 split vanilla beans in a small pot, and stir. Bring to a rolling boil, stirring to prevent scorching. Reduce heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. Strain through a fine sieve and discard the vanilla beans. Will keep in the refrigerator for 2 or 3 weeks.

About: The best-known Champagne cocktail, the Kir Royale, turns any glass of bubbly into a special occasion.
Instructions:
Add the crème de cassis to a Champagne flute, and top with the sparkling wine.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Naren Young
About: Applejack, pear brandy and hard pear cider? That’s a perfect formula for autumn cocktail fans everywhere.
Ingred: .5 oz Clear Creek Pear Brandy.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except hard pear cider to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice.

Top with hard pear cider.

Author: Claire Sprouse
About: Who doesn’t love an equal-parts cocktail? Pineapple syrup lends a silky thread to this sunny blend of rum and dry vermouth.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe.

Author: Baileys
About: Curl up in front of the fireplace with this mixture of hot chocolate and java.
Instructions:
Pour the Baileys and hot chocolate into a coffee mug.

Top with a dollop of whipped cream.

Garnish with 3 coffee beans.

Author: Andrew Volk
About: It’s the guiding principle for all members of Star Trek’s Starfleet: Don’t mess with other civilizations and sully up their worlds. Which is a pretty good rule to follow for drinks, too. Keep things light and herby with this gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Stir all of the ingredients, and strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Alex Renshaw
About: During his shift at Miami’s Broken Shaker, Alex Renshaw of Chicago’s Drumbar served this balanced blend of Bacardi 8 rum, bitter amaro, apple juice and Demerara syrup as a tribute to his home city’s brisk climate.
Instructions: Shake and strain on 1x1 cubes.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Served in a Mason jar, this refresher is a summertime staple.
Instructions:
Fill a Mason jar with ice and add the VeeV.

Fill with lemonade and add a splash of cranberry juice.

Seal the jar, shake and garnish with a lemon half-wheel.

Author: Chad Doll
About: The classic Rusty Nail gets an update.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Dewar's White Label Scotch Whisky 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a Champagne flute.

About:
The Long Island Iced Tea is what happens when four different spirits collide to create one powerful drink. It’s not clear who thought this was a good idea and if this tastes at all like iced tea, but one can agree that the Long Island Iced Tea is responsible for a few stories of irresponsibility, at least a dozen memories of good times and even more hangovers than we can count.
The story of the Long Island Iced Tea is shrouded in mystery. But rest assured this drink is easy to master, if only one can say the same for the morning after.
Instructions:
Fill a highball or hurricane glass with ice and add all the ingredients except the cola.

Top with a splash of cola and stir briefly.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Lucid Absinthe
About: A refreshing and fruity patriotic cocktail.
Ingred: G.E. Massenez Framboise Sauvage Raspberry Brandy
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blueberries.

Add the vodka, absinthe, syrup and lemon juice, and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a highball glass. Drizzle with brandy and top with ginger beer.

Garnish with one sugar cube.

About: Mix up the Americano on the Fourth of July or anytime the spirit moves you.
Instructions:
Pour the Campari and vermouth into a rocks or highball glass filled with ice.

Add a splash of club soda and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Famed bartender Dick Bradsell invented this classic at Fred’s Club in London’s Soho in the ’80s, inspired by the fresh blackberries he used to get as a child on the Isle of Wight.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup in a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into an Old Fashioned glass over crushed ice.

Lace over top with the creme de mure.

Garnish with a lemon half-wheel and a fresh blackberry.

About: Add the flavors of the classic dessert to a sweet, frothy cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the cognac, syrup and liqueur to an ice-filled mixing glass.

Stir and strain into a coupe.

Froth the half-and-half to semi-stiff peaks (as you would a latte), and add to the top of the drink.

Place a pulled sugar swizzle over the edges of the glass, making sure not to submerge.

*Banana cognac syrup: Chop 2 lbs bananas and add to 2 750 mL bottles of cognac, leaving room at the top so you can see when the bananas float. After 2 to 3 days, when all the bananas are floating, strain and replace with another 2 lbs chopped bananas. Repeat the process and strain well. Stir in 1 1/2 cups of brown sugar and 1 oz high-proof grain alcohol.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: If you’re getting tired of the same old Bloody Mary recipe, it’s time to meet her distant cousin from the East, the Vladimiry.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the sprigs and pickles, to a blender, and blend until smooth.

Pour into a highball glass, fill with ice, and stir lightly.

Garnish with a pickle spear and 2 sprigs of dill.

Drink Name: Rock Your Face Off Hot Toddy
Author: Nate Dumas
About: This Toddy is the perfect vehicle for Mister Katz’s Rock & Rye from New York Distilling Company. Combine the flavorful rye with honey syrup, lemon juice and bitters for a dram that will keep you warm all winter.
Ingred: 1 dash Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a Toddy or 6-ounce juice glass.

Add 3 ounces of hot water and stir.

Garnish with half a lemon wheel.

About: This Dallas-inspired cocktail has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 2 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the mineral water to a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or coupe, and top with the mineral water.

Let settle for a few seconds, and garnish with grated dark chocolate.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: You have to mix one up to find out why it’s so grand.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker.

Fill with ice, shake hard and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a thin lime wheel.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Looking for a way to use up that bottle of peppermint schnapps? Try this holiday gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the 7 Up to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Top with 7 Up.

Author: Jeff "Beachbum" Berry
About: Throw a classic Mojito in the blender to get this frozen tropical concoction.
Instructions:
Add .25 ounce of the Mint Syrup to each of two chilled cocktail glasses and set aside.

Add the rum, lime juice and ice to a blender and blend until a uniform frappé consistency.

Divide the mixture evenly between the two glasses and top each with an additional .25 ounce of the Mint Syrup.

Garnish each glass with a mint sprig.

Author: Robert Krueger
About: Bring together East & West in the form of Scotch whisky and Japanese green tea.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Laphroaig Single Malt Scotch Whisky 1⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Collins glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Liquor.com
About: Born in the 1970s during the days of disco, the Kamikaze is an easy-to-make shooter that’s perfect for knocking back quickly and getting the party started. While there are many variations of this pre-game favorite, this rendition has a citrus-dominating flavor that will have you back on the dance floor in no time. No chaser needed.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass or divide between two shot glasses..

Author: Sailor Jerry Rum
About: This spicy rum-and-beer concoctions is for sinners only.
Instructions:
Squeeze the lime into a pint glass.

Fill with ice and add the rum, Tabasco and ginger beer.

Top with beer.

Author: Naren Young
About: Need a last-minute fall cocktail? This four-ingredient stunner will satisfy any pear-loving party guests.
Ingred: Tiny pinch of cinnamon and nutmeg
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except sparkling wine to mixing glass with two ice cubes.

Add five ounces of sparkling wine.

Stir well for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled glass.

Garnish with slice of pear.

Author: Willy Shine
About: It just blew in from Montego Bay.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the ginger.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Mount Gay
About: Drinking this rum-based cocktail is a dark, rich experience.
Ingred: 2 oz Mount Gay Black Barrel Rum
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and shake (without ice) for 10 to 15 seconds.

Add ice and shake again for 30 to 45 seconds.

Strain into a rocks glass over a large piece of ice and garnish with a lemon peel and a maraschino cherry.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Climb aboard a tequila and espresso delight.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Martini glass.

Float an espresso-roast coffee bean on top of the drink.

Author: David Wondrich
About: If you’re cold (or you have a cold), make this hot Scotch drink.
Instructions:
Rinse a mug or heatproof cup with boiling water to warm it.

Add the sugar and a swatch of thin-cut lemon peel.

Add 1 oz boiling water and stir to dissolve the sugar.

Add the Scotch (see Other information for recommended brands).

Finish by adding 1 oz more of boiling water to bring the heat back up.

Author: Juan Coronado
About:
The season’s best sippers bring a little brightness to the warm and fuzzy. The Winter Charm cocktail does exactly that—a balancing act of spiced and tropical flavors held together by a backbone of BACARDÍ Black rum. And if barley syrup sounds too strenuous an undertaking, don’t worry—it’s easier to make (and more delicious) than you think. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 BACARDÍ Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pot, and bring to a boil.

Remove from heat and serve in a coffee mug.

Garnish with a dehydrated pineapple slice and star anise.

*Barley syrup: Pour 1/2 cup barley into 2 cups water, and let sit overnight, then drain. In a saucepan, combine the barley with 2 cups sugar and 2 cups water, and bring to a boil. Remove from heat, and let cool before using.

Author: Karin Stanley
About: Canadian whisky, mezcal and sherry combine to form a smooth, smoky trio in the glass.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Del Maguey Vida mezcal 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a rocks glass over ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Charles Vexenat
About: Take first place with this Beefeater 24 Gin drink.
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, bruise the apple and cucumber.

Add the gin, curaçao and sherry, and fill with ice.

Stir, and pour (unstrained) into a pilsner, wine or Collins glass.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Jackson Cannon
About: How sweet it is.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz

Author: Kimber Weissert
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
4 dashes Woodford Reserve Bourbon Barrel Aged Sassafras & Sorghum bitters
Instructions:
Add the bourbon, sorel, syrup and bitters to a Yarai mixing glass.

Add ice and stir well.

Put an ice sphere in stemmed Old Fashioned glass.

Double-strain to glass, and garnish with bruleed figs.

Author: Harrison Ginsberg
About: This crowd-pleasing cocktail comes from Harrison Ginsberg at The Dead Rabbit
Ingred: .5 oz Clear Creek eight-year-old apple brandy.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Barbadillo Pedro Ximénez sherry 1⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz White miso cane syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with grated nutmeg.

*Ginger syrup: Add 16 oz ginger juice and 16 oz white sugar to a stainless steel pot, and heat at 160 degrees F for 45 minutes. Remove from heat, and allow to cool at room temperature. Strain through a cheesecloth. Bottle, label and store in a refrigerator.

**White miso cane syrup: Place 16 oz water and 2 tbsp miso paste in a stainless steel pot, and heat at 180 degrees, stirring frequently until the paste is completely dissolved. Add 4 cups cane sugar, and increase the temp to 210 degrees, bringing to a boil and stirring occasionally. Remove from heat, and allow to cool at room temperature for 30 minutes. Bottle, label and store in a refrigerator.

About: Add the warm, bold spice star anise to your next Sazerac.
Instructions:
Add the Angostura bitters to a beaker, then add the Peychaud's bitters, simple syrup, cognac and rye.

Add ice to the beaker and stir for 10 seconds.

Spray a snifter once with the absinthe.

Strain the drink into the snifter.

Garnish with 3 star anise pods.

Author: Wild Turkey Bourbon
About: Try this summertime favorite with a bourbon punch.
Instructions:
In a large saucepan, boil 2 cups of water and the sugar.

Remove from the heat and add the tea bags.

Steep for 8 minutes and then discard the bags.

Add the remaining 2 cups of water.

Transfer to a pitcher and chill.

Add the mint and crush with a wooden spoon until fragrant.

Stir in the remaining ingredients.

Serve in tall glasses filled with ice.

Garnish each glass with a mint sprig.

About: This Asian twist on the classic Gimlet recipe is the signature cocktail of the Hakkasan restaurant chain. Shake up a Shiso Gimlet tonight.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao Ancienne Methode 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a shiso leaf.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: Hitch a ride on this rye whiskey, lemon juice and white tea liqueur cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Qi White Tea Liqueur 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Grade b organic maple syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake hard and strain the drink into a 12 oz bucket glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: Top a classic Whiskey Sour with red wine to get this delicious pre-Prohibition tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the wine to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Carefully pour the wine over the back of a spoon so it floats on top of the drink.

About: This cocktail is built around the comfortable confines of aged rum and Campari but then is taken into a new direction and layered with fino sherry, honey water and salt.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Pour into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with pineapple sage.

*Honey water: Pour honey into equal-parts water, and shake well until no longer separated.

Author: Larry Rice
About:
This play on the classic Gin Martini by Chicago’s Dos Urban Cantina bar manager Larry Rice evokes thoughts of carving up that stuffing-filled bird (or enjoying an open-faced sandwich or mushy piece of gravy bread for days afterward). Gin infused with thyme and saffron, as well as a salty syrup made with turkey broth, lend the drink a super savory component.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Right Drink. For Every Bit of the Thanksgiving Meal.”
Ingred: 2 oz Thyme- and saffron-infused Plymouth gin
Scrappy’s celery bitters, to rinse glass
Instructions:
Add a few drops of the celery bitters to a coupe glass, swirl to coat, and pour out the remainder.

Add the gin, apéritif, turkey broth syrup and orange saffron bitters to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into the prepared coupe glass.

Garnish with a speared thyme sprig, saffron sprig and crouton.

*Thyme- and saffron-infused Plymouth gin: Add a 1 L bottle Plymouth gin, 9 thyme sprigs and 20 sage leaves to a glass container. Let sit for 24 hours, then strain out solids.

**Turkey broth syrup: Bring 16 oz turkey broth (no sugar), 30 turns of pepper from a grinder, 1pinch salt, 1/2 pinch garlic powder, 2 sprigs saffron and 3 sprigs thyme to a simmer in a saucepan for 10 minutes. Remove the mixture from heat, strain out solids, and add 2 cups of sugar and 10 turns of the pepper grinder. Whisk until sugar is dissolved. Store syrup in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

Author: Ron Abuelo
About: The ultimate indulgence: a sweet caramel-and-spice cocktail with a pat of rich butter.
Ingred: 1 oz Van Gogh Dutch Caramel Vodka
1 cup Hot water, add more if desired
Instructions:
In a mug, stir together the butter, brown sugar, honey and spices until they've formed a batter.

Add the remaining ingredients and stir vigorously until the batter is fully dissolved.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Patrón Tequila
About: Like Cosmopolitans? Try this flavorful and easy tequila version of the drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Brett Hughes
About: Get refreshed with this icy-cold rhubarb, sherry and gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Lesley Jacobs Solmonson
About: Until recently, fassionola syrup, which was used in many old Tiki drinks including the Hurricane, was lost to the past. The Jonathan English Company bottled it in the 1950s, and modern bartenders have either created house-made versions or substituted passion fruit syrup. Recently, Cocktail & Sons’ Max Messier bottled a seasonal version of it with local New Orleans strawberries, as well as pineapples, mango, passion fruit and steeped hibiscus flower syrup. The little-known Cobra’s Fang was created at Don the Beachcomber and also uses falernum, which has seen its own resurgence in recent years.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly squeezed orange juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Blend all of the ingredients with 6 oz of crushed ice for 5 seconds, and pour into a highball glass or tall Tiki mug.

Garnish with a mint leaf and lime wheel.

Author: Naren Young
About: This seasonal riff on the classic Flip features pumpkin flavor in two forms.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake until combined.

Add ice and shake very hard until chilled and frothy.

Strain into a rocks glass.

Author: Trudy Thomas
About: A refreshing twist on the classic.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries, basil, lime juice and simple syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a Margarita glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel and additional basil leaf.

Author: Dre Masso & Henry Bessant
About: Beat the rush for this drink.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Crème de mure (French blackberry liqueur) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the crème de mure to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice.

Drizzle the crème de mure over the top of the drink and garnish with a lemon spiral twist and 3 blackberries.

Author: Joel Schmeck
About:
“Capturing the essence of lemon bars, our milk punch utilizes gorgeous winter citrus with fresh Meyer lemon juice, as well as a Meyer lemon baking spice oleo saccharum, graham-cracker-steeped organic whole milk, aged rum, amaro and liqueur,” says Anna Caporael, the general manager of Portland, Ore.’s Irving Street Kitchen, of this cocktail by lead bartender Joel Schmeck. “Plan to make this recipe during a rainy week and reward yourself at the weekend!”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Eggnog Is Great. But This Holiday Season, Go for a Beautifully Clear Milk Punch.”
Ingred: 29 oz Flor de Caña four-year-old rum
.5 gal Organic, nonhomogenized whole milk.5 gal
Instructions:
Makes 30.

To make the oleo saccharum, crack the cinnamon sticks with a mortar and pestle, and add them to a nonreactive container along with the powdered sugar, vanilla beans and Meyer lemon peels (reserving the lemons). Muddle the peels, then let the mixture set for a day. In a separate nonreactive container, add the whole milk and crushed graham crackers, steep in the refrigerator for 1 day, and strain out the solids.

Juice the Meyer and regular lemons, and add them to the oleo saccharum along with the first four ingredients, and stir to combine.

To clarify the punch, slowly pour the lemon-liquor mixture into the strained whole milk.

Once it has started to curdle, place it in the refrigerator for 1 or 2 days, then strain it through a cheesecloth-lined chinois and then a coffee filter if necessary. Keep the punch chilled.

To serve, pour 3 oz in a mug over ice.

Garnish with ground nutmeg.

Author: Shane Paule
About: This cocktail from Shane Paule, the bar manager at Austin’s Isla, sports the usual good stuff found in a Mai Tai but with an additional scrumptious nutty layer of macadamia nut liqueur.
Ingred: .5 oz Trader Vic’s macadamia nut liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Pour into a hurricane glass over crushed ice, and sprinkle with fresh ground nutmeg.

Author: Bols Genever
About: Genever, lime and a chile pepperapparently they like it spicy in Holland.
Ingred: quarter Red chile pepper, seeded and sliced
.5 oz Rich sugar syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water).5 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the chile.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a red chile pepper.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Add a little rum to the Sidecar and you get this provocatively named classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Flame an orange peel over the glass and discard before serving.

Author: Selvarey Rum
About: A delicious chocolate-flavored rum is the base for this spin on the classic.
Instructions:
In an Old Fashioned glass, muddle the sugar, bitters and a splash of club soda.

Fill with ice and add the rum.

Stir, and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Find out what happens when you add mango to an all-time classic.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Shannon Tebay Sidle
About:
Shannon Tebay Sidle, a bartender at New York’s Death & Co, created this cocktail inspired by colonial-era ingredients.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Surprising Thing That Fueled the American Revolution. And the Rise of Our First President.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Yellowtail
About: Sparks will fly with this sparkling rose and cranberry juice cocktail.
Instructions:
Soak a sugar cube in orange bitters.

Place it in a flute.

Add elderflower liqueur and cranberry juice and gently top off the drink with Yellow Tail Rose.

Garnish with a rock candy stir stick.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Master the all-time gin classic. The Tom Collins is essentially a sparkling lemonade spiked with a healthy dose of the juniper spirit. While there is a debate which side of the pond this drink was born, this cocktail lives up to his classic status with every sip.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part water, one part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the lemon juice, simple syrup and gin to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball or Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel and a cherry.

Author: Kristen Struckmeyer
About: While the rest of the drinking world sips from the green-beer spigot this St. Patrick’s Day, class it up with this gold-studded Irish whiskey cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Islay scotch (or some other peaty scotch) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into a cocktail shaker and dry-shake (no ice).

Add ice and shake again until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with edible gold flakes.

*Ginger honey syrup: Combine 1/4 cup chopped ginger, 1 cup honey and 1/2 cup water to a saucepan, and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat and simmer for 2 minutes, then let stand until room temperature. Strain into a container, and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Julien Escot
About: Like the Vieux Carré? Try this rum and pear-cognac liqueur version of the classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a long lemon twist.

Author: Alex Day
About: This cocktail by Alex Day and Devon Tarby at The Normandie Club
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Spiced almond demerara syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a dried apple slice.

*Coconut bourbon: Toast 3 1/2 tbsp coconut flakes on medium heat for 5 minutes or until slightly golden. Combine flakes with a 750mL bottle of Old Forester

Author: Vance Henderson
About: Who says coffee cocktails can’t be a little topical? This creation from Vance Henderson of Drambuie
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients, except for the club soda, in a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain over fresh ice in a Collins glass, and top with the club soda.

Garnish with 3 fresh basil leaves.

Author: Long Thai
About: This Irish whiskey  take on Tiki  combines flavors of pistachio, apricot, matcha and more.
Ingred: 1 tsp Coco Lopez mactha green tea powder mix
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a Tiki mug or Collins glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and fresh mint sprigs.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: This rum cocktail combines spicy Thai chiles and cooling coconut milk.
Garnish: 1 Pineapple leaf and Thai chile pepper
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the Thai chile pepper and Grand Marnier.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tiki mug filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf and another Thai chile pepper.

Author: Ben Rojo
About:
Presented by Chivas 
Ben Rojo is this year’s Chivas Masters Champion.
Instructions:
Combine Chivas Regal 12 Year Old, coconut water, cold brew coffee, and palm sugar syrup in a mixing glass.

Separately, use a hand blender or dry shake to lightly whip and combine heavy cream and vanilla salt, then set aside.

Add ice to mixing glass, stir gently to chill and lightly dilute, then pour contents into a chilled pousse-café glass.

Using the back of a bar spoon, float the vanilla salted cream over the top of the drink, then garnish with additional vanilla salt.

Author: Jorge Vargas Baquedano
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Dow's Fine Tawny port 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Tempus Fugit Crème de Cacao A La Vanille 1⁄4 oz
10 drops Bittercube cherry bark vanilla bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Serve with a plate of figs and smoked cinnamon sticks.

*Fig syrup: Add 2 qts water and 2 qts granulated sugar to a pot, stir and bring to a boil. Turn down to simmer. Cut tips off 5 lbs dried mission figs and add to pot. Add 5 dried bay leaves, 4 cinnamon sticks and 2 lemon peels from 2 lemons to pot. With a cheese cloth, build a satchet with 1/4 cup black peppercorns, 1/2 cup black peppercorns, 1/2 cup coriander seeds (toasted if desired) and 6 star anise pods, tie, and add to pot. Let simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour. You can adjust thickness of syrup by adding or reducing water. Syrup is ready when figs are plump, syrup is to desired thickness and lemon peels are translucent.

Author: Becky Hardin
About: Made with white wine and hard apple cider, it’s the perfect football party cocktail.
Ingred: 32 oz Unfiltered apple cider or apple juice
Instructions:
Mix all of the ingredients together in a punch bowl or iced tea jug.

Serve over ice with sliced fruit as garnish.

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About: Fire up a traditional tequila shot with a little hot sauce.
Instructions:
Pour the tequila into a tall shot glass.

Add a few drops of Tabasco Sauce and stir gently.

Lick some salt off your hand, drink the tequila and then bite the lime wedge.

Author: Christopher Elford and Anu Apte
About: The ultimate bubbly fall punch, best served in a pumpkin punch bowl.
Ingred: 12 oz Ancho Reyes Ancho Chili Liqueur
1 Large pumpkin, top sliced off and insides removed
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a large punch bowl or hollowed-out pumpkin.

Add large ice cubes and top with the sparkling cider.

Garnish by floating thinly-sliced lime and lemon wheels on top.

Grate nutmeg and cinnamon over final product and serve.

Author: Kate Perry
About:
In this cocktail by Kate Perry, the general manager at Seattle’s iconic rum bar Rumba, spiced rum plays with bold flavors.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Next Generation of Spiced Rum Will Make You a Believer.”
Instructions:
Rinse a rocks glass with a dash of absinthe and set aside.

Add the rum, lime juice, passion fruit juice and falernum into a shaker with ice, and shake well.

Strain into the prepared glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with 2 dashes of the bitters, a smoked star anise (or a mint crown) and a metal straw.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About: This cocktail from Washington, D.C.’s Espita Mezcaleria
Instructions:
Rim a coupe glass with sal de gusano and set aside.

Add all the other ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into the prepared coupe glass.

Author: Kahlua
About: A potent mix of strong coffee and sweet liqueur.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Overdose on antioxidants.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, blueberries and simple syrup.

Add the vodka and lime juice, and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball or rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mint sprig or skewer of additional blueberries.

About: This cocktail is the ultimate three-ingredient classic.
Instructions:
Fill a cocktail shaker half full with ice, add all of the ingredients, and stir until well chilled and diluted.

Garnish with a cherry.

Serve in a coupe.

Author: Jessi Lorraine
About: This San Francisco–inspired cocktail has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 1 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch
1.5 oz Pür Likör spice blood orange liqueur
3 dashes Fee Brothers Aztec chocolate bitters
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a shaker with ice, and shake until appropriately diluted and chilled.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with 1 or 2 dehydrated lime wheels floating on top.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Enjoy the “milk of Marseille” the traditional French way.
Instructions:
Add the Ricard Pastis (and grenadine, if desired) to a highball glass and pour in thewater.

Fill with ice and stir.

Author: Eben Freeman
About: Break the rules by mixing pomegranate and bourbon together.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange wheel and a cherry.

Author: Celine Bossart
About: Looking for something to warm you up when it’s cold out? Try this cocktail from Smith & Whistle at the Sheraton Grand London Park Lane.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Bring all of the ingredients to a boil while stirring occasionally.

Strain into an Irish Coffee mug, and garnish with 2 dried apple slices and a cinnamon stick.

*Cinnamon-infused honey: Add 3 to 5 cinnamon sticks to a small jar (4 oz or so), and fill with honey of choice. Let sit 4 to 6 days, tasting on occasion, and remove the cinnamon sticks once the cinnamon flavor is satisfactory (i.e. present without being overwhelmingly strong).

Author: Jim Meehan
About: A tasty mix of rum, cider, sherry, pear brandy and an exotic allspice liqueur.
Ingred: .5 oz Gonzalez Byass Solera 1847 Oloroso Dulce Sherry.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Clear Creek Pear Brandy 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with an apple fan.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: Shrunken head not included.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir well and strain into a chilled wine glass.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Jonathan Howard
About: Jonathan Howard, the brains behind the cocktail program at Manhattan’s American Whiskey, uses Veev and Aperol in this homegrown concoction.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: This fizzy, fruity refresher has just four ingredients.
Instructions:
In a rocks or Collins glass, muddle the raspberries and simple syrup.

Add the vodka and fill with ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with additional raspberries.

Author: Kathy Casey
About: Don’t worry about the name; there’s no reason to doubt this classic cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a Martini glass.

Spear 3 Drunken Plumped Cherries on a cocktail pick and drop into the drink.

Author: Salvatore Calabrese
About: The classic tequila shot gets a master mixologist’s upgrade.
Instructions:
Pour the tequila into a shot glass.

Stir together the bitters and pepper on a saucer until they form a paste and coat one side of the lime wedge with the mixture.

Take a bite of the lime and then sip the spirit.

Author: Audrey Saunders
About: This gingery cocktail found in “New York Cocktails” (Cider Mill Press, $19.95) by Amanda Schuster was created by Audrey Saunders for NYC’s Pegu Club as a gateway gin drink for vodka lovers. Not only did it succeed, it inspired many variations around the world.
Instructions:
In a mixing tin, muddle the simple syrup, lime juice and 1 mint sprig.

Add the gin, ginger beer and ice, and shake well.

Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with 1 mint sprig, and serve with a straw.

About: Pure decadence in cocktail form.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with three raspberries on a pick.

Author: Dave Buggy
About: This Irish Coffee by Dave Buggy of The Copper Still in New York City hits all of the right fruity notes. It’s an Irish cure-all for bad coffee and cocktails.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except for the cream to an Irish Coffee mug and stir.

Add the cream to top, and dust with cocoa powder.

About: Welcome the summer with open arms by making a citrusy, spicy spirit-forward spin on the classic Vieux Carré.
Ingred: 1 oz Carpano Antica Formula sweet vermouth
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel soaked in Angostura and Peychaud’s bitters.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Created in New York in the early 1900s, the iconic Old Fashioned is deemed “the original cocktail.” But even the most established classics can do with a refresh every now and then. Try it with Bacardí 8 Años rum instead of whiskey and call yourself a visionary.
Instructions:
Add the sugar, water and bitters with a barspoon into an Old Fashioned glass.

Add half of the rum and 2�"3 large ice cubes, stirring repeatedly.

Pour in the second half of the rum and 2�"3 more ice cubes, continuing to stir.

Express the oil of an orange peel over the drink, and drop in the peel.

Author: Bulleit
About: Spicy rye whiskey gets a little sweet in this Manhattan-esque drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jasmine Fajardo, Louie’s
About: La Bruja Dulce is a witch’s brew of high-quality rye and stand-out liqueurs. The spirit-forward cocktail perfectly balances sweet and spicy flavors.
Ingred: .5 oz Luxardo Amaretto di Saschira liqueur.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Leopold Bros. maraschino liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, and stir.

Pour into a bucket glass, and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Partida Tequila
About: Reintroduce yourself to this simple-to-make classic.
Ingred: 1 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Margarita or cocktail glass, or an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Exotic tamarind syrup is the secret to the drink.
Ingred: .5 oz Navan Natural Vanilla Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with three brandied cherries on a toothpick.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: Turn leftover jam into a delicious drink with the Clover Club cocktail.
Instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Chris Chamberlain
About: Autumn’s favorite flavor takes center stage in this festive glass of apple cider, gin, honey syrup and cinnamon.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and shake vigorously.

Double-strain into a 5.5-ounce coupe and garnish with an expressed lemon twist.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: This iced tea-and-bourbon cocktail is the key to great night.
Instructions:
Add bourbon, PAMA and lemon juice to a Collins glass and fill with ice.

Top with the tea (and simple syrup, if necessary) and garnish with a lemon slice.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: Julie Reiner sees the value in drinking tequila straight. If you want to have your cake and eat it too, pair your bottle with her recipe for Sangrita, a tomato-based citrus concoction that can be enjoyed on the side.
Ingred: 1 Jalapeño, sliced in half and seeded (leave the seeds in for a spicier Sangrita)
Instructions:
In a pitcher, combine the jalapeño, juices, Tabasco, Cholula, salt, paprika and pepper.

Stir, cover, and let the mixture sit in the refrigerator for 30 minutes. Remove the jalapeño.

To serve, pour five ounces of the Sangrita into a Collins glass filled with ice and serve alongside a two-ounce shot of blanco tequila.

Author: Simon Ford
About:
The Vesper, also known as the Vesper Martini, was made famous by James Bond. The cocktail best known for being ordered “shaken not stirred” was invented by none other than Bond author Ian Fleming. The Vesper first appeared in his book “Casino Royale,” which was published in 1953 and gets its name from fictional double agent Vesper Lynd.
When Bond orders the Vesper, it comes with strict instructions that must be followed by any who make it: “Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel. Got it?”
While some might claim that shaking will “bruise the gin” or have an adverse effect on the drink, when making a Vesper, it’s best to follow the original instructions.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Twist a slice of lemon peel over the drink, rub along the rim of the glass and drop it in.

Drink Name: Mezcal, Concord Grape, Citrus, Market Mint
Author: Cary Goldberg
About: Mezcal and Concord grapes? The surprising duo create a smoky, fall-forward cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe.

About: Different single malts mingle in this spirit-forward cocktail. It’s a wonder that the peaty flavor still shines through all the other tasty elements.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Don Ciccio walnut liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Pour into a coupe glass.

Express an orange peel over top.

Garnish with the orange peel.

Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Islay single malt Scotch 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine blended scotch, lemon juice, and syrup in a cocktail shaker and add ice.

Shake and strain into a rocks glass with fresh ice.

Top with single malt Scotch.

Garnish with candied ginger.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Combine summer and autumn flavors in this simple drink you can make any time of year.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist and a cherry.

Author: Kara Newman
About: At new Chicago restaurant Fat Baby Tacos
Instructions:
Rim half of a rocks glass with chile piquin.

Add the mezcal, juices and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice.

Top up with the club soda.

Garnish with a grapefruit quarter wheel, cilantro sprig and jalapeño round.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: The most important meal of the day just got a whole lot more fun.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel and serve with buttered toast on the side.

Author: Virginia Miller
About: At one of downtown Vancouver’s celebrated farm-to-table restaurants, Royal Dinette
Ingred: .5 oz Odd Society crème de cassis.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Black sesame orgeat syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into a mixing tin, and dry shake to emulsify egg white.

Add ice and shake again for 10 to 15 seconds.

Fine-strain into small rocks glass but with no ice.

Garnish with dehydrated beetroot sugar.

*Black sesame orgeat syrup: Lightly toast 2 cups of black sesame seeds in a pan. Let cool, then blend in a blender or food processor. In a separate saucepan, bring 1 1/2 cups sugar and 1 1/4 cups water to a light simmer. Once the sugar has dissolved, add the blended sesame seeds to the saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium heat, then remove from heat and cool for 3 hours. Once the mixture has cooled, strain through a fine-mesh strainer or cheesecloth until silky. Add 1 tsp orange blossom water and 1 oz vodka. Bottle and refrigerate. Can be stored for up to 3 months.

**Dehydrated beet sugar: Juice 4 large beets, take the pulp (or byproduct), and ring out excess juice using a kitchen towel or cheese cloth. Spread the pulp onto a tray, and place the tray in a dehydrator or oven at 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Once the pulp is completely dry, add it to a spice grinder or blender with 1/2 cup white sugar, then blitz into a fine powder. Makes 1 cup.

Author: Carmen Polcyn
About: Though one thinks of limeade and lemonade as summer drinks, bartender Carmen Polcyn at Chicago’s Bar Toma gives this tipple that’s good with or without booze a wintery hint of rosemary and warming, smoky punch. You can spike the drink with tequila or mezcal, the latter adding even more smoky fun to the drink.
Instructions:
Add the tequila or mezcal (optional), citrus juice and simple syrup to a rocks glass with ice and stir.

Top with the club soda or, for more sweetness, the tonic water, and garnish with a sprig of rosemary.

*Citrus juice: Cut 1 lemon and 1 lime in half, and dip the open sides in turbinado sugar to coat. Grill each half over high heat, with the cut edge toward the flame, until the sugar has charred on the citrus. Once cooled, juice the fruit.

Author: Eric and Shannon McQuilkin
About:
This signature cocktail at The Box Social in Portland, Ore., is vividly rosy with a purée blend of passion fruit, blood orange and pomegranate.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: December 2017.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz The Perfect Purée of Napa Valley El Corazon fruit purée
Instructions:
Rim a highball glass with salt and pepper and set aside.

Add all the ingredients except the mezcal to a shaker with ice, and shake thoroughly.

Strain into a Highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with an inverted 1/2 lime with the juice squeezed out (a lime boat).

Fill the lime boat with the mezcal.

Author: Baileys
About: Creamy and comforting, but exotically spiced.
Instructions:
Brew a pot of chai tea.

Add 2 tsp of the brown sugar for every cup and stir until dissolved.

Add the Baileys and 3 oz of the tea to a mug and stir with the cinnamon stick.

(This drink can also be served cold: Simply chill the tea before mixing and serve in a tall glass filled with ice.).

Author: Max Soh
About: This take on the New Orleans classic uses popular Korean spirit soju.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: Who says Jell-O Shots have to end at college? These tried and true party drinks are fun, easy to make and instant crowd pleasers. Pro tip: Jell-O Shots are a blank canvas for creativity so mix it up with different colors, flavors and shapes. Your friends will love them.
Ingred: 3 oz Jell-O or other flavored gelatin (any flavor will work, but do not use unflavored)
Instructions:
In a medium bowl, stir together the Jell-O and boiling water until the Jell-O dissolves.

Add the vodka or rum and cold water, and stir to combine.

Pour 1 ounce of the mixture into each of 16 shot glasses (small plastic or paper cups will also work) and chill until solid.

Author: Talmadge Lowe
About: You’ll fall in love with this Champagne cocktail that tastes of strawberry and chocolate.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz White crème de cacao 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the strawberry shrub and crème de cacao to a chilled Champagne flute.

Slowly pour in the Champagne and garnish with a woodland strawberry or a tiny regular strawberry.

About: Port and sparkling wine make a perfect holiday duo that’s easy as can be.
Instructions: Add port to a Champagne flute and top with sparkling wine.

Author: Marco Dionysos
About: Scotch is a most unusual base for this fruity cocktail recipe.
Ingred: 1.5 oz The Famous Grouse Scotch Whisky
Garnish: 1 Brandied cherries and a flamed blood orange twist
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with brandied cherries and a flamed blood orange twist.

About: Let the flavor of cognac shine in this sweet, spicy interpretation of a Sidecar.
Garnish: Half-rim superfine sugar, Meyer lemon oils
Instructions:
Coat half the rim of a coupe glass in superfine sugar.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe.

Express the oils of a Meyer lemon peel over top.

*Peppercorn syrup: Toast 2 tbsp white peppercorns in a pan until they start popping. Let them cool, then grind coarsely in a spice grinder. Add to a medium pot with 2 cups water and 2 cups white sugar. Bring to a boil and reduce for 15 to 20 minutes. Let cool before using.

Author: Bénédictine
About: The Vieux Carré is pure Old New Orleans and was invented at the city’s famed Carousel Bar. This cognac and rye whiskey cocktail packs a powerful punch and is delightfully complex.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Angel's Envy Rye whiskey 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass.

Fill with ice and stir.

About: Put an Irish twist on the Bijou with a little Jameson Irish Whiskey and Green Chartreuse.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
Garnish: Expressed oils from an orange peel
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Express the oils of an orange peel over the glass and discard.

Author: Park
About: If you’re looking to add a little chill to your pre-dinner coffee but don’t quite want to go the cold-brew route, the Lynx at Cambridge, Mass.’s Park is the cocktail for you. Instead of serving the drink over ice, the chilling agent is actually a giant, frozen cube of coffee. (This idea could get very dangerous, very fast.)
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients, except for the cube of coffee, in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over the large frozen coffee cube.

Author: Liquor.com
About: The classic Jack Rose cocktail gets a splash of Irish whiskey.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Nico de Soto
About: Inspired by the earthy flavors of cardamom, this cocktail combines espresso, pistachio vodka and cardamom syrup.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a punch cup.

Garnish with three cardamom pods.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
Instructions:
Pulse pistachios in a food processor until finely ground. Combine the sugar and water in a pot over medium heat and stir until sugar dissolves completely. Boil the syrup for three minutes, then add in the ground pistachios. Turn the heat down to low and simmer for another three minutes, then slowly increase the temperature to medium high. Just before it starts to boil, remove it from the heat and cover with a lid.

Allow the covered nut mixture to infuse for at least 3 hours or up to 8 hours. Then, strain it through two layers of cheesecloth, discarding the ground hazelnuts for another use. Stir the orange flower water and vodka into the nutty syrup. Use a small funnel to portion the orgeat into bottles or a jar. Store in refrigerator for up to two weeks.

Author: Pama Pomegranate Liqueur
About: Bubbly meets pomegranate in this gorgeous crimson cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: All the flavors of a Margarita are distilled down into this tasty shot.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a shot glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: This cucumber-and-mint refresher is the next-best thing to a massage.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice or double-strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cucumber slice and a mint sprig.

Author: Chris Chamberlain
About: Gin and cognac give this Egg Nog double the heft while a spiced syrup lends rich winter flavor.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into an ice-filled shaker and shake vigorously (20-30 sec).

Double-strain into a 10-ounce rocks glass filled with fresh ice, and garnish with a star anise pod.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The cognac-and-rye classic Vieux Carré cocktail was invented at New Orleans’ famed Carousel Bar.
Ingred: 4 dashes Dale DeGroff's Pimento Aromatic Bitters
3⁄4 oz George Dickel Rye Whiskey 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: Chartreuse and Bénédictine add herbal notes to cognac in this spirit-forward creation.
Instructions:
Rinse a Collins glass with the absinthe, and fill it with crushed ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the Collins glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Ryan Puckett
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
.5 oz Punt E Mes vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
In a pre-iced mixing glass, pour in the bourbon and both vermouths.

Dash in your bitters and, with a stirring spoon, stir all of your ingredients until properly chilled and diluted (on average, 40 to 50 rotations).

Place a Julep strainer over the mixing vessel, and strain the cocktail into a pre-chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a speared Luxardo maraschino cherry.

Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Muddle fresh ginger in a shaker, and add the remaining ingredients except for the Craigellachie 13.

Fill the shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into an ice-filled rocks glass, and float the Craigellachie on top.

Garnish with a piece of candied ginger.

Author: Franky Marshall
About: With a slug of spicy bourbon, this blackberry cocktail isn’t as demure as she looks.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Massenez Crème de Mure 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a blackberry and lemon wheel.

Author: Liquor.com
About: This spicy gin and ginger cocktail bites back. This British version of a Moscow Mule marries the clear spirit with ginger for a spicy kick. Lime adds a citrusy touch for a taste that will keep you coming back for more.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
A little bit of muddling goes a long way in this fresh, minty take on a watermelon Margarita.
For more great summery Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos too!—head right this way.
Instructions:
Add the mint leaves and agave to a shaking tin and gently muddle.

Add the remaining ingredients plus ice, shake, and double-strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with fresh mint sprig and watermelon slice.

Author: Bobby Hicks
About: The Ascot is a sophisticated sipping cocktail, smooth in texture but worldly in manner.
Ingred: .5 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: What’s better than one super-fruit cocktail? A whole pitcher.
Ingred: 12.5 oz VeeV Açaí Spirit (half a bottle)
Instructions:
In a pitcher, muddle the mint.

Fill three-quarters of the way with ice and add the VeeV, simple syrup, lime juice and blueberry puree.

Stir well and top with club soda.

Garnish with blueberries.

Author: Michael Dietsch
About: Use a blended scotch that’s not too mild, such as Compass Box Great King Street or The Famous Grouse Smoky Black, in this cocktail from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails
Ingred: 2 oz Blended scotch (Compass Box Great King Street or The Famous Grouse Smoky Black)
Spicy ginger ale or ginger beer, as a topper
Instructions:
Add the scotch and lime juice to a highball glass full of ice, top with the ginger ale, and stir briefly.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

About:
The Blood & Sand is a classic scotch-based cocktail that has withstood the test of time. The recipe first appeared in 1930 in The Savoy Cocktail Book by Harry Craddock and has become a mainstay on bar menus ever since.
It gets its name from a 1922 bullfighter movie and points to its ingredients: The “blood” represents Heering cherry liqueur, and the “sand” is for the orange juice. 
The key to the cocktail is to use a smooth scotch that’s not too smoky and freshly squeezed orange juice. So forget about your Islay scotches (for now), and avoid that carton of OJ in the fridge.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz The Glenrothes Select Reserve single-malt Scotch whisky 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Orange juice, freshly squeezed 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: With muddled strawberries, honey and a couple complex liqueurs, this drink delivers on its name.
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water).5 oz
.5 oz Solerno Blood Orange Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake very well and double strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with half a strawberry.

Author: Christy Pope
About: Warm chicken soup may be your go-to on a sick day, but why not take it up a notch with some gin and juice? This chicken-stock-based Hot Toddy by Christy Pope of Cuffs & Buttons and Dallas’ Midnight Rambler Bar  turns your sick day into a party in the best way possible.
Ingred: 3 oz Swanson organic free-range chicken broth
3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a small pot on the stove, combine all ingredients except the gin over medium heat.

Once the liquid starts to steam, add the gin and remove from the stove.

Pour the heated cocktail into a Toddy glass.

Garnish with star anise.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: The super-food-trifecta: açai, blueberry and pomegranate.
Instructions:
Shake all the ingredients with ice and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with blueberries and a mint sprig.

Author: Dominic Venegas
About: Unexpected flavor combinations abound in this whiskey, maple, blueberry and wine cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz George Dickel Old No. 8 Tennessee Whisky
1 oz Ravenswood Sonoma County Old Vine Zinfandel
Glass: Mason jar or Bordeaux wine glass
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the wine to a shaker.

Shake vigorously (without ice) for 10 seconds.

Fill with ice and shake for an additional 15 seconds.

Fine strain into a chilled 8-ounce Mason jar or a Bordeaux wine glass.

Float the wine on top using a spoon.

Author: BarSol
About: Get to know Peru’s national spirit in this tropical cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a white wine glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with pineapple chunks and a cherry.

Author: Liz Martinez
About: The bright, fresh taste and warming herbal properties of this cocktail by bartender Liz Martinez at The Purple Pig bring to mind Christmas trees, cold snowy mornings and evenings spent by a crackling fire.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Shake all of ingredients in a shaker with ice until chilled.

Strain into a Martini glass, and garnish with cinnamon shavings.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: This infusion makes a fast-as-lightning cocktail. Just let pineapple chunks and rum hang out together for a few days. Then shake, strain and sip.
Ingred: 1 Pineapple, peeled, cored, and cut into one-inch pieces
1 750 ml bottle Vodka or white rum
Instructions:
Place the pineapple pieces and the vodka or rum in a large nonreactive metal or glass container with a lid. Cover and let sit for one week in the refrigerator, stirring it once a day.

Strain the liquid through a fine-mesh sieve set over a bowl, allowing the fruit to sit in the strainer for 30 minutes so as to get all the liquid. Discard the fruit and funnel the infusion back into the  original bottle and label. The infusion will keep for two weeks in the refrigerator.

To serve, pour 3 ½ ounces of the pineapple infusion into a shaker and shake with ice until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a pineapple wedge.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Please, have a fire extinguisher handy.
Instructions:
Fill a pint glass halfway with beer.

Add the amaretto to a shot glass and top with the rum.

Set the rum on fire and very carefully drop the shot glass into the beer.This is one drink best to order in a bar and not make at home.

Author: Cody Modeer
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.

Strain into a Martini glass, and garnish with a burnt orange.

Author: Scott Beattie
About: This sweet-and-citrusy cocktail calls for not one but three different types of spirits.
Ingred: .5 oz Del Maguey Vida Mezcal.5 oz
.5 oz Charbay Ruby Red Grapefruit Vodka.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice for 10 seconds.

Fill with ice and shake for another 10 seconds.

Strain into a bucket glass filled with fresh ice and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: TJ Lynch
About: The secret ingredient in this blushing glass? A hint of refreshing aloe vera juice.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake well.

Strain contents into a rocks glass over ice. Garnish with an orange or lemon twist.

Author: Bulleit
About: Spicy rye whiskey gives the Southern classic a bit more edge.
Instructions:
In a rocks glass, muddle the mint leaves and simple syrup.

Add the rye and fill with crushed ice.

Stir well and garnish with a sprig of mint.

Drink Name: Where No Man Has Gone Before
Author: Paul Gustings
About: This Star Trek–inspired brandy cocktail uses a bunch of ingredients that might make a cocktail aficionado turn up a nose. And honestly, this recipe from Paul Gustings of Broussard’s  in New Orleans might be a joke. (It wasn’t exactly delicious when we tested it.)
Ingred: .5 oz Dekuyper Pucker sour apple schnapps.5 oz
Instructions:
Prepare the instant vanilla pudding, and combine all of the ingredients with the pudding, minus the water, in a mug.

Add the hot water, stir until the instant pudding is dissolved, and serve warm.

About: A cocktail doesn’t need to be complicated to have a complex flavor profile. Just look at this simple, elegant scotch cocktail.

Author: Mary Chojnacki
