About: An Irish Coffee is all about the ingredients. And this one by Mary Chojnacki of the Chicago Athletic Association features amazing coffee, incredible whiskey and a pleasant dash of spice.
Instructions:
Warm a coffee mug with hot water, and discard the water.

Pour the coffee to fill 3/4 of the way up.

Add a spoonful of brown sugar, and add the whiskey.

Slowly top with the heavy whipping cream, and garnish with allspice powder.

Author: Lauren Schell
About: “The fire caramelizes the sugar, giving the drink depth and added richness,” says Lauren Schell of Seaworthy in New Orleans. “It’s a crucial element of balance, in addition to being eye-catching and purposefully interactive.” The Chartreuse-meets-sugar fire inside a hollowed-out lime might be simple to create but is a visual stunner while simultaneously helping to balance out the drink’s citrus notes.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except for the Chartreuse, bitters and sugar cube into a shaker, and dry-shake.

Pour into a chilled rock glass, top with crushed ice, and float 3 dashes of Angostura bitters.

Hollow out a lime half, and place it cut side up on top of the drink. Add the Chartreuse and sugar cube to the lime half. Light the lime half, aiming for the Chartreuse, let it burn for 10 to 15 seconds, and blow out the flame.

Author: Liquor.com
About: It doesn’t get any simpler than a Rum & Coke with lime.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Naren Young
About: For super intense flavor, poach your pears in a simple syrup flavored with warming winter spices like clove, cinnamon and star anise.
Ingred: .5 oz Syrup from poached pears.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a blender with a scoop of crushed ice.

Blend until smooth.

Author: Tekla Israelson
About: Complex aged rum makes this easy strawberry cocktail anything but simple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

About: Use this base to make the perfect Hot Buttered Rum in a snap.
Ingred: 1 qt Vanilla ice cream, softened slightly
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ice cream to a bowl and stir to combine.

Add the ice cream and stir again.

Transfer to a container with a lid, seal and store in the freezer.

Refer to the Hot Buttered Rum recipe to build the drink.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This underrated mezcal cocktail takes a classic Negroni and adds the smoke of mezcal.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and fill with ice.

Stir until cold and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: This cocktail is the next best thing to a bouquet of roses.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Simon Ford
About: After a few sips you’ll be begging to join.
Instructions: Add the rum and ginger ale to a highball glass filled with ice.

Author: Ariane Resnick
About: This cocktail from The Thinking Girl’s Guide to Drinking (Cocktails Without Regrets)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a Martini glass, and garnish with a celery frond.

Author: Shawn Chen
About:
Both locations of RedFarm are local NYC go-tos for hip dim sum and a red-and-white-checkered farmhouse vibe. During these cold winter days, Shawn Chen serves the warming Harvest Time. BenRiach scotch’s smoky campfire notes are given tart, bitter and spiced balance from warm apple cider, a touch of Campari liqueur, house-made ginger syrup and fresh yuzu citrus.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Cold Enough? Try These 11 Warm Cocktails in Bars Now.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz BenRiach Curiositas peated 10-year-old scotch 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Yuzu or lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Bring the apple cider to a simmer in a medium saucepan.

Add the scotch, liqueur, syrup and juice, and stir until warm.

Remove from heat, and pour into a heatproof mug or glass.

Garnish with a sprinkle of cinnamon powder and a lemon wheel studded with 3 cloves.

*Ginger syrup: Purée 2 cups peeled sliced ginger and 2 cups boiling water on high in a Vitamix. Add 4 cups light brown sugar and stir to combine. Let macerate for a day, strain out solids and store syrup in the refrigerator.

Author: Dan Farber
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice. Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

Author: Dave Taha
About: At the award-winning Greenhouse Tavern
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except for the ginger ale and nutmeg in shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into rocks glass over ice, and top with the ginger ale.

Gently stir, and garnish with ground ginger.

Author: John Currence
About: This tasty gin drink mashes up the classic Last Word and Gin Fizz. Try the Last-Word Fizz cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and shake without ice for 20 seconds.

Add a few crushed ice cubes and shake again for 15 seconds.

Strain into two cocktail glasses and top each with a splash of club soda.

Drizzle both drinks with the cherry juice.

Rub each rim with a lime twist and use as garnish.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: A transatlantic twist on the classic aperitif.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Lustau East India Solera Sherry 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with one large ice cube.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: Blanc Armagnac is a relative newcomer to the scene and has only been officially recognized by the Armagnac powers-that-be for a handful of years. Its youth in a world of grand dames, though, means it serves as a fine introduction to the spirit for those not quite ready to take the VSOP plunge. This fruity play on a traditional Brandy Crusta
Ingred: 1.5 oz Château du Tariquet Folle Blanche Armagnac
.5 oz Leopold Bros. American orange Liqueur.5 oz
.5 oz Leopold Bros. maraschino liqueur.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass with ice, and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This classic tequila cocktail was created by Julio Bermejo in the early ’90s at Tommy’s Mexican Restaurant in San Francisco where it’s still offered.
Instructions:
Prepare a rocks glass with a salt rim.

All all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain over ice into a rocks glass.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Rum, cognac and just a dash of vanilla flavor this rich favorite.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (two parts clover honey, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into two chilled punch cups.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

About: Kids and teetotalers alike love the non-alcoholic Shirley Temple cocktail. Believe to have been originated in 1930s Hollywood, the name comes from the iconic former child star. These days, it’s a staple cocktails for children. Not into the sober life? Just add vodka or rum to booze up this classic.
Instructions:
Fill a Hurricane or Collins glass with ice and add the grenadine.

Fill with ginger ale, 7UP or Sprite.

Stir, and garnish with a maraschino cherry and lemon wedge.

Author: Chris Chamberlain
About: Fresh pear puree lends fall flavor to this bubbly blend of gin, elderflower liqueur and Champagne.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except Champagne to an ice-filled shaker and shake vigorously.

Double-strain into a 5.5-ounce coupe.

Top with a splash of Champagne and garnish with a fresh slice of pear.

Author: Mount Gay
About: Try this Caribbean take on the classic rye whiskey drink.
Ingred: 2 oz Mount Gay Black Barrel Rum
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled rocks glass (no ice).

Garnish with a twist of lemon.

Author: Billy Nichols
About: Thoroughly testing the depth of Star Wars nerdiness, Billy Nichols, the bar manager at Faun
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (1 part honey, 1 part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker, and dry-shake to froth the egg white.

Add ice, then shake again.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with dried chamomile blossoms.

*Chamomile-infused tequila: Add 4 standard tisane bags of chamomile tea to a 750 mL bottle of blanco tequila, and allow to sit in a dry, cool place for 1 1/2 hours. Then discard the tea bags and strain for any particles.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: It’s tasty, and you should try it.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice or a chilled cocktail glass.

About: This slightly boozier take on the classic Sangaree balances citrus and sweetness with a hint of spice.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with fresh grated nutmeg.

Author: Brett Esler
About: “The Midnight Oil brings to life in cocktail form one of my all-time favorite snack combos: a morning coffee and a slice or two of banana bread,” says bartender Brett Esler of Whisler’s in Austin. “With an aged rum base, a touch of the Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur for a little depth and some vanilla extract to round it out, you have yourself a slightly caffeinated, fall-driven sipper.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Mount Gay Black Barrel rum
1⁄4 oz Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe, and garnish with a skewered bruleed banana slice.

Author: Zak Doy
About: This drink from Zak Doy of Toronto’s Rush Lane & Co. enlists the help of a maple plank for smoking the inside of a glass (and reinforces Canadian pride, of course).
Ingred: 2 oz Mount Gay Extra Old rum
Instructions:
Char the maple plank with the flame from a blowtorch, then cover the smoking surface with the glass so the smoke coats the inside of the glass with the maple aromatic.

Add all of ingredients to the smoked glass with one large ice cube, and stir to combine.

Author: Ted Kilgore
About: We won’t squeal on you if you make this apple, ginger and bourbon drink.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Ginger beer or ginger ale
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice and stir briefly.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

About: Add tequila to spicy Mexican hot chocolate and you’ll get this delicious shot recipe.
Instructions:
Coat the rims of 2 shot glasses with chile powder and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glasses.

Garnish each with a corn chip.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The Whiskey Sour is one classic cocktail that won’t make you sour.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (1 part water, 1 part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cherry and lemon wedge.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Start your night with this refreshing bubbly and citrus concoction.
Instructions:
Squeeze the fruit wedges into a highball glass filled with ice and then drop them in.

Add the VeeV and the lime juice and stir.

Top with the tonic water and garnish with a citrus wheel.

Author: Cindy Augustine
About: There’s a lot going on in this Sour at Bacari GDL, at The Americana at Brand in Glendale, Calif., but savory cocktails are often pretty complex, and this is no exception. Using duck-fat-infused dry orange curaçao (made sous vide style), it’s mixed with rye, fresh lemon juice, simple syrup and egg white.
Ingred: .5 oz Duck-fat-infused dry orange curaçao.5 oz
Instructions:
Rinse a coupe glass with absinthe.

Add the rye, curacao, juice, syrup and egg white to a shaker with ice and shake.

Pour into the prepared coupe.

Garnish with a few dashes of cranberry bitters and fresh grated cinnamon.

*Duck-fat-infused dry orange curacao: Add 500mg dry curacao and 50g duck fat into a plastic bag, seal and cook sous vide for 4 hours at 165 degrees F. Freeze, then strain.

Author: The Bon Vivants
About: You don’t need to be in the Arctic to enjoy this mezcal cocktail recipe.
Ingred: .5 oz Tempus Fugit Spirits Crème de Menthe.5 oz
6 drops Angelica Tincture or celery bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

About: Most popular in western Europe, especially Germany, this two-ingredient beer cocktail is easy to make and refreshing.
Ingred: .5 cup Ginger ale (or ginger beer).5 cup
Instructions: In a pint glass, combine the lager and ginger ale (or ginger beer).

Author: Chris Hannah
About: New Orleans mixologist Chris Hannah makes this cognac-and-merlot concoction for Mardi Gras celebrations.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a wine glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Nicholas Bennett, Porchlight
About: This cocktail was created by Nicholas Bennett at Porchlight for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a Julep cup or double Old Fashioned glass.

Fill halfway with crushed or pebble ice, then swizzle to chill.

Pack the glass with more ice, forming a mound at the top.

Garnish with the mint and finely grated lemon zest over the surface of the drink.

Author: Phil Ward
About: This recipe from all-star New York bartender Phil Ward appears in Death & Co, Modern Classic Cocktails, with More Than 500 Recipes.
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, gently muddle the raspberries.

Add the remaining ingredients to the mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and double strain into a double rocks glass over a few fresh ice cubes.

Garnish with a raspberry.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: Cool down with this icy blackberry and bourbon refresher.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blackberries, mint and simple syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a wine glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with an additional blackberry.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: Sweet, cooling, and perfect for warm weather.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon, cucumber, strawberries and sugar.

Fill with ice and add the cachaça.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with strawberry and cucumber slices.

About: This simple drink, sometimes spelled calimotxo or calimocho, is wildly popular in the Basque Country.
Instructions: In a large red wine glass over rocks, fill with the wine, Coke and juice of half a lemon. Garnish with a lemon slice.

Author: Pierre Ferrand Cognac
About: Try this cognac cocktail flavored with citrus, cucumber and ginger; it’s as sophisticated as it sounds.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Pierre Ferrand Ambre Cognac, divided
2 oz Lemon-flavored club soda (San Pellegrino Limonata)
Instructions:
Place the lime peel and ginger slices in a short tumbler.

Add half of the cognac.

Lightly press the lime and ginger 2 or 3 times using a muddler or the back of a spoon.

Fill the glass halfway with ice.

Stir for 5 seconds.

Add the remaining cognac, club soda and cucumber peel.

Stir for another 5 seconds.

Drink Name: Grey Goose L’Orange Winter Sangria Martini
Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: With hints of elderflower and pomegranate, this Martini recipe is delicious all year round.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a rose petal.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Seasonal fruits are the key to this drink’s winter flavor.
Instructions:
In a sturdy double Old Fashioned glass, muddle the cloves.

Add the pear, lemon, orange and simple syrup, and muddle again.

Fill with ice, add the tequila and stir to combine.

Author: Tad Carducci
About: Serve a big bowl of this festive mezcal concoction at your next party.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a punch bowl and fill with ice.

Garnish with grapefruit and lemon slices.

Author: Liquor.com
About: Basil brings out the best in the 100 percent natural botanicals in Beefeater gin. Get fresh ingredients and make this refreshing cocktail.
Ingred: 1 oz Agave syrup (1 part agave nectar, 1 part water)
Instructions:
Add the agave syrup and basil leaves into a shaker and muddle lightly.

Add the gin, lime juice and ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Double strain contents into a chilled coupe and garnish with a fresh basil leaf.

Author: Ran Duan
About: This autumnal apple-brandy cocktail gets added depth from three different rich syrups.
Ingred: .5 oz Fee Brothers Orgeat Cordial Syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker.

Shake briefly without ice to combine.

Fill with ice, hard shake and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with grated nutmeg.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The snap of ginger, the smoke of scotch
Ingred: 2 oz Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch whiskey
Instructions: Pour all of the ingredients in a Collins glass filled with ice.

Author: David Wondrich
About: In honor of the state’s 220th anniversary, Liquor.com advisory board member David Wondrich created this refreshing Bluegrass tipple.
Ingred: 2 oz Unaged corn or rye whiskey
Instructions:
Add the sugar and water to a highball glass and stir until the sugar has completely dissolved.

Add the mint leaves and press lightly with a muddler.

Pack the glass with finely cracked ice (wrap cubes in a towel and bash the bejeezus out of them with something hard and heavy) and then add the whiskey.

Stir, add more ice to make up for any shrinkage and garnish with two or three sprigs of mint and a straw.

Author: The Ritz Carlton New Orleans
About: An extra-spicy Bloody Mary gets a crawfish-tail garnish for New Orleans flair.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pint glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and garnish with four spiced pickled string beans, two olives and four crawfish tails.

Author: Armando Zapata
About: Milk does a body good, even when there’s tequila in it.
Ingred: 2 oz DeKuyper Crème de Cocoa White Cream
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain the mixture into a small glass.

Drink Name: The Apple Fell Far from the Tree
Author: Steven Tuttle
About:
This SoCal-style fall refresher by Steven Tuttle, the bar manager at San Diego’s Kettner Exchange, includes butterfly-pea-flower-infused blanco tequila, which means the drink turns a rich shade of blue to purple. It hints at autumn with the allspice-rum notes of Hamilton pimento dram, brightened by lime and Fuji apple syrup—all without losing the vibrancy of the tequila.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: November 2017.”
Ingred: .5 oz Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple rum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

*Butterfly-pea-flower-infused blanco tequila: Steep 1/2 cup dried butterfly pea flowers in 1 750 mL bottle of tequila for 20 minutes.

**Fuji apple syrup: Peel 12 Fuji apples with a citrus peeler, using 4 cuts to save the apple cores. In a saucepan, add peels and cores to 6 cups of sugar and 9 cups water. Bring to a boil and let simmer for 35 minutes. Strain out peels and cores, and keep refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Simple, sweet and sour.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker (adjusting simple syrup to tartness of lemons) and fill with ice.

Shake hard, and strain into a chilled Martini glass half-rimmed with sugar.

About: Meet the crisp, light two-ingredient Martini you’ve been waiting for.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with lemon zest.
Pour ingredient into cocktail or rocks glass.

About: If you’re craving a classic cocktail, pour yourself this three-ingredient stunner.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with cracked ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Sam Treadway
About: Sam Treadway, the owner of Somerville, Mass.’s backbar
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cucumber and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients with ice and shake well.

Double-strain into a rocks glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice, basil sprig and dandelion, if accessible.

Author: Peter Novotny
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“I have been a Cowboys fan since I was about six years old,” says bartender Peter Novotny of Dallas’ Armoury D.E. “I go to games when I can, but getting a good seat at the Death Star [the nickname for the Cowboys stadium] costs a pretty penny. I usually end up tailgating and sitting in the cheap seats or party-pass seats.” 
This bright blue riff on a Margarita is a nod to the Cowboys team colors. Novotny even stencils a Cowboys star onto the top of the drink.
Ingred: .5 oz Giffard blue curaçao liqueur.5 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Rim a coupe glass with salt.

Add all of the ingredients to shaker, and dry-shake (without ice) to aerate the ingredients with the egg white.

Wet-shake (with ice), and fine-strain into the prepared glass.

Use a star stencil and spray a blue curaçao star on top of the drink.

*Cinnamon agave syrup: Simmer 6 cinnamon sticks in a 1:1 agave:water simple syrup for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Discard cinnamon sticks before using.

Author: St. John Frizell
About: Cherry brandy and espresso come together beautifully.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the espresso to a shaker and shake (without ice) until frothy.

Fill with ice and add the espresso.

Shake well and strain into two small cocktail glasses.

Author: Jeremy Allen
About: Jeremy Allen, the head bartender and general manager at Los Angeles’ MiniBar
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a floating apple slice.

Dust with grated cinnamon and star anise.

Author: Giancarlo Quiroz Jesus
About: A coffee-liqueur rinse turns the classic whiskey cocktail into a digestive delight.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled Old Fashioned glass with Galliano Ristretto and set aside.

In a mixing glass, muddle the bitters and sugar cube.

Add the whisky and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Break a kaffir lime leaf in four places over the drink, run along the rim of the glass and discard.

Author: Matt Grippo
About: Turn the French 75 on its head by swapping in tequila, fennel liqueur and honey syrup and topping with bubbles.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Don Julio blanco tequila 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Ciccio E Figli Finocchietto liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except sparkling wine to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a flute over ice.

Top with sparkling wine and garnish with a fennel frond.

Author: Yellowtail
About: Warm up with this shiraz-and-vodka drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Chris Chamberlain
About: This bright and bubbly glass of gin, lemon juice, simple syrup and Champagne is a timeless classic for good reason.
Ingred: .25 oz Simple syrup .25 oz Simple syrup
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except Champagne to an ice-filled shaker and shake vigorously.

Uncap shaker and add Champagne.

Strain mixture into a Champagne glass and garnish with an expressed lemon twist.

Author: Nick Checcio
About:
Fresh orange and lemon enlivens this Whiskey Sour variation, with spiced notes of cinnamon and dried harissa in a house-made syrup, resulting in a nuanced but bracing sipper. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Whiskey Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Evan Williams White Label bourbon
Instructions:
Rim 1/3 of a coupe glass with crushed aleppo pepper.

Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into the prepared coupe.

*Harissa syrup: Toast 20 cinnamon sticks in an oven on medium-high heat for 3-5 minutes or until aromatic. Add 1 qt sugar, 1 qt water and 4 tbsp La Boîte Izak N.37 harissa-inspired spice blend. Heat until all sugar is dissolved, then remove cinnamon sticks. Let the syrup sit overnight, then strain with cheesecloth and chinoise. Keep refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Yael Vengroff
About: One of Yael Vengroff’s signature Bar Shift hits, this warmly-spiced coupe is made with Dewar’s White Label, D’ussé Cognac, St-Germain, green cardamom pods, lemon juice and bitters. The addition of aromatic cardamom was inspired by Vengroff’s time spent in Mumbai, India, and a playful green-apple fan provides the finishing touch.
Instructions:
Smash the green cardamom pods and add them to a shaker with the rest of the ingredients and ice.

Shake, and double strain into a coupe.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: You put the lime in the coconut and drink ’em both together.
Instructions:
Muddle the lime and sugar in a shaker.

Add the Leblon Cachaça, fill with ice and shake well.

Pour, unstrained, into an old fashioned glass and top with Vita Coco.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

About: The Añejo Highball is the hip Caribbean cousin of the Moscow Mule. It was created by Dale DeGroff, one of the masters of modern mixology, as a tribute to the Cuban bartenders of the early 1900s.
Instructions:
Add the rum, liqueur, juice and bitters to a Highball glass with ice.

Add the ginger beer, and give the mixture a good stir.

Garnish with an orange wedge.

Author: Nick Bennett
About: In celebration of New York’s historic 7 subway line extension, this cocktail salutes the purple route emblem of the 7 train and marries essential characteristics of the Sazerac and Aviation.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and double strain into an absinthe-rinsed glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: The old-timey version of sangria features American applejack.
Ingred: 2 oz Beaujolais nouveau wine (you may substitute another red wine)
1.5 oz Laird's Straight Bottled in Bond Apple Brandy
1⁄4 oz Grade B maple syrup (you may substitute other dark maple syrup) 1⁄4 oz
Garnish: 1 Thin apple slices and grated cinnamon
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with thin apple slices and grated cinnamon.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: There’s nothing wrong with a French 75, but replacing gin with Polish vodka is an inspired twist. Make it today to see which one you prefer.
Ingred: Moët & Chandon Impèrial brut Champagne, to top
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne.

Author: St-Germain Liqueur
About: You don’t have to be from the east or old to enjoy this St-Germain, Plymouth Gin, cucumber and mint cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint and cucumber.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice or a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a mint leaf and a cucumber slice.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: It’s common knowledge that an Old Fashioned is a great vehicle for good whiskey. What’s surprising is just how well it showcases unfiltered vodka, too.
Instructions:
Add the sugar cube and soda water to a rocks glass and muddle.

Add the vodka, the bitters and 1-1/2” x 1-1/2’’ ice cubes, and stir until chilled.

Garnish with a finger-length lemon and orange peel.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: The Dry Martini is a classic cocktail that, like a tailored suit, is timeless. Although the original of the tipple is unclear, the Dry Martini has maintained a place in cocktail history due to being easy to use and endlessly sophisticated. Elegant for the fancy and boozy for the heavy-handed, this potation is truly the everyman’s cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until very cold and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jerry Nevins
About: Ginger, maple and bourbon
Ingred: 3 1⁄4 oz Buffalo Trace Kentucky straight bourbon
2 oz Dolin Dry Vermouth de Chambéry
2 3⁄4 oz Cabin Fever maple flavored whiskey
Instructions:
Makes 4.

Add all the ingredients in a medium-size metal bowl and stir.

Pour the liquid into a large freezer bag, and place it in the freezer until frozen for approximately 4 hours.

When ready to drink, massage the freezer bag by hand until it’s a wet, slushy consistency. If it’s not breaking up, run the bag quickly under hot water and massage some more.

Divide among four Old Fashioned or rocks glasses.

Garnish each glass with a strip of crispy bacon.

Author: Cameron Dale
About: This classic vodka cocktail couldn’t be easier to make.
Instructions:
In a Collins glass, add the vodka, fill with ice, top with the tonic water, and add a squeeze of lemon.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Gaston Martinez
About: Celebrate Cinco de Mayo and the Kentucky Derby at the same time.
Ingred: 1 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blackberries and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Julep cup filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with blackberries and a mint sprig.

Author: Gui Jaroschy
About: While in Chicago for his Bar Shift, Gui Jaroschy scored local lemongrass and marigolds for his signature cocktail while exploring Millennium Park. A sunny glass of Bacardi Heritage, lime juice and a kaffir-citrus cordial mixed with rosemary and St-Germain, the Southernmost State of Mind personified Jaroschy’s native Miami perfectly.
Ingred: 1 oz Sunshine Mix (kaffir and citrus cordial mixed with rosemary and St-Germain)
Instructions:
Shake first 3 ingredients and strain into collins glass with collins spear ice if possible.

Drop thin sliced clementine wheel inside glass, top with soda, and garnish rim with another clementine wheel and a sprig of rosemary.

Author: Pusser's Rum
About: A twist on the Piña Colada, the Painkiller cocktail is a rich and fruity tropical drink that’s a specialty of the British Virgin Islands. Coconut cream, orange juice and pineapple juice join rum  in this drink that brings the tropics right to your glass.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a hurricane glass or snifter filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a pineapple wedge.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: This drink combines England’s deep history and ties with tea with the Brazilian sugarcane spirit cachaça.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Earl Grey tea syrup (1 part sugar, 1 part brewed Earl Grey tea) 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Giffard Vanille de Madagascar Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice, shake again and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda.

Author: Simon Ford
About: The Piña Colada is a classic tropical cocktail with rum, pineapple and coconut milk. This classic recipe will transport you to paradise. Getting caught in the rain is not required.
Instructions:
To make the Piña Colada add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Hurricane glass filled with fresh ice.

(You may also blend all the ingredients with crushed ice instead.) Garnish with a cherry and a pineapple wedge.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
“This cocktail is basically just whiskey
Instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir.

Author: Galliano
About: It takes a steady hand to make this layered shot.
Instructions: Carefully layer the ingredients in a shot glass in the order shown (Galliano on the bottom, cream on the top).

Author: Dominic Venegas
About: You’ll gain a new appreciation for amaro in this cocktail with hints of strawberry and vanilla.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Jeremy Allen
About: Instead of stocking bottles of amaretto liqueur, Jeremy Allen of MiniBar
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain over fresh ice into a double Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a house-cured cherry.

*House-made amaretto: Start with 1 qt dried, cleaned cherry pits. Crack each one open with a hammer (don’t pulverize), add 1 L vodka

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Your slow cooker does most of the work in this big-flavored pork taco recipe. A touch of sweet potatoes and Mexican chorizo builds the flavors even more. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great hot-weather tequila drinks.
Ingred: .5 lb Sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/3” to 1/2” cubes.5 lb
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Stir together the chile powder, salt, sugar, cumin, oregano, garlic powder, red pepper flakes and garlic in a large mixing bowl. Add the whole pork shoulder and rub with the spice mix to coat evenly.

Bring a large skillet to medium-high heat and add the vegetable oil. Use tongs to transfer the shoulder to the skillet, and brown for 2 to 3 minutes on each side.

Remove from the skillet and place into a slow cooker on high heat. Let cook for 3 and a half hours, at which point you should be able to easily shred the pork with two forks. Shred the pork and let cook on low for another hour.

When the pork is nearly finished, start preparing the sweet potatoes.

Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F degrees. Cook the chorizo in a cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat for about 3 minutes until the fat begins to render. Add the sweet potatoes, then lower heat to medium and cook for another 5 minutes.

Transfer the skillet to the oven and roast for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally, making sure the potatoes don’t blacken. Remove the skillet from the oven and set aside.

Make the pico de gallo by combining the chopped red onion, tomato, cilantro, jalapeño, lime juice and salt and pepper.

When ready to serve, brush both sides of the tortillas with olive oil, and grill on a hot grill or stovetop griddle for about 2 minutes on each side. Assemble the tacos by piling on the pulled pork followed by the sweet potatoes and chorizo, pico de gallo, sour cream and a squeeze of lime.

Author: Emilio and Miguel Salehi
About: This drink takes the subtle flavors in a Boulevardier and adds dark cherry and bitter roasted coffee liqueur. Spicy Rittenhouse rye and Campari bring balance for a deep and complex cocktail.
Ingred: 1 barspoon St. George NOLA coffee liqueur
Instructions:
Add all of ingredients into a mixing glass with ice.

Stir and strain into a Nick & Nora glass or serve in a rocks glass with a large hunk of ice.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Ryan Puckett
Ingred: .5 oz Punt E Mes vermouth.5 oz
.5 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir vigorously, and strain into a coupe glass with a julep strainer.

Garnish with one to two speared cherries.

Author: Ryan Morris
About:
What could melt the slick, seemingly frosty demeanor of a stoic storm trooper in ‘Star Wars’? Well, for starters, Ryan Morris, the general manager of Venkman’s in Atlanta, thinks one must start with rum. Of course! Sometimes, when the weather calls in the balmy South, he likes to run this tropically tweaked tipple through his on-premises slushy machine. But you can shake it up, too. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Celebrate the Release of ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ with These Great ‘Stars Wars’ Cocktail Recipes.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Collins glass over ice.

Author: Chris Cheng
About:
Bartender Chris Cheng of Westroot Tavern in San Diego professes a distaste for puns but couldn’t resist employing one for this decadent made with horchata vodka and cold-brew coffee. And as his city is home to an installment of the world’s biggest fantasy fest, Comi-Con, it’s only fitting that he’s ready to whip out a few George Lucas–loving cocktails faster than a nimble little Grand Master Yoda employs a lightsaber. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Celebrate the Release of ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ with These Great ‘Stars Wars’ Cocktail Recipes.”
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Giffard white crème de cacao liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (without ice) for 5 seconds.

Add ice, and shake again until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with 1 pinch of cinnamon sugar.

About: Similar to Brazil’s famed Caipirinha
Ingred: 1 oz Simple syrup (or 1 tbsp granulated white sugar)
Instructions:
Fill an Old Fashioned glass with cracked ice to chill.

In a mixing glass, add the simple syrup (or sugar) and lime quarters.

Muddle to extract the juice without forcing the rind from the lime.

Dump the ice from the glass into the mixing glass, add the vodka, and shake.

Pour the entire drink with the ice into the chilled glass, and garnish with 4 lime quarters.

Author: Christiana DeLucca
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“This cocktail is an ode to the ’85 Bears and the fleeting Honey Bears cheerleaders. I have vivid memories of watching them both during that season, even at six years old,” says bartender Christiana DeLucca of Chicago’s Formento’s. “It’s also an homage to Buddy Ryan’s 4–6 defense. That man is a legend, and this is my tip o’ the hat to him in cocktail form. Served Toddy style, this cocktail is all about embracing the fall season. Make a large batch, grab a thermos, and you’ve got the perfect tailgating cocktail to impress your friends.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Buckwheat honey (or clover honey) 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
6 oz Hot-brewed Davids Tea Pumpkin Chai black tea (or any chai)
Instructions:
Add heavy whipping cream to an empty bottle, and shake until lightly whipped for about 1 minute.

Add the bourbon, liqueurs, honey, lemon juice and hot tea to a mug.

Top the drink with the whipped cream, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: James Moreland
About: A little gin adds the perfect depth to this pomegranate and Champagne cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the gin and the pomegranate juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Champagne flute or small coupe.

Top with the Champagne.

Author: Finlandia Vodka
About: Berries, berries and berriesin the vodka, liqueur and garnishmake this an ideal summer drink.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Finlandia Wild Berries Fusion Vodka 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail class.

Top with the club soda and garnish with fresh berries.

Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
.5 oz St. Elizabeth’s All Spice Dram.5 oz
Instructions:
Add ingredients (minus the orange peel) into a shaker.

Add ice to shaker tin and shake for 10-15 seconds.

Strain into cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lightly expressed orange peel.

Author: Brick Lane Curry House
About: Add a little Indian flavor to the Mexican classic with this deliciously tangy cocktail.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with salt, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Will Thompson
About: Swap the vermouth in a Martini for sherry and you’ll get this simple but delicious drink.
Ingred: 3 drops The Bitter Truth Celery Bitters
Garnish: 1 Lemon twist and olive or other pickled vegetable
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail or rocks glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist and an olive or other pickled vegetable.

Author: Leo's
About: This riff on an Irish Coffee swaps in espresso from Leo’s in San Francisco and balances those bold flavors with a little mint.
Ingred: .5 oz Caffè Borghetti espresso liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Dirty-dump into a chilled highball glass, and top with the mint whipped cream.

Garish with mint sprigs.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Hail to the chief and mix up El Presidente cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Absolut Vodka is a sturdy base for this unique concoction of lime, vanilla and Crème Yvette.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

About: Of course Aberlour 12 year is good enough—by far—to stand on its own. Make a highball to open up the premium single malt even more.
Instructions:
Add the Aberlour 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch to an ice-filled highball glass.

Top with soda water.

Author: Virginia Miller
About: This cocktail served at Snackbar
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the melon, cucumber, jalapeño, cilantro, lime juice, grapefruit bitters and agave syrup.

Add the tequila, Cointreau and salt, and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass with ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice, jalapeño slice and parsley leaf sprinkled with cumin seeds.

Author: Classic And Vintage Artisanal Spirits
About: Mix up this version of the Scottish classic made with single malt whiskey distilled in upstate New York.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir well.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a  cherry or lemon twist.

Author: Somer Perez
About: Combine gin, grapefruit juice and St-Germain and you’ll have the perfect refreshing cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a grapefruit half-wheel.

Author: Lesley Jacobs Solmonson
About: This cocktail has a good deal in common with the Brandy Alexander and the Grasshopper  with its crème de cacao and cream. Where it differs markedly is in the inclusion of crème de noyaux, a once popular but relatively forgotten liqueur that is similar to amaretto. The red color of the liqueur usually comes from cochineal, which doesn’t affect the singular herbal-meets-bitter almond flavor.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Tempus Fugit crème de noyaux 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Tempus Fugit white crème de cacao 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker filled of ice and shake until cold.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with grated nutmeg.

Author: Matt Tocco
About: This riff on the Negroni features an Italian alpine amaro that adds a minty, pine essence to this fall cocktail.
Ingred: Clear Creek Douglas Fir Eau de Vie
Instructions:
Rinse a rocks glass with Douglas Fir Eau de Vie.

Combine remaining ingredients in a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice into the rocks glass.

Garnish with a lemon pigtail.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: She always leaves you wanting more.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Karl Franz Williams
About: This complex cognac cocktail might just become your new favorite drink.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Combier CrÃ¨me de PÃªche 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.

Top with a red wine float.

Author: Aisha Sharpe and Dushan Zaric
About: Don’t believe your eyes: There’s no whiskey or vermouth in this cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: BarSol
About: The refreshing snap of lime and pisco with the fizz of ginger ale is what makes the Chilcano delicious.
Instructions:
Add the pisco and lime juice to a highball glass filled with ice.

Top with ginger ale and add the bitters.

Garnish with a lime twist.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Looking for a taste of summer? Try Allen Katz’s ginger, rum and fresh juices cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Tommy Bahama White Sand Rum
1⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a thin apple slice.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Making an Irish Car Bomb is easy. Grab a pint and detonate this guilty pleasure.
Instructions:
Add the Baileys and Jameson Irish Whiskey to a shot glass.

Drop the shot into a half-pint of Guinness Beer.

Author: Beau du Bois
About: This complex spin on Eggnog includes rum, armagnac and fernet.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz El Dorado 5 Year Old Cask Aged Rum 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake again.

Double-strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with a large piece of ice.

Garnish with grated nutmeg and cinnamon, and cracked black pepper.

Author: Willy Shine
About: With apple juice and Tennessee whiskey, this orchard is one you’ll want to visit over and over.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Philip Pepperdine
About: A fruity concoction to remind you of warmer times.
Ingred: 2 oz Montecristo Spiced Blend Rum (or other spiced rum)
Instructions:
In a shaker, gently muddle the strawberry, lime, lemon, orange and mint (do not break up the mint).

Add the spiced rum and St-Germain, and fill with ice.

Shake lightly and pour (unstrained) into an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Juan Coronado
About: Recall Planet Hoth, the world of snow and ice, with this rum-based coupe laced with lime juice and maraschino liqueur.
Ingred: 2 oz Bacardi Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake vigorously, and double strain into a coupe.

Garnish with nutmeg.

Author: Allen Katz
About: This fruity and spiced concoction is perfect for holiday entertaining.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: This delicious low-alcohol cocktail recipe is bitter, sweet and seasonal.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Clover honey syrup (1 part clover honey, 1 part simple syrup)
Instructions:
Strip the leaves from the rosemary sprig and add them to a shaker.

Muddle, and then add the Meyer lemon juice and egg white.

Shake without ice for 5 seconds.

Add the Campari and honey syrup and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a short rosemary sprig.

Author: Nate Wales
About: Tequila, ginger, pineapple and corn all show up to class in this spicy cocktail from Austin, Texasâ€™s La Condesa.
Ingred: 2 oz Habanero-infused Siembra Azul Blanco Tequila
Garnish: Hibiscus-rose salt rim and mist of Herbsaint
Instructions: In a shaker, muddle the corn kernels, then add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice. Shake hard, and double strain into a hibiscus-rose saltâ€"rimmed coupe glass. Mist with two to three sprays of Herbsaint.

About: Celebrate Cinco de Mayo year-round with the tasty tequila Paloma cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the tequila and lime juice to a highball glass filled with ice.

Fill with grapefruit soda and stir briefly.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Go ahead: give into temptation.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice or a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an apple slice or mint sprig.

Author: Dustin Drankiewicz, Moneygun
About: This cocktail was created by Dustin Drankiewicz at Moneygun for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into a bucket glass with 1 fresh ice cube.

Garnish by twisting a lemon peel over the surface of the drink to express its oils, then drop the peel into the glass.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: One sip of this cognac-based sipper and you’ll be dancing the night away to your favorite Motown tunes.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Rothman & Winter Orchard Apricot 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a slice of lemon peel.

Author: Rob Krueger
About: Carrots, cayenne and caper brine, yes. Tomatoes, no! The Bunny Mary, created by Extra Fancy
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (equal parts honey and water).5 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Collins glass with the pimenton salt and fill with ice.

Combine all of the ingredients, and stir until chilled.

Garnish with a parsley sprig.

*Pimenton salt rim: Combine 1 tbsp smoked sweet paprika, 1 tbsp salt and 1/2 tbsp cayenne pepper in a small bowl, enough to rim 14 glasses.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: You need authentic Mexican grapefruit soda to make an authentic version of the tequila classic.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with ice and add the tequila and salt.

Squeeze the lime half into the glass and drop into the drink.

Fill with grapefruit soda.

Author: Ashford Castle
About: Break out the bubbly and the pineapple juice for a tasty Champagne Cobbler.
Instructions:
Add the orange juice, pineapple juice and maraschino liqueur to a mixing glass and stir to combine.

Add the Champagne and fill with ice.

Stir again gently and strain into a Champagne flute.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
What’s even better than a tequila and soda? A tequila and soda with a hit of blood orange juice to brighten the color and flavor in the best possible way. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now
Instructions:
Combine the tequila, blood orange and lime juices, and agave nectar in a shaker with ice, and shake.

Strain into a Collins or Highball glass filled with ice, and top with the club soda.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Jared Schubert
About: Nobody will suspect a thing if you just sit quietly and enjoy this sophisticated bourbon cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cherry and an orange slice or twist.

About: This cocktail brings Averna amaro to life with cognac, Appleton Estate rum, lemon juice, simply syrup and chocolate bitters.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a rocks glass over pebble or crushed ice, and garnish with an orange wedge.

About: Tea cocktails meet the Sidecar in this update of a classic.
Ingred: 2.5 oz Tea-infused Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège cognac
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe.

Garnish with an orange peel.

*Tea-infused Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège cognac: Add 1 tea bag of Earl Grey tea to 8 oz Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège cognac. Infuse for 1 week.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About: This drink at Trifecta
Ingred: 1 bottle Jameson Black Barrel Reserve Irish whiskey (750 mL)
1 bottle Cocchi Storico Vermouth di Torino (750 mL)
1 bottle Dolin Génépy des Alpes or Green Chartreuse (750 mL)
Sugar maple wood piece, the size of a lemon
Instructions:
Makes 3 quarts, or 32 3-oz cocktails.

Combine the three spirits in a sous vide bag and set aside.

Char the sugar maple in a wood-fired oven or with a crème brulée torch.

Once the wood has stopped smoking, place it in the bag with the spirits, then place that bag in another sous vide bag, and set in a sous vide machine set at 150oF for three hours. Remove the wood after the infusion.

For each cocktail, combine 3 oz of the mix with ice and stir. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Meredith Hayman
About:
When Meredith Hayman, the bar manager at Michael’s in Santa Monica, Calif., had a bunch of Galliano liqueur to use up, she created this market-driven take on the Manhattan. It makes use of kumquats, the diminutive citrus fruit with a thin rind and a low amount of pith.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Muddled Drinks in Bars to Crush on Now.”
Instructions:
Muddle the kumquat and cloves in a mixing glass.

Add the whisky, liqueur, amaro and bitters, add ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a kumquat.

Author: Nolet's Silver Dry Gin
About: Sweet, tart, citrusy and delicious.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker.

Dry shake until emulsified (about one minute).

Add ice and shake again, vigorously.

Double strain into a chilled Martini or coupe glass and garnish with three raspberries.

About: This tequila cocktail made with snap pea shrub and mint is a true culinary masterpiece.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake very hard and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

About: Everyone’s favorite Easter candy gets transformed into a creamy, chocolatey, boozy treat. Need more sweet inspiration? Check out the five best cadbury creme egg cocktails.
Ingred: .5 oz White crème de cacao.5 oz
Instructions:
Grate or chop the chocolate and place in a small shallow bowl or rimmed plate. Melt on low heat in the microwave. Dip the rim of the cocktail glass in the chocolate, and chill to set.

Combine the vodka, Chartreuse, crème de cacao and cream in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well.

Strain into the chocolate-rimmed glass.

Grate additional chocolate curls over the top of the drink.

Top with a Cadbury Creme Mini Egg, cut open to reveal the "yolk."

Author: Kamil Kouiri
About: Give your winter Toddy a Greek vacation by adding Tentura, a Greek liqueur spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves.
Instructions:
Place two ounces of the Tentura liqueur into the mug and add the hot brewed coffee.

Stir in the steamed milk and top with two tablespoons of the foam.

Sprinkle with ground cinnamon.

Author: David Wondrich
About: One of the earliest vodka-cocktail recipes created in the US, this simple tipple dates back to 1938.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with cracked ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Twist a swatch of thin-cut lemon peel over the top and discard.

Author: Allison Lindsey
About: When Allison Lindsey, the head bartender at Baltimore’s Bar Vasquez
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with a rosemary sprig.

*Salted cucumber juice: Using a juicer, juice peeled cucumbers to yield 1 quart. Strain juice to remove any pulp, and add 1 to 1 1/2 tsp sea salt to add flavor and preserve the juice. Store the mixture in the refrigerator.

Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir well.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with lemon zest and a cherry.

Author: Gary Regan
About:
The legendary Cosmopolitan is a simple cocktail with a big history. It reached its height of popularity in the 1990s, when the HBO show “Sex and the City” was at its peak. The pink-hued Martini was a favorite of the characters on the show.
According to Gary Regan, the original Cosmopolitan was created by South Beach bartender Cheryl Cook. Eager to invent a new cocktail for the Martini glass, Cook riffed on the classic Kamikaze using a newly introduced citrus-flavored vodka plus a splash of cranberry juice. 
There’s some debate about who created the original Cosmopolitan, whether it was Cook, Dale DeGroff (at New York City’s Rainbow Room) or Toby Cecchini, who devised a Cosmo in 1988 during his tenure at NYC’s Odeon. However, all agree that Cecchini popularized the vodka-and-cranberry ’Tini.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Jesse Held
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
Jesse Held, a bartender for Minneapolis’ Jester Concepts group, felt a certain obligation to not only create a cocktail that represents the Vikings but also pays homage to Minnesota’s “fabric of heartiness.” “The color had to be purple for many reasons, for our recent loss of our Prince and of course our gridiron gladiators, the Minnesota Vikings,” he says. “The gold leaf garnish is an atypical flash we Minnesotans aren’t accustomed to having, but staying true to our purple people eaters, by wearing purple and gold, is only fitting when it comes to imbibing in the name of the Vikings.”
This drink has a base of aquavit from Minneapolis’ Tattersall Distilling. “Using aquavit was essential to making a cocktail that was a true representation of the Great White North,’” says Held. To sweeten the drink, he uses a syrup and a shrub from his elixir company, Earl Giles, which can be subbed for homemade versions.
Ingred: 3⁄4 ml Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 ml
3⁄4 oz Earl Giles blueberry-thyme shrub 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Earl Giles vanilla syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of ingredients to a shaker with dense ice and shake vigorously.

Double-strain into a cocktail glass over a chunk of hand-chipped ice.

*Jalapeño-infused aquavit: Steep one large washed and slice jalapeño in a 750 mL bottle of aquavit for four to six hours, then remove the jalapeño.

**Homemade blueberry-thyme shrub: Make a syrup by combining 1 cup gently crushed blueberries, 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar and a few thyme sprigs of in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is completely dissolved and remove from heat. Strain when cooled. Combine 2/3 blueberry-thyme syrup with 1/3 apple cider vinegar. Store in the refrigerator until use.

***Homemade vanilla syrup: Combine 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar and 2 halved vanilla beans in a small pot over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is completely dissolved and remove from heat. When cool, strain into a plastic container, and refrigerate until use.

About: Gin and cucumber get a Daiquiri twist from The Mayhaw at St. Roch Market.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a blender, and blend until smooth.

Garnish with a cucumber wheel.

*Plum syrup: Chop 12 plums, removing seeds. Add 12 cups of water and 12 cups of sugar to a pot. Once the sugar dissolves, add the plums and bring to a boil. After it reaches a boil, turn the heat down and let it simmer, for approximately 2 hours, until the plums are soft. Strain out the plums and transfer to a bottle with a second strain.

**Cucumber syrup: Follow the same steps as the plum syrup but using 8 cucumbers instead.

Author: Virginia Miller
About: This classic French cocktail combines licorice and almond flavors.
Instructions: Add the pastis and orgeat syrup into a Collins glass with ice, top with sparkling water, and stir.

About: While many cocktails are garnished with olives or cherries, it’s traditional to serve the Air Mail with a postage stamp. It can be stuck on the edge of the glass or placed to one side.
Instructions:
Add the rum, lime juice and honey into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a postage stamp.

Author: Jenn Knott
About: “Sweet, herbaceous and acidic all at once, this is a great pre-dinner cocktail before a nice glass of white wine,” says 312 Chicago
Ingred: Basil salt (chopped fresh basil combined with coarse salt), to rim glass
Instructions:
Rub the lemon wedge on half of the outside of a coupe glass, coat with the basil salt mixture and set aside.

Add the gin and syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into the prepared coupe glass.

Float the chilled prosecco on top.

*Honeydew-basil-white-balsamic shrub: Cut off the rind and remove the seeds from 1 whole honeydew, then cut the melon into chunks. Combine it in the blender with 1 cup fresh basil, and blend until smooth. Pour the mixture into a saucepan, add 4 cups white sugar and 4 cups cold water, and simmer until the sugar has dissolved, being careful not to overheat. Remove it from the heat and let it cool, then strain through a chinois cloth. Add 1 ½ cups white balsamic vinegar, and keep the shrub in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Don’t let Mary steal all of the limelight.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Le Citron Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the vodka, cucumber, Tabasco and vermouth. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.

Top with the tomato juice and garnish with a Kirby cucumber spear.

About: Lean in for a whiff of this fragrant, fall-ready toddy.
Ingred: .5 oz Rittenhouse Bonded Rye Whiskey.5 oz
.5 oz Grade B maple syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the water to a preheated mug.

Top with the boiling water and stir to combine.

Top with grated cinnamon.

Author: Sazerac Company
About: It doesn’t get much more classic than this NOLA standard.
Instructions:
Pack an Old Fashioned glass with ice and set aside.

In a second Old Fashioned glass, muddle the sugar cube and bitters, and add the rye whiskey.

Pour the ice out of the first glass, add the Herbsaint and rotate the glass to coat the inside, discarding any excess.

Add the whiskey mixture to the prepared glass and garnish with a lemon peel.

About: This cocktail incorporates Cynar with unfiltered apple juice, cinnamon syrup and ginger beer, transforming a summertime special into something more appropriately autumnal.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except the alcoholic ginger beer in a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Fine-strain into a pilsner, and top with the ginger beer.

*Cinnamon syrup: In a small saucepan, add 2 cups of water and 9 oz of broken-up cinnamon sticks (approximately 4 sticks), and bring to a boil. Simmer for 10 minutes, and strain out the cinnamon sticks. Bring the water back to a boil, add 1.5 cups of sugar, and stir until sugar is dissolved.

About: This cocktail is pure boozy magic. Watch the fluff of sugar disappear before your very eyes!
Ingred: Gourmet cotton candy Gourmet cotton candy
Instructions:
Place a big fluff of cotton candy in the cocktail glass.

Add rum and lime juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, then strain into the glass, dissolving the cotton candy.

Top with Champagne. Garnish with a lime wheel.

About: The classic bourbon Brown Derby cocktail is named for the eponymous hat-shaped Los Angeles diner. It’s both sweet and sour with a hefty dose of grapefruit juice and a touch of honey syrup. Try this recipe now to find out what all the hype is about.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit wedge or twist.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: With peach liqueur and apricot, this vodka drink is packed with fruit flavor.
Instructions:
Muddle the apricots and simple syrup in a shaker.

Add the Crème de Peche, Chopin Vodka, bitters and ice.

Shake and double strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a dried apricot.

Author: Damon Dyer
About: Two French liqueurs plus American rye and lemon juice equals one fine drink.
Instructions:
Shake all the ingredients with ice.

Fine strain the mixture into a chilled coupe or small cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Liquor.com
About: Ring it in with fruit and bubbly.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and cranberry juice to a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne and garnish with 5-6 raspberries on a long skewer.

Author: Bulleit
About: Sambuca instead of the traditional absinthe makes this an Italian twist on the New Orleans favorite.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Stirrings Blood Orange Bitters 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass.

About: No need to look away from this potent and tasty cocktail.
Ingred: 1 oz Don Julio 70 Añejo Claro Tequila
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the mezcal to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass containing a 2-inch ice cube.

Float the mezcal on top.

Author: Ryan Welliver
About:
At The Cocktail Club in Charleston, S.C., bar manager Ryan Welliver puts an inventive spin on the usual citrus rum cocktail by combining two types of rum with citrus and spice in the form of an infused syrup with cinnamon sticks and toasted cumin seeds.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Can the Classic Drinks of Summer Be Transformed for Winter? Yes. And This Is How.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass or Tiki mug over crushed ice.

Cut a lime in half, squeeze out the juice of one half, set atop the drink, pour overproof rum inside the shell, and carefully light on fire.

*Cinnamon-cumin syrup: Toast 1 tbsp cumin seeds in a sauté pan on medium-low heat until fragrant. Let cool, then grind into a coarse powder. Bring 2 cinnamon sticks and 1 cup water to a boil in a medium-size saucepan, and allow to boil for 10 minutes. Turn off the heat, add 2 cups granulated sugar and the toasted cumin powder, and stir until sugar has dissolved. Allow the syrup to cool, then strain through a fine-mesh strainer. Bottle and refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Liquor.com
About: The glittering mixture of local bourbon, orange liqueur, two kinds of bitters, and Champagne is the signature drink of Louisville’s Seelbach Hotel. Once thought to be a classic rediscovered in the ’90s after decades of obscurity, the drink’s inventor recently confessed to having fabricated the vintage backstory. Regardless, the elegant sip is sure to be delighting guests (and faraway strangers) for years to come.
Instructions:
Stir together bourbon, Cointreau and bitters in an ice-filled mixing glass.

Strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with cold Champagne or sparkling wine, and garnish with twist.

Author: Flora, Oakland, Calif.
About: This fruity spin on the classic Whiskey Smash is a real winner.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon, peach, mint and sugar cane syrup.

Add the bourbon and Cointreau, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a sprig of fresh mint.

Author: Jeremy Oertel
About: This festive vodka creation is cause for celebration thanks to the additions of red wine, spiced pear liqueur and maple syrup.
Ingred: .5 oz St. George Spiced Pear Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except seltzer to a glass over ice.

Stir and top with seltzer.

Garnish with a pear fan and grated nutmeg.

Author: Tracy Chang
About:
Green Chartreuse liqueur gives herbal sweetness and sparkling sake makes it fizzy and refreshing in this cocktail at Pagu. “We use healthful, whole ingredients, such zucchini water in the Fields of Travel cocktail,” says Tracy Chang, the chef and owner of the Cambridge, Mass., restaurant.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 Vegetable-Heavy Cocktails You Can Make at Home.”
Ingred: 2 oz Hou Hou Shu sparkling sake
Instructions:
Add the sake, liqueur and zucchini water to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Top with the sake.

Garnish with a skewered cucumber ribbon.

*Zucchini water: Process 5 whole zucchinis through a juicer (which should yield 1 quart.) Add 1 oz. fresh lime juice, 1 oz. raw cane sugar and 1 barspoon vitamin C powder.

About: This classic Tiki drink was created in 1978 at the Aviary bar of the Kuala Lumpur Hilton.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Dark aged Jamaican rum or Cruzan Black Strap rum
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass three-quarters with ice, and add all of the ingredients.

Shake until chilled for about 30 seconds.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice cubes or one large piece of ice, and add the garnish.

Author: John Stanton
About: In this cocktail from Sable Kitchen & Bar in Chicago, pistachios pay a nice complement to cognac.
Ingred: .5 oz Marie Brizard Orange Curaçao.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Brian Means
About: Mezcal and pistachios whisper sweet nothings in this cocktail from Dirty Habit in San Francisco.
Garnish: Candied ginger and an espelette pepper
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a piece of candied ginger and an espelette pepper.

Author: Canadian Club Whisky
About: Hi-diddly-ho whisky-rino!
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: Brian Miller
About: Wear this on a hot day.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña White Rum
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberry.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a pilsner glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with an additional strawberry.

Add ingredients to the mixing glass.

Add ice to mixing glass and serving glass.

Stir ingredients for 30-40 seconds.

Strain into serving glass.

Garnish with a lightly expressed orange peel.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: Find out what happens when you add raspberries to this classic gin drink.
Garnish: 1 Lemon wheel, mint sprig and raspberries
Instructions:
In a highball glass, muddle the raspberries and simple syrup.

Add the gin and lemon juice, and stir.

Fill with ice and top with the club soda.

Garnish with a lemon wheel, a mint sprig and two raspberries.

Author: Erik Reichborn-Kjennerud and Todd Smith
About: Though a bit rare, this smoky whisky cocktail is delicious when made well.
Instructions:
Stir all ingredients together with ice.

Serve over fresh ice, and add a lemon twist for garnish.

Author: Chris Cosentino
About: Celebrity chef Chris Cosentino begins brunch with this spicy, beer-based, oyster-topped culinary concoction.
Ingred: 12 oz Castelvetrano or other mild green olives
12 Oysters (preferably Kumamato or Kusshi), shucked, liquor reserved
Instructions:
Place 2 olives in each of 6 pint glasses.

Pour half a bottle of beer into each glass and top with the Roman Mix, divided evenly among the glasses.

Place 2 shucked oysters with their liquor in each glass and garnish with an additional olive, a serrano chile and a few chile threads.

Author: Lesley Jacobs Solmonson
About: If you appreciate a good Manhattan—a rye Manhattan specifically—then the Remember the Maine will most likely find a home in your drinks repertoire. The cocktail comes from Charles H. Baker, Jr’s. The Gentleman’s Companion
Instructions:
In a chilled coupe or cocktail glass, add the absinthe. Roll around to coat and discard the excess.

Add the rye, vermouth and liqueur to a mixing glass with ice and stir well.

Strain into the prepared glass, and garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Maxwell Britten
About: Built on a base of malty genever and pisco, this cocktail gains warm fall flavor from homemade Demerara and cinnamon syrups and a handful of Concord grapes.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker.

Shake, and strain over a glass filled with crushed ice.

About:
Simple syrup is the building block for delicious cocktails. It’s easy to make, and you likely already have the ingredients at home. You’ll wonder why you ever bought simple syrup from the store. 
If you want a richer flavor, try using demerara sugar. It’ll take your cocktail to the next level. If you want to impart some extra flavor in your cocktail, you can experiment with adding herbs, citrus and/or spices into your simple syrup.
Instructions:
Add water and sugar to a small saucepan over medium heat.

Stir until sugar is dissolved.

Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid.

Simple syrup will keep, refrigerated, for about a month.

Author: Captain Morgan
About: Throwing a big party? This tropical spiced rum punch recipe serves 25.
Ingred: 1 bottle Captain Morgan Original spiced rum (750mL)
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a punch bowl or large pitcher and stir.

Serve in punch glasses filled with ice.

Author: Kevin Denton
About: If you’d like to make your drink a festive shade of green for the holidays, try this vodka and wheatgrass recipe. “Wheatgrass shots are so shockingly green that I knew as a cocktail ingredient they would add some sweet, fresh and lusciously vegetal flavors,” says Kevin Denton, the national mixologist for Pernod Ricard
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Shake all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass with no ice, and garnish with 3 mint leaves and a watermelon radish slice.

Ingred: 2 oz DEWAR’S WHITE LABEL Blended Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Muddle the lemon, mint and simple syrup in the bottom of a mixing glass.

Add DEWAR’S, shake and strain into a Collins glass filled with crushed ice.

Top with seltzer water.

Author: Julian Cox
About: Two types of peppers combine with mezcal, citrus and ginger in this sweet-and-savory concoction.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the bell pepper slices and lime wedges.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a double Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a piece of beef jerky.

About: This cocktail is warm take on the Sazerac, with cardamom, bitters and Luxardo maraschino liqueur.
Instructions:
Place an ice sphere in a rocks glass.

Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice, and stir well.

Strain over the ice sphere in the rocks glass.

Garnish with a sage leaf and lime peel.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Juicy marinated pork and a fresh pineapple salsa add up to great tacos. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: Corn tortillas, warmed in the oven or grilled
Instructions:
Serves 6.

In a large zip-top bag, combine the pineapple juice, garlic, vinegar, lime juice, tomato paste, chili powder, salt and cinnamon sticks. Add the pork loin and rub to coat. Refrigerate for 4 hours or up to overnight.

Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F. Remove the pork from the refrigerator and let sit at room temperature for about 15 minutes.

Remove the pork loin from the bag, let excess marinade drip off and transfer the pork to a roasting pan. Roast until a meat thermometer inserted into the center of the loin reads at least 145 degrees F, about 45 minutes.

Transfer the pork to a cutting board, and let rest for 10 minutes. Slice into 1/2”-thick rounds, then slice those rounds into strips.

While the pork roasts, make the pineapple jalapeño salsa.

Assemble the tacos starting with a few strips of the pork, then the salsa, sour cream and cilantro.

*Pineapple jalapeño salsa: Combine 1 cup diced fresh pineapple, 1 tbsp diced jalapeño, 1/2 small diced red onion, 1 tbsp lime juice and 1/3 cup lightly packed chopped cilantro.

Author: Paolo Votano
About: A fruity taste of summer.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the raspberries and mint leaves.

Add the remaining ingredients except the ginger ale and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball or large wine glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with ginger ale and garnish with a raspberry and a mint sprig.

Author: Matt Merkin
About: This X-Files–inspired cocktail is a classic Whiskey Sour with a pineapple twist. A Green Chartreuse float gives the drink an ethereal appearance, but the high-proof, medicinal bite keeps it grounded.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the Green Chartreuse to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Top with a float of Green Chartreuse.

Author: Bulldog Gin
About: What’s not to love about this fresh and fruity gin tipple?
Instructions:
In a double Old Fashioned glass, muddle the strawberry and basil leaves.

Fill with ice and set aside.

Add the gin and lemonade to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with a splash of club soda and garnish with a strawberry and a basil leaf.

Author: Virginia Miller
About:
This cocktail at Chica in Las Vegas’ Venetian is a balanced version of a Tiki classic, the Painkiller.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: February 2018.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Pour into a metal cup or highball over crushed ice.

Garnish with a skewered cherry and orange slice.

Dust with fresh grated nutmeg.

*Grilled pineapple juice: Grill 6 pineapple wedges in a stovetop pan on medium-high heat for 2 minutes on each side. Muddle and strain.

About: Used in other recipes such as the Pumpkin & Spice.
Ingred: 2 cup Raw oats (such as Quaker Oatmeal)

About: Try a refreshing cognac cocktail with lime juice and Thai basil leaves.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a crown of Thai basil.

*Honey syrup: Combine 1 1/2 parts honey to 1 part water. Bring to a simmer until the honey dissolves, then let cool before using.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: If you’re worldly and you know it, drink this cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Freshen up this classic cocktail by adding Jack Daniel’s Tennessee rye. The incredible new spirit adds a whole extra level of complexity.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Jack Daniel's Tennessee rye 3⁄4 oz
Instructions: Add all the ingredients into a rocks glass, add ice, stir and serve.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This Paloma at Nashville’s Pinewood Social
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over a large chunk of ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: In this refreshing Sangria variation, vodka and elderflower play off the bright flavors of fruit and white wine.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Square One Cucumber Vodka or Square One Botanical Spirit
3 oz White wine (sauvignon blanc, Sancerre, albariño or verdejo)
Garnish: 1 Mint or tarragon (use the same herb as in the drink)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill three-quarters of the way with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and pour (unstrained) into a large wine glass.

Garnish with a mint or tarragon sprig.

Author: Allen Katz
About: With rum, cream and egg, this drink is the perfect nightcap.
Instructions:
