Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a cocktail glass or 5-ounce juice glass.

Garnish with a light dusting of freshly grated nutmeg.

About: This garden-fresh simple syrup recipe will add a hint of basil to your favorite cocktails.
Ingred: .5 cup Packed fresh basil leaves.5 cup
Instructions:
Combine the sugar and boiling water.

Stir until the sugar is dissolved.

Add the basil leaves and steep in hot simple syrup for 15 minutes.

Strain into a clean jar, cover and refrigerate for up to two weeks.

About: A bit of heat goes a long way in this spicy cognac cocktail.
Ingred: 2 dashes Miracle Mile Chocolate Chili bitters
Garnish: Orange peel, Dried chile de arbol
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass with carved ice.

Express an orange peel around the top and rim of the glass, then garnish with the peel and a dried chile de arbol.

Author: Galliano
About: You’ll be king of the road when mix up this creamy classic.
Ingred: 1 oz Bols Crème de Cacao White
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with chocolate shavings if desired.

Author: Kyle Fountaine
About: Muddled strawberries and cilantro bring out tequila’s fresh side.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cilantro, strawberries and lime juice.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and double strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an additional strawberry and a few cilantro sprigs.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: This classic brunch cocktail hails from New Orleans.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass, and garnish with grated nutmeg.

Author: Ultimat Vodka
About: Cool down with this chilly concoction.
Ingred: .5 oz Patrón Citrónge Orange Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a tall glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a watermelon slice.

Author: Bols Genever
About: Dutch genever and Spanish sherry make this cocktail a European tour in a glass.
Instructions:
Add enough raisins to cover the bottom of a shaker and muddle.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with four speared raisins.

Author: Jason Littrell
About: Meet the ensemble cast critics will cheer for, featuring heavy-hitters like tequila, Yellow Chartreuse and velvet falernum.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a pitcher.

Briefly stir with ice, strain, and funnel into an empty punch bowl.

Refrigerate remaining punch for later use.

About:
Whiskey Sling
Classic Drink. Modern Taste.
When a drinker from long ago found his spirit to be a bit lacking in flavor, eggs and sugar were mixed in and the result was the “Flip” cocktail. Another fellow solved the same problem by adding baking spices. Creating the “Toddy.”  But eventually someone was lucky enough to come across an exceptional whiskey and the subtle, understated “Whiskey Sling” was born. It’s a cocktail crafted to highlight a spirit’s taste. Like the crisp balanced flavor of Gentleman Jack. Twice mellowed for exceptional smoothness. It’s just the whiskey the Sling was made for.
Instructions:
Shake all ingredients with ice.

Then strain into an ice-filled glass.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Kara Newman
About: Paloma means “dove” in Spanish, which means this drink’s name translates to “little dove.” This Paloma
Ingred: Jarritos grapefruit soda Jarritos grapefruit soda
Instructions:
Rim a Collins glass with vanilla-flecked salt.

Add the vodka and lime juice to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice.

Top with the soda.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Jeff Bell
About: Ancho chile liqueur, tart drinking vinegar and a cap of Pilsner give this cocktail its fizzy kick.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Pok Pok Pineapple Drinking Vinegar 3⁄4 oz
Garnish: La Boite 37 Spice and Salt Blend
Instructions:
Combine Don Julio Blanco Tequila, ancho chile liqueur, fresh lime juice and Pok Pok Pineapple drinking vinegar in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake well.

Strain contents into a rocks glass rimmed with La Boite 37 Spice and Salt blend over ice. Top with Pilsner.

About: Capture the bright flavors of blackberries in this simple cognac and cherry cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Combier Rouge Cherry liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with frosted blueberries and an edible flower.

*Blackberry syrup: Take 6 oz sugar, 6 oz water and 6 oz blackberries and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook for 20 minutes. Remove from heat, strain, and add salt to taste.

Author: Victoria D'amato-Moran
About: Find your center with this whiskey and green tea liqueur cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz Zen Green Tea Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass.

Add ice and stir briskly for 20 seconds.

Strain into a chilled 4 oz cocktail glass.

Garnish with a sugar covered cherry.

Author: Tommy Quimby
About: This coffee cocktail by Tommy Quimby at San Francisco’s Rich Table
Ingred: 1 oz Tempus Fugit crème de cacao
Instructions:
Add the fernet, creme and coffee to a heat-proof glass and stir.

Top with the cream.

*Pistachio whipped cream: Combine pistachio nut paste, sugar and heavy cream (to taste), and whip.

Author: Giuseppe Gonzalez
About: This rich and creamy rum-spiked Coquito is a classic Puerto Rican holiday cocktail recipe.
Ingred: 24 oz Cream of coconut (such as Coco Lopez)
750 ml White, añejo or spiced rum
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients except the rum in a saucepan over medium heat.

Bring to a simmer, stirring constantly.

Remove from the heat, let cool, and stir in the rum.

Transfer to bottles (making sure that at least one cinnamon stick goes into each bottle), seal and store in the refrigerator.

Serve over ice in rocks glasses.

Garnish with 2 cinnamon sticks.

About: When it comes to a Martini, some people believe the less vermouth you use, the more sophisticated the drink. On the other hand, when does a Martini stop being a Martini? This recipe evens the balance with equal measures of Bacardí Superior rum and Martini rosato vermouth.
Instructions:
Add the rum and vermouth in a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Author: Thor Slaughter
About: This pleasantly purple gin cocktail features a fermented Concord grape soda that Bar Tartine makes with local organic grape juice. (At home, you can use a good-quality grape soda like Boylan’s in its place.)
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fermented Concord grape soda 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Top with .75 to 1 ounce Concord grape soda.

Author: Anna Archibald
About: This cocktail combines blood orange and lemon oleo saccharum with gin and a little sherry to cut the sweetness.
Ingred: .5 oz Blood orange oleo saccharum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over 1 large ice cube.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
There’s little as refreshing during the summer swelter as a cool limeade. But when you add a bit of chile heat and tequila, well, that cooler gets a whole lot hotter.  
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 8 sprigs Cilantro leaves, plus a full sprig for garnish
Instructions:
Combine agave nectar, cilantro leaves and jalapeño slices in a shaking tin.

Muddle gently.

Add tequila, lime juice, and ice.

Shake and double strain into a collins or highball glass filled with ice.

Top with club soda.

Garnish with fresh sprig of cilantro.

Author: Sasha Petraske
About: This tasty gin and citrus cocktail comes from master mixologist Sasha Petraske.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

Drink Name: Knob Creek Horse's Neck (with a Kick)
Author: Knob Creek Bourbon
About: Extra-spicy ginger beer gives this old favorite new life.
Ingred: 1 dash Fee Brothers Old Fashion Bitters
1 Peel of a whole lemon (preferably in one piece)
Instructions:
Add the bourbon, bitters and lemon peel to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Top with the ginger beer and jiggle the glass lightly to combine.

Author: Death & Company
About: This complex Scotch drink inspires reverence.
Ingred: 2 oz Highland Park 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail or coupe glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Bartender Audrey Saunders is best known for her work at Soho’s Pegu Club, where her drink credits include this Mojito-meets–French 75 classic.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Muddle the lime juice, syrup and mint in a mixing glass.

Add the rum, bitters and ice and shake.

Double-strain into a coupe glass, and top with the Champagne.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Sweet but with a real kick, just like its namesake.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Nonna Titulauri
About: This month, as daytime skies grow dark for the first total solar eclipse in 38 years, you’ll want to find yourself a comfy perch, some protective eyewear and a tasty cocktail. We have you covered on the last one with this playful spin on a Rum Sour, made with activated charcoal and seasonal berries.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker, muddle the blackberries in a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients, and dry-shake (without ice) until the egg white turns foamy, for 20 seconds.

Add ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with 3 dashes of Angostura bitters.

About: This complex and spirit-forward cocktail is a showcase for award-winning single malt. And other delightfully unexpected ingredients elevate the scotch.
Ingred: .5 oz Pierre Ferrand dry curaçao.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing tin and stir.

Strain into a snifter glass.

Express a lemon peel over top.

Author: Trudy Thomas
About: Relax with this bubbly drink from Scottsdale, Ariz.’s Camelback Inn Resort & Spa.
Ingred: 1 oz lime sour (two parts organic lime juice, one part organic agave nectar)
.5 oz Square One Organic vodka.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the sparkling wine to a Champagne flute.

Top with sparkling wine.

Slap a thyme sprig once between your palms to release its oils.

Use it to stir the drink and leave it in as a garnish.

Author: Jacqui Berardi
About: You heard the cocktail: Drink up.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a cucumber slice and a mint sprig.

About: Love the Negroni? Try its south-of-the-border tequila cousin.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice or a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Kenta Goto, Bar Goto
About: This cocktail was created by Kenta Goto at Bar Goto for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add the cognac, plum wine and bitters to a highball glass.

Fill with ice, and top with the soda.

Stir gently to combine.

Author: Jeff Lyon
About: Try this bourbon and sherry creation from a top San Francisco bartender.
Instructions:
In a mixing glass filled with ice, add the bourbon, sherry, amaro, Bénédictine, and both bitters and stir.

Strain into an old- fashioned glass filled with one large ice cube.

Flame the orange peel over the glass and add.

Serve.

Author: Mike Criss
About: Not a fan of rum? Try this classic tiki drink with Chartreuse instead.
Ingred: 2 oz Base spirit (rum, Green Chartreuse, Campari or mezcal)
1 oz Coco Lopez cream of coconut
Garnish: Nutmeg cube of pineapple with two pineapple leaves
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with crushed ice.

Fill the top of the glass with crushed ice and top with nutmeg.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Sherry cocktails are getting a lot of love from the bartender community, and this underrated 19th-century drink is a delicious way to go.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with cracked ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe, and garnish with a lemon twist.

About: This recipe comes from Harry’s New York Bar in Paris. It’s said to be named after a World War I  U.S. army captain who used to be chauffeured to the bar in a motorcycle sidecar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a preserved cherry or orange peel.

About: A clever oatmeal-infused vodka is why this fall drink is truly unique.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 1⁄4 oz
1 dash Fee Brothers Black Walnut Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 25 seconds and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: This drink is delicately pink and 100 percent spa day, which is exactly how I imagine the life and times of Joan Collins.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker, muddle the lime, cucumber and mint.

Add the syrup and vodka with plenty of ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain over ice into a Collins glass, and top with soda water. Serve with a cucumber wheel for garnish.

*Honey-hibiscus syrup: Bring .5 cup of honey and .5 cup of water to simmer, stirring to incorporate.

Remove from heat, add 1 hibiscus tea bag, and let cool.

Remove the tea bag and store in the refrigerator for up to a month.

About: Try a sweet-tart Sidecar made with cognac and Cointreau.
Instructions:
Rim a cocktail glass with sugar.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake very gently.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Bulldog Gin
About: Once the mercury starts rising, it’s officially time to wheel out the lemonade. Since summer cocktails should be simple to stir together in the heat of the moment, there’s no better duo than Bulldog Gin and tart lemonade over ice. This simple tipple is a must when the temperature starts to rise.
Instructions:
Add the gin and lemonade to a double Old Fashioned glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Tequila and watermelon go together like summer and sunshine in this twist on the Paloma.
Garnish: Watermelon wedge and paprika sea salt rim
Instructions:
Rim a Collins glass with a paprika sea salt mixture.

Add all ingredients to a mixing glass except the seltzer and fill with ice.

Shake well and add the seltzer to the mixing glass.

Double strain into the rimmed Collins glass and garnish with watermelon wedge.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: A unique combination of gin, vermouth, sherry, absinthe and a French thyme liqueur.
Instructions:
Rinse a small coupe glass with absinthe and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir for 30 seconds and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a slice of lemon peel.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: After a long day shopping for the holidays, reward yourself with this Veev holiday cocktail.
Ingred: 3 oz Sparkling apple or pear cider
Instructions:
Muddle the mint and simple syrup in the bottom of a shaker.

Add VeeV Açaí Spirit, Green Chartreuse and ice.

Shake well.

Pour into a highball glass and top with sparkling cider.

Garnish with an apple chip.

Author: Naren Young
About: Like the traditional Pisco Sour? You’ll really love this fruit-filled take on the classic.
Instructions:
Add pisco, lime juice and the strawberry-rose syrup to a blender and add two scoops of ice.

Blend for 20 seconds.

Add egg white and blend again for five to 10 seconds.

Strain through a coarse strainer into glasses.

Author: Jenn Harvey
About:
Named for the command that Daenerys Targaryen uses to get her dragons to breathe fire in “Game of Thrones,” this kicky riff on a Dark ’N’ Stormy kinda does the same thing, says Jenn Harvey, the bar manager at Temple Bar in Cambridge, Mass. “While too much spice tends to kill people’s palates, this cocktail has an initial gentle heat that builds as you drink it, ultimately leading one to breath fire.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The 5 Recipe Variations Every Dark ’N’ Stormy Lover Should Know.”
Ingred: 2 oz Llanllyr Source Fiery ginger beer
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a double Old Fashioned glass with ice and stir.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

*Ancho-chile-infused bourbon: Slice up 3 large ancho chiles and place them into a jar along with 1 L bourbon. Let set for 24 hours, then strain out solids.

About: Sweet honey syrup adds another layer of flavor to the classic citrusy Sidecar.
Ingred: .5 oz Orange oil and chamomile tincture.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass.

*Honey syrup: In a saucepan, bring 2 parts water to 1 part honey to a boil and simmer until the honey has dissolved. Cool and store in the refrigerator until ready to use.

Author: Vermont Gold Vodka
About: Maple syrup, apple cider and Vermont vodka: How much more autumnal could you get?
Instructions:
Combine equal parts cinnamon and sugar on a shallow plate and use to coat the rim of a cocktail glass.

Add the vodka and maple syrup to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with the cider.

Author: Donna Scala
About: Mojito + ginger beer = refreshing and delicious.
Instructions:
In a highball glass, muddle the mint, lime juice and agave nectar.

Add the tequila and fill with ice.

Top with ginger beer and stir.

Garnish with a mint sprig and a lime wheel.

Author: Louis Hirsch
About: Louis Hirsch, the GM of Morels Steakhouse & Bistro
Instructions:
Combine the tequila, agave nectar and juice into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Float with the white zinfandel.

Cut a hole in the corner of a lemon wheel (so it looks like the Death Star) and garnish.

Add a straw.

Author: Austin Carson
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
1 oz Punt e Mes sweet vermouth
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, beginning with the bitters, and top with ice.

Stir (54 times) and strain into a chilled coupe.Stir (54 times) and strain into a chilled coupe.

Express lemon twist over the drink, and then drop it into the cocktail.

Author: David Wondrich
About: McKinley’s Delight was created in 1896 to celebrate the 25th president’s electionthis lost classic is a spin on the Manhattan. Many presidents had cocktails created in their honor, but few have stood the test of time. Created in 1896 during the 25th president’s election, the McKinley’s Delight is an exception. It incorporates classic elements from the Manhattan, but dresses them up for the special occasion with cherry liqueur and a dash of absinthe.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Cut a thin swatch of lemon peel, twist over the drink and discard.

Author: Tommy J Lansaw
About: This light and refreshing cocktail is perfect for brunch.
Garnish: 1 Half of a celery stalk and a few mint sprigs
Instructions:
Add cardamom pod and cucumber wheel to a shaker and muddle.  Add remaining ingredients (except for the soda) and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with soda water, leaving room for garnish.Make a small, lengthwise cut in the half celery stalk and place on the rim of the cocktail.

Slap the remaining mint sprigs on the palm of your hand to release the aromas and use them to garnish the drink.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: Though its name means incorrect Negroni, this bubbly punch is the right drink for your next party.
Instructions:
Add the vermouth and liqueur to a punch bowl and add large ice cubes or a large ice block.

Add the fruit and top with the prosecco.

Stir gently and garnish with freshly grated cinnamon.

Author: Lyn Farmer
About: This bitter-and-sweet gin cocktail is named for its lovely orange color.
Instructions:
Add the gin, St-Germain and Aperol to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Mark DeVito, Cease & Desist
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries and mint.

Add the gin, simple syrup and lime juice with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a Collins or Highball glass over ice, and top with the soda water.

To make punch, multiply by 4 and get after it!.

Author: Brian Miller
About: Enjoy your favorite rye whiskey in this Dubonnet and Cointreau drink from Brian Miller.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: A standout Daiquiri doesn’t need to be complicated or crowded with garnishes. You simply need quality ingredients, like Bacardí Superior.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Demerara syrup (equal parts demerara sugar and water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake until cold.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lime twist.

Author: Ryan Magarian
About: Seasonal blood orange and fresh sage make this gin cocktail a wintry delight.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the orange and sage.

Add the remaining ingredients and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake again, very hard.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with a sage leaf.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: Inspired by spring, this fruity vodka  drink combines floral and strawberry flavors.
Ingred: .5 oz Pear liqueur (such as Merlet Crème de Poire William).5 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker, and dry-shake (without ice).

Fill with ice, shake again, and strain into a coupe glass.

Spritz the top of the drink with lemon bitters in a spray bottle or atomizer.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: With celery, cilantro and cucumber, it’s like a liquid salad.
Ingred: Celery (use a piece closer to the heart for sweetness)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cucumber, celery, cilantro and lemon juice to a pulp.

Add the vodka, agave nectar and Pimm's, and fill with ice.

Shake hard for 10 seconds and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a leafy celery stalk from the heart.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About:
The Hot Toddy is the grandfather of hot cocktails. Equally at home in a snowbound mountain cabin as it is on an acclaimed cocktail menu, the Hot Toddy has one job that it takes quite seriously: warming you up.
The Hot Toddy has been linked to warming up winter nights next to a fireplace, as well as warding off colds. You can use any kind of whiskey you like in this hot and comforting classic, and the end result will be equally delicious. Grab your favorite mug, and get ready for a warm whiskey embrace.
Ingred: Boiling water, to fill a mug
2 tsp Demerara sugar or brown sugar
2 oz Bourbon, rye whiskey, Irish whiskey or scotch
Instructions:
Fill a mug with boiling water and let stand for a minute or two to warm.

Meanwhile, stick the cloves into the lemon twist and set aside.

Empty the mug and fill about halfway with fresh boiling water.

Add the sugar and stir to dissolve.

Add the prepared lemon twist and stir.

Add the lemon juice and whiskey, and stir again.

Author: Darren McGettigan
About: Irish whiskey puts on its summer wardrobe in this fruity tipple.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blueberries and sugar.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and double-strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with blueberries on a cocktail pick.

Author: ri(1) Whiskey
About: A perfect autumn cocktail, with rye whiskey and apple cider.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for at least 6 seconds.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with apple slices.

Ingred: 1⁄4 cup Diced fresh poblano pepper 1⁄4 cup
1⁄4 cup Diced roasted poblano pepper 1⁄4 cup
1 bottle Sauza Blue Silver Tequila or other blanco tequila
Instructions:
Combine the poblano and tequila in a large jar or other container with a lid.

Cover, and let stand for 1 week.

If the infusion is not spicy enough, add the habanero and let stand for 1 day more.

Strain before using.

About: When it’s blood orange season, do yourself a favor and add it to this take on a classic French 75.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with sparkling wine, and garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Pam Wiznitzer
About:
Rather than adding coffee as an ingredient, Pam Wiznitzer of New York City’s Seamstress infuses it straight into Campari liqueur. From there, you can make a Boulevardier or anything else with the liqueur, but the classic Negroni is the best way to go.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Coffee Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Add the infused liqueur, gin and vermouth into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.

Express an orange peel over the drink, and drop it in.

*Cold-brew-coffee-infused Campari liqueur: First fill a Mason jar or similar vessel halfway with coffee grounds, and pour in the Campari. Steep for as little as 10 minutes or as long as overnight, then strain the coffee out with a standard coffee filter.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Toast Papa Hemingway with this citrusy-and-complex rum concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe glass filled with crushed ice.

Author: Arturo Sighinolfi
About: Celebrate the red, white and green with a little Campari, lemon and rum.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, syrup and lemon juice. Add the Campari and rum, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with prosecco and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Kevin Denton
About: If you’d like to make your drink a festive shade of red for the holidays, try this vodka
Ingred: 1 oz Blood orange juice or puree
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Shake all of ingredients in a shaker with ice until chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with an edible orchid and orange rind.

Fill mixing glass with ingredients, add ice, and stir gently for 10-15 seconds.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: The Thomas
About: A coriander-pink peppercorn rhubarb shrub makes this tasty treat a complex spring cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a pickled rhubarb stalk.

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About:
The Tequila Sunrise, with it’s bright striations of color, evokes a summer sunrise. This simple classic has only three ingredients—tequila, grenadine and orange juice—and is served unmixed to preserve the color of each layer.
The Tequila Sunrise was created by Bobby Lozoff and Billy Rice in Sausalito, Calif. The cocktail achieved notoriety after Mick Jagger began drinking it, and The Rolling Stones dubbed their 1972 tour “the cocaine and Tequila Sunrise tour.” The drink has been a part of the cocktail canon ever since.
Ingred: 1.5 oz El Tesoro Reposado Tequila, chilled
Instructions:
Add the tequila and then the orange juice to a chilled highball glass.

Float the grenadine on top and garnish with an orange slice and a cherry.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: This punny cocktail is Absolut-ly delectable.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blueberries.

Add the vodka, lime juice and simple syrup, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne and garnish with 3 blueberries on a toothpick.

Author: Nahm Kim, Sunda
About: This cocktail was created by Nahm Kim at Sunda for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a snifter glass.

To garnish, twist an orange peel over the surface of the glass to express its oils, then discard.

Float the star anise in the glass.

Author: Hastings Cameron
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. Hastings Cameron, a bartender at several Madison, Wisc., bars, including Imaginary Bar, describes this cocktail tribute to the Green Bay Packers as a “perverse Shamrock shake,” in which the mint and fennel of Strega are fortified by similar notes in gin from Death’s Door Spirits, a Wisconsin distillery. 
“I grew up in Chicago rooting for the Packers as a little contrarian,” says Cameron. “As an adult, I still love blue and orange (mostly orange) but couldn’t possibly care less about the Bears, or the Cubs for that matter,” he says. While this drink was purely aesthetically inspired by the Packers’ team colors—“Lil Wayne didn’t need anything more than the team’s colors to inspire this,” says Cameron—it involves a pretty complex matcha foam, evidence of Cameron’s tendency toward molecular gastronomy-like bartending. 
The booziness of the cocktail is inspired by the ice-cold winters in Wisconsin. “Drink builds tend to swell in volume the farther north we get from Madison. The 2.5 ounces of 80-plus-proof booze is a nod to that cultural imperative,” he says.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Clear Creek muscat grappa 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz St. George Spirits Green Chile vodka 1⁄4 oz
2 drops Saline solution (or tiny pinch of salt)
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a coupe, express the oil of a lime peel, and garnish with the peel.

Top with matcha foam.

*Matcha foam: Whisk 10 grams matcha with 600 grams hot water. Divide the tea evenly into 2 plastic containers. While still hot, add .95 percent gelatin by mass to the first container and whisk. Allow the second container to cool, then whisk in 2 percent xanthan gum by mass. Combine the two containers, and whisk in 1 barspoon hydrated gomme. Whisk in 100 grams of simple syrup and a pinch of ascorbic acid. Place in an ice bath to cool completely. Fill an iSi canister with ice water to cool. After 15 minutes, empty the water and fill the canister with the matcha foam base. Screw on the lid, add charge, shake, vent, add second charge, shake, vent, add third charge, shake, vent.

Author: Ryan Puckett
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Demerara syrup (1 part demerara sugar, 1 part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Using an atomizer, spritz several squeezes of absinthe into a double rocks glass, thoroughly coating the interior.

Shake out the excess.

Add remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir vigorously, and strain into the double rocks glass.

Fill with cubed ice and garnish with a dried orange slice.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
This teal-blue Shandy, named for Jacksonville, Fla., Jaguars owner Shad Khan, is made using some of Restaurant Orsay bartender Josh Strickland’s favorite local ingredients: beer from Intuition Ale Works (which is adjacent to Everbank Field, home of the Jags), rum from Marlin & Barrel distillery in nearby Fernandina Beach and a fresh Florida orange slice. 
“This is perfect for those über-hot Florida tailgates early in the year. It’s bright and refreshing without being so boozy that you’re in trouble before the fourth quarter starts,” says Strickland. “If you are a savvy tailgater, you will cook up a batch beforehand and simply top them off with beer and ‘blue stuff’ as you go.”
Ingred: Local Intuition Ale Works Jon Boat ale Local Intuition Ale Works Jon Boat ale
Instructions:
Add the rum, lemon juice, syrup and bitters to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Collins glass (or red Solo cup) over ice, and top with the beer.

Float a pour of the blue curaçao on top, and garnish with half an orange wheel.

*Honey syrup: Add .25 cup water and .5 cup honey to a small saucepan over medium heat, and stir until the honey completely melts. Strain into a jar and seal with a lid.

Author: Absolut Vodka
Ingred: 3⁄4 pt Honey syrup (1 part honey, 1 part water) 3⁄4 pt
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne and garnish with a grapefruit and lemon twist. .

About: This classic is named for the hotel where it was invented.
Instructions:
Pour the gin, Bénédictine and cherry brandy into a sling or highball glass.

Fill with ice and top with club soda.

Squeeze a lime wedge over the drink, drop it into the glass and stir.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: This easy-to-make peppermint syrup is a versatile base for spring entertaining.
Instructions:
In a saucepan, bring the water to a boil.

Add peppermint tea bags and steep for 3 minutes.

Remove the tea bags and add the sugar, stirring until it dissolves.

Let the syrup cool; it can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: This fiery and refreshing concoction is ideal for summer.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with honey sugar, fill with ice and set aside.

In a shaker, muddle the watermelon and chiles.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a watermelon wedge, a whole serrano chile and a mint sprig.

Author: Jimmy Russell
About: Named for Jimmy Russell’s 56 years distilling Wild Turkey.
Glass: Silver julep cup or double Old Fashioned
Instructions:
In a traditional silver julep cup or double Old Fashioned glass, muddle the mint, brown sugar and 1 ounce of the bourbon.

Add the ice and remaining bourbon, and garnish with a sprig of mint.

Author: Beau Williams
About:
The staff at Kansas City, Mo.’s Julep Cocktail Club wanted a seasonal take on the classic Old Fashioned that emphasized some of fall’s favorite flavors and ingredients. This recipe from co-owner and bar manager Beau Williams uses Barbadian rum, which lightens the drink, and apple cider syrup for added sweetness. Bonus: The syrup can be further reduced and drizzled over everything from warm apple pie a la mode and coffee cake to pancakes and waffles.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “So You Love a Whiskey Old Fashioned. How About the Rise of the Rum Old Fashioned?”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass.

Express the oil of an orange twist over the drink, then drop the twist into the drink.

*Apple cider syrup: In a small saucepan, combine 1 cup apple cider and 2 cups brown sugar on medium heat, stirring constantly to emulsify the sugar. Once the liquid reaches a boil, reduce the heat to a simmer, and continue to stir occasionally until the liquid’s consistency coats the back of a spoon. Add 1 pinch salt, stir, remove it from the heat, and allow it to cool. Transfer the syrup to a Mason jar, and store for up to 2 weeks in the refrigerator.

Ingred: .5 oz Pear liqueur – can sub for fresh pear Juice or nectar(0.75 oz).5 oz
Instructions:
Shake all with ice and serve in a double rocks glass with ice.

Garnish with lemon swath and pear fan.

Author: Allen Katz
About: This extra-citrusy cousin of the Daiquiri gets a kick from Cointreau.
Ingred: 2 oz White rum (Flor de Caña 4-Year-Old Extra Dry)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a lime half-wheel.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: A classic cocktail made with one of the world’s classic rums, this Mai Tai mixes up tropical flavors like almond and spice to become your next Tiki go-to.
Instructions:
Add the BACARDÍ Superior rum, curaçao, juice and orgeat into a shaker with crushed ice and shake lightly (about 3 seconds).

Pour into a double Old Fashioned glass, then float the BACARDÍ Black rum.

Garnish with a lime wheel and mint sprig.

Author: Liquor.com
About: Who says you can’t have spring and summer all in one glass? Two warm-weather booze titans come together in this fun, fizzy punch of sparkling rosé and strawberry- and basil-infused tequila. Pro tip: Opt for a bubbly on the drier side to keep the flavors from leaning too sweet.
Instructions:
In a punch bowl, combine the tequila, lime juice and agave syrup.

Add cubed ice, and stir with a ladle to mix.

Top with the sparkling rosé.

Garnish with 1 cup sliced strawberries and lime wheels from 2 limes.

Rim punch glasses with rose salt before serving (optional).

*Strawberry-basil-infused blanco tequila: In a glass jar, combine 1/2 cup sliced strawberries and 1/2 cup fresh basil leaves with 1 750 mL bottle blanco tequila. Seal jar tightly and let sit, unrefrigerated, for 3-5 days. Shake daily. Strain out solids, and rebottle the infused tequila.

** Rose salt: Add 4 tbsp sea salt and 1 tbsp dried rose buds to a mortar and pestle, and gently grind. Place on a small plate for rimming.

Author: Tim Laird
About: A refreshing Margarita with a cucumber twist.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cucumber and lime wedges.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice and lime wedge.

Author: Dan Q. Dao
About: This layered shot originated around the early ’90s in the U.S. and is meant to be imbibed hands-free.
Instructions: In a shot glass, slowly pour the amaretto, then the Irish cream, and top it with the whipped cream without mixing. .

Author: The Hideout
About: The distinct flavor of maple syrup turns this tropical drink into something more complex.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a piece of pineapple leaf.

Ingred: 2 cup Peas, removed from their pods
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a blender and puree until smooth, about 30 seconds.

Author: Gary Regan
About: Before it called for rye whiskey, the New Orleans classic was made with cognac.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled Old Fashioned glass with the absinthe, fill with crushed ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir.

Discard the ice and any excess absinthe from the prepared glass and strain the drink into it.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Nicolas Bouriache
About: Its flavor is full-size.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint and lime.

Add the rum and agave nectar, and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a highball glass.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Taha Ismail
About: Beverage director Taha Ismail wanted to do a seasonal riff on a Pisco Sour
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the rosé to a shaker, and dry-shake (no ice).

Add ice and shake until chilled.

Add the sparkling rosé to a Collins glass, and strain the cocktail on top.

Top with fresh ice, and garnish with a mint sprig.

*Mandarin cordial: In a blender, combine 3 cups mandarin juice, 2 ½ cups granulated sugar, 1 ¼ oz Everclear, 1 oz yuzu juice and ¼ tsp xanthan gum, and blend until smooth.

Author: Willy Shine
About: Strong black tea and spices give this Irish-whiskey-and-apple-juice tipple a kick.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
3⁄4 oz Irish Spiced Tea Syrup 3⁄4 oz
1 oz Pressed apple juice (or non-alcoholic apple cider)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About:
“The Moscow Mule is a classic vodka-based cocktail for a reason. Speaking the name of the cocktail conjures up images of the sweating copper mug that’s the de rigeur vessel for the Moscow Mule. While said mug is preferred for serving, it’s not necessary and shouldn’t deter you from making a Moscow Mule.
The Moscow Mule was in born the 1950s during the heydey of vodka. And this organic version brings the legendary drink up to date while remaining true to its refreshing roots. Combining ginger beer, lime juice and vodka, the Moscow Mule is deceptively simple and incredibly easy to mix, making it perfect for any season.”
Instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a Moscow Mule mug (or highball glass) filled with ice, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Adam McDowell
About: Adam McDowell’s book Drinks: A User’s Guide
Instructions:
Pour the vodka into the chocolate milk carton, close the spout, and shake.

Drink through a straw, if available.

About: A little bit of Tiki meets cognac in this stirred cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Pierre Ferrand dry orange curaçao 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain over a 2” x 2” ice cube in a rocks glass.

Garnish with dehydrated clementine.

About: Mixing up the Greyhound is as quick as its namesake.
Instructions:
Add the vodka to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Top with grapefruit juice and stir.

Garnish with a lemon or lime wedge.

(To make a Salty Dog, coat the rim of the glass with salt and leave out the garnish.).

Author: Dale DeGroff
About:
The Margarita is one of the most popular cocktails in North America—for good reason. Combining the tang of lime and the sweetness of orange liqueur with the distinctive strength of tequila, our classic Margarita strikes all of the right keys.
Although many people reach for premade sour mix, we highly recommend using fresh lime juice. The end result is—let’s face it—superior. 
When talking Margaritas, it’s easy to get lost in stories about who invented the drink or get mired in debates over salt versus no salt; blended or frozen; triple sec, Cointreau or Grand-Marnier. In our opinion, this version is the tried-and-true recipe for the best Margarita you can make. Memorize it, and you’ll always impress.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fresh squeezed lime juice 3⁄4 oz
1 oz Cointreau, triple sec or another orange liqueur
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

For a slightly sweeter drink, add a dash of agave syrup (one part water, two parts agave nectar) before shaking..

Author: Elizabeth Blau
About:
The green juice used in this drink has been a staple since Las Vegas’ Honey Salt opened. “We wanted to offer a lighter cocktail option where you can get your nutrients and a buzz in one glass,” says Elizabeth Blau, the founder and CEO of restaurant planning and development company Blau + Associates.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 Vegetable-Heavy Cocktails You Can Make at Home.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

*Green goodness juice: Add 3-5 kale leaves and stalks, 1 whole lemon, 2 stalks celery, 1-inch piece of peeled ginger, 1 cucumber and 2 Granny Smith apples to a juicer. Juice all ingredients and strain out solids.

Author: Kenta Goto
About: By adding a jolt of sesame to this milk punch with matcha, the cocktail becomes fuller and rounder, a harmony of fresh green and deep, nutty flavors. Just as sesame successfully amplifies food, it provides another subtle layer to drinks.
Instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin, and dry shake to aerate. Shake with ice, and fine-strain into a ceramic teacup.

Author: Travis St. Germain
About: Bourbon, kumquats and oregano make unlikely, yet delicious associates in this herbaceous Smash.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the kumquats and simple syrup.

Add remaining ingredients and fill shaker with 6 Kold Draft ice cubes.

Pour the mixture, unstrained, into a frozen rocks glass.

Garnish with a wreath of oregano.

Author: Allen Katz
About: The secret to this gorgeous tipple is chilled hibiscus tea.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: ri(1) Whiskey
About: Spike your iced tea with rye whiskey.
Ingred: .5 oz Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water).5 oz
3 oz Brewed tea (Kashmiri Spiced Tea), chilled
Garnish: 1 2 Lemon wheels and freshly grated nutmeg
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass, fill with ice and stir.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with 2 lemon wheels and freshly grated nutmeg.

About:
The Singapore Sling was originally served at Long Bar in the Raffles hotel in Singapore around the turn of the century. The original recipe is attributed to Raffles bartender Ngiam Tong Boon and is a variant on the Gin Sling. 
Our recipe evokes the classic recipe, which is fruit-forward, herbaceous and strong, though most incarnations of the “classic” Singapore Sling are based on general notes and nostalgia. Later, more modern incarnations of the drink created an overly sweet drink based more on grenadine than citrus. The earliest published version of the recipe was in the 1930 classic by Harry Craddock, “The Savoy Cocktail Book.” David A. Embury states in his book “The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks” that no two published recipes for the Singapore Sling are the same. 
What does that mean? The Singapore Sling is a classic and refreshing cocktail that’s fun to experiment with. Our recipe below is as true to the classic as we can get, but you should feel free to experiment and come up with your own version.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass.

Fill with club soda and garnish with an orange slice and a cherry.

Author: Galliano
About: The Harvey Wallbanger is a modern classic that combines a Screwdriver with the Italian liqueur Galliano. Reportedly born in the 50s, the cocktail was a hit in the 1970s. Recently, Galliano converted back to their original recipe so try this drink today if you want to relive the golden days of disco.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and the orange juice to a tall glass filled with ice.

Stir, and float the Galliano on top.

Garnish with an orange slice..

Author: Joey Picchi
About: This frothy chamomile and gin recipe is on the the menu at San Francisco cocktail bar Oddjob.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker.

Dry shake until the ingredients emulsify.

Fill the shaker with ice and shake again until well chilled.

Double strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with chamomile dust and burnt rosemary.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: A spot of coffee never sounded so good.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Brown sugar syrup, if desired 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a mug or heat-proof highball glass and stir.

Spoon about 2 tbsp of whipped cream on top.

Author: Brian Miller
About: This voluptuous rye-based cocktail packs a wallop.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Maker's Mark
About: Swap gin for bourbon to create a tasty spin on the classic Tom Collins.
Instructions:
Add the bourbon, lemon juice and sugar to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with an orange wheel and a maraschino cherry.

Author: Jamie Gordon
About: This boozy classic is named for the French word for jewel.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Nicholas Boden
About:
Head bartender Nicholas Boden invented a caffeinated, bittersweet take on the classic Chocolate Martini for his bar at Tavernonna Italian Kitchen, in Kansas City, Mo.’s Hotel Phillips. The foamy drink uses Italian amaro to complement the Italian cuisine served at the restaurant, and the drink is topped with three coffee beans meant to represent health, happiness and prosperity.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Coffee Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Chill a Nick & Nora glass with ice and set aside.

Brew a shot of espresso, and pour into a shaker over ice.

Quickly strain the ice out to avoid dilution.

Add the amaro and liqueur to the shaker, add ice, and shake vigorously to foam the espresso.

Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

Garnish with 3 coffee beans.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Drink this tart and fizzy rum cooler to escape the heat.
Ingred: 3 oz Pink grapefruit soda (Ting or Izze)
Garnish: 1 Lime wheel or long lime twist
Instructions:
Add the rum and lime juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the grapefruit soda and garnish with a lime wheel or long lime twist.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Drink like the husband-and-wife detective team in The Thin Man.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Prat dry vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add both the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a small Spanish olive without pimento.

Author: Kyle Darrow
About:
Monaco Hotel lead bartender Kyle Darrow macerates sugar-coated brûléed banana slices and cinnamon sticks in bourbon for at least a week. For the drink, he flambés blueberries, brown sugar and overproof rum in a Julep tin, sprinkles it with cinnamon, crushes the mixture into a slurry and extinguishes the flame. He adds the infused bourbon and crushed ice and swizzles it, garnishing the drink with skewered blueberries and banana chips. “If you would throw it on your oatmeal at breakfast, it’ll probably taste good infused with bourbon,” he says.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “9 Infused Bourbon Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
Instructions:
Combine the blueberries and brown sugar in a Julep tin, and dash some overproof rum on top.

Quickly light the mixture, and while it’s burning, sprinkle ground cinnamon on top. (Be careful as it may spark.).

Use a large muddler to crush the mixture into a slurry and extinguish the flame.

Add the banana-infused bourbon and crushed ice, and quickly swizzle.

Top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with skewered blueberries and banana chips.

*Banana-infused bourbon: Slice 3 or 4 peeled overly ripe bananas into 1/2-inch pieces. Sprinkle sugar in the raw on top of them, and with a culinary torch, brûlée them. Combine the prepared bananas, 1 cinnamon stick and 1 L bourbon in a large jar. Keep it in a cool dark space, and allow to infuse for at least 1 week. Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve, then again through double-layered cheesecloth. Allow it to rest overnight, and strain again through cheesecloth if necessary.

Author: Steve Schneider
About: Mezcal shoots to kill in Steve Schneider’s smoky cocktail that’s bolstered by chile-tinged bitters and a homemade honey-pineapple syrup for sweet balance.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a grind of pink peppercorn.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: This drink a tart and boozy riff on a Whiskey Sour
Instructions:
Fill a Julep cup with crushed ice, add the Jim Beam, and stir for 30 seconds.

Add the Mike’s Hard Lemonade, and top off with more crushed ice.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: This tequila shot recipe is perfect for the holidays.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a shot glass with cinnamon and sugar, and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Absolut Vodka makes an unexpected friend of Amaro Montenegro in this finely balanced libation.
Ingred: .5 pt Brown sugar syrup (1 part brown sugar, 1 part water).5 pt
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel. .

Author: Morten Sohlberg
About: This warming Scandinavian tipple is just what you need during chilly winter months.
Ingred: 1 Large orange's peel, cut into large strips
Fresh ginger, peeled and crushed slightly with the back of a spoon
Instructions:
Add the water, brandy, orange peel, vanilla extract, ginger and spices a large saucepan and bring to a boil over high heat.

Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10 minutes.

Add the remaining ingredients and simmer for one minute, stirring until the sugar dissolves.

Strain out the cloves and orange peel and decant into a serving vessel, leaving behind as much of the other spices as possible.

Serve in mugs garnished with raisins and sliced blanched almonds.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Rhubarb’s uniquely tart flavor is an ideal backbone for this complex vodka cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an apple fan on a cocktail pick.

Drink Name: Set the New Year on Fire
Author: Yael Vengroff
About: This New Year’s Eve-inspired libation comes with all the pyrotechnics.
Ingred: 2 oz Bowmore 12 Years Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add the lime juice, cane syrup, and mint leaves to a Collins glass and press gently with a muddler.

Add the Scotch and fill with crushed ice.

Float the Campari on top and fill with more crushed ice.

Garnish with a flaming lime shell.

Author: Brandon Josie, 15 Romolo, San Francisco
About: Caramelized-pineapple syrup makes this tropical rum drink something very special.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine-strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with a splash of club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Tobin Ellis, BarMagic
About: Watermelon juice should be a more common part of your summer cocktails. Start here.
Instructions:
Place one large ice cube into an old fashioned glass and add all the ingredients.

Stir well and garnish with a pinch of cracked black pepper and a small edible orchid.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Yellow Chartreuse adds extra spice to this classic ginger-and-vodka cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a copper mug filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Everyone loves Sriracha, that famous spicy condiment. Put it on some shrimp for a perfect taco that’s as crowd-pleasing as it is delicious.
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great hot-weather tequila drinks.
Ingred: Corn tortillas, warmed in an oven or on a grill
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Place a wire rack on a baking sheet. Pat the shrimp dry with paper towels. Using two skewers side by side, skewer the shrimp snugly against each other, about 5 shrimp per set of skewers. Place the skewers on to the prepared rack.

Whisk together 2 tbsp olive oil and 2 tbsp Sriracha, and use a grill brush to evenly coat both sides of the skewered shrimp. Sprinkle evenly with salt and pepper. Refrigerate for half an hour.

Bring a grill or grill pan to high heat and use tongs to place the shrimp firmly onto the grill, letting cook for 3 to 4 minutes on each side or until cooked through and charred outside. Transfer the skewers to a plate and use tongs to slide the shrimp off the skewers.

Use a fork to combine the remaining 2 tbsp of Sriracha with the mayonnaise. Assemble the tacos starting with a few shrimp, followed by the red cabbage slaw and Sriracha mayo. Serve with lime.

*Red cabbage slaw: Whisk together 1/3 cup sour cream, 1 tbsp olive oil and 1 tbsp lime juice in a medium bowl. Add 2 cups thinly sliced red cabbage (from about half of a small red cabbage), 1/2 cup chopped green onion and 1/2 cup shredded carrot (from about 1 large carrot), and toss to coat evenly. Season with salt and pepper.

Author: Dre Masso
About: Pucker up for this gin, Bénédictine and lemon juice combo.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with an orange wedge and cherry.

Author: Employees Only
About: Try the delicious and simple rum-based Hemingway Daiquiri. Papa approved!
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel and black cherry on a skewer.

Author: Brian Miller
About: Like Martinis? Try this complex drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: David Kupchinsky
About: Add a touch of pineapple juice and apricot brandy to a classic Daiquiri to get this delicious concoction.
Ingred: .5 oz Petite Canne Sugar Cane Syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with large, cold ice cubes.

Shake, and double-strain into a coupe glass.

About: New to absinthe? This classic cocktail is for you.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker add the absinthe and anisette.

Fill with ice and shake well until chilled.

Strain into a julep cup filled with crushed ice.

Top with additional ice and garnish with the mint sprig.

Author: Eben Klemm
About: Expand your citrus horizons with this tangerine drink.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the tangerine.

Add the tequila and fill with ice.

Shake 20 times and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a kaffir lime leaf.

Author: Jaime Salas
About: Add some spice to the classic tequila cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Rub the lime wedge along the rim of an Old Fashioned glass and dip the rim into salt to coat it.

Fill the glass with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and double-strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with the lime wedge.

About: Go old-school with this straightforward whiskey and beer concoction.
Instructions:
Pour the whiskey into a shot glass.

Fill a pint glass halfway with beer.

Drop the shot glass into the beer.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About:
This blended cocktail proves there’s more to cachaça than just Caipirinhas. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Funky Rum. Everything You Need to Know About the Booming Trend.”
Ingred: 1 oz BG Reynolds passion fruit syrup
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a blender with 1/2 cup of ice, and blend until smooth.

Pour into a rocks glass over pebble ice.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

Author: Kenny Freeman
About: Chamomile gin and pineapple juice? This cocktail from Houston cocktail bar Julep is delightfully unexpected.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the apple cider to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh crushed ice.

Fill the top of the glass with crushed ice and layer the apple cider on top.

Garnish with chamomile buds and serve with a long straw.

About: This cocktail is named for the Gaelic hag goddess of winter, Cailleach Bheur, to whom the great Corryvreckan serves as laundry basin. The use of preserved citrus and seed serve as ode to her season’s bounty, with a crack of pepper to highlight the malt’s spice.
Ingred: 2⁄3 oz Rich fennel seed syrup 2⁄3 oz
Garnish: Dehydrated lemon slice; Fennel frond; Black pepper
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda water into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into Collins glass over two large chunks of ice, and fill with the soda water, being careful to pour directly onto the surface of the liquid to keep carbonation intact.

Garnish with a dehydrated lemon slice, a large frond of fresh fennel and a twist of freshly ground black pepper.

*Rich fennel seed syrup: Pour 1 cup very hot water over 1 oz cracked fennel seeds. Add 2 cups granulated sugar, and stir until dissolved. Let cool, then strain.

**Puréed preserved lemon: Purée store-bought or homemade preserved lemons. If you don’t have a blender, muddle a small piece of preserved lemon.

About: For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. This drink by Matthew Polzin of The Olde Bar is inspired by the Philadelphia Eagles, whose team color is represented by the Green Chartreuse and team’s eagle represented on the bottle of Fernet-Branca
Instructions:
Add the cognac, rye, Chartreuse and bitters to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.

Add a splash of the fernet to a rocks glass, roll the glass to coat the sides, and discard the excess.

Add one large ice cube to the glass, strain the drink over the cube, and garnish with a mint sprig.

About: A perfectly decadent after-dinner treat for your next party. Set out a few bottles of your favorite spirits and liqueurs and let your guests choose their own adventure.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Spirit of choice (Kahlúa, Baileys Irish Cream, peppermint schnapps, Green Chartreuse or bourbon)
Instructions:
Put the chopped chocolate in an Irish Coffee mug.

Pour the hot milk into the mug and let stand for 2 minutes, then stir with a spoon until smooth.

Pour in the spirit of your choice and stir to combine.

Garnish with mini marshmallows.

Author: Laura Bellucci
About: At New Orleans’ delightful SoBou
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Laura’s Thai chili sauce 3⁄4 oz
Garnish: Speared basil leaf and lime peel
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake well.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a speared basil leaf and lime peel.

*Laura's Thai chili sauce (makes a large batch): Chop 10 cloves garlic, 2 green peppers and 1/4 cup chopped ginger. Add all to a saucepan seasoned with 3 tbsp soybean, vegetable or coconut oil. Add 1 tsp sesame oil, and let simmer for 5 minutes. Pour 1 qt water and 1 1/2 qts rice vinegar into a saucepan, and bring to a boil over high heat. Stir in 2 qts sugar, 2 tbsp soy sauce and 1/8 cup red pepper flakes. Add ground pepper to taste. Simmer on low for 20 minutes. Stir in 1 tbsp cornstarch. Remove saucepan from stove to cool, then transfer to an airtight jar. Save for cocktails or dipping sauce.

Author: Dan Q. Dao
About: The classic Gimlet takes gin, but many opt for this vodka version.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Will Thompson
About: Strawberry-infused rum is a must in this summer cocktail with just a hint of spice.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Vance Henderson
About: It’s hard to deny that spaghetti squash seems like a head-scratcher of a cocktail ingredient, much like tequila
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients into a mixing glass and stir until the glass begins to cloud.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

*Spaghetti squash cordial: Add 1.5 cups of squash purée, 1 cup of granulated sugar and 1 sprig of rosemary to a heavy-bottom saucepan, and bring to a rolling simmer over medium heat, stirring slowly. Remove from the heat and let cool. Strain through fine-mesh cloth into a clean bowl, and stir in 1 cup of vodka to the mixture until combined. Use immediately or refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
Sangria is most often made with wine. But when you swap the grape stuff for tequila and toss in some tropical fruit, a good drink gets a little more interesting. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 1.5 cup Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now
Instructions:
Makes 6.

Combine all ingredients except champagne in a pitcher.

Add ice and stir to incorporate.

Pour into serving glasses with fresh ice and top individual servings with champagne.

Author: Audrey Saunders
About: Pear eau de vie and dry Riesling make natural mates in this gently spiced coupe.
Ingred: 1 oz Poire William Eau de Vie
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into coupe.

Garnish with star anise.

Author: El Jimador Tequila
About: The tequila-based Paloma is perfect after a hard day of work.
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a tall glass and fill with ice.

Author: Kim Haasarud
About: Celebrate in style.
Ingred: 1 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
1.5 oz Moët & Chandon Rosé Imperial Champagne
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the raspberries and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients except the Champagne and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a mint spring and a raspberry.

Author: Jaime Salas
About: This complex combo of tequila and sherry with chocolate and spice is sophisticated and delicious.
Ingred: .5 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Cut a long swatch of orange peel with a vegetable peeler, twist over the drink, rub along the rim of the glass and use as garnish.

Author: David Wondrich
About: The Ward Eight, a turn-of-the-20th-century concoction, is one of Boston’s major contributions to mixology.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with 2 speared cherries.

Author: Kimber Weissert
Ingred: 2 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
Garnish: Amarena cherry on a cocktail pin
Instructions:
Add the bourbon, vermouth and bitters to Yarai mixing glass.

Add ice and stir well.

Author: Jorge Vargas Baquedano
Ingred: 1 oz Martini & Rossi Rosso Sweet Vermouth
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Express the oils from an orange peel over the top of the drink and garnish with a new orange peel.

Author: Purely Syrup
About: Grapefruit adds a welcome citrus note to this New Orleans specialty.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir for approximately eight seconds.

Spray absinthe into a cocktail glass with a spritzer. Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with grapefruit peel.

Author: Karen Grill
About: Channel the alien planet from Star Wars with this creamy combination of gin, coconut cream and blue curaçao.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a milk bottle or Collins glass.

Author: Raul Yrastorza
About: Mezcal in a Martini? Try this olive juice-spiked concoction.
Ingred: 2 oz Del Maguey Santo Domingo Albarradas mezcal
.5 oz Dirty Sue olive juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with Kalamata olives.

About: The mouthwatering mix of spirits in the Rapscallion strike a delicate, delicious balance. The result is proof that fine single malt loves company.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Gonzalez-Byass Nectar PX sherry 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to ice filled mixing glass, stir until cold.

Strain and serve up Stirred in a single (small) rocks glass with a Laphroaig scotch rinse.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Get transported to Jamaica with this coconut and pineapple concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Combier
About: Drink like a blue blood for the evening.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint and lemon.

Add the Royal Combier and fill with ice.

Shake hard and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a fresh mint sprig.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Childhood memories of apple cider with a little something extra to remind you why being an adult is OK, too.
Ingred: 2 oz Bonded applejack (Laird’s), cognac or bourbon
Instructions:
Fortunately, the labor-intensive part of this drink lies solely in baking the apples.

Take half as many Macintosh apples as you'd like to make drinks, core them, peel them and wrap them in wet parchment paper.

Bake them in a 350-degree oven for 30 to 45 minutes until completely soft.

Set aside until cool.

For each drink, warm a heatproof mug by rinsing it with boiling water.

Put in half a baked apple and a heaping teaspoon of sugar and muddle them quickly together.

Add 1 ounce of boiling water and stir.

Add the applejack, cognac or bourbon and stir again.

Add 1 ounce of boiling water.

(The staggered addition of the water keeps the drink as hot as possible).

Grate nutmeg over the top and serve.

Author: Michael Dietsch
About: This 1970s-era drink, named for the popular film The Godfather, is often made with equal parts, but this version from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, add the ingredients, and stir until chilled.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

About: The Gin Rickey is delicious whether it’s made with gin or whiskey.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with ice and add the gin or bourbon.

Juice the lime halves into the glass and drop in the juiced lime shells.

Fill with club soda.

Author: Kevin Martin
About: Try this spiced summertime take on the classic cold-weather toddy.
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a pitcher and stir to combine.

Garnish with whole star anise pods and thinly sliced lemon wheels.

(This recipe makes 4 servings.).

Author: Moon Mountain Vodka
About: This is a fruitier take on the classic grapefruit concoction.
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Moon Mountain Wild Raspberry Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a rocks glass with salt.

Fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit peel and/or a fresh rosemary sprig.

Author: Gosling's Rum
About:
The Dark ’n Stormy is a simple but delicious two-ingredient cocktail of dark rum (the “dark”) and ginger beer (the “stormy”).
It’s usually garnished with a lime wedge. But any way it’s served, the Dark ’n Stormy is tasty and refreshing.
Ingred: Stormy ginger beer, to top Stormy ginger beer, to top
Instructions:
Fill a tall glass with ice, and add the rum.

Top with the ginger beer.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

About: This bourbon cocktail will get you out of any sticky situation.
Instructions:
Add bourbon, ginger ale and soda water to an old fashioned glass and fill with ice.

Float bitters on top.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Take a sip, close your eyes and soak up the sun.
Instructions:
Add the Van Gogh Coconut Vodka, Van Gogh Pineapple Vodka and pineapple juice to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice. Shake and pour into a Martini glass.

Add splash of grenadine and garnish with a pineapple wedge.

Author: Erick Castro
About:
The Mint Julep is a bourbon cocktail best known for being the signature drink of the Kentucky Derby. But this easy-to-make refresher shouldn’t be reserved for only one day a year. This classic cocktail was created in the southern United States during the 18th century and is still a favorite today. 
The Mint Julep is traditionally served in a Highball glass or silver Julep cup over crushed ice and garnished with mint. Since bourbon is the only liquid in the drink, you’ll want to use a high-quality bourbon you know you love.
Instructions:
In a Julep cup or rocks glass, lightly muddle the mint and syrup.

Add the bourbon and pack tightly with crushed ice.

Stir until the cup is frosted on the outside.

Top with more crushed ice to form an ice dome and garnish with a few drops of bitters, if desired, and a mint sprig.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: A three-note combination of creamy caramel, rich java and smooth vodka.
Ingred: 2 oz Van Gogh Dutch Caramel Vodka
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a rocks glass and fill with ice.

Stir to combine.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Sweet, tart and ice cold. Plus a big slug of tequila.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Add water and sugar to a small saucepan over medium heat.

Stir until sugar is dissolved.

Let cool, then stir in the vanilla extract.

Strain into a jar or bottle and seal tightly with a lid.

Author: Gary Regan
About:
The White Russian is decadent and sophisticated. Combining vodka, Kahlúa and cream and serving it on the rocks create a delicious alternative to adult milkshakes. 
The White Russian came about in the ’60s when someone added a bit of cream to the Black Russian. It would be a great story to say that the White Russian’s star rose from that point on, but unfortunately that would not be true.
The truth is the White Russian suffered a bit from a stodgy, antiquated reputation until the 1998 movie “The Big Lebowski” came along and breathed new life into the cocktail with Jeff Bridge’s character, The Dude, sipping it exclusively.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and Kahlúa to an Old Fashioned glass filled with ice.

Top with a large splash of heavy cream and stir.

Author: Tony Abou-Ganim
About: It would be rude not to introduce yourself to the neighborhood with this delightful Negroni recipe.
Ingred: 1 oz Martini and Rossi Sweet Vermouth
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until well chilled and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a flamed orange twist.For the Italian version, add all the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Austin Carson
Ingred: 1 3⁄4 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except the tea in a tabletop electric tea kettle.

Bring to a boil and quickly remove.

Place the tea in a tea strainer, and place the strainer over a pouring vessel.

Pour the hot cocktail over the tea, and discard the tea.

Add a large ice cube to an Old Fashioned glass.

Slowly pour the hot mixture over the ice cube.

Express a lemon twist over the cocktail and discard. Serve.

Author: Matt Ragan
About: At upscale Dallas gastropub Victor Tangos, bartender Matt Ragan wanted to offer his guests a turmeric-infused vodka drink that could give them a nice healthy buzz.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with a celery stick.

*Turmeric-infused vodka: Combine 1 stick chopped turmeric and 750 mL vodka, and let infuse for 24 hours. Check to taste, and let infuse longer as needed. Strain.

Author: Tim Miner
About:
This drink created by the talented Timothy Miner of Brooklyn’s beloved Long Island Bar promises to take you from cranky to calm in a mere sip, even if you’re feeling as rattled as a gnarly-toothed rancor in ‘Star Wars.’

This recipe originally appeared as part of “Celebrate the Release of ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ with These Great ‘Stars Wars’ Cocktail Recipes.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a frozen double Old Fashioned glass over 1 large ice cube.

Express the oil from a large orange peel over the top of the drink, and discard the peel.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Grand Marnier’s Smash is so simple but so refreshing.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon and mint.

Add the Grand Marnier and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

About: You don’t need to overthink things when you’re working with fresh, high quality ingredients, like fresh pressed apple juice and fine single malt whisky. The Horseapple is greater than the sum of its parts.
Ingred: 2 oz Aberlour A’Bunadh Single Malt Scotch
1 Freshly pressed Granny Smith Apple Juice
Instructions:
Add one large ice cube to a double rocks glass and pour in the Aberlour A’Bunadh Single Malt Scotch.

Top with the  apple juice and stir.

Grate fresh horseradish on top to finish.

Author: Victoria D'amato-Moran
About: Try this minty and fruity cocktail with a hint of melon.
Ingred: 6 Basil leaves, gently torn in half
Instructions:
In a chilled shaker glass, add all the ingredients.

Add ice, shake for 15 seconds and strain into a Collins glass.

Garnish with a basil leaf and one raspberry.

Author: Virginia Miller
About: From Perez Klebahn, the bar manager at Baltimore’s Rye, this cocktail is a tall on-the-rocks refresher that surprises. The drink unfolds with salty-sweet intrigue from a house-made caramel by bartender Steve Lamb.
Ingred: .5 oz Tempus Fugit Gran Classico bitter aperitif.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with a charred lemon wheel.

*House-made caramel: In  heavy pot, heat 1 quart white sugar, 1 cup water and 1 oz lemon juice to a boil, stirring with a wooden spoon until the sugar begins to turn dark brown and brushing down the sides with a pastry brush. Remove from heat, slowly add 3 cups water and stir. Keeps refrigerated for a few weeks.

About: Swap out the gin in a Negroni for rye whiskey and you get the delicious Boulevardier. It’s equally complex as its gin-based predecessor, but the whiskey adds warmth, making it perfect for autumn and winter drinking.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir to combine.

Garnish with an orange twist.

To serve the drink up, add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Jordan Bushell
About: This citrus, maple syrup and cognac cocktail is hard not to love.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and mandarin.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Alejandro De La Parra
About: This surprisingly light grog is the crowd-pleasing autumn punch you didn’t even know you were missing. “Squash is amazingly flavorful and adds luscious texture to cocktails,” says Alejandro De La Parra, the bar manager at Teardrop Lounge. “[For this cocktail] we roasted the butternut squash with demerara sugar, mace, clove and allspice.”
Instructions:
Makes 6�"8 cups.

Combine all of the ingredients except the club soda and brut, in a shaker and shake gently.

Strain into a punch bowl filled with ice, top with the club soda and sparkling wine, and garnish with hibiscus flowers and pomegranate seeds.
