About: These eyeballs will give your guests—and cocktails—a scary night to remember.
Ingred: 2 Small green or black olives, chopped
Instructions:
With a small paring knife, hollow out a small hole in the cocktail onion.

Insert a piece of olive into the cocktail onion (with additional cutting to make sure it fits).

Dip a toothpick into the red food dye and trace along the cocktail onion to create veins.

Place the onions in the freezer for 5 to 10 minutes to set the dye, then slip into a cocktail.

Author: Ashford Castle
About: Address this Champagne cocktail as “Your Highness.”
Instructions:
Add the Pimms to a highball glass filled with ice and top with Champagne.

Garnish with cucumber slices and a mint sprig.

About: This Sidecar variation celebrates the local producers of Detroit, offering smooth citrus flavors and a tangy finish.
Ingred: 3 oz Unity Vibration cranberry clementine kombucha
Instructions:
Muddle the large slice of ginger in a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients and ice, and shake vigorously.

Strain the drink into a cocktail glass.

Use a lemon twist to rim the glass and discard.

Author: Jeff Bell
About: Smoky Scotch whisky is the unexpected base for this fruity and fizzy punch.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Johnnie Walker Double Black Scotch Whisky
Garnish: La Boíte Borneo N. 26 Spice Mix
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the pilsner to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a pilsner glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the pilsner and garnish with a pinch of La Boîte Borneo N.

26 Spice Mix and a grapefruit half-wheel.

Author: Tory Miller
About: At James Beard Award winner Tory Miller’s pan-Asian restaurant, Sujeo in Madison, Wis., a duo of fresh pineapple and orange juices round out a Tiki-style libation (modeled on the classic Painkiller) built for two thirsty revelers.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Pour with the ice into a Tiki mug, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Olive tapenade and herbs take this savory Bloody Mary to another level.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Vodka (Original or Le Citron)
Instructions:
Rub the lemon wedge on the outer edge of a tall glass and then roll the glass lip in the salt.

Add the remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a cucumber spear and an olive.

Author: Jeremy Allen
About: More of a chef’s table Rickey than a backyard Rickey, the Alpine Hippie Juice is “hyperconcentrated, super tart and and dry,” says creator Jeremy Allen, of Los Angeles’ MiniBar
Ingred: 1 oz Zirbenz Stone Pine Liqueur of the Alps
Instructions:
Add the cassis, liqueur and lime juice to a shaker with ice and shake well.

Strain into Champagne flute.

Top with the soda water.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Try this smoky variation of the gingery refresher, the Moscow Mule, by Jim Meehan of New York City’s PDT.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Boiron passion fruit purée 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the lime juice and cucumber slices to a mixing glass and muddle.

Add the rest of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Stain into a rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice and a piece of candied ginger and top with a pinch of ground chile.

Author: Boxes and Booze
About:
The classic three-ingredient Negroni is reimagined as a boozy sorbet.
The Negroni Sorbet originally appeared in our DrinkWire channel.
Ingred: 2 cup Fresh squeezed ruby red grapefruit juice
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into an ice cream maker and freeze, according to the ice cream maker instructions, until the mixture begins to obtain the consistency of sorbet.

Transfer to a closed container and store sealed in the freezer for at least 2 hours.

Serve in a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist or peel cut into the shape of a flower.

Author: Theo Lieberman
About: Love vermouth? Try the Montauk, a gin cocktail that includes both sweet and dry.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Stir to combine and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Paul Taylor
About: The spirit-forward nature of this cocktail makes it perfect for enjoying slowly by the fireside.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Cocchi Vermouth de Torino 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with oils expressed from an orange peel.

Author: RumChata
About: The King of Rock & Roll’s favorite snack has become the stuff of junk food legend. Channel that indulgent sandwich with this equally rich combination of Rumchata’s creamy, cinnamon-laced liqueur, peanut butter, banana liqueur and chocolate syrup. Elvis would surely approve.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender.

Blend until smooth and pour into a tall glass.

Drizzle with chocolate syrup.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About: These flavorful brandied cherries are worth the extra work.
Instructions:
Clear away anything that you don't want to get spattered with cherry juice.

It sprays and it stains, even when you're careful, so wear an old t-shirt.

Pull off the stems and punch out the pits of the cherries with a cherry pitter.

Bring to a simmer, stirring just until the sugar is dis­solved.

Add the spice bundle and continue to simmer for about 5 minutes.	Add the cherries.

Using the slotted spoon, stir the cherries until they are all soaked in the syrup and are thor­oughly warmed.

(You don't want to actually cook the cherries, just let them absorb the syrup.) Return the liquid and cherries to a simmer and pour in the brandy, rum, and bourbon, stirring to mix.

When the liquid is warmed through, remove the pot from the heat.

(Be sure not to boil the liquid because you don't want to cook off too much alcohol.)	Using a wide-mouth funnel or jar filler and a slotted spoon, pack each canning jar with cherries, filling it to the top.

Give the jar a good tap on the counter to settle the fruit so there are minimal air gaps.

Ladle the hot syrup into the jars up to about half an inch from the rim.

Place the flat part of the lid on the jar, and screw the band on lightly.

Allow them to cool and let the seals form properly.

You'll hear a nice pop as the vacuum forms and the lid is sucked down.

Tighten the rings of all the jars that have sealed properly.

About: This take on the classic Horse’s Neck uses premium cognac to add a whole new level of complexity and richness.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

*Rich simple syrup: Add 2 parts sugar to 1 part water in a saucepan. Bring to a boil and simmer until the sugar dissolves. Let cool before using.

Author: Allen Katz
About: This is a refreshing twist on the classic New York Sour.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz American Fruits Sour Cherry Cordial 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Apple, bourbon and cinnamon create the perfect autumn tipple.
Ingred: 1 slice Organic Granny Smith or Fuji Apple (eighth inch)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the apple slice.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

(Do not double-strain; you want some apple bits in the finished drink).

Garnish with an additional apple slice.

About: This scotch
Instructions:
Place a napkin over the top of a Champagne flute, place the sugar cube on top, add 3 dashes of Angostura bitters onto the cube so it soaks into the sugar cube, then flip the napkin so the sugar cube falls into the flute.

Add the scotch, stir lightly, and top with the prosecco.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Vodka and peach liqueur combine to create a cocktail so enticing, you won’t want to let it out of your sight.
Ingred: .5 fl oz Rothman & Winter Orchard Peach Liqueur.5 fl oz
.5 fl oz Dry curaçao.5 fl oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist. .

Author: Jared Schubert
About: This bourbon-based cocktail is on the menu at Louisville, Kentucky’s watering hole The Monkey Wrench.
Ingred: .5 oz Esprit de June liqueur.5 oz
3⁄4 oz Grenadine (Wilks and Wilson, or any traditional grenadine with a touch of rose water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously, and strain into a cocktail glass, express lemon over top,.

For a lighter version, serve the drink over fresh ice with a slice of lemon.

About: This crisp apple and cranberry cocktail is ridiculously easy to drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: This twist on the classic Champagne Cocktail is spiked with apple brandy and orange liqueur.
Instructions:
Add the first three ingredients to a Champagne flute and top with the Champagne.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Xavier Herit
About: This tequila and mezcal cocktail from New York bar Wallflower was inspired by chilled corn soup.
Ingred: .5 oz Jalapeño-infused Del Maguey Vida Mezcal.5 oz
.5 oz Agave syrup (3 parts agave nectar; 1 part water).5 oz
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with four dashes of basil oil.

Author: Kevin Augustine
About: The secret to this summery cocktail? Tepache liqueur, based on the traditional Mexican beverage that’s made with fermented pineapple, unrefined brown sugar and spices.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and strain into Martini glass.

Garnish with freshly-grated cinnamon.

Author: Hakkasan USA
About: This sophisticated spin on the classic Bellini is a great brunch drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and stir briefly.

Pour into a Collins or flute glass.

Author: Liquor.com
About:
This two-ingredient cocktail is a twist on the Cuba Libre. Instead of white rum, it takes dark rum.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “How to Drink Rum in Havana.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: This pear cocktail gets a boost from bubbly.
Ingred: 3 oz Pear purée (one or two fresh pears pureed with a dash of sugar or simple syrup)
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a chilled Martini glass with the red sugar and set aside.

Add the vodka and pear purée to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with Champagne and float a pear slice on top.

Author: Toby Maloney
About: Respect your elders.
Ingred: .5 oz White crème de cacao.5 oz
Instructions:
Rinse a coupe glass with cinnamon liqueur and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with ground cinnamon.

Author: Emily Arden Wells
About: This variation of the Penicillin is a local favorite at The Punch Room, at The Ritz-Carlton Charlotte, and is made with honey from beehives at the restaurant’s rooftop garden and locally grown ginger.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz House-made honey ginger syrup 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Rim a rocks glass with smoked lava sea salt.

Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into the prepared glass over ice.

*Honey ginger syrup: Add 2 cups water and 3 thumb-size pieces of peeled and thinly sliced ginger to a small pot, and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer for 30 minutes. Add 1.5 cups local honey, strain out the ginger, and let cool. Store in the refrigerator. Keeps up to 3 weeks.

Author: China Morbosa
About: This twist on a traditional Rickey by China Morbosa at West Hollywood’s Eveleigh
Ingred: 2 oz Ilegal joven mezcal (or gin or whiskey)
Instructions:
Add the mezcal, sherry and lemon juice into an ice-filled Highball glass and stir.

Top with the mango-infused carbonated coconut water.

Garnish with edible flowers.

*Mango-infused carbonated coconut water with mango: Cook down 2 L coconut water in half. Add 1 finely chopped mango and 1 cup sugar. Cook on medium for 10 minutes. Strain the mango, and let cool. Add 1 oz club soda and swizzle.

Author: Adam Seger
About: Bring a little mayhem to your mouth with this beer cocktail’s complex combination of sweet, sour, smoky, bitter and bubbly.
Instructions:
Add the mezcal, Campari and Mayhaw Syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a pint or highball glass half-filled with fresh ice.

Top with the beer and garnish with an orange wheel or twist.

Drink Name: Super Sunday Punch Bowl of Freedom
Author: Mike Ryan
About: Whether you’re watching football, baseball or basketball, this bourbon punch goes well with friends and sports.
Instructions:
Wrap the cinnamon sticks, cloves and allspice in cheesecloth, tie into a bundle and place in a punch bowl.

Add the remaining ingredients and stir thoroughly.

Fill with ice, stir and garnish with apple slices.

(If assembling ahead of time, refrigerate after stirring together the ingredients and add the ice just before serving.).

Author: Jen Ackrill, Darren Crawford, Enrique Sanchez and Brian MacGregor
About: Created by a team of four top San Francisco bartenders, this drink won a Gentleman Jack cocktail competition.
Ingred: .5 oz Cara cara orange juice.5 oz
2 dashes Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Aged Bitters
Garnish: 1 Cara cara orange twist and cherries
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice, shake again and double-strain into an Old Fashioned glass.

Twist a slice of cara cara orange peel over the drink, spear it on a toothpick with three cherries and use it as garnish.

Author: Willy Shine
About: This bubbly whiskey drink isn’t English, but it does have soul.
Ingred: 2 oz Gentleman Jack Rare Tennessee Whiskey
3⁄4 oz Spiced Tea Agave Syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the whiskey, lemon juice and syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with a mint sprig.

About: This energizing blend of fruit and cognac has a fizzy ginger twist.
Garnish: Orange zest and sugar rim, Mint sprig
Instructions:
Rim a cocktail glass in a mixture of sugar and orange zest.

Squeeze the juice of 1 orange slice into a shaker, then add the remaining ingredients and ice.

Shake and strain into the prepared cocktail glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: John deBary
About: “Conundrum,” the episode of “Star Trek: The Next Generation” in which everyone gets their memories erased and Data thinks he’s a bartender, is one of the series’ best. He makes this drink for Troi after losing a game of 3-D chess. It goes from clear to green to red in the blink of an eye. We don’t yet have the technology to recreate that marvel, but we can mimic it using a trick with red-cabbage-infused rum. The drink will turn from purple to red with the addition of the fruit juices.
Instructions:
Chill a large snifter with ice and set aside.

Add the white rum, cabbage rum, triple sec and simple syrup to a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously for 15 seconds.

Strain into the chilled snifter.

Add 3 oz sparkling water.

In a separate container, combine 3/4 oz grapefruit juice and 1/2 oz lime juice. Pour the juice into the snifter.

Add 1 pinch salt.

*Cabbage rum: Combine 1/2 head purple cabbage, chopped, with 4 oz white rum in a blender, and blend on high until smooth. Strain using a fine-mesh strainer. Makes 4 oz.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: It’s delicious even outside Massachusetts.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint leaves, simple syrup and lime juice.

Add the vodka and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a highball glass.

Top with club soda.

Author: Flor de Caña Rum
About: Start your celebration with this spicy cocktail.
Ingred: 3 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the watermelon.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and pour (unstrained) into a cocktail or Margarita glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Josephine Estelle
About: Aquavit gives this Daiquiri-inspired sip from New Orleans’ Josephine Estelle a Scandinavian accent.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a thyme sprig.

About: The orange-kissed Sidecar is a classic that will never go out of style.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Author: Cole Schaffer
About: This soju cocktail’s name translates to “Sweet Poison #2.”
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass.

Top with soda and garnish with half a kumquat.

Author: Lucinda Sterling
About: This sweet and tart cocktail is made with a blend of whiskey and pomegranate liqueur.
Ingred: 2 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except for the tonic water in a rocks glass.

Fill with ice and top with tonic water.

Garnish with a cucumber wheel.

Author: Aaron Joseph
About:
In addition to spices, bartender Aaron Joseph at Baltimore’s r.bar  uses citrus, ginger and dried hibiscus flowers in his heady rum sip. He recommends reserving the strained out flowers and ginger slices and using them to garnish the drink. Select a lighter-style pinot noir so it won’t compete with the delicate, lightly aged rum.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “These Are the Only 3 Mulled Rum Cocktails You’ll Ever Need.”
Instructions:
Serves 10.

Add all the ingredients into a large pot on medium heat.

Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, and allow to simmer for 20 minutes.

Remove from heat, strain out solids, and serve in a mug or rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange peel skewered with 3 cloves.

About: After Prohibition, the Bacardí Cocktail became enormously popular, tempting unscrupulous barmen to serve it with whatever rum was on hand. Fortunately, the New York Supreme Court stepped in to protect cocktail fans by decreeing it could only be made with Bacardí rum.
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a shaker and stir.

Fill the shaker halfway with crushed ice, top with cubed ice, and shake vigorously until the shaker is frosted.

Fine-strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: As majestic and strong as its namesake.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well.

Strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

About: The name is misleading, since this aperitivo is an Italian classic. It’s the perfect marriage of Campari and Cinzano, two of the most delicious and historic Italian exports. Encourage customers to kick off their brunch with this Italian original, and don’t settle for any knockoffs.
Instructions:
Add the liqueur and vermouth to a rocks glass with ice and stir.

Top with a splash of soda water.

Garnish with an orange slice and lemon twist.

Author: Joe Dobias
About: Recreate the deli favorite Dr. Brown’s Cel-Ray Soda in cocktail form with this unique recipe.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with a mix of celery salt and sugar.

Fill with ice and add the gin, Celery Syrup and lime juice.

Top with club soda and stir briefly.

Drink Name: Bushmills Black Bush The Black Nail
Author: Bushmills Irish Whiskey
About: A long name for a simple drink.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Bushmills Black Bush Irish Whiskey 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add Bushmills Irish Whiskey and Irish Mist to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Jay Zimmerman
About: This classic Martini uses a classic London dry-style gin.
Instructions:
Chill the gin and a cocktail glass in the freezer for at least two hours.

Add the gin and vermouth to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the frozen cocktail glass.

Garnish with a slice of lemon peel.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: Now this is one set of rules that’s not hard to follow.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a highball glass with cinnamon and fill with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Finlandia Vodka
About: A Finnish twist on an old Parisian classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Dante Alston
About: Gin and citrus combine to make one seriously refreshing tipple. Created by Dante Alston and can be found at Stanton Social.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the grapefruit wheel.

Add remaining ingredients and fill shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass.

Author: Kristin Struckmeyer
About: For those who love Girl Scout season and whiskey year round, this simple take on the classic Mint Julep will have you emptying your cookie boxes.
Ingred: .5 oz White crème de cacao.5 oz
Instructions:
Place the mint leaves and syrup into julep cup and gently muddle.

Add the bourbon and white crème de cacao and pack halfway with crushed ice.

Stir until the cup is frosted on the outside.

Top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and Thin Mint cookie.

Author: Ben Schaffer
About: The Bacardí Cocktail became one of the most popular drinks of the period immediately following the repeal of Prohibition. It is a variation of the Daiquiri
Instructions:
Chill a coupe glass with ice and set aside.

Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the chilled coupe.

*Homemade grenadine: Quarter 2 pomegranates, and juice them with an electric masticating juicer. Combine the juice and 1/2 cup granulated sugar in a container, and stir until sugar dissolves. Bottle and store in refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

About: Some people would rather start their day with caffeine. Those drinkers will appreciate the Franny & Joe. The mix of authentic hazelnut liqueur and cold-brew coffee makes this cocktail perfect for brunch. Add cream to transform this cocktail into the right kind of morning starter.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the optional cream to a rocks glass with ice (or a coupe without ice) and stir.

Express an orange peel over top.

As an option, add a dash a cream.

Garnish with the orange peel.

Author: Dominic Venegas
About: Add some maple syrup to the classic Bourbon Rickey to get this sophisticated fall cocktail recipe.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with ice and insert the lime wheels.

Add the maple syrup, lime juice and bourbon, and then fill with club soda.

Stir briefly to combine.

Author: Megan Krigbaum
About: This gin cocktail by Tom Macy of Clover Club in New York City combines sweet and tart flavors.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain over crushed or cracked ice in a rocks glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig and speared blackberry and raspberry.

*Cinnamon syrup: Mix 1 cup sugar in 1 cup of water, and boil until sugar is dissolved. Add 6 cinnamon sticks, cover, and let it sit overnight. Remove the cinnamon sticks. Keeps for 1 month in the refrigerator.

Author: Erik Adkins
About: Like Mint Juleps? You’ll love the Whiskey Smash, a citrusy 19th-century cooler. Legendary bartender Dale DeGroff at the Rainbow Room in New York modified the classic recipe by adding muddled lemon wedges. DeGroff calls the citrus-and-mint combination the perfect cocktail for those who say they’ll never drink whiskey.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice or one large ice chunk.

Slap a mint sprig between your hands and use as garnish.

Serve with a straw.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
A solid shake is required for this refreshing Tequila Sour. It’s worth every move.
For more great summery Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos too!—head
Garnish: Bittermens Xocolatl mole bitters (or Angostura bitters)
Instructions:
Makes 1.

Add all the ingredients except the bitters to a shaker, and dry-shake (without ice) for 15 seconds.

Add ice, shake, and double-strain into a rocks glass.

Garnish with 3 drops of the bitters.

Author: Phill Watts
About: Challenge your palate with this complex Italian cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Van Ongevalle
About:
Belgian bartender Ran Van Ongevalle’s winning drink at the 2017 Bacardí Legacy Global Cocktail Competition is a stirred beauty that pairs Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron eight-year-old rum with amontillado sherry, crème de cacao, absinthe and saline solution.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “This Is How Chocolate and a Family Business Won This Bartender a Fancy Cocktail Competition.”
Ingred: 2 oz Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron eight-year-old rum
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with three drops of olive oil.

About: Created by Eric Tecosky in the 1990s, this popular cocktail can be made as a shot. But you can civilize this Jägermeister
Bet you never thought you’d see maple syrup and pineapple juice become best friends?
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Hard shake, and strain into coupe glass.

Garnish with three drops of Angostura Bitters.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About: It doesn’t get much simpler than this easy take on the classic.
Ingred: 3 oz Homemade Margarita mix (three parts sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
Rub the rim of a Margarita glass with the lime wedge and then dip in salt to coat.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Alex Attart
About:
Life may be all sunshine and Disney magic in Orlando, but at Taverna Opa, bartender Alex Attart likes to take a walk on the dark side of life. Here, his homage to the imperial superweapon skews the color of Darth Vader’s cape with good use of Jägermeister digestif and Coca-Cola. He also makes a nifty little ice orb replica of the Death Star for extra empirical effect, but regular cubes will do just fine.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Celebrate the Release of ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ with These Great ‘Stars Wars’ Cocktail Recipes.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients in a Collins glass over ice and stir.

Garnish with a straw.

About: The Finnieston in Glasgow, tabbed as a gin
Ingred: 1 oz Bruichladdich The Classic Laddie scotch
3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Pink Grapefruit Juice 3⁄4 oz
BrewDog Elvis Juice IPA float BrewDog Elvis Juice IPA float
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except for the IPA in a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a Collins glass over ice, and top with the IPA.

Garnish with a grapefruit slice.

Author: Lucy Brennan
About: This herb-and-lemon concoction is a recipe you can share with the kids.
Ingred: 1 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the of cilantro.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

(If you're not a fan of cilantro, try this recipe with mint, basil or any soft herb.).

Author: T.J. Palmieri
About:
T.J. Palmieri, the owner and operator of Madrina’s in Gainesville, Fla., created this take on the classic Ti’ Punch. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “It’s About Time to Fall in Love with This Rum Cocktail. It’s Called the Ti’ Punch.”
Ingred: 2 oz Clément Canne Bleue blanc rhum agricole
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a rocks glass with crushed ice, and swizzle using a bois lélé (swizzle stick).

Garnish with a lime wheel.

*Hibiscus syrup: Bring 2 cups sugar, 1/2 cup dried Jamaican hibiscus leaves and 1 cup water to a boil, then reduce heat and let simmer until sugar is dissolved. Allow leaves to steep for 6 minutes, and fine-strain into a container. Keep refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

About: This Chicago-inspired cocktail has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch
1 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur
1 dash The Bitter Truth chocolate bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into Julep cup, and top with crushed ice.

Garnish with freshly grated wild tonka bean.

Author: Moon Mountain Vodka
About: It’s rhyme time with this sweet-and-tart vodka drink.
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Moon Mountain Coastal Citrus Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Punch up this brunch favorite with a splash of Grand Marnier.
Instructions:
Add the Grand Marnier and fresh orange juice to a Champagne flute and top with Champagne.

Garnish with a strawberry (optional).

Author: Stolichnaya
About: This citrusy drink will beguile you.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

Author: Claire Sprouse
About: Meet the trifecta of perfectly balanced, bittersweet flavor: amaro, sweet vermouth and rye.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a rocks glass over large ice cube.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Dan Warner
About: Try Dan Warner’s simple but elegant Beefeater 24 Gin Martini.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Lauren Rothman
About: An essential part of Christmas in Mexico, sweet, fragrant Ponche Navideño can be found simmering away on stovetops and at traditional outdoor markets all across the country from December 12 through January 6, the period during which the holiday is celebrated. Featuring traditional Mexican flavorings such as fresh sugar cane, guavas and tejocotes (a crabapple-type fruit), the punch is spiked with a healthy dose of rum and served piping hot to ward off any winter chills. Here in the U.S., it can be hard to find these items fresh. So this recipe relies on easy-to-find ingredients that lend their Mexican flair to an irresistible rum punch.
Ingred: 12 oz Piloncillo (Mexican-style unrefined brown sugar), grated (or 1 cup packed dark brown sugar)
2 Tart apples, peeled, cored, finely chopped
1 Ripe pear, peeled, cored, finely chopped
.5 cup Packed raisins or golden raisins.5 cup
1 cup Dried hibiscus flowers (also known as jamaica or sorrel), tied inside a square of cheesecloth
Instructions:
In a large stockpot, add the water, piloncillo, cinnamon sticks, cloves and tamarind paste, and bring to a boil. Drop to a simmer, and stir to completely dissolve the tamarind paste. Simmer for 15 minutes.

Add the apples, pear, raisins and hibiscus flowers, and simmer for 15 minutes, until the fruit is soft and raisins are rehydrated.

Squeeze the remaining liquid out of the cheesecloth packet and discard. Remove the cinnamon sticks and cloves and discard. Stir in the lemon juice and rum.

Ladle the punch between 12 punch glasses, thinly slice 2 lemons, and garnish each glass with a slice.

About: You won’t be suffering through this cognac-based update on the Suffering Bastard.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger ale to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled highball glass.

Top with the ginger ale.

Garnish with candied ginger and a mint bouquet.

Author: Joey Smith
Ingred: 1 oz Cartron Crème de Pêche Vigne liqueur
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and shake.

Double-strain into coupe glass, and garnish with a mint sprig and raspberry.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Add some herbal freshness to the classic lime cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Float a basil leaf on top of the drink.

About: Made with cucumber, elderflower and Irish whiskey, this is a sour cocktail you can’t help but get sweet on.
Ingred: 2 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
3⁄4 Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) 3⁄4
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cucumber slices.

Add remaining ingredients and fill shaker with ice.

Shake vigorously, and fine-strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice.

About:
The Blood & Sand is a classic scotch-based cocktail that has withstood the test of time. The recipe first appeared in 1930 in The Savoy Cocktail Book by Harry Craddock and has become a mainstay on bar menus ever since.
It gets its name from a 1922 bullfighter movie and points to its ingredients: The “blood” represents Heering cherry liqueur, and the “sand” is for the orange juice. 
The key to the cocktail is to use a smooth scotch that’s not too smoky and freshly squeezed orange juice. So forget about your Islay scotches (for now), and avoid that carton of OJ in the fridge.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz The Glenrothes Select Reserve single-malt Scotch whisky 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Orange juice, freshly squeezed 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

About: Make your next Mule even more refreshing by adding a fruity twist and topper of effervescent ginger beer.
Ingred: .5 oz Fresh homemade raspberry cordial.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain over crushed ice in a copper mug, then top with the ginger beer.

Top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with fresh raspberries.

*Raspberry cordial: In a saucepan, bring 10 oz water and .3 lb raspberries to a boil, and simmer for 10 minutes. Add .7 lb fine sugar, and stir until dissolved. Fine-strain the cordial into bottles.

Author: Jack McGarry
About: This tasty Irish whiskey concoction combines whiskey, sherry and orange marmalade with a soothing ginger syrup.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Knappogue Castle 12 Year Old Single Malt Irish Whiskey
3 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The Grasshopper cocktail is a minty classic that is better than your traditional dessert.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Grate fresh nutmeg directly over the center of the drink.

Author: Nicholas Boden
About: This modern take on the Gin Rickey
Instructions:
With a torch, light the rosemary sprig, place a coupe glass over it to fill it with smoke, and set aside.

Add the gin and citric acid to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into the prepared glass.

Top with the lavender-infused soda water.

Garnish with edible flowers.

*Lavender-infused soda water: Boil 30 oz water and 1/2 cup lavender syrup in a pot for 1 hour. Strain and let cool in the refrigerator for 3 hours. Add to a SodaStream (or similar soda maker) container and carbonate.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About:
This easy-to-prep, seasonal take on the Dark ’N’ Stormy by Jeffrey Morgenthaler, the bar manager of Portland, Ore.’s Clyde Common and Pépé Le Moko, is super forgiving even if you eyeball the amounts rather than rely on a jigger. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tired of Boring Bartender Staff Parties? These Tips Will Change How You Celebrate.”
Instructions:
Add the spiced rum to a chilled Collins glass over ice.

Top with ginger beer.

Garnish with a lime wedge and straw.

*Chinese-five-spiced rum: Using a funnel, add 1 tsp Chinese five-spice powder to a 750mL bottle of Gosling's Black Seal rum, and shake vigorously. Let set for at least 1 hour but preferably overnight. Strain the rum through a coffee filter set inside of a large strainer into a bowl, then funnel back into the original bowl and label.

Author: Carlos Perez
About: This day-drinking-ready cocktail from Carlos Perez at Chicago’s Nellcote is simultaneously elegant and ready to blaze.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass.

Soak a fresh rosemary sprig upside down with 100-proof alcohol for five minutes.

Put the sprig upright in the rocks glass, and light right before the first sip.

Author: Lucinda Sterling
About: Try this fresh take on the timeless Manhattan.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Leopold Bros Georgia Peach Whiskey 3⁄4 oz
2 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass and fill with ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Tippling Bros.
About: With apple butter, maple syrup and hard cider, this cocktail is like fall in a cup.
Ingred: 2 oz Highland Park 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
3⁄4 oz Grade A maple syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the hard cider to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with hard cider and garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Justin Oliver
About: This eclectic cocktail from San Francisco’s Smuggler’s Cove uses pineapple, almond, whiskey and rum.
Ingred: 6 drops Tiki bitters or Angostura Bitters
3⁄4 oz Lemon Hart or Hamilton 151 3⁄4 oz
Glass: Hollowed pineapple with hole for straw, or Collins
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the 151 to a hollowed out pineapple and fill with crushed ice.

Blend well and float the 151 or Lemon Hart on top.

Author: Anthony Malone
About: A whiskey supper from the Emerald Isle.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Joann Spiegel
About: Leave it to the pros at The Dead Rabbit to create a cocktail that pairs Irish whiskey with strawberries and tart balsamic vinegar. Lillet Rose and sherry complete this ingenious coupe.
Ingred: 2 oz Knappogue Castle Single Malt Irish Whiskey 12-Year
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a coupe.

Garnish with a strawberry.

About: Sweet, bitter and rich, this cocktail hits all the right notes.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Pratt sweet vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: Feeling spendy? Try this deluxe cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Sean Kenyon
About: What do you get when you combine ZU Bison Grass Vodka, Amaro Montenegro and hard apple cider? This regal cocktail, thought up by respected Denver bartender Sean Kenyon. It’s piquant and coolingboth qualities of a great summer drink. Plus, when you drink it, you’ll feel like nobility.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients (except the cider) to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Top with Ace Hard Apple Cider and garnish with an apple fan. .

Author: Chris Barry
About: You can find this pineapple and gin concoction at The Musket Room in New York.
Ingred: 1 oz Greenhook Beach Plum gin liqueur
3⁄4 oz Palm sugar rooibos syrup 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Tempus Fugit Kina L'Aréo d'Or apéritif.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the sparkling wine to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a wine glass filled with fresh ice and top with the sparkling rosé.

Garnish with a sage flower and/or leaf.

Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Pecan liqueur or orgeat syrup 1⁄4 oz
Garnish: Grapefruit swath and small pinch of cinnamon
Instructions:
Shake and serve over cracked ice frappe in white wine glass.

Garnish with large grapefruit swath and small pinch of cinnamon.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: At just 120 calories, this fruity sipper is tasty and good for your waistline.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with chunks of fresh seasonal fruit.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About:
The Amaretto Sour gets a bad rap. Too often, it’s overly sweet and relies on premade sour mix. We enlisted Portland mixologist Jeffrey Morgenthaler to give us his take on the classic Amaretto Sour. What he came up with is nothing short of magic. This drink turns out frothy, sweet, sour, nutty and strong. 
Combining amaretto with bourbon, fresh lemon juice, rich simple syrup and egg white creates a perfectly balanced Amaretto Sour. What are you waiting for? Go nuts with our recipe below.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake to combine.

Add fresh ice to the shaker and shake again until chilled.

Strain over fresh ice into an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with lemon peel and brandied cherries, if desired.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: This fizzy, citrusy concoction is distantly related to its cousin Tom.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker.

Fill with ice and shake hard.

Strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice and top with the club soda.

Stir with a spoon and garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Allison Widdecombe
Ingred: .5 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into chilled cocktail or coupe glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This drink was the new, new thingat the turn of the 20th century.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Johnnie Walker Black Label Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add the lemon juice and sugar to a shaker and stir.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a maraschino cherry if you like.

Author: Chester Browne
About: This old-timey favorite will keep a whole houseful of guests satisfied.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a punch bowl and stir to combine.

Let stand for 2 hours and serve in punch cups filled with ice.

Garnish each cup with a cherry.

Author: St-Germain Liqueur
About: This St-Germain and bourbon drink will always be trendy.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and garnish with an orange peel.

About: This cognac cocktail packs a citrusy punch with lemon, orange and grapefruit flavors.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Pamela Wiznitzer
About: Pamela Wiznitzer of Seamstress in New York City thinks that if you have just one drink, you might as well Make It Count. This lovely red-hued cocktail takes the bitterness of Campari and mellows it out with a little honey syrup and sweet blood orange. It gets a little sparkle from soda water and proves perfectly refreshing on hot day or as an after-dinner treat.
Ingred: 1 oz The Perfect Purée of Napa Valley blood orange concentrate
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass with ice, and stir gently.

Garnish with an orange chip.

*Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use, the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Toast the seasons with this tasty tequila cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle all the ingredients except the Ginger Syrup.

Add the Ginger Syrup and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice or a highball glass without ice.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Lucid Absinthe
About: Get inspired by absinthe, mint and pineapple juice.
Garnish: 1 Mint sprig and a lime wedge
Instructions:
Muddle the mint leaves with the lime wedge in a shaker.

Add the Lucid Absinthe, pineapple juice and fill with ice.

Shake briefly and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with Sprite or 7-Up and garnish with a mint sprig and lime wedge.

Author: Nick Mautone
About:
The Bloody Mary is a vodka-soaked nutritional breakfast and hangover cure all in one. What else could you ask for?
The tomato-based cocktail has hundreds of variations, from heavy on the hot sauce to a splash of Guinness on top. It’s best to start with the classic recipe and work toward the way you like it, even if it’s topped with a shrimp skewer, a slice of bacon and a tiny cheeseburger. Crazy garnishes aside, there’s a reason this iconic beverage is a classic.
While the origin of this popular brunch cocktail is debatable, the Bloody Mary’s staying power leaves no question.
Instructions:
Pour some celery salt onto a small plate.

Rub the juicy side of the lemon or lime wedge along the lip of a pint glass.

Roll the outer edge of the glass in celery salt until fully coated.

Fill with ice and set aside.

Squeeze the lemon and lime wedges into a shaker and drop them in.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake gently and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a celery stalk and a lime wedge.

Author: Manny Ibanez
About: Strawberry, pineapple and rose combine in this refreshing gin cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberry and three rose petals.

Add remaining ingredients and fill shaker with ice.

Shake vigorously, and double strain into a tulip glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a rose petal.

Author: Orson Salicetti
About: HKB baijiu was created as a “gateway” baijiu for the Western palate. Orson Salicetti, at New York City’s Lumos, uses it in this cocktail for its floral, lightly sweet notes, which complement the pear juice and liqueur. With the inclusion of agave and lime, this is essentially a sour with some additional components.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a fresh sage leaf.

*Lumos spice elixir: Infuse 1 part allspice, clove and cinnamon separately in 3 parts baijiu. After 3 weeks, strain and taste each infusion, then combine the infusions. Transfer to a dropper and use by single drops as it is very powerful.

Author: Allen Katz
About: The secret to this Whiskey Sour variation is a bit of red wine. Try the classic New York Sour.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the wine to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Slowly pour the wine over the back of a spoon so that it floats on top of the drink.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Try this quintessential Old Fashioned cocktail with your favorite bourbon. It’s been said that the original cocktail contains sugar, bitters, whiskey and water. This variation, made by cocktail legend Dale Degroff, adds muddled fruit and soda water for a lighter, fruitier taste.
Instructions:
In an Old Fashioned glass, muddle the bitters, sugar, orange wheel, cherry and a splash of soda.

Remove the orange rind, add the bourbon and fill with ice.

Garnish with a fresh orange wheel and cherry..

About: You can’t get much more simple or refreshing than this three-ingredient Sidecar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with cracked ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: You’ll think completely differently about chai after tasting it in this cognac-based cocktail.
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Louis Royer Force 53° VSOP cognac
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with large, cold ice cubes.

Shakevigorously and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with three dried organic rosebuds.

Ingred: 1.5 oz Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro rum
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients and shake with ice.

Double-strain into a coupe glass.

About: Why settle for the usual Bloody Mary? Give it a delectable smoky update by adding Ardbeg and all the right garnishes. It will quickly be clear how premium scotch can elevate the classic vodka cocktail.
Garnish: Lemon and smoked salt rim, Kale, Celery, Bacon, Pickled vegetables
Instructions:
Pour some smoked salt onto a small plate.

Rub the juicy side of the lemon wedge along the lip of a pint glass.

Roll the outer edge of the glass in smoked salt until fully coated.

Add all the ingredients to a pint glass with ice and stir.

Garnish with kale, celery, bacon and pickled veggies.

Author: Emily Arden Wells
About: This Vodka Martini is a variation typically made with gin and Atholl Brose, a Speyside single-malt scotch
Instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: Try the classic bourbon and vermouth Manhattan with just a hint of smoky Scotch.
Instructions:
Rinse a cocktail glass with the Scotch and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until chilled and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Frankie Thaheld
About: Mix up this refreshing fresh-and-fruity cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the kiwi.

Add the simple syrup and St-Germain, and fill with ice.

Shake until chilled and add a splash of club soda.

Strain into a cocktail glass and top with the sparkling wine.

Garnish with a kiwi slice.

Author: Ben Scorah
About: Take a trip south of the equator with this tasty Sangria.
Ingred: Fresh seasonal fruit (recommended: strawberry, lime, orange, kiwi and passion fruit)
Instructions:
In a shaker, thoroughly muddle the fruit with the absinthe, cachaça, brandy and orange liqueur.

Pour into a wine glass.

Float the red wine on top and stir briefly.

Author: Adam Brewer
About: Chocolate, mint and a big, peaty Scotch flavor this drink. Trust us, it works.
Ingred: 1 1⁄3 oz Talisker 10-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
1⁄3 oz White crème de menthe (the cheaper the better) 1⁄3 oz
2 dashes Chocolate bitters (Scrappy's, The Bitter Truth or Fee Brothers)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupette glass. Twist a piece of lemon peel over the drink to extract the oils and discard. This drink is one of Gary Regan's 101 Best New Cocktails.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About:
This hot tequila-and-cider concoction will warm you head to toe.
Warm up some more by making this Crock-Pot chicken recipe.
Instructions:
Add the tequila and cider to a pre-warmed Irish Coffee glass.

Float a little heavy cream on top and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a cinnamon stick.

About: This Japanese cocktail is all about the whisky—and the ritual. Make sure you count your stirs.
Instructions:
Stack several large cubes of ice in a highball glass.

Pour the whisky into the glass and slowly stir it 13 and a half times.

Fill the glass with ice again, and top with sparkling water.

Stir three and a half more times to finish the drink.

Author: James Horn
About: Homemade lemon-pumpkin soda is easy to prepare in just a few minutes and lends the Smashing Pumpkin fresh fall flavor. A base of aged rum and allspice liqueur add warming contrast, making this the perfect way to incorporate the season’s favorite squash in your cocktails.
Instructions:
Add the rum and allspice liqueur to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Top with the Lemon-Pumpkin Soda and garnish with a bay leaf.

About: This cocktail takes single malt for a slightly tropical spin. And yes, it’s as delicious as it looks.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into chilled cocktail glass.

About: Booze buzz meets sugar buzz in this decadent dessert cocktail. (Trust us, you need this in your life.)
Instructions:
Scoop the chocolate ice cream into a chilled pint glass.

Drizzle with chocolate syrup.

Slowly pour the Guinness over the ice cream.

Serve with a straw.

About: Mix up the Americano on the Fourth of July or anytime the spirit moves you.
Instructions:
Pour the Campari and vermouth into a rocks or highball glass filled with ice.

Add a splash of club soda and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Añejo tequila and spicy chili powder give a kick to this spiked hot chocolate.
Instructions:
Add the tequila and hot chocolate to a half-pint glass.

Garnish with a dollop of whipped cream and a dash of chili powder.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Try this rainforest spin on the classic Cosmo.
Ingred: .5 oz Grand Marnier or other orange liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist or a strawberry.

About: Vodka, sherry and Cynar liqueur are more interesting mixers than milk and sugar. Try them with your next cold-brew coffee in this spin on the Old Fashioned.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with cubed ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with large-format ice and garnish with orange zest.

*Demerara syrup: Add 1/2 cup demerara sugar and 1/2 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. It will keep, refrigerated, for about 1 month.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
A simple rosemary syrup gives the classic grapefruit Paloma a hint of a little something special. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos too!—head right this way.
Instructions:
Add the tequila, syrup and juice in a shaker with ice and shake.

Shake and strain into a Collins glass.

Fill the glass to the top with ice, and top with grapefruit soda.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

*Rosemary simple syrup: Combine 2 tbsp fresh rosemary leaves (from about 1 sprig) and ½ cup water in a pot, and bring to a boil.

Add 1 cup sugar and stir constantly until fully dissolved. Strain rosemary leaves and let syrup cool to room temperature before using. Do not refrigerate to quicken cooling time, as sugar may crystallize from cooling too quickly.

Once cool, use immediately or store refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Neal Bodenheimer
About: At Cure
Ingred: 1.5 oz Buil & Giné Priorat Natur vermut
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into a slightly chilled coupe or Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: No leprechauns were hurt in the making of this recipe.
Ingred: .5 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water).5 oz
1⁄4 oz Egg white (that is about half of an egg white) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake again.

Strain into a double rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and a lemon wheel.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: The soda fountain just grew up.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Cherry Noir Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Stir briefly and garnish with a cherry.

About: A little bit tropical, a little bit tart, this is bound to be your next easy-drinking cocktail.
Instructions:
Muddle the pineapple and place in a Collins glass, then fill it with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the Collins glass.

Garnish with a cherry, orange slice and pineapple wheel.

About: Cinnamon syrup which is used in other recipes
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a small saucepan.

Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce heat to low and simmer for a few minutes.

Remove from heat, cover, and let stand for at least 6 hours.

Strain, and store in the refrigerator.

About: A Gin & Tonic is one of life’s simplest, crispest pleasures, and it doesn’t get any easier to make than this one.
Instructions:
Add the gin to a Highball glass, then half-fill the glass with the tonic water.

Fill the glass with ice, then add a lemon and orange wheel.

Top with more tonic and stir.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Try this citrusy twist on the classic South American Pisco Sour.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Campo de Encanto Acholado Pisco
1 oz Clover honey syrup (one part clover honey, one part water)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cilantro and clementine.

Add the remaining ingredients and shake without ice for 5 seconds.

Fill with ice and shake well.

Double-strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with a cilantro sprig.

About: Start your evening (or your day) with a coffee-cognac concoction.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe.

*Coffee syrup: Combine equal parts coffee and sugar. Heat until the sugar dissolves and let cool.

Author: Zacatecas Tacos & Tequila
About: This spicy Southwestern take on the Margarita is something altogether new, with roasted poblano-infused tequila.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Easy, breezy, tropical.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients except the soda to a tall glass filled with ice.

Top with soda and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: A cocktail you can really sink your teeth into.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Top with Champagne and garnish with a fresh lime wedge.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: This bubbly, gin and lemon cocktail will have you saying “oui.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a flute.

Top with Champagne and garnish with Maraschino cherries.

Author: Benjamin Amberg
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a well-chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Suzanne Taliercio
About: Herbal and complex Averna from Italy combines with bright and crisp Death’s Door Gin from Wisconsin in a refreshing sip-on-the-patio beverage.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, cucumber and simple syrup.

Add the Averna, gin and lime juice, and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mint sprig and cucumber wheel.

Author: Canadian Club Whisky
About: Ron would definitely approve.
Instructions:
Add the whisky and ginger ale to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Top with a splash of cranberry juice.

About: This sweet, locally inspired coffee drink from Harold’s Cabin in Charleston, S.C., adds a crumble of benne seed wafers, a South Carolina low country staple, for a unique, crunchy garnish. If you can’t find benne seed wafers, use thin sesame wafers instead.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Strawberry-infused Striped Pig rum 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with benne seed wafer crumble.

*Strawberry-infused Striped Pig rum: Fill a Mason jar with halved strawberries, and add Striped Pig rum to completely cover the strawberries. Store in a cool, dark place for up to 2 weeks. The berries will turn ghost white. Strain through a metal strainer into a second jar. Keeps for 3 months.

Author: Phil Ward
About: The classic Last Word cocktail goes south of the border.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: Pistachios, coconut, lychee and rum combine to make one tasty drink that’s on the menu at BDK in San Francisco.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Belgian beer glass over cobbled ice.

Garnish with toasted coconut and lime zest.

About: The fizzy Ramos Gin Fizz cocktail is all shook up.
Instructions:
The secret to this drink is to shake, shake and shake some more.

Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and shake vigorously without ice.

Open the shaker, fill with ice and shake again.

Strain into a Collins glass.

Pour a little bit of club soda back and forth between the empty halves of the shaker to pick up any residual egg white, and then pour into the glass.

(This will make for a frothier head.).

Author: The Bitter End
About: A few drops of spicy bitters heat up this sweet pomegranate cocktail.
Ingred: 4 drops The Bitter End Moroccan Bitters
Instructions:
Add the bitters to a chilled cocktail glass and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Ricardo Murcia
About: This cocktail at Las Vegas’ Lago by Julian Serrano
Instructions:
Muddle the raspberries in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.

Add the vodka, liqueur, lemon juice, raspberry syrup, egg white and ice and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into a white wine glass, and top with the chilled prosecco.

Garnish with a caramel nest and golden raspberry.

Author: Allen Katz
About: The American-whiskey classic has only two ingredients.
Ingred: 2 oz Bourbon, brandy or American rye whiskey
Instructions:
Add the whiskey to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Fill with ginger ale and garnish with a long strip of lemon peel.

Author: Jeremy Strawn
About: This classic cocktail has a seriously nutty twist.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake hard, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Mai tai means “out of this world” in Tahitian, and it’s the perfect name for an irresistible exotic cocktail. This recipe was created in 1944 by Trader Vic Bergeron at his Polynesian-themed restaurant in San Francisco.
Ingred: 2⁄5 parts Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 2⁄5 parts
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously.

Fine-strain into an Old Fashioned glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and an orange wedge.

Author: Chad Leuthje
About: Savor the dog days of summer with this fruity cooler.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, lime juice, agave nectar and watermelon.

Add the rum and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Cameron Dale
About: This version of a Brass Monkey, made famous by the Beastie Boys, uses a chilled glass and cold beer, instead of a warm 40-ounce bottle.
Instructions:
Fill a chilled beer glass with the lager, and top with the orange juice.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Brock Schulte
About: Kansas City, Mo.’s Monarch Cocktail Bar & Lounge feels plucked straight out of London—but with a Midwest welcome. Pull up to the white Italian marble bar for bar director Brock Schulte’s inspired cocktails, which include the From Jura to Java, a drink that showcases Jura Superstition
Ingred: .5 oz Isle of Jura Superstition single-malt scotch.5 oz
2 dashes The Bitter Truth chocolate bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until properly diluted.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with 1 large ice cube.

Express the oil from a lemon peel over top.

Garnish with a black garlic financier (or other garnish of choice) on a curved pick.

Author: Big Bar, Chicago
About: This gin-and-cranberry Christmas cocktail just might earn you a kiss.
Instructions:
In a Collins glass, muddle the cranberries and orange.

Add the gin and simple syrup, and fill with ice.

Top with a mixture of two parts cranberry juice to one part club soda.

Stir with a thyme sprig and garnish with three additional cranberries.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: This cocktail was a Judges Choice Winner and was named Best in Show at the 2010 Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America Convention.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with two cherries on a cocktail pick or skewer.

Author: Crystal Sykes
About: Making your own cannabis-infused liquor that’ll give you a buzz in two ways isn’t as hard as you think. After decarbing your cannabis and infusing your spirit, you can then use that liquor to make this mezcal cocktail.
Garnish: Lime wheel and tajín spice rim
Instructions:
Rim a rocks glass with lime juice and press into a plate of tajín spice.  Set aside.

Add the cannabis-infused mezcal, lime juice and agave into a shaker with ice.

Shake well and strain into the tajín-rimmed rocks glass with fresh ice.

Add drops of the bitters and serve in a rocks glass.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: Get dizzy with this Averna and lemon cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with lemon and lime wheels.

About: This Daiquiri
Ingred: 1.5 oz Black Magic black spiced rum
1⁄3 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄3 oz
Instructions:
Blend all of the ingredients with ice in a blender.

Pour into a highball glass, and garnish with Italian sprinkles (jimmies) and a straw.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This delicious mix of rum and lemonade is a Beantown classic.
Ingred: 2 oz Smith & Cross Traditional Jamaica Rum
Instructions:
Fill a shaker with finely cracked ice.

Add the rum and fill with lemonade.

Shake briefly and pour (unstrained) into a pint glass.

Add a straw and garnish with either freshly grated nutmeg or half a strawberry and an orange slice.

About: This cognac cocktail is as easy-to-make as it is delicious.
Instructions:
Muddle the mint and lemon in a highball glass, then fill with ice.

Add the cognac and mint syrup.

Stir, and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: Ruby-red-infused vodka
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients, except for the beer, in a cocktail tin and shake.

Strain into a pint glass, and top with the beer.

Author: Brandon Lockman
About: What’s the one downside to enjoying a Spritz? Getting to the end of it, of course. Head bartender Brandon Lockman, the head bartender at Red Star Tavern
Instructions:
Coat the inside of a coupe or Nick & Nora glass with absinthe, remove the excess, and set aside.

Add the infused Aperol, Lillet and rhubarb bitters to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into the prepared glass, and top with sparkling wine.

Garnish with a speared strawberry and lemon twist.

Serve the remainder of the drink in a small carafe over ice alongside, if desired.

*Strawberry-infused Aperol: Soak 1/2 pint fresh strawberries in 1 750 mL bottle Aperol for at least 8 hours or overnight, then strain out solids.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: It doesn’t have to be Halloween to enjoy this cocktail.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe or Martini glass with absinthe and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Plymouth Gin
About: This old-timey recipe makes a delicious fruity classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with cracked ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball or Collins glass filled with fresh cubed ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon half-wheel and a cherry.

Author: Alex Frane
About:
Created at Upstairs at The Gwen in Chicago, this original recipe uses a house-made coffee cordial and coconut water, but home bartenders can easily replicate it by substituting brewed coffee and a bit of almond milk. Either way, it’s a slightly sweet, rich coffee drink that’s great for any time of day.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Coffee Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Pour the rum, whiskey and brewed coffee into a heated Irish coffee mug.

Top with the almond milk.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About: The Portobello Fajita Tacos aren’t just for vegetarians. Anyone who appreciates a good kick with their Mexican food will love these.
Ingred: 10 Large portobello mushroom caps, stems removed and sliced into ½-inch thick pieces
1 Large white onion, peeled and cut into 8 slices, like an orange
1 Red bell pepper, cut into 1-inch wide strips
1 Yellow bell pepper, cut into 1-inch wide strips
1 Green bell pepper, cut into 1-inch wide strips
.5 cup Fresh corn kernels, from 1 cob.5 cup
Corn tortillas warmed in an oven or grilled
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Skewer the mushrooms, onions and bell peppers. It’s best to not mix vegetables on the skewers as you may find they need slightly different cooking times. Place the skewers on a large baking sheet.

Combine the olive oil, cilantro, jalapeño, garlic and lime juice in a mixing bowl. Use a grill brush to brush the mixture onto the skewers on both sides, and finish with a pinch of salt and pepper. Refrigerate the vegetables for 20 minutes.

While the vegetables are marinating, heat a grill or grill pan up to high heat. Brush the grill or grill pan with canola oil and place all of the skewers in a single layer. Grill for 5 minutes, until the vegetables have begun to char, and flip and repeat for another five minutes.

Use tongs to remove the skewers from the grill and slide the vegetables off the skewers onto a serving platter.

Assemble the tacos starting with the grilled vegetables, followed by the corn, avocado, crema and squeeze of lime.

Author: Katie Astrauskas
About: This is a good Rickey to imbibe as you head into the fall. Instead of citrus and botanical flavors, this cocktail by Katie Astrauskas at Chicago’s GreenRiver
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with a lime wheel and freshly grated nutmeg.

*Cinnamon syrup: Mix 1 cup sugar and 1 cup boiling water, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Add 5 cinnamon sticks, remove from heat, and let sit for 2 hours. Pour into a jar, and let cool. Keeps refrigerated for up to 3 weeks.

Author: Trudy Thomas
About: It’s not traditional, but it is tropical and tasty.
Instructions:
Muddle the pineapple, mint and agave nectar in a tumbler, being careful not to pulverize the mint.

Add the rum, Navan and a handful of ice.

Top with club soda and stir.

Garnish with a pineapple wedge and a mint leaf.

Author: Jeff Berry
About: This tropical drink by legendary Donn Beach of Don the Beachcomber restaurant kicked off the Tiki
Instructions:
Put all of the ingredients in blender, adding 6 oz of crushed ice last.

Blend at high speed for no more than 5 seconds.

Pour into a glass, add ice cubes to fill, then add the garnish.

*Donn’s mix: Bring 3 crushed cinnamon sticks, 1 cup of sugar and 1 cup of water to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved.

Simmer for 2 minutes, then remove from the heat and let sit for at least 2 hours before straining into a clean glass bottle.

Then add 1 part of the syrup and 2 parts of fresh grapefruit juice together.

Author: Brown-Forman
About: A great orange-and-ginger twist on the classic Margarita.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a wine glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Jason Stevens
About: This unique twist on a Whiskey Sour uses maple syrup, port and Bittermens Molé Bitters.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Grade B maple syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a double Old Fashioned glass with ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and a cherry.

Author: Maria Hunt
About: This Champagne and Aperol combo is frothy, fizzy and sophisticated.
Instructions:
Add the Aperol, lemon juice, simple syrup and egg white to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake until well-chilled and frothy.

Pour the Champagne into a Martini glass.

Strain the Aperol mixture into the glass.

Pinch the strip of orange zest to release its oil into the glass and then lay it atop the foam.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
“The War Streets Spritz is named in honor of Franco Harris’ Italian army and the historic Mexican War Streets neighborhood on Pittsburgh’s North Side,” says bartender Michael Anderson of Butcher and the Rye. “Not far from the Steelers’ Heinz Field, War Streets represents an ideal setting for a low-alcohol pregame cocktail before walking down the hill for tailgating. Incorporating premium agave spirits and made in an Italian style, the War Streets Spritz is a great way to kick off a day of watching the Steelers dominate the competition.”
Ingred: .5 oz Del Maguey Vida mezcal.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the prosecco to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a Collis glass over ice, and top with the prosecco.

Garnish with 2 lemon wheels, 1 slice of fresh ginger root and 1 basil leaf.

*Ginger syrup: Add 8 oz of cleaned (no need to peel it), roughly chopped ginger (each piece should be about the size of your pinkie tip) 8 oz of sugar and 8 oz of boiling water to a blender and blend on high until mixture is smooth, then fine-strain through a sieve, and let cool to room temperature.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Absolut Vodka and the bitter aperitif Aperol combine to make this complex, citrusy cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with an orange wheel. .

Author: Chester Browne
About: A mug of this rich drink will fortify you against the cold and snow.
Instructions:
Rinse a coffee mug with boiling water to warm it up.

Add the rum and Buttered Rum Batter to the heated mug.

Top with boiling water and stir well to combine.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Alex Day
About: Say merci beaucoup to a glass of this warm wine-based drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a small saucepan.

Cook over medium heat until hot.

Pour into a thick-walled mug and garnish with an apple slice and a cinnamon stick.

Author: Franky Marshall
About: Try this drink named for the black cloaks worn by Dominican friars.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Pierre Ferrand Pineau des Charentes Selection
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a small wine or cocktail glass.

Twist a slice of lemon peel over the drink and use as garnish.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The Whiskey Sour is one classic cocktail that won’t make you sour.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (1 part water, 1 part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cherry and lemon wedge.

About: Named for a street in New Orleans, this herbaceous take on the Sazerac shines with maple and cardamom notes.
Instructions:
Fill a rocks glass with a hearty dash of the Chartreuse, then fill with crushed ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a rocks glass with fresh ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Discard the crushed ice from glass, ensuring it is adequately rinsed, and strain in the cognac mixture.

Express the oils from an orange twist and serve.

Author: Laura Bellucci
About: When SoBou’s executive chef Juan Carlos Gonzalez was ordering cases of perfectly in-season satsuma, a Chinese seedless and easy-peeling orange, bar chef Laura Bellucci felt she had to do a cocktail using the sweet fruit. “I really like working with Amaro Montenegro
Ingred: Chilled Simonet sparkling rosé, to top
Slice of satsuma or lemon peel, for garnish
Instructions:
Add the amaro, juice and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled flute, and top with the chilled sparkling wine.

Garnish with a satsuma slice or lemon peel.

*Ginger syrup: Purée 2 cups peeled sliced ginger and 2 cups boiling water on high in a Vitamix. Add 4 cups light brown sugar and stir to combine. Let macerate for a day, strain out solids and store syrup in the refrigerator.

About: Put on your Members Only jacket and mix up this ’80s classic.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

(To make a Hairy Navel, substitute vodka for half the peach schnapps.).

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The classic cocktail of gin and grapefruit is called a Greyhound. Add a salt rim, and it’s a Salty Dog. Mess it up with grapefruit beer and spicy seasoning salt, and you get a Bodega Dog.
Instructions:
Rim a highball glass with the Tajín, and fill with ice.

Pour in the gin or vodka, and top with the Schofferhofer.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: The Dry Martini is a classic cocktail that, like a tailored suit, is timeless. Although the original of the tipple is unclear, the Dry Martini has maintained a place in cocktail history due to being easy to use and endlessly sophisticated. Elegant for the fancy and boozy for the heavy-handed, this potation is truly the everyman’s cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until very cold and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: Short shake all the ingredients with 3 ice cubes, then double strain into a double rocks glass filled with crushed ice. Garnish with the apple fan and serve with a straw.
Ingred: .5 fl oz 10-year tawny port.5 fl oz
.5 fl oz Lemon juice.5 fl oz
.5 fl oz Maple syrup.5 fl oz

Author: Tripper Duval
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe glass with absinthe.

Add all ingredients except absinthe to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the rinsed glass.

Garnish with orange zest and peel.

Author: Bulleit
About: Spicy ginger syrup takes center stage in the delicious Rye Swizzle.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Ginger Syrup (such as Fee Brothers Warm Ginger Cordial Syrup) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Angostura and Peychaud's bitters to a shaker.

Shake (without ice) and pour into a highball glass.

Fill with crushed ice and swizzle, keeping the mint on the bottom of the glass.

Fill with more crushed ice and top with the bitters.

Garnish with a mint sprig and a piece of candied ginger.

Author: Justin Lavenue
About: Cassia bark and lemon peels are usually discarded. But in this room-temperature gin
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass without ice and stir well.
