In a small ramekin, combine cassia bark chips and dried lemon peel, then carefully light with a torch. After everything begins to smoke, invert a white wine glass over the ramekin, and capture the smoke inside the glass to season it for 20 to 30 seconds.

Strain the drink into the prepared wine glass.

Express the oils of lime and grapefruit peels over the glass, then discard.

Author: Galliano
About: Try the creamy, citrusy Golden Dream dessert drink after your next meal.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Cointreau or other orange liqueur
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Ryan Fitzgerald
About: This gin drink will help guide your night.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Cointreau
About: Try this extra-citrusy spin on the classic French 75.
Instructions:
Add the Cointreau and bitters to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Domaine de Canton
About: Strike it rich with ginger liqueur and bourbon.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: The Aperol Spritz was the drink of the summer a few years ago. Beefeater Gin has given it a London upgrade by combining the bittersweet flavors of Aperol with the classic notes of a Gin &  Tonic.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a goblet or large wine glass filled with ice.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

About: You can’t get much easier than this refreshing two-ingredient cognac cocktail.
Instructions:
Add 4 to 5 cubes of Kold-Draft ice to a Highball glass.

Add the cognac.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Michael McCollum
About: This cocktail is inspired by the classic Jack Rose cocktail (apple brandy, lime, grenadine) and uses Amaro di Angostura instead of brandy. The bracing drink, named for a character in pirate legends (Angostura is from Trinidad, hence the name), is all about the balance of the spice and bitterness of amaro, vibrant lime and the sweet-tart grenadine.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake vigorously, and strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lime wedge and serve.

Author: Dane Barca
About: A strong whiskey concoction and a fizzy lemon-juice mix combine in an elegant dance.
Ingred: 1.5 oz George Dickel Old No. 8 Tennessee Whisky
Instructions:
Add the Gran Gala, Punt e Mes, whisky and bitters to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir to combine.

Add the remaining ingredients to a second mixing glass and fill with ice.

Strain the contents of both mixing glasses simultaneously into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange peel and grated nutmeg.

Author: Jennifer Peters
About:
This light, effervescent drink by Jennifer Peters at Denver’s Just BE Kitchen is perfect in the morning or during tea time. It’s festive and fun, and you can change the whole flavor profile and health benefits depending on what kind of kombucha you use.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Everything You Need to Know About the Drinks That Could Save Your Morning.”
Instructions:
Pour the sparkling wine into a Champagne flute.

Top with the kombucha.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
Okay, okay: It’s not technically a Martini if it’s made with tequila. But this kicky version of the classic is well worth going against the grain for. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.

Shake and double strain into a martini glass.

Garnish with lemon twist.

Author: Don Lee
About: You can’t refuse this complex beverage.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Top with prosecco and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Sailor Jerry Rum
About: Get your sea legs with this nautical spiced-rum concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients, except ginger beer, to a highball or rocks glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Top with ginger beer.

Author: Yuri Kato
About: Enjoy Japanese whisky’s sweeter side.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled Martini glass, and garnish with a maraschino cherry.

Author: Vanessa Coupar
About: Bartender Vanessa Coupar (currently the bar manager at El Santo
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Crème de cacao liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Pour all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with shaved chocolate.

Author: Rémy Martin
About: Make this classic the old-fashioned way, with French brandy.
Ingred: 2 oz Rémy Martin 1738 Accord Royal Cognac
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, sugar and a dash of water.

Add the cognac and fill with shaved ice.

Shake until frosted and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

About: A burst of C02 gives the traditional Horse’s Neck a breath of fresh air.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredient except the C02 to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Collins glass.

Top with the C02 and lemon peel.

*Honey ginger syrup: Combine 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar, 1 cup honey, 5 cup ginger juice and 2 orange peels in a saucepan over medium heat. Whisk until the sugar dissolves, then cover and remove from the heat. Let cool to room temperature and fine-strain.

About: Try a brighter, fresher take on the French 75 with honey and ginger.
Ingred: 1 oz Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a burnt lime wheel.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: You don’t have to drink this out of a coconut shell, but…
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and fill with ice. Blend until smooth.

Pour into a hollowed-out coconut shell or a mug and garnish with cherries and coconut shavings.

Author: Willie Jane
About: Ginger, lavender and honey grace this Southern bourbon drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with a large ice cube.

Garnish with a slapped lavender sprig.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: The classic combination of gin, lime juice and simple syrup gets a fresh-produce boost in the Cucumber, Basil & Lime Gimlet. Swap out gin for vodka, add a little lemonade and you’ve got the ideal warm-weather cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the basil and cucumber.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge or cucumber wheel.

Author: Cody Modeer
About: This bourbon cocktail is perfect for fall.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass, and garnish with lime zest peel.

Author: Kara Newman
About: All aboard for this legendary gin libation!
Ingred: .5 oz White crème de cacao.5 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled for about 15 seconds.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe, and top with a lemon twist.

Author: David Wondrich
About: The recipe for this classic Philadelphia tipple is at least 200 years old.
Ingred: 750 ml Smith & Cross Traditional Jamaica Rum (or other strong, pungent Jamaican )
Instructions:
At least a day ahead, fill a 2-quart bowl with water and freeze until completely solid.

In a large punch bowl, muddle the lemon peels and sugar.

Let the mixture stand for at least 3 hours.

Add the boiling water, stirring until as much as possible of the sugar has dissolved.

Add the remaining ingredients and stir to combine.

To serve, add the ice block and garnish liberally with freshly grated nutmeg.

This recipe serves 25.

Author: Joaquín Simó
About: An elegant spin on the classic Whiskey Sour, the Kilbeggan Secret Sour uses Irish whiskey, lemon and grapefruit.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Nolet's Silver Dry Gin
About: This two-ingredient cocktail is a simple gin concoction. Try the NOLET’S Silver Dutch Mule now.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a wine glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a large grapefruit wheel and a sprig of mint.

Author: Jonny Raglin
About: Have a taste of the Emerald Isle.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake heavily for about a minute and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with three drops of mint bitters.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Have a few thirsty buddies? Mix up a few of these for a grand slam.
Instructions: Add ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Author: Killian Lee
About: For this cocktail, Jameson
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the stout to a mixing tin and stir.

Strain into a rocks or mini stout glass.

Dry-shake (without ice) the stout, and add to the top of the cocktail.

*Ginger-brown-sugar syrup: Combine equal parts fresh ginger juice with dark brown sugar in a blender, and blend until fully incorporated.

Author: Kenta Goto
About: Mix up this gin, citrus juice, St-Germain elderflower liqueur and Champagne cocktail for a taste of paradise.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an edible pansy if desired.

Author: Adam McDowell
About: Adam McDowell’s book Drinks: A User’s Guide offers ways to enjoy a cocktail under less-than-ideal circumstances, calling such a drink an ad-hoctail, including this Un-Cosmopolitan.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and Kool-Aid into a child’s sippy cup with ice.

Close the lid, shake, add a splash of orange soda, and enjoy.

About: A cocktail with peanut rum, chocolate liqueur and vodka. Take that, Reese’s!
Ingred: 1.5 oz Van Gogh Dutch Chocolate Vodka
Instructions:
Drizzle chocolate syrup along the inside of a chilled Martini glass and place the glass in the refrigerator.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a peanut butter cup.

Author: Lucien Conner
About: Basically the cocktail version of salsa verde, this Michelada
Ingred: 1⁄4 cup Tabasco green jalapeño sauce 1⁄4 cup
Salt and lime wedges, for rimming
Instructions:
Makes 6.

Peel the cucumbers and tomatillos, and roughly chop.

Grill the jalapeños until blistered and slightly blackened.

Add the cucumbers, tomatillos, jalapeños, lime juice, black pepper and hot sauce into a blender, and blend until smooth.

Strain into a large container.

Rim 6 Highball glasses with salt and fill with ice.

Fill each glass with 5 oz of the mixture, and serve each with a beer.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
“Introduced in 1930, Honolulu blue and silver have been the distinctive look of the Detroit Lions for almost the entire life of the franchise,” says Selden Standard bartender Rob Wilson. “Inspired by those colors, the cocktail features blueberries and [blue agave] silver tequila. The idea is to have the vinegar create a really pungent garnish, kind of like a pickled onion on a Martini. Fresh berries will lack that zing, so I’d definitely suggest pickling them or even just soaking them overnight in Champagne vinegar to at least get some of that flavor.”
(As for the name, in 1958, the Lions traded quarterback Bobby Layne to the Pittsburgh Steelers. Layne, in response, supposedly said the Lions would not win for 50 years—though this statement has been disputed as a hoax and was never published at the time. But for the next 50 years, the Lions had the worst winning percentage of any NFL team.)
Ingred: 1 oz 100 percent blue agave silver tequila
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.

Strain into a cocktail glass or coupe, and garnish with 3 pickled blueberries on a toothpick.

*Pickled blueberries: Gently warm blueberries in a small pot with a little Champagne vinegar, salt and sugar, and let cool overnight.

About: This cocktail manages the impressive feat of using award-winning single malt in a light and refreshing cocktail. Make one for yourself to discover how cooling scotch can be.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing tin and stir.

Pour into a Highball glass over ice.

Garnish with a mint leaf and lemon slice.

Author: Alex Frane
About: Chicago’s RPM Steak
Ingred: 1 oz Blaum Bros. Oak Reserve gin
.5 oz Carpano Antica Formula vermouth.5 oz
3⁄4 bottle Fever-Tree Indian tonic water 3⁄4 bottle
Instructions:
Fill a Burgundy wine glass halfway with cracked ice.

Add the gin, fernet and vermouth, then top with the tonic water.

Garnish with 2 dehydrated (or fresh) lemon wheels, 1 cinnamon stick and 4 star anise.

Express the oil from an orange peel over top.

Author: Paul McGee
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a large shaker.

Add one cup of crushed ice and shake vigorously for five seconds.

Pour entire contents of shaker into a large tiki bowl.

Add two additional cups of ice and garnish tropically.

About: Hang 10 with a Tiki-inspired cognac cocktail laced with coconut and banana.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Tiki mug filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with cacao dust.

*Cinnamon-honey syrup: Bring 2 cups of water and 4 cinnamon sticks to a boil, and let simmer for 15 minutes. Add 2 cups honey and stir to dissolve. Let cool before using.

Author: Nonna Titulauri
About: It’s time to give your G&T
Instructions:
Pour the gin into a wine glass filled 3/4 with ice.

Top with the tonic.

Place juniper berries, a lemon wheel and thyme into the glass.

*Suggested alternate garnish combinations:.

Sliced fig, lavender/verbena flower, vanilla bean, lemon wheel, juniper berries.

Sliced peach, thyme, saffron, lemon wheel, juniper berries.

Author: Victoria D'amato-Moran
About: The red-and-green punch screams Christmas cheer.
Ingred: .5 oz Flor de Cana Rum Platino.5 oz
Garnish: 1 Cranberries, pear slices pierced with cloves, 2 cinnamon sticks and winter melon balls
Glass: Cocktail or punch   Cocktail or punch   Cocktail or punch
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into a cocktail or punch glass.

Garnish with the cranberries, pear slices pierced with cloves, 2 cinnamon sticks and winter melon balls.

To make a punch version multiply the recipe by eight.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
A taco with spiced cauliflower? Absolutely! These simple roasted-cauliflower tacos are big on flavor and easy to put together. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: 4 oz chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, finely chopped
3⁄4 cup sour cream plus extra for serving 3⁄4 cup
Corn tortillas, warmed in the oven or grilled
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Preheat oven to 425℉ degrees and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. You may need to use two pans depending on their size because you don’t want to overcrowd the cauliflower pieces during roasting.

In a large mixing bowl, toss the cauliflower florets in the olive oil to evenly coat. Add the cumin, chili powder and a hefty pinch of salt and pepper and toss to combine. Pour the cauliflower out onto the prepared baking sheets in a single layer, making sure the florets are not crammed together. Roast for about 45 minutes, until the bottoms of the florets have browned and are extremely tender with crispy edges. Remove from the oven.

In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the chipotle peppers and ¾ cup sour cream. Add the cauliflower and toss to evenly coat.

Assemble the tacos starting with the cauliflower, followed by red onion, additional sour cream and cilantro.

Author: Joshua Pearson
About: This drink proves that gin and beer play well together.
Garnish: 1 Long strip of lemon peel and cinnamon stick
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the pale ale to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the pale ale and garnish with a long strip of lemon peel and a cinnamon stick.

About: Violet liqueur gives this pineapple Daiquiri
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients and 1 lime wedge into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a chilled Martini glass, and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Cameron Dale
About: This super easy vodka cocktail is popular with those trying to cut calories.
Instructions:
In a Collins glass, add the vodka, fill with ice, top with the club soda, and add a squeeze of lemon.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Brandi Austin
About:
For your next party, make this shot from Brandi Austin of STIRR in Dallas. You can sub in vodka for the Frangelico liqueur if you want it a touch more potent.

This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tired of Boring Bartender Staff Parties? These Tips Will Change How You Celebrate.”
Instructions:
Pre-batch equal parts Baileys Irish cream, crème de menthe and Frangelico liqueurs and chill.

Drizzle chocolate sauce in a shot glass.

Add 1-oz servings of the batch.

Garnish with whipped cream and mint leaves.

About: The Martini’s savory second cousin, the Gibson uses a pickled cocktail onion in place of the typical briny olive to add an umami undertone to the classic cocktail. The Gibson is believed to have been created by San Francisco businessman Walter D.K. Gibson in the late 1800s, who thought that eating onions prevented colds, hence the addition of the mini allium.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a whole cocktail onion.

Author: Morgan Zuch
About: The folks at Datz
Ingred: 1 Jalapeño pepper, sliced in half, plus 3 fresh jalapeño slices
3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (1 part honey, 1 part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the 3 slices of the jalapeño pepper in the honey syrup, lime juice and matcha concentrate.

Add the mezcal, coco liqueur and orange flower water and shake.

Double-strain into a rocks glass over ice.

Cut a small slit in 2 jalapeño peppers and anchor them on either side of the glass to create a Yoda ear garnish.

About: This brunch cocktail, served at Barcelona’s popular Xixbar, is ideal for an early-morning pick-me-up.
Instructions:
Shake the gin, lemon and lime juices, simple syrup, egg white and bitters with ice, strain and serve in highball glass with 2 ice cubes.

Fill with club soda. Garnish with an orange peel and 2 bendy straws.

Author: John Besh
About: Enjoy the classic New Orleans cocktail, Brandy Milk Punch, with brunch.
Ingred: 3 tbsp Powdered sugar, plus more to taste
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and fill with ice.

Blend for 20 seconds.

Taste, and add more sugar if desired.

Strain the mixture into four tall glasses filled with crushed ice.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The beautiful thing about shrubs is that there are only two rules: something sweet and something acidic. Typically some variety of sugar does the heavy lifting, but here maple syrup offers a perfect hit of character and complexity. And although the beets maybe seem like an odd or unnecessary addition, they actually keep the sweetness in check with a welcome earthiness, and the shrub makes a fantastic mixer in this riff on a Margarita.
Ingred: 1⁄4 Lime juice, plus lime wheel for garnish 1⁄4
Instructions:
Add the mezcal, maple beet shrub, lime juice and ice to a cocktail shaker and shake well.

On one plate, pour the maple syrup. On another plate, mix the salt and pepper. Dip the rocks glass in the maple syrup and gently shake to remove excess before dipping into the salt and pepper mixture.

Strain the drink into the prepared glass, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Douglass Miller
About: Do some molecular gastronomy at home.
Instructions:
Line a jelly-roll pan with parchment paper and lightly grease the paper with oil.

Cut a second piece of parchment paper the same size, oil it lightly and set aside.

Sprinkle the gelatin over half a cup of cold water and briefly stir to completely moisten it and break up any clumps.

Let the gelatin sit in the cold water until it swells and softens (10 to15 minutes).

Combine the sugar and corn syrup with the remaining half cup of water in a heavy bottomed saucepan and stir to moisten the sugar.

Cook over high heat, stirring constantly until the mixture comes to a boil.

Immediately stop stirring and skim the surface to remove any scum that has risen to the top.

Continue to cook over high heat, occasionally brushing down the side of the pan using a pastry brush and water, until the mixture registers 242 degrees on a candy thermometer.

Remove the mixture from the heat and let cool to approximately 210 degrees.

Place the gelatin in a heatproof-bowl over a pan of simmering water.

Stir constantly until the mixture is clear and liquid.

Mix the liqueur into the dissolved gelatin.

Mix the gelatin into the cooked sugar mixture and transfer to a mixing bowl.

Whip the mixture with an electric mixer on high-speed until medium peaks form (about eight to 10 minutes).

Quickly spread the mixture onto the lined pan.

Top the mixture with the prepared oiled parchment paper and use a rolling pin to smooth it into an even slab.

Place the pan in the freezer for at least eight and up to 24 hours before taking the slab out of the pan.

After chilling, gently peel off the paper from one side.

Lightly dust the marshmallow slab with some cornstarch.

Flip the slab over and gently peel off the parchment paper from the other side.

Dust with cornstarch.

Cut the marshmallows to your desired size.

You can store the marshmallows in an airtight container in the freezer for up to four months.

Author: Dustin Drankiewicz, The Promontory
About: This cocktail was created by Dustin Drankiewicz at Promontory for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add the cognac, lemon juice and sugar to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a flute, and top with the Champagne.

Garnish by twisting the lemon over the surface of the drink to express its oils, then drop the peel into the drink.

Author: Michael Dietsch
About: Opt for a high-proof rye, such as Rittenhouse 100-proof, in this variation on the classic Manhattan from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, and add the ingredients.

Stir for about 30 seconds, until well chilled, and strain into a chilled rocks glass.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: A vodka and citrus explosion.
Instructions:
Pour Van Gogh Oranje Vodka and orange juice into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a flute.

Top with sparkling wine and garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Alex Frane
About:
Campari liqueur and pineapple juice in your cup of joe? Yep! From Cindy’s in Chicago, this cocktail is a balancing act of bitter and sweet, with a backbone of Amaro Meletti and cold-brew coffee. Think of it as Tiki’s Italian cousin with a caffeine buzz.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Coffee Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a double rocks glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with 1 cinnamon stick.

Author: Blade & Bow
About: Earthy Cynar and Maraschino liqueur balance each other in this smooth bourbon-based coupe.
Ingred: 1 1⁄3 oz Blade & Bow Kentucky Straight Bourbon Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupette.

Author: Naren Young
About: Kumquats are perfect partners for brown spirits. Turn the bittersweet fruit into an inspired cocktail syrup and shake it into a fresh Whiskey Sour or a warming Hot Toddy.
Instructions:
Add the water and sugar to a medium sized saucepan and bring to a low boil.

Add the kumquats.

Press down using a potato masher to release more flavor from the fruit.

Bring back to a low boil and turn the heat off.

Allow the mixture to cool and strain it into a clean container.

Mix in the vodka to preserve for up to one month.

Author: RumChata
About: Try RumChata’s take on the classic Root Beer Float.
Ingred: 1 oz Root beer (A&W; or Dad’s Root Beer)
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a Rocks glass filled with fresh ice and stir to combine.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Try this lemon twist on the classic Margarita, with an egg white for extra richness.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice, shake again and strain into a coupe glass.

Twist a swatch of orange peel over the drink and discard.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This gin
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, express the oil of a lemon peel over the drink, and garnish with that lemon peel.

About: Mint liqueur, mocha gelato and a whole lotta love go into this frozen drink from New Orleans’ Erin Rose.
Instructions:
Blend the Brancamenta, gelato and milk in a blender until smooth.

Serve in a 12 oz plastic cup, and top with coffee.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: No seed-spitting required.
Ingred: 1 cup Seedless watermelon, cut into 1-inch cubes
1⁄4 oz Agave syrup (1 part agave nectar, 1 part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Muddle the watermelon and agave syrup in a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients and ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a watermelon slice.

Author: Zach Faden
About: Washington, D.C. French restaurant Mirabelle
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz One Eight Distilling District Made vodka 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz G.E. Massenez Mirabelle plum brandy 3⁄4 oz
Schramsberg Mirabelle brut rosé, to top Schramsberg Mirabelle brut rosé, to top
Instructions:
Add the brandy, vodka, juice and syrup to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled flute, and top with the chilled sparkling wine.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Bénédictine
About: Practice your couplets and quatrains while sipping this cocktail named for the Scottish poet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Twist a lemon peel over the glass to release its oils and then drop it into the drink.

Author: Juan Bautista
About: The addition of gum syrup lends silky richness to this frothy classic.
Instructions:
Combine the first five ingredients in a shaker.

Dry shake for 15 seconds, then add ice and shake again to chill.

Double strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Dot the top with drops of Angostura bitters.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Drink like Bogie, Bacall and the Rat Pack: This was the house cocktail of their favorite Hollywood watering hole.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except ginger beer to a tall glass.

Fill halfway with cracked ice, drop in a juiced lime half, fill with ice and top with ginger beer.

This was the house cocktail of the Los Angeles restaurant where the Rat Pack was formed and Bogart and Bacall did their drinking.

Author: Bols Genever
About: Dutch genever makes an intriguing version of this classic Italian aperitif.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a large piece of orange zest or an orange half-wheel.

About: Since 1938, it’s been a tradition to enjoy a Mint Julep at the Kentucky Derby in Louisville. The drink is made with good old Kentucky bourbon, but you can’t beat the flavor and smoothness that’s added by substituting it for Bacardí 8 Años rum.
Instructions:
Add the mint leaves, syrup and bitters into mixing glass, and using the end of a barspoon, gently press them together.

Add cubed ice, add the rum, and give it a good stir.

Fine-strain into a rocks glass over crushed ice.

Stir again, and top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with mint leaves.

Author: Alex Day
About: The crisp freshness of the Spanish white wine pairs perfectly with fresh mint.
Ingred: 3 oz Albariño wine (Terras Gauda Abadia de San Campio 2009)
1 tsp Crème de pêche (or high-quality peach liqueur)
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a julep or large old fashioned glass.

Add lots of crushed ice and garnish lavishly with mint.

Author: Liquor.com
About: This sparkling classic got its start at Venice’s famed Harry’s Bar.
Instructions:
Add the peach purée to a Champagne flute and fill with prosecco.

Garnish with a peach slice.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: A tasty twist on a Brazilian classic.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the sugar, raspberries and lime.

Add the cachaça and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with an additional raspberry.

Author: Joann Spiegel
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a punch glass.

Grate a cinnamon stick over top.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Paul Dellevigne
About: Try this simple but sophisticated Scotch-and-Cynar cocktail.
Ingred: 1 oz The Macallan 12 Years Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Mike Isabella
About: Bourbon and ginger liqueur combine most deliciously in this concoction.
Garnish: 1 Lime wedge stuffed with candied ginger
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Push a piece of candied ginger into the flesh of a lime wedge, squeeze over the drink and drop it in as a garnish.

Author: Andrew Olsen
Ingred: 1.5 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
3⁄4 oz Tea leaf honey syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients in shaker tin, dry shake, wet shake and strain into chilled coupe.

Garnish with drops of Angostura bitters in the foam.

About: This cognac-based Rickey is tart, bubbly and a perfect summertime sipper.
Instructions:
Place the lime wheel and ice in a Collins glass.

Muddle the lime and raspberries in a shaker.

Add the cognac with ice to the shaker and shake.

Double-strain into the Collins glass and top with the Champagne.

Garnish with an additional lime wheel.

About: Embrace the simplicity of a restrained layered cocktail.
Instructions:
Pour each of the ingredients in the order listed directly into a snifter.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Revae Schneider
About: Chicago cocktail consultant Revae Schneider is fond of anything with rum, lemon, maple syrup and a little bit of bitters, served warm. Set this fragrant punch on the stovetop before guests arrive and let the comforting scent waft as they walk in the door. Or, transfer to an ice-filled punchbowl if the weather’s still warm.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients, except the bitters, to a large saucepan over medium heat.

Stir to blend.

Once warm, transfer to a punch bowl for serving, or ladle into glasses directly from the pot.

Add two dashes of Angostura Bitters to each punch cup.

Serve warm, or transfer to an ice-filled punchbowl for warmer weather.

Author: Rémy Martin
About: Rémy Martin Cognac and white wine, crowned with a fresh-grape garnish.
Ingred: 2 oz 1738 Accord Royal Rémy Martin Cognac
1.5 oz Sancerre or sauvignon blanc wine
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the grapes and simple syrup.

Add the cognac and wine, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with additional grapes.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About:
Few actresses captured the world’s imagination like Greta Garbo did in the 1920s and ’30s. The Swedish-born star won her way into people’s hearts with roles in such films as “Torrent,” “Flesh and the Devil” and her first talkie, “Anna Christie,” whose opening line—“Give me a whiskey, ginger ale on the side, and don’t be stingy, baby!”—cemented her legendary status in Hollywood and beyond. 
So it’s no surprise that someone created a cocktail in her honor. But who invented it and where? Sadly, those details have eluded history. What we do know is that famous people often inspire famously delicious drinks, and this one’s no exception. Adapted from Knut Sundin’s 1930 book, “Two Hundred Selected Drinks,” this recipe calls for a delicate mix of BACARDÍ® Carta Blanca rum, Cointreau liqueur, fresh lime juice and grenadine, made silky with a few drops of absinthe. Whiskey and ginger it ain’t. But we think Garbo would love it just the same.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe with 2 dashes of absinthe, then discard.

Add the remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Fine-strain into the prepared coupe.

Garnish with a star anise.

About: This garden-fresh simple syrup recipe will add a refreshing hit of mint to your favorite cocktails.
Instructions:
Combine the sugar and mint in a bowl.

Add water and stir until sugar is dissolved.

Steep the mint leaves for 15 minutes.

Strain into a jar, cover and refrigerate for up to two weeks.

Author: Amy Zavatto
About: This classic cocktail from the 1920s and ’30s takes its name from its main ingredient of applejack and the resulting color from grenadine.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lime or lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Fine-strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a lime or lemon twist.

Author: Tony Abou-Ganim
About: Tony Abou-Ganim’s tasty pumpkin and cinnamon cocktail is the perfect drink for a fall party.
Garnish: 1 Whipped cream and freshly grated nutmeg
Instructions:
Separate the eggs and refrigerate the whites.

In a mixing bowl, beat the yolks until creamy.

Gradually add in .25 lb sugar, beating at high speed until thick.

Stir in the rum, milk, vanilla, cinnamon and pumpkin, and chill for at least two hours.

Beat the egg whites until soft peaks form.

Add the remaining .25 lb sugar, beating to stiff peaks.

Fold the chilled rum mixture into the egg whites.

Serve in Martini glasses garnished with freshly grated nutmeg and a dollop of whipped cream.

Author: Erik Adkins
About: The cocktail equivalent of a New York egg cream, this rich and fizzy bourbon drink is absolutely delicious.
Ingred: .5 oz House Spirits Coffee Liqueur or other coffee liqueur.5 oz
.5 oz Almond orgeat (bottled or homemade).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and double-strain into an 8-ounce Fizz or Collins glass.

Fill with club soda, pouring from about 6 inches above the glass.

Wait a few seconds and then add another splash of sodaÂ-this will Â"liftÂ" the foam above the top of the glass.

Serve with a straw.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“When you think about spirits in the desert of Arizona, tequila
Ingred: .5 oz Watermelon syrup (1:1 watermelon juice:sugar).5 oz
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until cold.

Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass, and garnish with a dried lemon wheel.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: Break out the bubbly for this classic cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Fill with Champagne and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Desiree Bacala
About: This cocktail from Public Belt at the Hilton New Orleans Riverside changes color from light purple to deep purple to a bright fuschia.
Ingred: 1 Dropper of b’Lure butterfly pea flower extract
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except for the lemon juice into a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a Martini glass, and add the lemon juice to change the color.

Author: The Dead Rabbit
About: Looking for a refreshing drink? Try this tequila, watermelon and grenadine cooler.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice. Fill with chilled club soda.

Author: Teddy Nixon
About:
At Bar Mash in Charleston, S.C., bar manager Teddy Nixon wanted to replicate the changing leaves during a New England autumn. “I also wanted the flavors to change from bright and sunny to a little more earthy and spicy,” he says. “So the drink goes from bright green to a deep red, just like the leaves.” The trick? Ice cubes made with pomegranate, beets and allspice, which transform the color of the drink’s muddled baby peas.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Can the Classic Drinks of Summer Be Transformed for Winter? Yes. And This Is How.”
Ingred: 2 barspoons Le Sueur very young small sweet peas
Instructions:
Muddle the peas in the bottom of mixing tin, then add the remaining ingredients.

Add ice and hard-shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a short-stemmed glass.

Top with flavored ice cubes.

*Small pomegranate/beet/allspice ice cubes: Combine 2 cups pomegranate juice, 1/2 cup red beet juice, 3 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram and 20 dashes The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas' bitters in a pitcher. Freeze in ice cube trays.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Gin, grapefruit juice and absinthe make one tasty drink.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled cocktail or coupe glass with absinthe and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About:
There’s a reason the Aperol Spritz is making a comeback. It’s one of the most popular apéritifs in Italy, and it’s as tasty as it is refreshing. Low in alcohol, aromatic with citrus and slightly bitter, Aperol pairs perfectly with chilled prosecco. The Aperol Spritz is as easy to make as it is to drink, meaning it’s perfect for any time of day and any occasion. It doesn’t hurt that it has a gorgeous coral hue.
Meeting friends for an after-work Spritz is a long-established Italian tradition and one that’s easily replicated anywhere.
Instructions:
Pour the prosecco into a Collins glass filled with ice.

Add the Aperol and lime wheel, and top with club soda.

About: This vodka cocktail is both sweet and tart.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Double-strain into cocktail glass.

Top with splash of grapefruit soda.

Garnish with grapefruit peel.
Theme: Brunch Fall Holiday Season Romantic Spring Summer Winter

Author: Tad Carducci
About: With a mezcal base plus apple cider and a fizzy apple soda, this cocktail makes an intriguing fall sipper.
Instructions:
If desired, combine equal parts five-spice powder and sugar, and use to coat the rim of a tall glass.

Fill the glass with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients except the Sidral Mundet to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with the Sidral Mundet and stir gently.

Garnish with an apple slice.

About: The combination of mezcal, blood orange and fine single malt is as surprising as it is delicious. This refreshing and complex original cocktail is perfect for almost any occasion.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Cruz de Fuego espadín mezcal 3⁄4 oz
1 oz Fresh blood orange juice with citric acid
Instructions:
Prepare a rocks glass with a chocolate, chipotle and sea salt powder rim.

Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a dehydrated blood orange wheel.

Author: Phil Ward
About: This spicy and sweet cocktail will have you seeing stars.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña 4 Year-Old Rum
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the sugar cubes and 1 oz of the club soda until they dissolve.

Add several 1-inch pieces of watermelon and muddle again.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir until well chilled.

Strain into a snifter with one large ice cube inside.

Top with the remaining 2 oz club soda and garnish with a pineapple slice and a strawberry.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This historic summer punch brings back the good ol’ days.
Instructions:
In a 1-gallon punch bowl, muddle the lemon peels with the sugar and let stand for 3 or 4 hours.

Add the lemon juice and stir until the sugar dissolves.

Add the remaining ingredients and stir to combine.

Slide in a 1-quart block of ice and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Ladle into punch cups in 3-ounce portions.

(This recipe makes about 30 servings).

Author: Pama Pomegranate Liqueur
About: This tart, fruity and fizzy recipe makes about a gallon of punch.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger ale to a bowl or pitcher and refrigerate until cold.

Pour the mixture into a large punch bowl and fill with ice.

Gently stir in the ginger ale and garnish with orange, lemon and lime slices.

Author: Seth Weinberg
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.

“A classic Margarita
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Cut an orange peel into the shape of a dolphin.

Strain the mix into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with the orange peel.

Jalapeño agave syrup: Combine 12 oz agave syrup, 12 oz filtered water and 2 to 3 sliced jalapeños in a saucepot. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally. Reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes, tasting periodically until reaching desired level of spiciness. Remove from heat and skim off and discard jalapeño slices. Cool to room temperature before using. Will keep in the refrigerator for about 1 month.

Author: Theo Lieberman
About: This scotch cocktail will warm you up for a night of caroling or any time.
Ingred: 2 oz The Macallan Fine Oak 10-year-old single-malt scotch
1⁄4 oz St. Elizabeth allspice dram 1⁄4 oz
.5 oz Honey syrup (1 part honey, 1 part water).5 oz
Garnish: Barker & Mills bourbon vanilla cocktail cherry
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with grated nutmeg and a Barker & Mills Bourbon Vanilla Cocktail Cherry.

Author: Jon Gasparini
About: Throw a party South American style.
Instructions:
Add the lemon juice and cloves to a Tupperware container or cake mold and freeze until solid.

Add the remaining ingredients to a large punch bowl and add the lemon ice block.

Author: Kristen Struckmeyer
About: The fresh peaches of summer may be long gone, but you can relive the magic in this fruity fun cocktail. All you need is vodka, peach schnapps, pineapple juice and a little mint, and you can party like it’s the middle of July.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda water to a shaker with cubed ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a double Old Fashioned glass over crushed ice.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Charles Joly
About: An alliance of Irish and French spirits yields one delicious concoction.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Twist a piece of lemon peel over the top and drop into the drink.

Drink Name: I Left My Heart in Jalisco
Author: William Batson
About: This warm, spicy and romantic tequila  cocktail makes enough for two.
Ingred: .5 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the milk, cocoa powder and chocolate to a saucepan over medium heat and cook, stirring, until the chocolate melts.

Add the sugar, star anise, vanilla bean, Cayenne pepper and salt, reduce the heat to low and cook for about 10 minutes.

Strain the mixture into two mugs, and add 1.25 ounces of tequila and .25 ounces of Ancho Reyes to each.

Stir, and garnish with orange twists and a sprinkle of cocoa powder.

Author: Matt Lewis
About: You’ll never look at ice cream the same way again.
Ingred: 3 cup Premium vanilla ice cream, plus more if needed
Instructions:
Place 4 heavy pint glasses in the freezer to chill for 30 minutes.

Add the ice cream, milk, ice cubes, bourbon and 4 tbsp of the chocolate syrup to a powerful blender.

Blend until smooth.

(A good milkshake should be eaten with a spoon, �-so if the mixture seems too thin, add another .25 to .5 cup ice cream and blend again.).

Divide evenly among the prepared glasses and top each with .5 tbsp of the remaining chocolate syrup.

Serve immediately.

About: This strawberry-mint cognac cocktail is a perfect for drinking on a porch on a warm summer evening.
Instructions:
Muddle the strawberries and mint sprig in a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients and ice, and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and strawberry.

Author: Phil Ward
About: Spice up your night with this complex cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
Instructions:
In a shaker, dissolve the sugar cubes in 1 ounce of the club soda.

Add the cardamom and muddle.

Add the rum, lime juice, grapefruit juice and bitters, one at a time, while stirring.

Fill with ice and stir.

Strain into a cocktail or punch glass and top with the remaining 2 ounces of club soda.

Garnish with lime wheels.

Author: Meaghan Dorman
About: It won’t help you navigate, but it’s delicious.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Compass Box The Peat Monster Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Sean Kenyon
About: Crushed beans and Colorado whiskey make this tasty concoction fit for even the most grizzled cattle-driver.
Instructions:
In a shaker, crush the coffee beans.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Squeeze a lemon peel over the drink and garnish with the peel and an additional coffee bean.

Author: Erik Adkins
About: Love the Tom Collins? Try its frothy, bubbly cousin, the Gin Fizz. The secret to creating the perfect creaminess and froth is to shake, shake, shake—and then shake some more.
Instructions:
Add the club soda to a Fizz or Collins glass and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice for about 10 seconds.

Add 3 or 4 ice cubes and shake very well.

Double-strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: This Shandy served at San Francisco’s  Homeroom is ideal for those completely green to mixing cocktails who want something light for summer.
Instructions: Combine the kölsch and limeade in a Mason jar and enjoy.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: Cheerleaders would be a lot more entertaining if they practiced this one more often.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: This gin classic (and bartender favorite) is bitter and sweet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir to combine.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Warren Lindsay
About: This sake-based cocktail from Warren Lindsay of Andaz Tokyo is inspired by beautiful cherry blossoms.
Ingred: .5 oz Kirsch with Griotte Cherries.5 oz
Instructions: Add all ingredients, except the Kirsch, to a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir, and strain into a sake glass over one large piece of ice. Float the Kirsch over top and garnish with a sakura flower and cherry.

Author: Rémy Martin
About: No need to get dressed up to enjoy this cognac cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz 1738 Accord Royal Rémy Martin Cognac
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled rocks glass.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

Author: Juan Coronado
About:
This boozy hot cider touches all the bases: BACARDÍ Carta Oro gold rum, apple cider, chamomile tea and a one-two punch of simple syrup and citrus to round out the edges. For an added snap of seasonal spice, don’t miss the grated nutmeg garnish.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 BACARDÍ Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Ingred: 2 oz BACARDÍ Carta Oro gold rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pot and bring to a boil.

Remove from heat, and serve in a coffee mug.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This underrated gin cocktail is perfect if you’re looking for something refreshing, citrusy and not too sweet. It also works well with other spirits besides gin.
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice, and shake to chill.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.

About: The Tom Collins is such a classic they named the glass after it.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a Collins glass.

Fill with ice, top with club soda and stir.

Garnish with 2 lemon slices.

Author: PDT
About: Fix this summery cocktail and then find a nearby porch to sip it on.
Ingred: 1 oz George Dickel No. 12 Tennessee whiskey
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon wedges and mint leaves.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice. Garnish with a sprig of mint.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: This fruity cocktail is sweet, sour and complex.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Cherry Noir Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with cherries on a cocktail pick.

Author: Jonathan Pogash
About: The best part? If you like one, you can conjure up a whole swarm.
Ingred: 1 oz Laphroaig Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the bitters to a shaker and shake without ice for about 10 seconds.

Fill with ice and shake again very, very wellÂ-about 30 seconds.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with ice and top with the bitters.

Author: Charles Vexenat
About: Make a big bowl of this refreshing absinthe and lime punch.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Garnish with cucumber slices and stir.

(This recipe can be multiplied to fill a large punch bowl.).

Author: Brian Means
About: Anchor’s Christmas Spirit is the merry result of distilling Anchor Brewing’s Christmas ale, which creates a smooth, winter-spiced spirit that’s ideal for holiday cocktails like this one, mixed with ginger liqueur, honey syrup and allspice bitters.
Ingred: .5 oz The King’s Ginger Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except for the ale and bitters to a cocktail shaker.

Dry shake, then add ice and shake again.

Double-strain into a fizz glass and top with ale.

Garnish with shaved nutmeg and three drops of bitters.

About: You’ll want this complex cocktail representing your interests.
Instructions:
Shaken and served in a cocktail glass.

Garnished with lemon oils and a sprig of fresh rosemary.
Theme: Brunch Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Chad Phillips
About: Pistachio-infused sherry? Seattle’s Shaker + Spear knows how to make an innovative cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Four Roses Yellow Label Bourbon 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Irish coffee glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Misty Kalkofen
About: The Brandy Old Fashioned is a classic Wisconsin cocktail that puts a brand new spin on the age-old recipe by using brandy instead of whiskey and just a touch of 7Up. Here’s how top bartender Misty Kalkofen’s mom in Green Bay likes hers.
Instructions:
Add the cherry, orange wedge, sugar, bitters and water to a double Old Fashioned glass.

Muddle until the sugar dissolves, adding a splash more water if needed.

Fill with ice and add the brandy.

Top with Sprite or 7Up and garnish with a fresh cherry and orange wedge.

Author: Jamie Gordon
About: This Gin & Tonic is summer in a glass.
Garnish: 1 Strawberries, grapefruit and lemon wheels, cucumber slices and a lavender sprig
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the tonic to a goblet or wine glass and fill with fresh ice.

Top with tonic water and garnish with grapefruit and lemon wheels, cucumber slices, strawberries and a lavender sprig.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: The classic Collins took a trip through the garden.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cucumber slice.

Author: Brendan Ambrose
About:
Mushy green beans from a can topped with canned onion straws? No, thanks. At Washington, D.C.’s Firefly, lead bartender Brendan Ambrose’s vegetal elixir (a new version of one he does with sugar snap peas,) is smoky, herbal and bitter, thanks to smoked beans and mezcal, and a splash of Chartreuse and Cynar liqueurs. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Right Drink. For Every Bit of the Thanksgiving Meal.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz El Pelotón de la Muerte mezcal
1⁄4 oz Salted lime simple syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with 1 cooked green bean.

*Salted lime simple syrup: Combine the peels of 2 limes, 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tsp sea salt and 1/2 cup water to a simmer, and continue to simmer until sugar and salt are dissolved. Remove it from the heat, allow to cool, and add 3 oz lime juice. Refrigerate the mixture for 12 hours, and then strain out solids. Store the syrup in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

**Pureed green beans: Add 1 lb fresh green beans, 1 qt mixed assorted nuts and 1 bottle El Peloton mezcal to a 1/3-inch-deep hotel pan and place the pan in a smoker at 165 degrees F for 2 hours. Remove the pan and let cool. Remove the nuts and 3 green beans and save to serve on the side as a garnish. Place the green beans and mezcal in a blender, and blend until smooth. Strain into a sealed container and refrigerate.

Author: Randy Hayden
About:
At Nine Mile Station in Atlanta, bar manager Randy Hayden’s winterized version of the Mai Tai uses dark rum instead of white for a richer, fuller flavor and apricot liqueur rather than banana.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Can the Classic Drinks of Summer Be Transformed for Winter? Yes. And This Is How.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass or Tiki mug over ice.

Garnish with a quarter orange wheel and brandied cherry.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: Even whiskey-drinkers can enjoy vodka with this Manhattan-inspired concoction.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jason Lara
About: If she was good enough for Fred Astaire, she’s good enough for you.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberry and clementine.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an edible pansy.

About: Tea-infused booze makes this frozen Daiquiri from New Orleans’ Catahoula Upstairs Bar deluxe.
Ingred: .5 oz Butterfly pea flower tea liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1.5 cups of crushed ice.

Serve in a hurricane glass, and garnish with an orchid and straw.

*Butterfly pea flower tea liqueur: Mix 2 parts Cane Run rum, 1 part honey, 1 part hot green tea and 1 tbsp pea flower powder.

Author: Ketel One Vodka
About: This easy cocktail is a good reason to keep a bottle of ginger beer on hand.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Move over tonic. Gin and cherries may be the perfect combination.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cherries, anise, lime and sugar.

Add the gin and port, and fill with ice.

Shake well and double strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with cherries.

Author: Devin Espinosa
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (3 parts honey, 1 part water).5 oz
2 dashes Fee Brothers Old Fashioned Bitters
Instructions:
Add one-quarter of a golden apple to a shaker and muddle to extract the juices.

Add remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into double Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.

Garnish with apple fan.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Named for the Royal Family’s Scottish summer home, this drink combines fine single malt and good English tea.
Ingred: 3 oz Glenfiddich 21-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add the Scotch, syrup and apple juice to a teacup and add a large ice cube.

Top with equal amounts of lemonade and Champagne.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and thistle.

(This recipe can multiplied to serve a crowd: Mix in a punch bowl with a large block of ice.).

Author: Bulleit
About: It’s the combo of sweet and dry vermouths that makes this classic perfect. Bulleit’s unorthodox twist on the old-school Manhattan? The use of both dry and sweet vermouth, in addition to a dash of potent blood orange bitters in place of the usual Angostura. The result is a doubly aromatic, complex take on the classic.
Instructions:
Add the rye and both vermouths to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the bitters and garnish with a Maraschino cherry.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: This vodka cocktail is good whether or not you can see stars.
Ingred: 1 oz Chilled Van Gogh Açai-Blueberry Vodka
Instructions:
Pour chilled Van Gogh Açai-Blueberry Vodka into a flute.

Top with sparkling rosé wine and garnish with a starfruit.

Author: Brooke Arthur
About: Celebrate the Scottish folk hero with the classic whisky-based Rob Roy cocktail. This recipe is similar to the beloved Manhattan, but uses Scotch instead of rye whiskey and orange bitters instead of aromatic bitters. The difference is delicious—try it for yourself.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: Transport yourself to tropical island with this vodka cocktail that has just a hint of tiki.
Instructions:
In a shaker, briefly muddle the basil leaves.

Add remaining ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a basil leaf.

Author: Maison Premiere
About: Try this simple twist on the classic Sazerac recipe.
Instructions:
Add a few ice cubes and the absinthe to a double rocks glass.

Stir a few times, liberally splashing the sides of the glass.

Tilt the glass so the absinthe reaches the rim and turn slowly to coat the entire glass.

Discard the ice and excess absinthe, and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Garnish with lemon twist.

About: A splash of citrus is all it takes to highlight the floral notes in Beefeater gin. The Ruby Sipper is a refreshing mix of these natural flavors, both perfectly suited for summer.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (1 part sugar, 1 part water).5 oz
1⁄4 oz Crème de cassis liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Pour all ingredients into a shaker filled with ice, and shake vigorously for 5 seconds.

Pour into a goblet or Belgian beer glass.

Grate orange zest over the top for garnish.

Author: Natalie Streiter
About: Good coffee and great whiskey make this an unforgettable Irish Coffee riff by Natalie Streiter of Fools Gold in New York City and the perfect addition to any meal.
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a shaker, hard-shake and pour into a Collins glass.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: The original Cuban Piña Colada is a mellow cocktail that is best made with fresh coconut water and pineapple, to remain true to its heritage, which goes all the way back to 1922.
Instructions:
Place the pineapple chunks into a cocktail shaker and muddle lightly.

Add the pineapple juice, coconut water and sugar, and stir to dissolve the sugar.

Add the rum and cubed ice, and shake until it’s frosted.

Strain into a Hurricane glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with a pineapple slice and pineapple leaf.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: The balance of sweet watermelon and spicy pepper makes this cocktail undeniably refreshing.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Black Pepper Honey Syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a watermelon cube coated on one side with ground black pepper.

Author: Chris Day
About: If you love your bourbon drinks bitter and boozy, the Bulleit 7 Hands cocktail is for you.
Ingred: 3⁄20 oz Cocchi Vermouth di Torino 3⁄20 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail or coupe glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Wilfred Sands
About:
This rum sour was created 40 years ago by Wilfred Sands, who at that time was the bartender at the exclusive Lyford Cay Club in New Providence, Bahamas. Today, he serves at mixologist at Red Turtle Tavern at John Watling’s Distillery in Nassau. The rum float here is important so you can really enjoy the different layers of flavors in the drink.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “How to Drink in the Bahamas.”
Ingred: .5 oz John Watling’s amber rum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the pale rum, egg white, lemon juice and sugar to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Gently pour the amber rum on top as a float.

About: New York City’s Saxon + Parole plays with plenty of fresh produce on its drink menu, which means that (depending on the season) guests often request “that watermelon thing” or “that pumpkin thing.” This time, head bartenders Maxime Belfand and Masa Urushido stayed one step ahead and named their heirloom-carrot-packed winter drink accordingly.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Great King St. Glasgow Blend scotch 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Del Maguey Vida mezcal 3⁄4 oz
1 oz Heirloom carrot juice (purple, orange and yellow)
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Prepare a rocks glass with a half-rim of smoked Maldon sea salt.

Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain over fresh ice into the prepared glass, and garnish with a carrot chip.

About: This cocktail from top bartender Jack McGarry puts an Irish twist on the “original” old fashioned cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Jack McGarry
About: Appreciate vodka in a whole new light with this complex cherry-lemon-tea concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About: This simple but delicious creation is packed with fruit flavor.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a wine glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Claire Smith
About: Add some bite to your Spritz and enjoy this vodka cocktail with your best gal pals.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and Aperol to a wine glass and fill with ice.

Stir gently and top with Champagne.

Garnish with a pink grapefruit twist.

Author: Maker's Mark
About: Muddled fruit gives this version of the classic Old Fashioned an extra kick of sweetness.
Instructions:
In an Old Fashioned glass, muddle the orange, cherry and sugar.

Fill three-quarters of the way with ice and add the bourbon and club soda.

Garnish with an additional orange wheel and maraschino cherry.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About:
The Hot Toddy is the grandfather of hot cocktails. Equally at home in a snowbound mountain cabin as it is on an acclaimed cocktail menu, the Hot Toddy has one job that it takes quite seriously: warming you up.
The Hot Toddy has been linked to warming up winter nights next to a fireplace, as well as warding off colds. You can use any kind of whiskey you like in this hot and comforting classic, and the end result will be equally delicious. Grab your favorite mug, and get ready for a warm whiskey embrace.
Ingred: Boiling water, to fill a mug
2 tsp Demerara sugar or brown sugar
2 oz Bourbon, rye whiskey, Irish whiskey or scotch
Instructions:
Fill a mug with boiling water and let stand for a minute or two to warm.

Meanwhile, stick the cloves into the lemon twist and set aside.

Empty the mug and fill about halfway with fresh boiling water.

Add the sugar and stir to dissolve.

Add the prepared lemon twist and stir.

Add the lemon juice and whiskey, and stir again.

Author: Allen Katz
About: A splash of herbal Bénédictine gives this Manhattan variation added complexity.
Instructions:
Add all in the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jon Gertsen
About: We give this simple gin-and-Campari drink an A-plus.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
Ingred: .5 oz Partida agave nectar (Cut 50/50 with water).5 oz
8 Pineapple pieces (about the shape of small lime quarter)
Instructions:
In a mixing glass muddle the pineapple and add two small grinds of pepper. Add tequila, lime and agave nectar.

Shake and strain over fresh ice in an old-fashioned glass, and float the port.

About: This marriage of the Amaretto Sour and French 75 is a relationship that’s built to last.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass, then top with Champagne.

Author: Sother Teague
About: Jäger, amaro and Aperol create one handsome cocktail.
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Beverly Wilshire Beverly Hills, a Four Seasons Hotel
About: Indulge in this white hot cocktail drink spiked with coconut rum.
Instructions:
Add the milk and chocolate to a mug and stir until the chocolate melts completely.

Stir in the rum and top with whipped cream.

Garnish with ground cinnamon.

Author: Jeff Bell
Ingred: 2 oz Juice Press raw coconut water
Instructions: Stir the bourbon, falernum and coconut water with ice, then strain into a chilled cocktail coupe, and top with the bitters.

Author: Matthew Tocco
About:
Admittedly, Strategic Hospitality beverage director Matthew Tocco says guests are less apt to order a cocktail if it has rum or brandy as a base, so he paired this drink at Nashville’s Pinewood Social with bourbon to make it a tad more accessible.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “So You Love a Whiskey Old Fashioned. How About the Rise of the Rum Old Fashioned?”
Ingred: .5 oz Arehucas Ron Miel Guanche rum.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over 1 large ice cube.

Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

Author: Max Soh
About: This take on the classic Italian aperitif uses popular Korean spirit soju instead of gin.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Crisp, cool and chock full of tequila.
Instructions:
Pour Don Julio Blanco Tequila into a highball glass filled with ice.

Top off with tonic water.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Jack McGarry
About: This complex Irish whiskey-based spin on the Manhattan won’t fail to impress.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Knappogue Castle 12 Year Old Single Malt Irish Whiskey
4 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Twist a slice of orange peel over the drink to release the oils and discard the peel.

About: This Vegas-inspired cocktail has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Chill a double Old Fashioned glass with ice, discard the ice, and set aside.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker ice and shake.

Strain into the chilled glass over a 1-inch-by1-inch ice cube, and garnish with edible flowers skewered on a thyme sprig.

Pour the warm jar of meadow flowers aroma into the flower pot ensemble. It will begin to mist out and volatilize the aromas. Quickly cover the misting flower pot ensemble with the terrarium to capture the delicate aromas. Lift the terrarium when serving.

Place the inverted terrarium beside the ensemble and a wooden coaster in front of this assembly.

*Himalayan honey pepper: Add .5 tsp fresh cracked black pepper to a small saucepan on low/medium heat until fragrant, keeping it moving so it doesn't burn. Add 3 oz HoneyTree’s raw organic wildflower honey, 1/8 tsp pink Himalayan salt and 2 oz water. Whisk thoroughly for 2 minutes and allow to simmer for 1 minute. Strain through 3 layers of ultra-fine mesh, and allow to cool. Yield: 4 oz.

**Meadow flowers aroma: To create a flower pot ensemble, add dry ice to the bottom of a glass jar, add twigs and flowers on top, and set aside. In another glass jar, add 2.5 oz water, .5 oz rose water, 1 bottle cap Luxardo maraschino liqueur and 5 drops honeysuckle essential oil, and shake vigorously to combine. Close and set aside, and warm before use.

Author: Nate Dumas
About: The Cave Creek cocktail is made with New York Distilling Company’s Rock & Rye—a bottled combination of rye whiskey, sugar and citrus that was all the rage in the 19th century, when it was made with rock candy.
Instructions:
Shake all ingredients over ice.

Add one ounce of chilled club soda and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist and serve with a straw.

Author: Gary Regan
About: In 2010, while in Athens judging the Diageo World Class bartender competition, barman Gary “Gaz” Regan tasted the very best Aviation
Ingred: .5 oz Giffard Marasquin maraschino liqueur.5 oz
1⁄8 oz Marie Brizard Parfait Amour liqueur 1⁄8 oz
Instructions:
Add the gin into a shaker and stir to release the aromas.

Add ice and the remaining ingredients and shake.

Fine-strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Alexandra Kuechler-Caffal
About: Bartender Alexandra Kuechler-Caffal is pretty devoted to her love of all-things Trekkie. She created this Star Trek–inspired rum cocktail to show her intergalactic love.
Instructions:
Stir all of the ingredients, and serve in a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a port-soaked prune.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Jazz up your ‘rita with a bit of Grand Marnier.
Instructions:
If desired, moisten the rim of a rocks or cocktail glass and coat with salt.

If using a rocks glass, fill with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: James Urycki, Langham
About: This cocktail was created by James Urycki at Langham for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rim a chilled coupe with sugar.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into the prepared glass.

Flame the orange disc over the surface of the drink, then drop into the glass.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: OK, sure, the name of this cocktail has a naughty Christmas sort of vibe. But that doesn’t mean you can’t sip this steamy drink all throughout the colder months, enjoying the pick-me-up hint of coffee paired with the rich bite of Armagnac.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Château de Laubade XO Bas Armagnac
Instructions:
In a small saucepan, combine all of the ingredients except for the water, and heat without bringing to a boil.

Strain the mixture into a toddy glass, and top with hot water to fill.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Start your own cheer with this pomegranate cocktail.
Ingred: Van Gogh Pomegranate Vodka Van Gogh Pomegranate Vodka
Instructions:
Fill an ice cube tray with a mix of equal parts pomegranate juice and water and freeze over night.

Place cubes in a tall glass and top with Van Gogh Pomegranate Vodka.

Garnish the drink with an orange wheel.

Author: Alexis Osborne
About:
Bartender Alexis Osborne of Denver’s Acorn created this cocktail to both be visually appealing and give drinkers a little healthy boost. “You drink with your eyes a lot, and I love colors,” she says. “Beets are antioxidants and anti-inflammatory, and nutmeg is considered a brain tonic.” The result is a sweet and earthy beverage that tastes warm and inviting while packing an electric pop of color. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Everything You Need to Know About the Drinks That Could Save Your Morning.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a yellow beet chip or lemon peel curl.

*Beet and nutmeg syrup: Crack open and toast 4 whole nutmeg in a pan over medium heat. Peel and chop 3 red beets. Add the toasted nutmeg, beets, 8 oz sugar and 8 oz water to a pot and bring to a boil. Let simmer for 25 minutes or until beets are tender. Remove from heat and let cool. Strain solids outs. Makes 16 oz.

Author: Averna
About: This blackberry-ginger cocktail is even good in the afternoon.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blackberries.

Add the lemon juice, Averna and vodka, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer and garnish with a few blackberries.

About: Fennel and citrus pair beautifully in salads. So it makes sense they would in a cocktail, too.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with grapefruit zest.

*Fennel cordial: In a saucepan, bring 10 oz water and .25 gram dried loose fennel seeds to a boil, and simmer for 10 minutes. Add .7 lbs fine sugar, and stir until dissolved. Fine-strain into bottles.

Author: Brandon Clements
About: Settle down PETA. It’s not what it sounds like.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Russian Standard Platinum Vodka 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a thick-cut grapefruit twist.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: This mashup of a Michelada and Margarita is a big ¡a huevo! (or “hell, yeah”). Tequila gets a sweetening assist from Bud Light Lime-A-Rita, fresh lime juice pushes the acid forward, and hot sauce (I’m a Valentina guy, but follow your heart) leaves a gentle burn on the end.
Instructions:
Salt the rim of a rocks glass.

Add the tequila and lime juice and hot sauce to a shaker with plenty of ice, and shake vigorously for 30 seconds.

Strain into the prepared glass, and top with Bud Light Lime-A-Rita.

Author: Waites Laseter
About: At New Orleans’ Root
Ingred: 4 drops El Guapo Love Potion No. 9 bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice).

Add ice and shake until well-chilled.

Top with 4 drops of El Guapo Love Potion No. 9 bitters and a splash of juice from a jar of Luxardo maraschino cherries.

Garnish with a lemon twist and Luxardo maraschino cherry.

Author: Brad Goocher
About: Pomelos—large thick-skinned citrus fruits—are easy to find in Asian markets. But grapefruit works just as well in this refreshingly fizzy drink. Brad Goocher, the beverage director at Charleston, S.C.’s Le Farfalle, also makes a mocktail version of the drink with three ounces of juice and one ounce each of honey and cream.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the seltzer to a blender with 1 cup of ice, and pulse until smooth.

Pour into a highball glass or Mason jar, and fill to the top with the chilled seltzer.

Author: Domaine de Canton
About: The tasty ginger liqueur Domaine de Canton doesn’t need much dressing up.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Dushan Zaric
About: Mix up this deliciously citrusy gin Gimlet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Brian Elder
About: After a trip to NYC’s Attaboy
Ingred: .5 oz Pineau des Charentes apéritif.5 oz
Instructions:
In a double rocks glass, add the strawberry cordial, then the lemon juice and then the booze.

Add 1/2 scoop pellet ice, and gently stir.

Add more pellet ice to top off the glass, and shape into a rounded crown peaking just above the rim.

Garnish with a basil sprig.

*Strawberry cordial: In a quart container, cover 1 qt strawberries in 1 pint granulated sugar, and let rest overnight at room temperature. Turn the container occasionally to facilitate the extraction process. After 1 day, there should be a good amount of translucent, red liquid. Strain the liquid off, and discard excess sugar and berries.

Author: Jaime Salas
About: Add a little heat to the Paloma cocktail with this ancho-chile spin on the classic.
Ingred: .5 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Run the lime wedge along the rim of a highball glass and coat half of the rim the salt.

Squeeze the lime wedge into the glass and discard it.

Fill the glass with ice and add the remaining ingredients.

Stir to combine and garnish with a thin grapefruit wheel.

Author: Benjamin Amberg
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Chateau de Beaulon Pineau des Charentes 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Nux Alpina Walnut Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1 tsp Dark amber maple syrup, grade B
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a well-chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Pete Vasconcellos
About: This bitter-and-sweet cocktail calls for lots of shaking.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the bitters to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake hard and strain into a pint glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the bitters.

Author: Jeff Yannuzzi
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
