“Our goal in creating a cocktail for the Bills was to capture the pride of the fans, whose loyalty is steadfast win or lose,” says bartender Jeff Yannuzzi of Buffalo’s Toutant
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold.

Double-strain over a large ice cube into a rocks glass, and garnish with an apple skin twist and green apple foam.

*Concord grape shrub: Combine 1 cup pureed concorde grapes (pushed through a sieve to remove seeds and skins) with 1 cup raw sugar in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is completely dissolved. Add 1/4 cup white wine vinegar, 1/4 cup red wine vinegar and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil and allow to reduce by half. Cool to room temperature before using. Will keep in the refrigerator for at least 1 month.

**Green apple foam: In a bowl, combine 450 grams Granny Smith apple juice, 10 grams citric acid, 120 grams granulated sugar and 5 grams gelatin. Stir and pour into an iSi canister, and charge once before using to top the drink.

About: Absinthe gives this rye whiskey cocktail something to brag about.
Instructions:
Rinse a Nick and Nora glass or a coupe glass with absinthe.

Add remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the Nick and Nora glass or coupe glass rinsed with absinthe.

Spray additional absinthe on top, if desired.

Garnish with a lemon twist.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Clover Club
About: This is one relative you’ll actually want to spend a lot of time with.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Duggan McDonnell
About: Mix up this flower of a cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a few orange slices.

Author: Gary Regan
About: It takes a good drink to survive a Moscow winter. This recipe renders a fairly dry version of the drink. You can use more Kahlúa  and less vodka to make a sweeter version.
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice.

Author: Little Black Dress
About: She knows how to spice up a Little Black Dress.
Ingred: 2 oz Little Black Dress Pinot Noir
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Gently roll the shaker to mix and pour into a tall glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Chaim Dauermann
About: This pear brandy cocktail is a nod to the Star Trek episode “The Inner Light.” In it, Captain Picard loses consciousness for 20 short minutes but winds up experiencing decades of a double life in his altered state on the planet of Kataan, a dying planet with water issues, in the village of Ressik. In this new reality, he’s known as a flute-playing family man named Kamin.
Ingred: .5 oz Mas Peyre Le Démon de Midi Rancio Sec (or similar rancio sec).5 oz
Instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a coupe and serve.

Author: Willie Jane
About: Raid your herb garden to make this simple but delicious vodka cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the rosemary, thyme, cucumber, lime juice and simple syrup.

Add the vodka and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a cucumber slice and a sprig of thyme.

Author: Pete Gugni
About: Get refreshed with this complex gin-based tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a strip of cucumber peel.

About: A Blue-Cheese–Olive Martini is a steakhouse classic that’s arguably more appetizer than cocktail. This modification uses pickled green tomatoes and Atsby Amberthorn
Ingred: 2 Froehlich's Martini Pickled Tomatoes, for garnish
1 Rogue Creamery Caveman blue cheese, for garnish
Instructions:
Stir the vodka and vermouth with ice, and strain into a picnic glass.

Slice the Martini pickle lengthwise, stuff with the blue cheese, skewer the pickles with a toothpick, and balance on the rim of the glass.

Author: Moet and Chandon
About: This official cocktail of the 2010 Academy Awards is appropriately elegant.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a coupe glass.

Garnish with a fresh mint sprig.

Author: Greg Seider
About: Tequila and watermelon is a woefully underused combination.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Agave syrup (one part agave nectar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the jalapeño slice.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and double strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Lucas England
About:
Inspired by the ingredients traded along the old spice routes in India and Sri Lanka, the best-selling cocktail at San Jose and San Mateo, Calif.’s Mortar & Pestle Bar, by beverage director Lucas England, balances the spicy and the lightly sweet. “Swapping in rum for whiskey in an Old Fashioned is a great way to surprise guests with warm, spiced flavors,” says England. “If the rum is overproof, it can be softened with sugar syrups or bitters.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “So You Love a Whiskey Old Fashioned. How About the Rise of the Rum Old Fashioned?”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Amrut Old Port Indian rum
1⁄4 oz Plantation O.F.T.D. overproof rum 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

Garnish with a lemon and orange peel.

*Garam masala syrup: Bring 1 cup water to a simmer, remove it from the heat, and add 1 cup sugar and 2 tbsp, plus 2 tsp garam masala powder. Stir until the sugar dissolves, then let the spices steep for 10 minutes. Fine-strain out solids through a cheesecloth, and store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: The icy bourbon Stone Sour is perfect for a hot summer night.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a cherry.

Author: Kelly Ronan
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
For the Seattle Seahawks, says bartender Kelly Ronan of Seattle’s Lark, “this is a perfect cocktail for morning games—not too boozy, and bright and refreshing with the effervescent ginger beer. We use lots of local products at Lark, even at the bar. OOLA is a fantastic local distillery—it’s right down the street actually—so we use its gin and Rachel’s Ginger Beer, which is a super spicy locally made ginger beer that nearly every Seattleite is obsessed with. The berries and kiwi add a little extra flavor and of course our favorite colors.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz OOLA gin (or other bright, floral gin)
3 oz Rachel’s Ginger Beer (or other high-quality ginger beer)
1 Kiwi fruit, peeled and sliced in wheels
Instructions:
Add the gin, apricot brandy, lime juice, simple syrup and mint leaves to a shaker with ice and shake until cold.

Strain into a Collins glass filled with the blueberries, kiwi and ice.

Top off the drink with the ginger beer, and garnish with a mint leaf and straw.

Author: St-Germain Liqueur
About: One part tequila and one part St-Germain. Simple but elegant.
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a rocks or Collins glass with salt and fill with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: John Deragon
About: A lime brown sugar syrup gives this tropical refresher complex flavor.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with grated nutmeg and a lime wedge.

Author: Bols Genever
About: An old-school recipe for a gin-and-juice.
Ingred: 1 oz Fresh ruby red grapefruit juice
Instructions:
In a mixing glass stir the ingredients with large, hard, cold ice cubes and double strain into a rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

About: The punch bowl can make or break any summer gathering. The Hibiscus Summer Garden Punch is just the recipe to delight your guests, with its fresh blend of natural ingredients.
Instructions:
In a punch bowl, combine all of the ingredients except for the bitter lemon soda.

Add cubed ice and gently stir with a ladle to mix.

Top with the bitter lemon soda, and garnish with a generous amount (2 to 3 cups) of raspberries and sliced strawberries.

Grate orange zest over the punch.

* Hibiscus tea: Steep 2 tea bags of hibiscus tea in 10 oz of boiling water for 5 minutes, occasionally stirring. Remove the tea bags and let cool to room temperature. Refrigerate prior to use to ensure your punch stays cool..

Author: Leo DeGroff
About: Go on a Continental tour with Irish whiskey, French vermouth and Spanish sherry.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
1 oz Dry Dolin Vermouth de Chambéry
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a piece of lemon peel.

About: Aged rum
Ingred: .5 oz Dolin Génépy Des Alpes.5 oz
.5 oz Giffard Crème de Pamplemousse Rose.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a speared grapefruit peel.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: Brighten your evening with this vanilla, mint and lemon cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon wedges and mint leaves.

Add the Navan and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig stuck into a lemon wheel.

Author: Little Black Dress
About: Two wines and some strawberries; what’s not to like?
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Korbel to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Top with Korbel and garnish with a strawberry.

Author: Basil Hayden's Bourbon
About: Bourbon and Champagne make beautiful music together.
Instructions: Add Basil Hayden's Bourbon and Champagne to a flute.

Author: Kara Newman
About: The subtle spice of ginger heats up this gin-and-prosecco drink.
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a Champagne flute with the sugar and place the cherry in it.

Add all the other ingredients except the prosecco to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until well chilled and strain into the prepared flute. Top with the prosecco.

About: This summery take on a Sidecar, bright with Meyer lemons, is sunshine in a glass.
Ingred: 2 oz Cherrywood-infused Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège cognac
2 dashes Hellfire bitters (or other spicy bitters)
Garnish: Sliced lemon wheel, Red chile threads
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Top a lemon slice with red chile threads, and use it to garnish the drink.

*Meyer lemon syrup: Peel 6 Meyer lemons. Use a paring knife to get rid of any remaining white spots on the peels. Blanch them three times in boiling water, then simmer in 1/2 L water and 1/2 L sugar for 20 minutes. Cool before using.

Author: Naren Young
About: This tart-and-sweet gin drink is good at any time of day.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake very hard and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Float a lemon wheel on top.

Author: Matthew Frederick
About: Say hello to this beer-centric update on the Irish Coffee by Matthew Frederick of EZ Inn in Chicago. And don’t worry, you don’t have to be a beer lover to enjoy it.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Coffee-infused Teeling Small Batch Whiskey
.5 oz Brown sugar coffee syrup.5 oz
5.5 oz Maplewood Fat Pug Nitro Milk Stout (or Guinness or any Nitro Milk Stout)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cream in a metal steaming pitcher. Let sit for a few seconds while the nitro from the beer dissipates. Steam with a milk steamer until the temperature reaches 170°F.

Pour into an Irish Coffee mug, and top with the whipped cream.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

*Coffee-infused Teeling Small Batch Whiskey: Mix 10 grams instant coffee with 750mL Teeling Small Batch Whiskey.

**Brown sugar coffee syrup: Heat 2 cups water, then add 2 cups dark brown sugar and 1 tbsp instant coffee.

Author: Joaquín Simó
About: Warm up with this modern twist on the traditional Hot Toddy.
Instructions:
Add the liqueur and bitters to a mug.

Top with hot water and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Mike Mills
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Pierre Ferrand dry curaçao 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a couple glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.%Coffee bitters:%Makes 750 mlINGREDIENTS:1 cup Coarsely ground dark espresso roast1 750ml bottle Vodka1 tablespoon Coconut extract (or to taste)PREPARATION:Place the coffee grounds into a sack of cheese cloth and soak them in the vodka for about 20 to 24 hours.

Remove the coffee grounds and filter the vodka through clean cheese cloth to ensure consistency.

Add coconut extract to taste.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Give a warm glass of cider a festive upgrade.
Instructions:
Add the VeeV to a lowball glass and top with cider.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick and a slice of orange peel.

Author: Jason Littrell
About: Go on a tour of northern Europe.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball or Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Francesco Lafranconi
About: Pisco is a natural partner for Concord grapes, which are muddled along with blackberries to create this frothy coupe.
Instructions:
Place the Concord grapes and blackberries in a shaker and muddle.

Add the rest of the ingredients and ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with Concord grapes and lemon peel twisted to release oils.

Author: Jerry Thomas
About: The classic original, from the original celebrity bartender, Jerry Thomas.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda to a shaker and fill with large, hard, cold ice cubes.

Shake, and double-strain into a Collins glass fill with fresh ice.

Top with soda and garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Chris Hewes
About: Hollywood bartender Chris Hewes would serve this spicy absinthe-based shot to a movie star who didn’t win an Oscar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a shot glass.

Author: Brian Means
About: This spirit-forward cocktail from San Francisco’s Dirty Habit combines Italian bitter amaro and Portuguese wine with Japanese whisky and Spanish liqueur.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir.

Strain into a Nick & Nora or coupe glass, and garnish with freshly shaved black cardamom.

About: Add a little more depth to your next Sidecar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass, then garnish with orange zest.

*Honey syrup: In a saucepan, bring 2 parts water to 1 part honey to a boil and simmer until the honey has dissolved. Cool and store in the refrigerator until ready to use.

Author: Nonna Titulauri
About: Originally called Adam’s Apple Martini, the Appletini became a crowd pleaser from the day it was invented at L.A. restaurant Lola’s in 1996. The original recipe simply used vodka
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Fresh Granny Smith apple juice
Instructions:
Add crushed ice to a cocktail glass and set aside to chill.

Add all the ingredients into a shaker with cubed ice, and shake for about 10 seconds.

Empty the ice from the cocktail glass, and double-strain the mixture into it.

Garnish with a skewered brandied cherry and 3 Granny Smith apple slices.

Author: Finlandia Vodka
About: This cocktail will ensure that the sun never sets on your evening.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: Hot chocolate + minty liqueur + whipped cream = an adult dessert.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Baileys with a Hint of Mint Chocolate
Instructions:
Pour the Baileys and hot chocolate into a coffee mug.

Top with a dollop of whipped cream and sprinkle crushed candy cane on top.

Garnish with a mint leaf.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: Whether or not the watchman is on duty, you’ll want to fix this rich bourbon cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake again.

Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with 8 drops of Angostura Bitters in the shape of a clock face.

Author: Patrón Tequila
About: Find out what happens when premium tequila meets antioxidant-rich fruit juice.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Patrón Citrónge Orange Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the tequila and orange liqueur to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Fill with pomegranate juice and finish with a squeeze of lime.

Author: Amy Zavatto
About: The chilly, coconut-y drink is having (another) delicious moment. And this recipe might be the best there is.
Ingred: 2 oz Dark rum (recommended: Don Q Anejo Rum)
Instructions:
Pour all ingredients into a shaker filled with ice.

Shake well for a good 30 seconds or so. Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a wedge of fresh pineapple.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About:
To many people, the Mojito represents the perfect rum cocktail. The origins of the drink can be traced back to Cuba and the 16th-century Cuban cocktail El Draque, named for Sir Francis Drake. Appropriately, almost all of the ingredients in the Mojito are indigenous to Cuba. Rum, lime, mint and sugar (derived from cane juice) are mixed with soda water to create a refreshing classic cocktail.
The Mojito is traditionally served over ice in a highball glass and often associated with summer. Like your cocktails with literary references? You’re in luck. The Mojito is said to have been a favorite of Ernest Hemingway. 
While the Mojito is slightly more labor-intensive than other cocktails because it involves muddling the mint, the end result is a delicious, refreshing cocktail that can be enjoyed any time of the year.
Instructions:
In a shaker, lightly muddle the mint.

Add the simple syrup, lime juice and rum, and fill with ice.

Shake well and pour (unstrained) into a highball glass.

Top with the club soda and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Nicole Rheaume
About: Its fizzy cranberry flavor and savory rosemary garnish will make you happy.
Instructions:
Muddle the cranberries in a shaker.

Fill with ice, add the vodka and shake vigorously.  Pour into a tall glass and top with the tonic water and sparkling cider.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Mark Stoddard
About: Mr. Collins promises you’ll love this drink.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lime twist.

Author: Johnny Swet
About: This riff on the traditional Hot Toddy by Johnny Swet of JIMMY at The James hotel in New York City plays up chicken soup’s savory flavors by adding carrot and celery. And who doesn’t want a good snack-like garnish in any drink?
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Pour all ingredients into a snifter.

Garnish with a carrot stick, celery stick and parsley.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Toast baseball’s legends with this minty concoction.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Martini & Rossi Rosso Vermouth 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Noilly Prat Original Dry Vermouth 3⁄4 oz
2 dashes The Bitter Truth Orange Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake gently and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Finlandia Vodka
About: You don’t have to be stubborn to give this cocktail a try.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Bradford Scott Knutson
About: The deep, caramel sweetness of a good balsamic vinegar matches beautifully with aged cognac.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a brandy snifter or coupe and swirl to combine.

If desired, garnish with a flamed orange peel.

About: Aurum means “gold” in Latin. The best cocktail bars serve this elegant drink with a spectacular ice ball and flecks of edible gold leaf to add a touch of magic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass with 1 large ice sphere.

Garnish with gold leaf flecks.

About: Swap that tired vodka-cranberry combo for a refreshing glass of this fizzy pomegranate mocktail instead.
Instructions:
Fill a Collins glass one-third of the way with ice.

Add the pomegranate juice and simple syrup.

Fill the glass to the rim with seltzer and stir gently.

Add more juice or syrup to taste.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig and serve.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: Ignore James Bond’s famous instructions and stir this vodka-based Martini instead of shaking. As British author W. Somerset Maugham once stated, “Martinis should always be stirred, not shaken, so that the molecules lie sensuously one on top of the other.” Wise words for gin and vodka Martinis alike.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Prat dry vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass with ice and add the vermouth.

Stir to coat the ice and strain, discarding the excess vermouth.

Add the vodka and bitters if desired, and stir well.

Strain into a chilled Martini glass and garnish with an olive or lemon twist.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This tasty Paloma
Ingred: Cava or other sparkling wine, to top
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cava to a Collins glass with ice and stir.

Top with the cava.

Garnish with a mint sprig and grapefruit peel.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“Being a Washington Redskins’ fan in San Francisco is tough, as I imagine it is for any foreign fan in a city that’s not their own,” says Kevin Diedrich, the owner and bartender of Pacific Cocktail Haven. Diedrich’s drink is a Whiskey Sour variation, bolstered by citrusy kalamansi and balanced with a deep, fruity ruby port float. It’s based on Copper Fox rye whiskey. “It’s a nod to rye whiskey, which was one of the first spirits to be made in D.C.,” he says. The kalamansi gives the cocktail a great gold color, and the port float adds the burgundy, echoing the team colors. “A gold-rimmed glass is a plus,” he says.
Ingred: .5 oz Boiron unsweetened kalamansi puree.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except for the port to a shaker filled with ice, and shake until frothy and chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice, and gently float the ruby port over the back of a barspoon on top of the drink.

Author: Jeff Steiner
About: For this slightly bitter and super refreshing drink, bartender Jeff Steiner uses Rainier beer (named for Seattle’s Mt. Rainier), which is a lager-style brew, but feel free to swap it out for your favorite lager.
Ingred: 4 oz Rainier beer or other lager
Instructions:
Fill a wine glass with ice, add all of the ingredients and stir.

Garnish with a lemon peel, and serve.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
Is it still a Manhattan when it’s made with tequila? Who cares when a drink is this satisfying?
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in mixing glass with ice, and stir 25 to 30 times.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Bryan Schneider
About: The Transfusion is a golf club standard made with vodka, ginger ale and grape juice. This twist combines homemade ginger syrup with Concord grape juice ice cubes that slowly infuse the drink with fall flavor.
Instructions:
Add vodka, ginger syrup and lime juice to a shaker filled with ice.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with Concord grape juice ice cubes.

Top with two ounces club soda and garnish with a Concord grape and piece of crystallized ginger.

Author: Derek Rowe
About: This nutty lemonade cocktail is so good, you won’t even notice it’s liquor-free.
Instructions:
Add the lemon juice and Orgeat Syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake until frost forms on the outside of the shaker and strain into a tulip or wine glass.

Fill with crushed ice and top with club soda.

Stir briefly and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Dominic Venegas
About: The Mancini is a bourbon cocktail that’s stirred and strong.
Ingred: .5 oz Tempus Fugit Creme de Cacao.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This gin
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a blender with crushed ice, and blend until smooth.

Pour unstrained into a Tiki mug or highball glass, and garnish with a parasol, edible flower, orange peel and straw.

*Passion fruit syrup: Mix 6 parts simple syrup to 1 part passion fruit purée.

Author: Sean Barlow
About: Forget crush, this has turned into a full-blown love affair.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries, mint, lime juice and simple syrup to a juicy pulp.

Pour (unstrained) into a tall Collins glass.

Fill with crushed ice and top with ginger beer.

Garnish with an additional strawberry and mint sprig.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The beautiful thing about shrubs is that there are only two rules: something sweet and something acidic. Typically some variety of sugar does the heavy lifting, but here maple syrup offers a perfect hit of character and complexity. And although the beets maybe seem like an odd or unnecessary addition, they actually keep the sweetness in check with a welcome earthiness, and the shrub makes a fantastic mixer in this gin and Campari cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the gin, Campari, maple beet shrub and ice to a cocktail shaker and shake well.

Strain into a rocks glass, or coupé if you're feeling fancy.

Author: Cabo Wabo Tequila
About: Celebrate with this spicy tangerine and tequila cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Agave syrup (1 part agave nectar, 1 part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the habanero and tangerine.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a tangerine wheel.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Make this simple drink to show off a fruit- or herb-infused spirit you made yourself.
Garnish: 1 Lime wheel and fresh lemon-basil leaf
Instructions:
Add the vodka or tequila, lime juice and simple syrup to a highball glass.

Fill with ice and top with soda.

Garnish with a lime wheel and fresh lemon basil leaf.

To serve the drink up, add the vodka or tequila, lime juice and simple syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake quickly and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with soda (Do not garnish).

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: This refreshing coconut and pineapple cocktail is perfect at the beach or for imagining you’re at the beach.
Ingred: 2.5 oz Pineapple-Infused Square One Organic Vodka
1.5 oz Coco Lopez cream of coconut
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and pulse until smooth.

Serve in a highball glass.

About: The Tom Collins is such a classic they named the glass after it.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a Collins glass.

Fill with ice, top with club soda and stir.

Garnish with 2 lemon slices.

Author: Ben Clemons
About: You’ve never had a strawberry cocktail like this before.
Ingred: Stiegl-Radler Grapefruit beer Stiegl-Radler Grapefruit beer
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice.

Top with Stiegl Radler Grapefruit Beer and garnish with 2 speared fresh strawberry slices.

Author: Dominic Venegas
About: Though its cousin the Gin Rickey is more common today, this classic cocktail recipe can also be made with bourbon.
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with cracked ice.

Squeeze the lime half into the glass and drop it in.

Add the bourbon and fill with club soda.

Stir briefly to combine.

About: Red peppers. Chocolate liqueur. Tequila. Your tongue will dance.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the whipped cream to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled old fashioned glass.

Layer the top of the cocktail with a dollop of whipped cream and garnish with a large pinch of crushed red pepper.

Author: Jason Asher
About:
No need to get out your blender. This Tiki masterpiece is shaken to perfection. One sip of this, and you’ll see Tiki cocktails in a brand new light.  
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tiki Grows Up: Three Drinks That Will Win You Over.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a coupe.

Garnish with an edible orchid.

Author: Jason Cousins
About: Try this gin-based, Italian-flavored concoction at your next brunch.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the tomatoes and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients except the club soda and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with a basil leaf wrapped around a grape tomato on a cocktail pick.

About: Pumpkin fans will love this easy blend of pumpkin beer and freshly-brewed black tea laced with chai spices, coconut and pineapple.
Ingred: 1 oz Pumpkin beer (recommended: Southern Tier Pumking)
Instructions:
Combine ingredients in a chilled glass.

Garnish with fresh ginger.

Author: Manny Hinojosa
About: Put on your top hat and tails to drink this sparkling concoction.
Instructions:
Add the tequila and cognac to a chilled Champagne flute and fill with Champagne.

Garnish with raspberries.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
Smash some blackberries to get a drink that’s as easy as it is refreshing. It’s punch but with tequila!
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 4 Blackberries, plus more for garnish if desired
3⁄4 oz Raspberry or blackberry liqueur 3⁄4 oz
1.5 oz Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now
Instructions:
Combine the blackberries, berry liqueur and agave nectar in a shaker and muddle.

Add the tequila, the lime juice and ice, and shake well.

Strain into a stemless wine glass, and garnish with 3 skewered blackberries and an orange peel.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: The Negroni is a classic Italian drink. Order a Negroni and you’ll be sure to Impress your bartender.
Ingred: 1 oz Sweet vermouth (Martini & Rossi Rosso or Cinzano Rosso)
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and fill with ice.

Stir until cold, and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

Author: David Wondrich
About: During Prohibition, the simple gin-and-orange-juice Orange Blossom tipple was a big hit among illicit imbibers. The recipe, which is very similar to a Screwdriver, was a perfect way to disguise booze. Try one for yourself to find out why it was such a hit with the flapper set.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: As sweet as she is tart.
Ingred: 1 dash Raspberry syrup or maraschino liqueur or grenadine
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake until a frost forms and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Tender falling-apart chicken might be the best filling for tacos that ever existed. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great hot-weather tequila drinks.
Ingred: 2.5 lb large skin-on split chicken breasts
Corn tortillas, warmed in oven or grilled
Instructions:
Serves 6.

In a large heavy bottom pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium-high heat until it shimmers.

Sprinkle the chicken breasts with salt, and place skin side down into the pot.

Brown for 5 minutes until skin has turned golden brown in color, flip and cook for another 5 minutes.

Transfer the breasts to a plate or cutting board.

Reduce the heat to medium and add the onion, chopped fresh tomatoes, jalapeño and pinch of salt, and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 8 minutes.

Add garlic, oregano, cinnamon and cumin, and stir constantly for about 30 seconds.

Add the chicken stock, bay leaves, canned tomatoes and reserved chicken and any juices.

Bring to a boil, then lower heat to medium, cover and simmer until the chicken is cooked through, about 30 minutes.

Transfer the chicken breast to a plate or cutting board and turn the heat to high, bringing the sauce to a boil and stirring occasionally for about 20 minutes until the sauce is reduced to a thick consistency.

Once the chicken is cool enough to handle, shred it with two forks, trying to get long thin shreds of meat. (Discard the skin if you like.).

Discard the bay leaves and return the chicken to the sauce.

Lower the heat, stir in the vinegar, and simmer for 15 minutes.

To assemble tacos, start with a scoop of chicken, followed by queso fresco, pickled jalapeños and cilantro.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About:
Put away the can opener and forget about that whole “jelly or whole berry” debate. Unlike the plate-staining side dish, this Cosmo variant at Bridges at New York Hilton Midtown has a boozy kick. Grapefruit vodka mimics the citrus peel that gives popping, simmering berries bright citrus, and a rosemary sprig adds a whiff of herbaceousness.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Right Drink. For Every Bit of the Thanksgiving Meal.”
Instructions:
Muddle the lime wedge, rosemary sprig and honey in a shaker.

Add the vodka, cranberry juice and ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: So good that even the daffodils take notice.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and double strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a single mint or microgreen leaf.

Author: Toby Maloney
About: The perfect punch to put any fiesta into gear.
Ingred: 7 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
In a large pitcher, muddle the limes, lemons and orange.

Add the tequila, simple syrup, lime juice, grenadine and bitters.

Stir well and add ice.

Top with the 7Up and stir gently.

Pour (unstrained) into 6 wine glasses and garnish each with a lime wedge.

Author: Paul McGee
About: Cardamaro’s spice and nuttiness are perfect complements to the fresh apple flavor of the Calvados and warming spice of the rye whiskey in this cold weather cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a footed rocks glass.

About: The Frizzante is a perfect sip for enjoying brunch alfresco. Crafted with wild Tonda Gentile hazelnuts from the Piedmont region of Northern Italy, Frangelico adds the perfect nutty flavor with a hint of sweetness complemented by the lime citrus in the Frizzante cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail glass with ice and stir.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Caitlin Laman
About: Caitlin Laman’s complex glass of Bacardi Gran Reserva, Fernet-Vallet, rich simple syrup and coffee bitters paid homage to her travels in Switzerland. During a visit to Bern, she spent each morning drinking strong Swiss coffee and each evening drinking local bitter liqueurs. The combination of the two led her to this unbeatable structure that works with just about every spirit out there.

Author: Maxwell Britten
About: This banana puree julep doesn’t monkey around.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Four Roses Yellow Label Bourbon
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Julep cup filled with ice.

Swizzle, and top with crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Channel the original Rough Rider with this rum cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Who says rum is a summertime spirit? Try this Eggnog recipe, and you’ll be enjoying premium rum throughout the holidays.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into an Old Fashioned glass with 1 large ice cube.

Garnish with a sprinkle of grated nutmeg.

Author: Alex Negranza
About: This cocktail by Alex Negranza, the bar manager at Houston’s Better Luck Tomorrow
Instructions:
Muddle the French sorrel leaf in a mixing tin.

Add the rest of the ingredients, dry-shake, then shake with ice.

Fine-strain into a coupe.

Garnish with a red-veined sorrel leaf.

Author: Harry Craddock
About: This old-timey cognac drink is a classic cocktail for hair-of-the-dog hangover relief. The Corpse Reviver family of cocktails was traditionally consumed as hair-of-the-dog hangover relievers, meant to refresh after a night of heavy drinking. Revivers were popular during the late 19th and early 20th century, but faded away after Prohibition. Unlike its brother, the No. 2, the Corpse Reviver No. 1 has a rich mixture of spirits with a strong Cognac base.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a cocktail glass.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: A whiskey and ginger ale with a delicious citrus twist.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and lime juice to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Top with the ginger ale and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Casey Elsass
About:
The beautiful thing about shrubs is that there are only two rules: something sweet and something acidic. From there, your imagination can run wild. Typically some variety of sugar does the heavy lifting, but here maple syrup offers a perfect hit of character and complexity. And although the beets maybe seem like an odd or unnecessary addition, they actually keep the sweetness in check with a welcome earthiness. 
Once your shrub is ready (the longer you let it sit, the better), it’s a fantastic mixer in a variety of cocktails, including these three favorites: the Shrub Julep, the Shrubarita and the G.C.S.
Ingred: 1 1-inch piece of ginger, peeled and thinly sliced
Instructions:
Peel the beets - cut each into eight wedges, and add to a 1-quart jar along with the ginger, mustard seeds and bay leaf.

In a saucepan, combine the vinegar, maple syrup and salt with 1 cup of water. Stir to combine and bring to a boil over medium heat. Pour enough liquid into the prepared jar to cover the beets and let cool to room temperature.

Refrigerate for at least 12 hours and up to 2 weeks, shaking the jar every few days to distribute the flavors. Makes 1 quart.

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About: Take a swing at this pineapple-juice-and-aged-tequila combo.
Instructions:
Add the tequila to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Fill with pineapple juice and garnish with a pineapple wedge.

Author: Liquor.com
About: The national cocktail of Martinique is as easy to make as it is to drink, using just three ingredients, including the island’s native spirit, rhum agricole.
Instructions:
Squeeze a lime wheel into a chilled rocks glass.

Add the remaining ingredients, and top with ice.

Stir with a barspoon, and top with more ice.

About: Who says you can’t have your copper mug and your bourbon, too? This twist on the Moscow Mule pairs American whiskey and ginger beer for a refreshing summer cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the bourbon and lime juice to a Moscow Mule mug or a highball glass.

Fill the mug or glass with ice and top with ginger beer.

Add mint sprigs for garnish.

Author: Matt Lanning
About: This mezcal cocktail is a sure thing.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Squeeze a grapefruit twist over the drink and use as a garnish.

Author: Ryan Puckett
Ingred: 1.5 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
Garnish: Small bunch of mint, bound by a channel of lemon
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a pre-iced mixing glass, pouring the bourbon last, and stir until properly diluted and chilled (usually 40 to 50 rotations).

Place a Julep strainer over the glass, and pour over ice into a rocks glass.

For the garnish, cut a long channel out of an unwaxed lemon with a channel knife.

Wrap the channel around the base of a small bunch of mint, and tie into a simple knot.

Drink Name: Grilled Shrimp Tacos with Corn Salsa
Author: Beau Ciolino
About: Looking for something quick and easy to whip up with your Margarita this Cinco de Mayo? Say hello to your new favorite taco recipe, with grilled shrimp, avocado and a corn salsa that makes the flavors pop.
Ingred: 1.5 lb large shrimp, peeled and deveined with tails removed
1⁄4 cup finely chopped cilantro, plus more for garnish 1⁄4 cup
1.5 cup sweet corn kernels (from about 3 cobs)
1 Juice of lime, plus lime wedges for garnish
Instructions:
Serves 6 (about 2 tacos per serving).

Prep time: 10 minutes, plus 30 minutes in refrigerator.

Total time: 45 minutes.

Pat the shrimp dry with a paper towel and skewer close together.

Combine 1/4 cup olive oil, half the garlic and half the cilantro in a small bowl.

Brush the oil mixture onto both sides of the shrimp, and season well with salt and black pepper.

Refrigerate uncovered for at least 30 minutes.

To make the salsa, combine the corn, red onion, tomato, jalapeño, honey and lime juice in a bowl and season with salt and pepper. Set aside.

To make the avocado crema, smash together the avocado, sour cream and lemon. Season with salt and pepper. Set aside.

Combine the remaining olive oil, garlic and cilantro in a large mixing bowl.

Place the chilled skewers a few inches apart onto a hot grill, and cook for about 3 minutes (until the bottom has begun to char), then flip. Cook for another 2 to 3 minutes, until shrimp are plump and bright. Remove from the grill, and slide them off of the skewer and into the olive oil and garlic mix. Toss to coat.

Heat tortillas on the grill for about 2 minutes on each side. To assemble tacos, pile a bit of the corn salsa into each tortilla, followed by the shrimp, a dollop of avocado crema, cilantro and a squeeze of lime. Serve.

Author: Baileys
About: This cocktail is bananas. B-A-N-A…you get where this is going.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Baileys with a Hint of Coffee
Instructions:
Swirl the inside of a highball glass with chocolate syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients to a blender and fill with ice.

Blend until smooth and pour into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a banana slice and 3 coffee beans.

About: Meet your new favorite light, effervescent spritz, perfect for summer sipping.
Ingred: Fever-Tree elderflower tonic water, to top
Instructions:
Add the vodka and aperitif to a Highball glass filled with ice.

Top with the tonic, and stir gently.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: Jack McGarry
About: We got famed New York bar The Dead Rabbit to share its recipe for delicious hot Irish Coffee.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Fill an Irish Coffee glass with hot water and let stand for a few minutes to warm.

Pour out the water and add the Demerara syrup, whiskey and coffee.

Stir to combine and top with a layer of heavy cream the width of your thumb.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Riazul Tequila
About: Sweet-and-tart pomegranate is the ideal addition to this Margarita variation.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

Garnish with a few pomegranate arils if desired.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: This refreshing Champagne cocktail is perfect for a date—the recipe makes a pair of drinks.
Ingred: 187 ml Brut Champagne or other sparkling wine (about 1 split bottle)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a large shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well for 10 seconds and double-strain into two flutes.

Top each with Champagne and chill the rest of the bottle in an ice bucket.

While drinking, top with more Champagne as needed.

Author: Gary Regan
About: Next time you say you’ve conquered Everest, you technically won’t be lying.
Ingred: 1 oz Coco Lopez cream of coconut
Instructions:
Stir together the cream of coconut and curry powder to make a paste.

Add the paste and the remaining ingredients to a shaker.

Fill with ice and shake vigorously.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with a sprinkle of additional curry powder.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: A sparkling cocktail that’s a big step up from a Mimosa.
Ingred: 2⁄3 oz Passion fruit juice or puree 2⁄3 oz
Instructions:
Add the Grand Marnier, cranberry juice and passion fruit juice or puree to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an orange spiral twist.

Author: Allen Katz
About: C for Campari; B for Benedictine.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir very well and strain into an old fashioned glass full of fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: The Lark
About: You probably don’t associate root beer syrup and nutmeg with Irish Coffee, but that’s exactly why you have to try this recipe from The Lark in San Francisco.
Instructions:
Preheat an Irish Coffee glass with warm water and discard the water.

Add the whiskey and syrup, and top with the coffee and a float of fresh lightly whipped cream.

Garnish with a dusting of grated nutmeg.

About: This version of a Buck, or cocktail using ginger beer, uses rye whiskey.
Instructions:
Fill a Tom Collins glass with ice, add the whiskey, top with ginger beer and add a squeeze lime.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Bring out Irish whiskey’s sweet side.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail or stemless wine glass.

Garnish with a thin apple slice.

About: This cocktail takes single malt for a slightly tropical spin. And yes, it’s as delicious as it looks.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into chilled cocktail glass.

About: Made with cognac and topped with bubbly, this Brandy Daisy is improved, indeed.
Ingred: .5 oz Giffard Abricot du Roussillon liqueur.5 oz
1 oz Moët Impérial Champagne, to top
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

Top with the Champagne, then express the orange peel over top and discard.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: With apple, lemon and ginger flavors, it’s like autumn in a glass.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Laird's Straight Bottled in Bond Apple Brandy
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with ginger beer and garnish with a lemon half-wheel.

Author: Jeremy Lake
About: This mezcal-spiked spin on the classic Old Fashioned cocktail is a south-of-the-border delight.
Ingred: 1 dash Fee Brothers Aztec chocolate bitters
Garnish: 1 Cinnamon, orange twist and Lounge Attire Cocktail Cranberry
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with grated cinnamon, an orange twist and a Lounge Attire Cocktail Cranberry.

Author: Vincent Anter
About: Tequila and tomatillo “salsa” take this Bloody Mary to Mexico.
Instructions:
Add the tequila to a Collins glass.

Fill glass with crushed or pebble ice, add the tomatillo salsa mixture and stir well.

Garnish with a tomatillo wheel.

About: This summer thirst quencher celebrates the bright, sweet flavors of peaches.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cognac to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain over 1 large ice cube in a highball glass, then top with the cognac.

Garnish with peach gummy rings and a lime peel.

Author: Matt Seiter
About: With this cocktail, you’ll never forget the season.
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the cucumber, lime and maraschino liqueur.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Rock the mixing glass back and forth 18 times and fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Float a paper-thin cucumber slice on top.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: What happens when you mix unfiltered premium vodka and unfiltered apple cider? You get a unique and delicious spin on a classic winter drink.
Ingred: 2 oz Pressed unfiltered apple cider, heated
Ground cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg blend, to taste
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a glass mug and stir.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: Homemade apple-cinnamon vodka makes this sweet concoction a perfect autumn elixir.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Apple- and Cinnamon-Infused Karlsson's Gold Vodka
3⁄4 oz John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum 3⁄4 oz
1 dash Bar Keep Baked Apple Bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 30 seconds  and double-strain into a frozen coupe glass.

Garnish with an apple slice.

(This drink may also be served warm: Combine all the ingredients in a small saucepan over medium heat and stir until warm, then strain into the coupe glass and garnish.).

Author: Dubonnet
About: This deep-red drink is perfect for a romantic evening.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a blood orange slice.

Author: Nick Korbee
About: Bartender Nick Korbee, the executive chef and beverage director at Egg Shop in New York City, uses honey in his tequila  cocktail, with a touch of smokiness thanks to a mezcal  wash, which goes brilliantly with the sweet nectar and tart lemon.
Ingred: Del Maguey mezcal rinse Del Maguey mezcal rinse
Instructions:
Rinse a highball glass with the mezcal, coating the inside of the glass with a thin layer and dumping out whatever doesn’t stick.

Add the tequila, syrup and lemon juice to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Pour into the prepared glass, and add 2 dashes of the bitters.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

*Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use, the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

About: Transport yourself to cognac with a Champagne cocktail inspired by the aromatics and spices of the region.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Lindera Farms honey vinegar 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

Top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

*Honey syrup: Add 1/2 cup honey and 1/2 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use, the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar, and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

Author: Canadian Club Whisky
About: The gin may be sloe but you’ll drink this cocktail quickly.
Garnish: 1 Cherry and half an orange slice
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with cracked ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a cherry and half an orange slice.

Author: Willy Shine
About: It’s also good for winter, spring and fall.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tumbler filled with fresh ice.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with some apple cubes.

Author: Selvarey Rum
About: This coffee-chocolate-rum drink is tasty hot or cold.
Ingred: 1 oz Espresso, cold-brew or other strong brewed coffee
Instructions:
To serve hot, add all the ingredients to a small saucepan over medium heat and cook, stirring, until hot.

Pour into a mug and garnish with a cinnamon stick.To serve cold, add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Vincent Toscano
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“I’m a lifelong San Diego Chargers fan and travel every year to see my Bolts play,” says bartender Vincent Toscano of Rye in San Francisco. “In honor of the team, this drink is refreshing because every week is a new beginning and bittersweet because we don’t always win.”
Toscano uses bourbon, American whiskey, because football is America’s sport. “And Wild Turkey should be America’s bourbon,” he says. “I like the family aspect of it. When you meet [Wild Turkey distillers] Jimmy, Eddie and Bruce, they are such genuine and honest people. It shows in their whiskeys. They don’t try to put a spin on their product or have this fantasy world of a story. They are bourbon makers first and foremost.”
Ingred: Bundaberg blood orange soda Bundaberg blood orange soda
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the blood orange soda to a shaker with ice, and shake until cold.

Fine-strain over ice into a Collins glass, fill to top with the soda, and garnish with a basil leaf and straw.

Add ingredients to the mixing glass.

Add ice to mixing glass and stir until cold.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Romantic Summer Winter

About: A good alternative to all those tequila shots you’ve had.
Instructions:
Pour buttershots liqueur into a chilled shot glass.

Carefully layer the rest of the glass with Irish cream.

About: This cocktail is an updated Sidecar with bright blood orange flavor.
Ingred: .5 oz Amara Amaro D'Arancia Rossa.5 oz
.5 oz Fresh blood orange juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except the lemon peel in a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Squeeze the lemon peel into the mixing glass and discard.

Strain into a coupe.

Garnish with a blood orange wheel.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: This spicy, gingery spin on the brunch classic is perfect for a warm day.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Collins glass with a mixture of sea salt and black pepper.

Fill with ice and add the remaining ingredients.

Stir to combine and garnish with a lemon wedge, olive, cocktail onion and celery stalk.

Author: Todd Thrasher
About: At first glance, rum
Instructions:
Combine the cinnamon and sugar in a shallow bowl. In a separate shallow bowl, add 1 tbsp of rum. Dip the rim of a double-rocks glass into the rum bowl followed by the cinnamon-sugar to coat, and set aside.

Add the butternut squash base, remaining 3 tbsp of rum, orange liqueur, simple syrup, bitters and juice of 2 lemon wedges into a cocktail shaker filled with ice and stir, then shake until well-chilled.

Strain into the prepared glass.

*Butternut squash base: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Combine .5 cup of butternut squash puree (or pumpkin puree), 2 tsp of brown sugar, 1 tsp of molasses and a pinch of salt. Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve into a clean bowl. Use immediately or store in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

Author: Nick Dietrich
About: The classic Caribbean Rum Swizzle gets an Irish whiskey makeover for a tropical St. Patrick’s Day drink.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Powers 12 Year Old Special Reserve Irish Whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Pilsner glass.

Fill with crushed ice and swizzle vigorously until slightly frothy.

Garnish with a large sprig of mint and a pickled cherry.

Author: Shawn Chen
About: Perfect for a Halloween or fall party, this pumpkin punch includes a six-spice syrup and little meringue tops.
Ingred: 8 oz Domaine De Canton ginger liqueur
6 tbsp Farmer’s Market organic pumpkin purée
Instructions:
Serves 8 to 12.

With a jagged edge, cut open the top of a pumpkin, scoop out the seeds, and rinse out the pumpkin.

Add all of the ingredients into the pumpkin with ice and stir.

Add 5 lemon wheels, thinly sliced, and 3 pineapple wheels, thinly sliced, to the bowl for garnish.

Serve in a mini hollowed-out harvest pumpkin or glass mug, top with Marshmallow Fluff or meringue that’s then toasted with a hand torch, and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

*Fall spice syrup: Toast 2 tsp of cardamom in a saucepan at medium heat. Add 5 whole star anise, 1 tsp of nutmeg, 5 diced stems of whole ginger root, 3 cinnamon sticks, 3 cloves, 1 whole orange twist, 2 cups of fine white sugar and 2 cups of water, and stir until the sugar has completely dissolved. Let it cool for 30 minutes, and use a fine-mesh sieve to strain into a Mason jar. (Keeps in the refrigerator for up to 4 weeks.).

**Toasted meringue: Separate 5 whole eggs and place the whites in a large bowl. Beat the egg whites with an electric or handheld mixer until they become soft. Add 3 tsp of sugar gradually as the egg whites are beaten to stiff peaks. Use a large spoon to transfer the meringue into a plastic-coated pastry bag to squeeze the meringue onto each punch-filled glass mug or mini pumpkin.

Author: Tripper Duval
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a brandied cherry. .
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer Winter

Author: Sailor Jerry Rum
About: Drink this easy-to-make rum cocktail on the lawn, porch or patio.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Ray Burns
About:
Ray Burns, the owner of Prohibition in Charleston, S.C., and Savannah, Ga., says there’s never a wrong time of year to drink an Irish Coffee, but it’s especially perfect for winter sipping. 
“As Irishmen, we take our Irish Coffee very seriously. The Gran Rosta Coffee has become one of our signature drinks at both Prohibition locations,” Burns says of the drink, which derives its name from the Gaelic words for “popcorn.” “The secret ingredient is a sprinkling of popcorn powder on top.” 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Irish Coffee: 3 Delicious Ways to Reconsider the Famed Cocktail.”
Instructions:
Add boiling water to an Irish Coffee mug, and let sit for 1 to 2 minutes.

Pour out the water, and add the whiskey and simple syrup.

Fill the mug with good-quality coffee.

Top with a layer of freshly whipped cream.

Sprinkle with popcorn powder (buttered and salted popcorn ground into a powder).

Author: David Wondrich
About: The Spanish word for daisy? Margarita.
Instructions:
In a shaker, stir together the lemon juice and sugar.

Add the tequila and Grand Marnier, and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Top with a small splash of club soda.

Author: Ryan Zemel
About:
Every cocktail on the bar menu of Fort Lauderdale restaurant Terra Mare contains a freshly pressed juice. “We wanted to use the natural characteristics of our fruits and vegetables to enhance our cocktails instead of sugars, syrups and other additives,” says general manager Ryan Zemel. For this Margarita riff named for the buxom redhead in the 1988 animated film, “Who Framed Roger Rabbit,” carrots, and their inherent sweetness, pretty much replace sugar.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 Vegetable-Heavy Cocktails You Can Make at Home.”
Instructions:
Rub a lime wedge on the outside of a Collins glass, coat with kosher salt, and set aside.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into the prepared Collins glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

*Cilantro simple syrup: Combine 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup water in a small saucepan. Simmer until sugar dissolves, then remove from the heat. Add 1 cup loosely packed cilantro, muddle gently, and let steep for 40 minutes. Strain out solids, and store the syrup in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

About: The modern classic has been perfected.
Instructions: Add the vodka, lime juice and ginger syrup to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a mule mug or Collins glass filled with fresh ice. Top with club soda and mound crushed ice over the top of the drink.

Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and roll back and forth from the mixing glass to another one.

Strain into a highball glass with ice, and garnish with a lemon wedge and celery stalk.

Author: Sammy Hagar
About: Want to party like Sammy Hagar? Try his signature Margarita recipe.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a large Margarita glass with salt.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: Sweet and tart without a kick.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries and cranberries.

Add the vodka, lime juice and simple syrup, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Brock Schulte
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
The Reiger
Ingred: 1.5 oz J. Rieger & Co. Midwestern dry gin
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the gin, syrup, lemon juice and vinegar to a shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a tulip glass over ice, top up with the ale, and fill with more ice.

Garnish with freshly grated cinnamon, 1 cinnamon stick and a straw.

*Wild plum syrup: Add sliced plums and sugar (2:1, plums:sugar, by weight) in a small pot and cook over medium heat until the plums become very soft and the sugar is completely dissolved. Strain out the solids through a chinois, and let cool.

Author: Joaquín Simó
About: At East Village cocktail destination Pouring Ribbons, cocktails get “rated” on a scale of “refreshing” to “spirituous,” “comforting” to “adventurous,” to help guide you to the right drink.  (Chartreuse lovers, ask for the bar’s vintage Chartreuse selection). On the refreshing side, the High King Highball was created by bar-star Joaquín Simón and features Clontarf Irish whiskey and Aperol, along with muddled raspberries, lemon and grapefruit juices, simple syrup, Peychaud’s bitters and a splash of soda. The artful creation is then garnished with a skewered lemon wheel and raspberry.
Instructions:
Pour the soda water into Collins glass with ice cubes.

Add all the other ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into the Collins glass.

Garnish with a skewered lemon wheel and raspberry.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Champion drinker Ernest Hemingway claimed to have invented the Death in the Afternoon, a risky pairing of absinthe and Champagne, himself. His exact instructions suggested adding iced Champagne to a jigger of absinthe until it attained “the proper opalescent milkiness,” then proceeding to drink three to five of the cocktails in one sitting.
Instructions:
Pour the absinthe into a Champagne flute or coupe.

Top with the Champagne.

Author: Woodward at Ames
About: Heat things up with this spicy tequila tipple.
Instructions:
In a highball glass, muddle the cranberries and jalapeño slice.

Fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a jalapeño pepper.

Author: Casa Noble Tequila
About: This south-of-the-border spin on the classic Old Fashioned calls for tequila and agave nectar.
Instructions:
In an Old Fashioned glass, lightly muddle the agave nectar, bitters and orange peel.

Add the tequila and one large ice cube, and stir.

Garnish with a fresh slice of orange peel.

Author: Jared Sadoian
About: Date molasses, thai chiles and citrus? We guarantee you’ve never tasted a mocktail so good.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Fill with club soda and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Nonna Titulauri
About: This fun, summer take on the Tequila Sunrise
Instructions:
Pour the syrup into a Highball glass and fill with crushed ice.

Add the rest of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain over the crushed ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist and raspberry.

*Raspberry syrup: In a small glass, muddle 6 raspberries. Add 6 oz simple syrup and stir. Fine-strain into a separate glass to remove the seeds.

Author: Simon Ogden
About: An all-Canada ingredients list makes this cocktail by Simon Ogden of Veneto in Victoria, British Columbia, extra nice.
Ingred: 2 dashes Bittered Sling Kensington Aromatic bitters
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin and stir.

Pour into a coupe.

Author: Pama Pomegranate Liqueur
About: She may seem demure, but she packs a powerful punch.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: This boozy tea by bartender Elia Covino at Chicago’s Rebar in Trump hotel will warm you up during winter. “I wanted to make something to replace the mulled wine we would serve around the holidays that would appeal to the Hot Toddy drinkers and that spirits people wouldn’t generally think would go well in a warm cocktail,” says Covino. “I knew I wanted vermouth to be a component, and the gin was a wonderful addition, adding more depth and a floral component. The milk chocolate elixir plays off both of those so well, and the ginger snap liqueur and honey add a touch of sweetness.”
Ingred: 1 oz Art in the Age ginger snap liqueur
1 tsp Rare Tea Cellar Emperor’s Milk chocolate elixir
Instructions:
Steep all the ingredients except for the dried fruit in 6 oz hot water for 4 minutes to make a tea.

Add the dried apples, apricots and strawberries in a cup.

Pour the tea over the fruit.

*Honey syrup: Add 1 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

**Dried fruit mix: approximately 2 apples, 2 apricots and 5 strawberries.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About: Who doesn’t love a chargrilled steak taco? It’s pretty much the perfect summer meal and goes great with any number of hot-weather tequila drinks.
Ingred: 4 garlic cloves, 3 smashed and 1 garlic clove minced
2 tbsp fresh lime juice, plus another whole lime for garnish
1⁄4 cup lightly packed chopped fresh cilantro, plus more for garnish 1⁄4 cup
Garnish: Bittermens Xocolatl mole bitters (or Angostura bitters)
Instructions:
Serves 6 (2 tacos per serving).

In a large zip-top bag, combine the olive oil, smashed garlic, lime juice, orange juice, 1/4 cup cilantro, horseradish and crushed red pepper. Add the skirt steak and seal. Marinate for at least 2 hours at room temperature or refrigerate overnight. (If refrigerated, let come to room temperature before grilling.).

Remove steak and use a paper towel to pat the surface somewhat dry. Get your grill extremely hot, and brush with small amount of vegetable oil. Cook for about 3 minutes, flip, and repeat. Surface should be charred, while inside should be medium. Transfer the steak from the grill to a cutting board, cover with foil, and let rest for 10 minutes.

Mash together the avocado, shallot and minced garlic in a mixing bowl. Add salt and pepper along with a squeeze of lime. Set aside.

Cut the steak across the grain into slices, then cut in the opposite direction into bite-size pieces.

To assemble the tacos, warm your tortillas on the grill and fill each tortilla with steak, avocado mixture and queso fresco. Top with sour cream, cilantro and a squeeze of lime, if desired.

Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker tin, add ingredients and shake.

Strain over ice.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Romantic Spring Summer Winter

Author: Sother Teague
About: Who said Jäger can’t be fancy? Mix it with bitters and sweet vermouth for a craft cocktail you’ll love.
Ingred: 3 dashes Devil’s Larder Root Beer Bitters
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a Collins glass and fill with ice. Top with seltzer.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: This simple cocktail is as refreshing as it sounds.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange slice.

Author: Virginia Miller
About:
Head under the palapa at Oakland’s new Kon-Tiki for Christ Aivaliotis and Matthew Reagan’s rum and Tiki drinks. This cocktail is a riff off a classic Trader Vic’s Grog.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: March 2018.”
Ingred: 2 oz Hamilton Reserve pot-still Jamaican black rum
.5 oz Small Hand Foods passion fruit syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with crushed ice, and give it a very short shake.

Pour into a Tiki mug over ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and cherry speared to a pineapple wedge.

Author: Liquor.com
About: They say the simplest cocktails are the hardest to master. This pre-Paleozoic sipper is no exception, consisting of just three vital ingredients. Our foolproof recipe will have you mixing it again and again. For a much stronger drink, try including actual alcohol.
Ingred: 6 oz Small-batch spring water (2:1 hydrogen to oxygen)
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with cubed ice and set aside.

Add the small-batch spring water into a shaker with cubed ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Dump the ice from the highball glass, and replace with 3 large ice cubes.

Strain the small-batch spring water into the highball glass.

Top with the sparkling water.

Float the distilled water over the top, and gently stir.

Garnish with a watermelon slice.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Who says medicine can’t taste amazing? This essential cocktail was created for sailors as a way to prevent scurvy. It didn’t take long to realize that this preventative drink was also delicious. While scurvy may be of the past, it seems like this tart tipple is here to stay. It doesn’t get much simpler or more refreshing than the classic Gimlet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass or an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

(You can substitute 1 oz lime cordial, such as Rose's Lime Juice, for both the lime juice and simple syrup).

Author: Crystal Sykes
About: Making your own cannabis-infused liquor that’ll give you a buzz in two ways isn’t as hard as you think. After decarbing your cannabis and infusing your spirit, you can then use that liquor to make this rum and coconut milk cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the rum, cannabis-infused coconut milk, pineapple and lemon juice into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a pineapple wedge and serve.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: It may look like one, but this sweet concoction is anything but a Martini.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with an olive.

About: This no-nonsense, four-ingredient cocktail created by the legendary Jerry Thomas is crisp, citrusy and sweet.
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with an orange and cherry flag.

About: La Salvación is a Caribbean favorite that was made famous by Dale DeGroff. This lovely, aromatic and complex cocktail combines fragrant sage with Bacardí Superior rum and two rather interesting liqueurs.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously.

Fine-strain the into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a sage leaf and pineapple leaf.

About: The Scotch & Ginger is better experienced than explained. The unforgettable blend of sweetness and spice defies description.
Ingred: 4 oz spicy ginger beer such as Blenheim’s Ginger Ale 4 oz spicy ginger beer such as Blenheim’s Ginger Ale
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except ginger beer to mixing glass filled with ice.

Stir until well chilled.

Strain into an ice-filled highball glass and top with spicy ginger beer.

Author: Carmen Polcyn
About: Nothing says winter holidays like a pine-themed drink. This one by bartender Carmen Polcyn at Chicago’s Bar Toma also utilizes cranberries and lemon, making it even more festive. Sip the nonalcoholic version all day, or make the cocktail at night for a cool, yet warming, seasonal tipple.
Instructions:
Add the bitters, lemon juice, pine syrup and cranberries to a shaker, and muddle the cranberries.

Add the gin or vodka (optional) and ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice, and top with the lemon-lime soda.

Garnish with 3 cranberries and a sprig of pine.

*Pine syrup: Bring 1 cup of water and 1 cup of sugar to a boil until dissolved. Reduce heat to low, and add a handful of chopped pine needles. Stir and remove from heat, and let sit for 2 hours. Strain and refrigerate. Keeps up to 3 weeks.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Toast the host of the 2016 Olympics with this acai, blueberry and lemonade combo.
Instructions:
Add Van Gogh Açai-Blueberry Vodka and lemonade to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Wake up to this orangey tipple.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a highball glass with açaí sugar, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a slapped mint sprig.

Author: Douglass Miller
About: According to cocktail historian David Wondrich, the Rusty Nail made its first appearance in 1937, and it wasn’t long before it became a classic. Don’t worry—there’s no need for a tetanus shot after drinking one of these.
Ingred: 1 oz Dewars White Label Scotch whisky
Instructions: Add the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir.
Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Erik Olsson
About: The cocktail is Sweden’s gift to you.
Ingred: 2 oz Mint syrup (simple syrup flavored with torn mint leaves)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass, fill with crushed ice and stir.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Toby Cecchini
About: A French take on the classic Scottish Blood and Sand.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fresh blood orange juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into 2 chilled stemmed cordial glasses.

Garnish each with a cocktail cherry and a lemon twist.

Author: Michelle Vera
About: A little pear syrup turns the basic Mojito into a great fall cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and mint.

Add the rum and pear syrup and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with a splash of lemon-lime soda and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: Satisfy a houseful of party guests with this festive libation.
Instructions:
In a large pitcher, combine all the ingredients except the club soda and bitters.

Cover with plastic wrap and chill for 24 hours.

To serve, pour the mixture into rocks or Collins glasses filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and a dash of bitters.

Author: Allen Katz
About:
The French Martini is the drink that helped to kick off the flavored Martini craze of the ’90s. The cocktail was brought to prominence in NYC restauranteur Keith McNally’s Balthazar, where it appeared on the menu after being placed on the menu in one of his other establishments. 
It’s sweet and creamy due to the pineapple juice and Chambord black raspberry liqueur. The primary spirit is vodka, though sometimes rum is used instead.
This recipe was created by venerable bartender Allen Katz and uses crème de cassis liqueur in lieu of Chambord. This imparts a deeper flavor from the currants that are a bit less sweet than raspberries. So this French Martini tends to be a little more spirit-forward and complex.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Crème de cassis liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Angus Winchester
About: Famed British bartender Angus Winchester likes to mix up this fruity tipple on rainy days.
Garnish: 1 Apple fan, mint sprig and grape
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, lemon, grapes, apple and simple syrup.

Add the gin and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh cracked ice.

Garnish with an apple fan, a mint sprig and a grape.

Author: Chilled Magazine
About: If you love popsicles and love cocktails, there’s nothing better than these easy-to-make treats. Have these on hand at your next summer gathering!
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Place all the ingredients in a blender and purée until well-blended.

Pour the mixture into popsicle molds.

Cover the molds with foil and cut a tiny hole in the center of each mold.

Place a popsicle stick through each hole.

Place in the freezer until frozen.

Author: Josey Packard
About: Go undercover with this top-secret applejack cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a small cocktail glass or coupe.

Top with cava or sparkling white wine.

Author: Liquor.com
About: This 1850s classic predates many of today’s most beloved cocktails, from the Daiquiri to the Margarita. But they all owe a tip of the cap to the three-ingredient OG, the Whiskey Sour. Here it’s topped off with egg white and Angostura bitters to give it a creamy, earthy texture.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker and dry-shake (no ice).

Add ice and shake again until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Top with 3-5 drops of Angostura bitters.

About: Named for Mexico’s largest city, this is an aged-tequila twist on the classic Manhattan.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime twist or a cherry.

Author: Martin Cate
About: Go tropical with this coconut water, lime and rum drink.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Rich simple syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water) 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Squeeze a lime wedge into the glass and drop it in the drink.

Author: Drexl
About: More refreshing than your average Irish Coffee, this drink from Drexl in Oakland, Calif., packs a surprising and delightful mix of flavors.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz St. George NOLA coffee liqueur 3⁄4 oz
.5 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur.5 oz
1⁄4 Tempus Fugit Crème de Noyaux liqueur 1⁄4
Garnish: The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas’ Own Decanter bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and dry-shake.

Add ice, and shake hard.
