Double-strain into an Irish Coffee mug, and add soda slowly to fill.

Garnish with a dash of bitters.

Drink Name: A Lonely Island Lost in the Middle of a Foggy Sea
Author: Paul McGee
About: This tiki cocktail recipe from Paul McGee of Chicago’s Three Dots and a Dash combines pineapple, coffee and three types of rum into one tasty concoction.
Ingred: .5 oz Cruzan Black Strap Rum.5 oz
.5 oz Old Port Deluxe Matured Rum.5 oz
3⁄4 oz Demerara syrup (1 part demerara sugar, 1 part water) 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz La Colombe Pure Black Cold Press Coffee 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 10 seconds and strain into a tiki mug filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with pineapple leaves and coffee beans.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Every home bartender should know how to make one of these.
Ingred: 1 oz Italian sweet vermouth (Carpano Antica Formula)
2 dashes Bitters (Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Aged Bitters)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until exceedingly well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Katie Loeb
About: Thai basil adds an irreplaceable accent to this vodka-and-ginger-ale concoction.
Ingred: 2 Lime wedges, cut in half (4 small pieces)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and sugar.

Add the vodka, syrup and lemon juice, and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and pour (unstrained) into a Collins glass.

Add a bit more ice and top with 1 to 1.5 oz of ginger ale.

Stir, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: Noted for its beautiful color, this old-school gin Aviation cocktail is as blue as the sky. Created before Prohibition, this staple was lost to the United States after the Noble Experiment. Luckily, the return of lots of classic liqueurs and quality spirits put this cocktail back on the market.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Crème de violette or Crème Yvette 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry if desired.

Author: Jordan Bushell
About: Cranberry sauce pairs perfectly with cognac in this fruity holiday tipple by Hennessy master mixologist Jordan Bushell.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Martini or coupe glass with a mixture of equal parts cinnamon and sugar, and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: Spike your old-timey cream soda with tequila and Campari.
Ingred: .5 oz Vanilla Bean-Infused Agave Syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cream soda to a shaker.

Shake without ice to incorporate the egg white.

Fill with ice and shake again, vigorously.

Strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the cream soda and garnish with lime zest.

Author: Claire Sprouse
About: Want to lighten up? Try this refreshing glass of amaro and grapefruit capped with bubbly.
Instructions:
Add amaro and grapefruit juice to a coupe and top with chilled sparkling wine.

Garnish with grapefruit peel.

Author: Jennifer Knott
About:
Head bartender Jenn Knott calls this cocktail “a one-stop shop for all of the flavors reminiscent of the changing seasons.” For it, she infuses Cutty Sark scotch with roasted pecans, then simmers it with apple cider, Fonseca Bin No. 27 port, honey syrup, cinnamon sticks and cloves. It’s served in an Irish coffee mug and garnished with a soft caramel candy. It reminds Knott of growing up in Michigan and picking apples at the orchards with her family during the fall.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Nuts for Pecans? Go Drink These Cocktails in Bars Across the USA.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Pecan-infused Cutty Sark blended scotch
3⁄4 cup Fonseca Bin No. 27 port 3⁄4 cup
Instructions:
Makes 10.

Place all the ingredients in a pan, and bring to a boil.

Reduce the heat to low, and let simmer for 1 hour.

Double-strain the cinnamon sticks and cloves from the hot cider.

Pour into an Irish coffee mug.

Garnish with a skewered soft caramel candy.

*Pecan-infused Cutty Sark scotch: Place 1 16-oz package of raw pecans on a baking sheet, and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Place in an oven heated at 200 degrees F, and roast for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring halfway through. Let cool. Pour pecans and 1L scotch into a large airtight container, and let set and infuse for 1 week. Strain out solids.

About: Now you have the perfect use for that bit of leftover wine.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients with 1 cup of ice to a blender and blend.

Pour into a stemless wine glass, and garnish with 2 blackberries.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: This variation on a Guinness Punch has ice cream stepping in for condensed milk and a splash of Appleton Estate rum for extra hair on the chest. It’s dedicated to fictional Olympic bobsledder Sanka Coffie.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a blender, and blend until smooth.

Serve in a chilled pilsner glass.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Feeling a little parched during brunch? The French 75 is a sparkling cocktail that’s perfect before, during and after your egg and bacon sandwich. And with the option of rum or gin, this is one classic you’ll want to rediscover again and again.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
The beautifully simple Old Fashioned gets a Mexican makeover with the addition of reposado tequila and a hit of allspice dram. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Instructions:
Combine the sugar cube and 1 small splash (about 1 1/2 tsp) club soda in a mixing glass.

Using a muddler, pulverize the sugar cube into the club soda to create a paste.

Add the tequila, allspice dram and bitters. Add ice and stir 25 to 30 times.

Strain into rocks glass over ice.

Express the oil of a lemon twist over top, and garnish with the twist.

About: This cocktail was created for Ernest Hemingway by bartender Constantino Ribalaigua of the El Floridita in Havana. Hemingway was diabetic, so the sugar in the drink was replaced with maraschino liqueur, grapefruit juice and an additional measure of rum.
Ingred: .5 parts Fresh white grapefruit juice.5 parts
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker filled with half cubed ice, half crushed ice, and shake until cold.

Fine-strain into a chilled Highball glass.

Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: This powerful cocktail is like an instant Caribbean vacation.
Ingred: .5 oz Clément Créole Shrubb Rum.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Martinique sugar cane syrup 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange wedge.

Author: Laphroaig
About: The formula for a perfectly balanced glass of fall flavor? Smoky Scotch, sweet cider and tart lemon juice.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Laphroaig 10 Year Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a glass over ice.

Garnish with a lemon wedge.

Ingred: 1.5 oz Pressed sugar snap pea with fennel bulb
Instructions:
Shake and strain all ingredients into chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with fennel frond.

Author: Jonathan Howard
Ingred: 1.5 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
3 dashes Woodford Reserve spiced cherry bitters
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, add the bitters, followed by the liqueurs and vermouth and then the bourbon.

Add ice and stir for medium dilution.

Strain over a large piece of chipped block ice into a rocks glass.

Finish with a spritz of Islay scotch.

Author: 42Below
About: This sweet-and-tart creation will set you abuzz.
Ingred: .5 oz Chambord or other raspberry liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Fill a highball glass with ice and squeeze the lime wedge into the glass.

Add the vodka and liqueur, and top with the cranberry juice.

Stir, and garnish with the squeezed lime wedge.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
About: Limoncello is produced with equal passion in multiple areas of Italy: in Sorrento, along the Amalfi coast and on the island of Capri. It’s a staple apéritif after many a dinner in Italy, and most restaurants hawk their own brand. Craving the sweet-tart pucker of this golden liqueur? It’s sublimely easy to make at home.
Instructions:
Use a vegetable peeler or zester to remove the peels from all of the lemons, avoiding peeling the bitter white pith. Place the lemon peels in a large jar and cover with alcohol. Allow the peels to steep for four weeks somewhere dark, like a closet or cabinet.

Strain the infused vodka into a large bowl and discard the lemon peels. Add one cup of simple syrup to the vodka and stir. Taste for sweetness, adding more simple syrup as desired. Use a funnel to bottle the limoncello and return to a dark area for two more weeks for the flavor to mellow. Chill thoroughly in the freezer before serving.

Author: Karlsson's Gold Vodka
About: This concoction will give your fall a fruity and spirited boost.
Ingred: 1 oz Rothman & Winter Orchard Pear Liqueur
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon juice and cranberries.

Add the remaining ingredients except the club soda and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 20 seconds and pour (unstrained) into a highball glass.

Add additional ice to fill the glass if needed and top with club soda.

Garnish with pear slices and fresh cranberries.

Author: RumChata
About: There’s no easier way to drink RumChata than on the rocks.
Instructions: Pack a rocks glass with ice and add RumChata.

Author: Paul McGee
About: The classic Irish Coffee goes tiki with this hot cocktail.
Ingred: 1.5 oz El Dorado 15 Year Old Special Reserve Rum
.5 oz B. G. Reynolds Don's Spices #2.5 oz
Instructions: Add all the ingredients to a large mug, stir and top with a dollop of Tiki Whipped Cream.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Kirschwasser, vermouth and raspberry make a romantic combination.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.

About: This classic gin drink, named for the French word for “jewel,” will put a twinkle in your eye.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Ingred: 1.5 oz Pressed sugar snap pea with fennel bulb
Instructions:
Shake and strain all ingredients into chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with fennel frond.

About: For football season, we have presented a drink by a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown. Bartender Alba Huerta is a major player in the Houston eating and drinking scene (Anvil, Julep, The Pastry War) and reps hometown pride for the Houston Texans with this chile-flake-infused cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Chile-flake-infused Clement Créole Shrubb orange liqueur 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Turbinado sugar syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water) 1⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Mix together the turbinado sugar and toasted benne seeds.

Coat the rim of a cocktail glass with lemon juice, and coat it in the sugar and seed mixture.

Add remaining ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Double-strain into the rimmed cocktail glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

About: Add a touch more sweetness to a traditional Sidecar with a sugar rim.
Instructions:
Rim a coupe glass in sugar.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the coupe glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jillian Vose
About: This cocktail from New York’s Dead Rabbit combines Irish whiskey and pistachio syrup for a truly nutty concoction.
Ingred: 2 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a fresh curry leaf.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Cooling cucumber and thirst-quenching coconut water contribute to this rum concoction.
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the Frangelico and cucumber.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and fine strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a cucumber slice.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: This creamy and minty concoction might just be better than a kiss.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a candy cane.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: San Francisco bartender and Liquor.com advisory board member H. Joseph Ehrmann says this is the world’s best Bloody Mary recipe.
Ingred: .5 oz Elixir Juice (a mixture of olive brine, dill pickle brine and various other pickle brines).5 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a pint glass with Old Bay Seasoning.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake lightlyÂ-you want to mix the ingredients without melting too much of the iceÂ-and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a kosher dill pickle spear and a cooked slice of thick-cut bacon.

Don't use a straw; drink from the rim in order to get a little of the Old Bay with each sip.

Author: Willy Shine
About: A twist on the classic.
Ingred: 1 dash Gary Reagan's Orange Bitters No. 6
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Express orange and lemon oils over the drink and garnish with the peels.

Author: Employees Only
About: A delicious mix of three spirits, pineapple, lime juice and, of course, ginger.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the pineapple, ginger and sugar until they form a paste.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill half way with ice.

Shake briefly and pour (unstrained) into a rocks or Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

Author: Eric Ochoa
About: This rhum agricole cocktail served at Over Proof
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

*Tiki-Tivo apéritif: Combine 1 oz Campari

Author: Blade & Bow
About: Mezcal lends a note of fire and brimstone to this bittersweet bourbon cocktail.
Ingred: 1 1⁄3 oz I.W. Harper Kentucky straight bourbon whiskey
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupette.

Garnish with nutmeg.

Author: Steven Lucas, Raised: An Urban Rooftop Bar, Renaissance Hotel
About: This cocktail was created by Steven Lucas at Raised for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz High West Double rye whiskey 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Cut off one third of the vanilla bean (reserve the rest for another use), scrape the seeds into a mixing glass, and add the remaining ingredients.

Fill with ice and stir.

Strain into a coupe, and garnish with an orange peel and the spent vanilla bean fragment.

Author: Jillian Vose
About: Jillian Vose, the bar manager at The Dead Rabbit
Ingred: .5 oz Lemorton Pommeau de Normandie brandy.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Sarah Baird
About: This classic gin cocktail is an alternative to the Bloody Mary.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Pour the salt and pepper onto a small plate.

Rub the juicy side of a lime wedge along the lip of a pint glass, rim the glass with the salt and pepper, and fill the glass with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into the prepared glass, and garnish with a celery stalk and lime wedge.

Author: Chambord
About: Toast the morning with this cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Chambord Black Raspberry Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the Chambord and orange juice to a flute.

Top with Champagne and garnish with fresh raspberries if desired.

Author: Brian Miller
About: The perfect companion on the road to enlightenment.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a coupe or rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Drink Name: Tippy Cow Halloween Layered Shooters: Mint Chocolate Moo
Instructions:
Layering trick: Pour first flavor into shot glass.

Shake second flavor vigorously for 10 seconds with ice then pour over spoon into glass.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About:
Make a roomful of people happy all at once.
Add to your fiesta with this delicious enchilada recipe.
Ingred: 3.5 oz Agave syrup or simple syrup
Instructions:
For this recipe you need a 52-ounce pitcher.

First, add the fresh lime juice and then the Cointreau.

Have a tasteÂ-it should still be a bit tart.

You can add a little more Cointreau but not much.

Adjust the sweetness with a little agave syrup (two parts agave nectar, one part water) or simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) but don't use more Cointreau, which would change the balance of the drink.

Add the tequila and taste.

The mixture should still be intense, because you haven't added any ice yet.

When a guest wants a drink, pour 3 ounces of the mix into a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a stemmed Margarita or cocktail glass with a half-salted rim or a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a thin wheel of lime.

If you have a large shaker or a gallon jar with a screw-top you can shake a whole bunch of drinks at the same time.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Feel the sweet sting of cognac and crème de menthe in the classic Stinger cocktail.
Instructions:
Add both of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Inspired by Kate Middleton’s giant sapphire engagement ring, this luxurious cocktail is royally delicious.
Instructions:
Add the gin, crème de violette and Curaçao to a mixing glass.

Squeeze the lemon wedge into the glass and discard.

Fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a light dusting of edible silver powder.

About: You need a French 75 in your life, especially one that’s made with cognac.
Ingred: Dry sparkling wine or cava, to top
Instructions:
Add the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with dry sparkling wine and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Kevin Beary
About:
Using a clarification technique pioneered by New York culinary whiz Dave Arnold, Kevin Beary, the beverage director at Chicago’s Three Dots and a Dash, creates a clear banana rum and a banana syrup by adding an enzyme called Pectinex. The enzyme helps break down the fruit’s pectin, which is a naturally occurring starch. When each solution is run through a centrifuge, the banana solids compress at the bottom of the device, leaving a crystal-clear liquid on top.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Clear Your Mind. Because the Time Has Come to Experience the New Banana Daiquiri.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a double Old Fashioned glass over 1 large ice cube.

*Clarified banana rum: Blend 150g ripe bananas (showing brown spots) with 1L Caribbean rum. Add 2g Pectinex, and using a high-powered blender, blend the mixture until it reaches 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Using a centrifuge, run the mixture at 4,000g for 20 minutes. Pour off the clarified rum and reserve.

**Banana syrup: Blend 150g ripe bananas (showing brown spots) with 1L simple syrup (1:1). Add 2g Pectinex, and using a high-powered blender, blend the mixture until it reaches 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Using a centrifuge, run the mixture at 4,000g for 20 minutes. Pour off the clarified banana syrup and reserve. Makes 1L.

***Lime 2.0: Mix 4g citric acid, 2g malic acid and .04g succinic acid.

Author: Desiree Marable
About: This peach-jalapeño cocktail is sweet, spicy and smooth all at once.
Instructions:
Add the mint leaves and peach-jalapeño syrup to a shaker, and crush the mint and syrup with a muddler to release the oils.

Fill the shaker almost to the top with ice.

Add the cognac and lemon juice, then shake and strain into a small ice-filled Mason jar.

Garnish with diced peaches and jalapeño slices.

*Peach-jalapeño syrup: Combine 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water and 1 sliced jalapeño in a saucepan, and heat until the sugar dissolves. Let sit for 1 hour or up to overnight, then strain. Repeat the same process with 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water and 1 diced peach. Combine the syrups once cooled, and store in refrigerator until ready to use.

Author: Jerry Thomas
About: A little lemon juice and dry vermouth fire up this classic cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Noilly Prat dry vermouth 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with large, cold, hard ice cubes.

Shake, and double-strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: 12 Bottle Bar
About: Swap gin for genever to get this twist on the classic French 75.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Fresh lemon juice, strained 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add genever, simple syrup and lemon juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne or sparkling wine and garnish with a lemon twist if desired.

Author: Marcos Tello
About: Celebrating a happy occasion? Try this Champagne-topped mezcal concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and muddle briefly.

Fill with ice, shake for 10 seconds and strain into a coupe glass.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a lime wheel and a mint sprig.

Author: Dubonnet
About: A grown up Cosmo with the refined taste of Dubonnet.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lime twist.

About: This twist on the classic combines cognac, Cointreau and fresh lemon juice.
Instructions:
Rim half of a coupe glass in raw sugar.

Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into the coupe.

Author: Nigel Jones
About:
When it comes to cooking with rum, you can’t completely eschew the sweet. At the weekend brunch at San Francisco’s Kaya, chef and co-owner Nigel Jones serves this Caribbean-inspired French toast topped with maple syrup infused with dark aged rum. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Another Thing to Do with Good Rum? Cook with It.”
Instructions:
In a medium-size saucepan, whisk together the eggs, heavy cream, coconut milk, vanilla extract, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice and clove.

Place the bread slices into the batter mixture, and flip to ensure both sides of the bread are well-coated.

Melt the butter in a large skillet or on a griddle. Place the bread slices in the skillet or on the griddle, and cook until golden brown on each side (about 2-3 minutes).

Serve immediately and top with the seasonal fruit, powdered sugar and rum maple syrup (1 cup maple syrup and 3/4 ounce dark aged rum combined in a saucepan over low heat until warm).

About: No need for a trip to the Three Broomsticks! Harry Potter’s favorite boozy beverage is easy to make at home. Grown-up wizards and adult muggles can make this famously boozy Diagon Alley treat right in their own cauldron. (No spells required.)
Garnish: Whipped cream & butterscotch syrup, or butterscotch whipped cream
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a frosty mug.

Top with a generous dollop of butterscotch whipped cream.

About: The cares of the day just simply disappear. It might just be your new favorite nightcap.
Instructions: Pour the coffee liqueur and vodka over ice, top with club soda and serve with a straw.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Make any day a celebration with this festive cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a Champagne flute.

Garnish with a strawberry slice.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team. 
Named after the Carolina Panthers’ signature dab move, Kindred bartender Blake Pope uses small-batch gin  from nearby Sutler’s Spirit Co. in Winston-Salem, N.C., to make this variation on a Tom Collins. “This drink is served long, packs a mean punch and has a nasty bite,” says Pope.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the gin, sherry, lemon juice and honey syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice, top with strawberry shrub, and garnish with a thyme sprig.

*Honey syrup: Add .25 cup water and .5 cup honey to a small saucepan over medium heat, and stir until the honey completely melts. Strain into a jar and seal with a lid.

**Strawberry shrub: You can buy on here

Author: Gary Regan
About: Cocktail expert Gary Regan imagines what the Sazerac would be like if invented in France instead of New Orleans.
Instructions:
Pour the absinthe into a chilled Champagne flute, tilting and rotating the glass to coat the interior.

Add a few ice cubes and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with fresh ice.

Stir.

Discard the ice and any excess absinthe from the prepared flute and strain the drink into it.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Add ingredients to shaker tin and fill with ice.

Shake and double strain into Old fashioned glass and fill with crushed ice.

Express orange oils over glass.

Garnish with peel.
Theme: Brunch Fall Holiday Season Spring Summer

Author: Julieta Campos
About:
This cocktail by bar manager Julieta Campos at The Whistler in Chicago takes inspiration from a classic Clover Club and the Bellevue-Stratford hotel in Philadelphia, where that drink was invented. Playing delicately with gin and fino sherry, the drink unfolds with subtle nutty, creamy, fruity, tannic and dry notes from a house-made pistachio white tea syrup and banana bitters. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Gin Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now.”
Ingred: .5 oz Pistachio white tea syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with 1 cube of ice, and shake.

Double-strain into a coupe.

Garnish with a stripe of Angostura bitters.

*Pistachio white tea syrup: Combine 50 grams of crushed pistachios with 500 mL sugar and 500 mL water in a pot. Bring to a boil at medium heat, then reduce to low heat and let boil for 10 minutes. Strain out solids. Combine the syrup with Chinese white needle tea (1 oz of tea per 1 L of syrup) for 1 minute. Strain through a coffee filter. Cool, bottle and refrigerate.

Author: Casa Noble Tequila
About: Organic tequila makes this simple version of the classic Margarita extra-special.
Instructions:
If desired, coat the rim of a Martini or Margarita glass with salt and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Dan Warner
About: Don’t pass up this gin-and-tea cocktail.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a Martini glass or small tea cup and stir to combine.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Juan Coronado
About: The addition of Fernet-Vallet liqueur to Juan Coronado’s riff on the Piña Colada, at Washington, D.C.’s Colada Shop, gives the classic blended cocktail a bracing menthol and herbal note that refreshingly offsets the drink’s rich creaminess.
Ingred: 2 oz Coco Lopez cream of coconut
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a blender with ice and blend.

Pour into a large stemless wine glass.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

Author: Greg Seider
About: Homemade peach-apricot-chipotle syrup takes this drink way beyond the Julep.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the shiso leaves.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and double-strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a shiso leaf.

Author: Jim Palumbo, Belle Shoals
About: This cocktail was created by Jimmy Palumbo at Belle Shoals for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Prat dry vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir, then strain into a cocktail glass, and garnish with a brandied cherry.

Author: Rob Montero
About: Cool down this summer with a frosty gin and mango cocktail at Blackbird Ordinary.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a blender and fill with crushed ice.

Blend thoroughly and pour into a pint glass.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About:
The classic Daiquiri is a super simple rum cocktail that’s well-balanced and refreshing. The combination of sweet, sour and spirit is refreshingly tangy and perfect for any occasion.
The Daiquiri’s classic cocktail status was long established before the contemporary cocktail phase. It was one of six classic cocktails that was featured in David A. Embury’s 1948 seminal book on cocktails, “The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks.” 
Once you’ve made this recipe, you’ll forget all about those terrible frozen, syrupy Daiquiris you’ve had in tropical locations. Add this foolproof drink to your bartending arsenal and your friends will thank you.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Simon Ford
About: Introduce yourself to the complex Czech herbal liqueur Becherovka with this sweet-and-sour delight.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highballglass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Kaitlyn Goalen
Instructions:
Add the date, salt, cumin and lime juice to a shaker. Let sit for 5 minutes, then muddle well so the date is pulverized.

Add ice and shake until chilled, then pour the contents of the shaker into a tall glass.

Fill to the rim with ginger beer and stir well to combine. Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Jorge Guzman
About: This corn and mezcal cocktail was named after the eponymous Mayan god of maize.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Mexican sweet corn juice (one ear of corn yields about 3 oz juice)
2 leaves of Epazote and Hoja Santa
Garnish: Pitiona leaves and a salted rim
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake and strain into the salt-rimmed rocks or cocktail glass.

Author: Daniel Victory
About: During his Bar Shift in New York City, Daniel Victory’s Brandy Crusta served as a reminder of his native New Orleans. The legendary cocktail was invented there and has been the base formula of countless other drinks that have inspired Victory since.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Champagne Coupe with a sugar rim and garnish with a lemon twist.

About: This light, refreshing drink is just the thing for a day at the beach.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Eben Freeman
About: Try this pomegranate variation on the classic.
Instructions:
Moisten the rim of a chilled Martini glass and coat it with sugar.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Mike Mammoliti
About: This fruity cocktail from MAMO in New York gets a hint of spice.
Instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake well, and strain into a coupe glass.

Author: Hophead Vodka
About: Hops-infused vodka makes this a brunch drink for beer lovers.
Garnish: 1 Shrimp, lemon zest, fennel and pink peppercorns
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a highball glass with sea salt.

Add the remaining ingredients and stir to combine.

Fill with ice and stir again, briefly.

Garnish with a cocktail shrimp, a fennel stalk, lemon zest and freshly ground pink peppercorns.

About: Swap out the rum in this Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Vessel.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeeze lime juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake.

Double-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This clam-juice-spiked Bloody Mary is the national cocktail of Canada.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a tall glass with celery salt, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Pour back and forth into another mixing glass a few times to mix.

Strain into the prepared glass and garnish with a celery stalk.

Author: Edin Lauren
About:
Eden Laurin, the head of spirits programs at Dove’s Luncheonette, Publican Anker and The Violet Hour in Chicago, spices an aged rum with warming cinnamon, cloves and star anise for her cold weather take on the Mojito. A splash of Licor 43, a Spanish liqueur flavored with vanilla and botanical herbs and spices, adds aromatics.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Can the Classic Drinks of Summer Be Transformed for Winter? Yes. And This Is How.”
Instructions:
Add the rum, lime juice and syrup to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Drop the mint sprig in the bottom of a Collins glass, add fresh ice, and strain the drink on top.

Garnish with a mint sprig, and slowly pour the liqueur onto the leaves and the top of the drink.

*House-spiced rum: Add 1 stick of cinnamon, 5 ground cloves and 3 ground star anise to 1 750mL bottle of aged rum. Let steep for at least 12 hours or until desired flavor is achieved, then strain out solids.

Author: James Menite
About: Love Game of Thrones and sophisticated drinks? Try this Scotch cocktail. Winter is coming.
Ingred: 1 oz The Glenrothes Select Reserve Single Malt Scotch Whisky
Instructions:
Add the egg to a shaker and shake without ice until emulsified.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake very well and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: A.J. Schaller
About: Making this sous vide G&T
Instructions:
Add the gin to a Highball glass with ice.

Top with the tonic water.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

*Sous vide tonic water: Add 4 cups water, 4 tsp powdered cinchona bark, 1 cup lemongrass, 1 roughly chopped lemon (with zest added and juiced), 1 roughly cut lime (with zest added and juiced), 1 roughly chopped orange (with zest added and juiced, 1 grapefruit (with zest added and juiced), 1 tsp allspice berries, 1/4 cup citric acid, 1/4 cup salt and half of 3/4 cup agave syrup to a sous vide bag. Cook in a water bath set at 158 degrees F for 2 hours. Strain the liquid several times through a chinois and coffee filter until clear, and stir in remaining agave syrup to taste. Cut with water (roughly 1 part tonic syrup water to 4 parts water), and carbonate in an iSi siphon.

Author: Vance Henderson
About: This drink doubles as a dessert and cocktail in one. Two different approaches to preparing acorn squash allow the vegetable to flex its muscles in a couple of different directions. For the vegetable-cocktail skittish, though, never fear: Allspice and clove help the drink to retain a more traditional “nog” flavor profile while adding in a welcome dose of crispness.
Ingred: .5 oz Green acorn squash cordial.5 oz
1 oz Roasted white acorn squash purée
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker and shake vigorously.

Double-strain into a double-rocks glass over ice, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

*Green acorn squash cordial: Add 1.5 cups of squash purée, 1 cup granulated sugar and .5 tsp of whole allspice into a saucepan, and bring to a simmer, stirring slowly. Remove from the heat and allow to cool to room temperature. Once cool, strain through fine-mesh cloth into a clean bowl. Stir in 1 cup of vodka in the mixture until combined. Use immediately or refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

**Roasted white acorn squash purée: Quarter and deseed a whole squash, then pierce the squash flesh with 10 to 12 cloves, depending on the size of the squash. Roast at 414°F in an oven-safe pan until the flesh is tender. Allow to cool and remove the cloves. Place the cooled squash in a blender, and pulse until smooth, streaming in cold water until the desired purée consistency is reached. Use immediately or refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

Author: Simon Ford
About: There is no shame in drinking this guilty pleasure.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with mint leaves if desired.

About: Put a spicy twist on the Vieux Carré with this cardamom- and sherry-spiked Hennessy cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir.

Add 1 large cube of ice to a rocks glass, and strain the cocktail over it.

Garnish with grated cardamom.

Author: Willy Shine
About: This twist on the summery classic is rich with antioxidants.
Ingred: 1 oz Demerara syrup (one part Demerara sugar, one part water)
.5 oz Pom Wonderful 100% Pomegranate Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blackberry.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Camus Cognac
About: Crémant d’Alsace sparkling wine completes this tasty rum-and-cognac cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
1⁄4 oz Marie Brizard Peach Liqueur 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the sugar cubes in the club soda until dissolved.

Stir in the remaining ingredients, except for the wine, one at a time.

Fill with ice and continue stirring until chilled.

Strain into a coupe or punch glass and top with the wine.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Devil’s Acre
About: This whipped and iced cocktail from Devil’s Acre in San Francisco is a mouthwatering and complex take on the Irish Coffee. It’s just the pick-me-up you need.
Instructions:
Whip all of the ingredients with 4 ice cubes until the cubes are almost fully melted.

Strain and shake-dry to further whip.

Pour into a tall zombie glass, and top with Mexican Coca-Cola.

Add 2 ice cubes, and spray the top of the drink with ammonia spirit.

Author: Gary Regan
About: No, the famed flag-maker Betsy Ross did not create this brandy- and port-based tipple. But it’s delicious nonetheless.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

About: The orange flesh of butternut squash has a natural sweetness to it, which gets sweeter still when roasted with a bit of maple syrup, making it an ideal veg to infuse into robust bourbon in the fall.
Ingred: dash Giffard Banane Du Bresil liqueur
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, combine all of the ingredients with ice and stir.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh cracked ice, and garnish with an orange peel.

*Squash-infused bourbon: Cut 2 cups of butternut squash into chunks. Add the squash, 1/4 cup of maple syrup and 1 tsp of cinnamon. Spread the squash on a baking sheet and bake in the oven at 350 degrees for 15 minutes or until soft. Allow to cool. In a large Mason jar, combine the squash with 1 750mL bottle of bourbon (like Buffalo Trace), and set the empty bottle aside until later. Cover tightly and allow it to infuse for two to three weeks. Strain the bourbon, funnel back into the empty bottle (be sure to label the bottle), and cap tightly. The infused bourbon should keep for five to seven days.

Author: Eric Rivera
About: Ambitious home cooks who want to add some fancy French flavors to their cocktail glasses should try this duck-stock-based drink by Eric Rivera, the executive chef at Seattle’s The Bookstore Bar & Café, that will seriously impress dinner guests.
Ingred: 3.5 oz Dolin Génépy des Alpes liqueur
1⁄5 oz St. George Absinthe Verte 1⁄5 oz
Instructions:
In a small saucepan, warm the duck stock. In a small bowl, combine the egg white and cold water, then stir that mixture into the warm stock. Bring to a simmer. Remove pan from heat and let stand for 5 minutes. (As the egg white cooks, it will coagulate and trap fine particles from the stock.) Pour the stock through cheesecloth into a small, clean bowl to strain out the particles and egg white. Add the salt and smoked pepper.

Pour the seasoned stock, Génépy and absinthe into a rocks glass.

Garnish with toasted juniper berries, whole caraway seeds and a rosemary sprig.

Author: Dan Q. Dao
About: This two-ingredient autumnal classic is traditionally made using two ounces of rye, bourbon, rum or brandy and topped with apple cider.
Ingred: 2 oz Rye, bourbon, rum or brandy
Instructions:
Add the spirit and bitters to a Collins glass over ice.

Fill the glass to the brim with the cider and stir.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Nick Detrich
About:
Nick Detrich of Cane & Table in New Orleans created this riff on the classic Ti’ Punch.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “It’s About Time to Fall in Love with This Rum Cocktail. It’s Called the Ti’ Punch.”
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz J. Rieger Caffé amaro 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a snifter glass.

Squeeze a lime wheel with the peel side down to maximize the oils.

Garnish with a lime wheel, sliced so there’s as much peel as meat on either side.

About: This cocktail, served at Barcelona gin joint Bobby Gin, is perfect for day drinking.
Instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, strain and serve neat in a double rocks glass. Garnish with a mounted lemon peel.

Author: Jason Eisner
About: This CBD hemp oil  and tequila
Ingred: 5 drops Organic cold-pressed CBD oil (extracted from industrial hemp)
Instructions:
Place all of the ingredients except for the CBD oil and aquafaba in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.

Fine-strain into a 64 oz container, and add the CBD oil and aquafaba. Emulsify the liquid for 5 seconds with a handheld emulsifier on turbo.

Transfer the liquid back into the cocktail shaker, and strain the liquid into a coupe glass with a Hawthorne strainer.

To create a pot leaf image atop the cocktail, use a stencil and ceremonial-grade matcha.

Author: Mayur Subbarao
About: This absinthe tipple holds powerful magic.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Pür Likör Blossom Elderflower Liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: Moscow’s Delicatessen, led by Vyacheslav Lankin, turns out old classics with new twists and brings surprising new ingredients into the mix, like this vodka cocktail made with beetroot shrub.
Instructions:
Combine the vodka, orange juice and apple juice in a mixing tin and stir.

Top with the beetroot shrub and absinthe.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: This watermelon cooler is perfect for a day at the beach.
Ingred: 1 oz Bright, crisp white wine, such as Sauternes or verdejo (optional)
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the watermelon juice or cubes and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a mint leaf slapped between your palms.

Author: Courvoisier
About: A bit of honey syrup is the secret to this summer cognac and citrus punch.
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.

Garnish with grapefruit and a lemon twists.

Author: Jamie Gordon
About: Go heavy on the vermouth for this tasty variation on the classic Martini.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: You can mix up this simple-but-sophisticated drink at any time of night.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Cherry Noir Flavored Vodka
.5 oz Noilly Prat Rouge Vermouth (or other sweet vermouth).5 oz
Instructions:
Add the vodka and vermouth to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Squeeze the orange peel over the drink and discard.

Garnish with a cherry.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Campari, sweet vermouth, and orange bitters play nicely with aged tequila.

Author: Robert Krueger
About: Try this zippy cachaça-based banana drink.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Giffard Banane Du Bresil liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and add a single ice cube.

Shake briefly to mix and strain into a Collins glass filled with pebble ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Erik Adkins
About: Forget the Hurricane. The Sazerac is what you should drink in New Orleans. One of America’s earliest cocktails, the Sazerac is a homegrown New Orleans specialty. Peychaud’s bitters are a key element and were created by Antoine Peychaud, a French Quarter pharmacist, who invented the cocktail in the 1830s. The Sazerac was originally made with cognac, but an insect epidemic destroyed many French vineyards and resulted in the lasting switch to rye whiskey.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside.

In a mixing glass, muddle the sugar cube and both bitters.

Add the rye, fill with ice and stir.

Strain into the prepared glass.

Twist a slice of lemon peel over the surface to extract the oils and then discard.

Author: Phil Ward
About: Rum cocktails are the life for me
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Demerara simple syrup (two parts Demerara sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients in a bowl or other container, cover and let stand overnight.

Strain, and refrigerate until cold.

Pour into a wine glass and garnish with a mint sprig.

About: This complex, herbal cocktail will win any argument.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and double-strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Lesley Jacobs Solmonson
About: Cocktails don’t come much easier than this one, which has been around since the late 1930s. A lot of recipes suggest equal parts, but you’re better off starting with two ounces of scotch and a half ounce of Drambuie, tinkering until you find your personal ratio. No matter how you drink it, you’ll be channeling the Rat Pack in no time.
Instructions:
Combine the ingredients in a rocks glass, add 1 large ice cube, and stir.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Jason Bran
About: This Mexican flower has bite.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

About: Cognac and apple cider are shaken into this ice-coldbut warmingcocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Chris Bostick
About: This tall, sweet and spicy gin drink is straight from the Lone Star State.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a higball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a fresh raspberry.

Author: Jackson Cannon
About:
Jackson Cannon, the co-owner and bar director of The Hawthorne in Boston, created this Old Fashioned variant in honor of the Freehand hotel in Miami Beach, Fla., that’s home to the Broken Shaker bar. “All spirits have a place in the Old Fashioned because it’s, in truth, the simplest and first cocktail ever mixed,” says Cannon. “Saying ‘I’ll have the Old Fashioned whiskey cocktail’ would have been a phrase used in the Golden Age in New York City bars, and the term stuck through the 20th century.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “So You Love a Whiskey Old Fashioned. How About the Rise of the Rum Old Fashioned?”
Ingred: 2 oz Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with the orange twist.

About: This three-ingredient Italian cocktail is as classic as a drink can get.
Instructions:
Measure all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and add a large ice cube.

Stir until cold, and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

About: Sweet honey syrup adds another layer of flavor to the classic citrusy Sidecar.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a rocks glass, then garnish with orange zest.

*Honey syrup: In a saucepan, bring 2 parts water to 1 part honey to a boil and simmer until the honey has dissolved. Cool and store in the refrigerator until ready to use.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: This classic rum cocktail is an exotic blend of passion fruit, orange and a hint of lime.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously.

Strain into a Hurricane glass over ice.

Garnish with a lemon wheel, orange peel and cherry.

*Passion fruit syrup: In a small saucepan, combine 1 cup water, 1 cup sugar and 1/2 cup passion fruit pulp (from 6 ripe passion fruits). Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring until sugar is dissolved. Reduce heat and simmer for 12 minutes. Fine-strain into a container and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

About:
Simple syrup is the building block for delicious cocktails. It’s easy to make, and you likely already have the ingredients at home. You’ll wonder why you ever bought simple syrup from the store. 
If you want a richer flavor, try using demerara sugar. It’ll take your cocktail to the next level. If you want to impart some extra flavor in your cocktail, you can experiment with adding herbs, citrus and/or spices into your simple syrup.
Instructions:
Add water and sugar to a small saucepan over medium heat.

Stir until sugar is dissolved.

Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid.

Simple syrup will keep, refrigerated, for about a month.

Author: Giuseppe Gonzalez and Richie Boccato
About: The Strawberry Daiquiri is a classic summertime drink. Chill down with this frosty rum concoction.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Aged Puerto Rican or Jamaican rum
Instructions:
To make the Strawberry Daiquiri add all the ingredients to a blender.

Blend until smooth and pour into a Margarita glass or wine goblet.

Garnish with an orchid and a cocktail umbrella.

Author: Adam McDowell
About: Adam McDowell’s book Drinks: A User’s Guide
Instructions: Add the whisky to a rocks glass with ice, swirl it around a bit, and fill the glass with the cherry cola.

Author: Ketel One Vodka
About: Face it: The Mad Men crew is cooler than you are. Take a step in the right direction with this classic. If you favor a vodka-based Martini, why not fill yours with a spirit boasting a rich, centuries-old legacy? The Nolet family has been distilling spirits in the Netherlands since 1691, which means Ketel One is the ideal partner for dry vermouth in a classic Vodka Martini.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist or olives.

Author: Jon Feuersanger
About: There are two ways to make this warming winter drink: One involves smoking your own honey, and the other involves a cheat and buying already smoked honey (a good option is Bee Local
Ingred: 1 oz Famous Grouse Smoky Black blended scotch (optional)
Instructions:
Add the scotch (optional), lemon juice, smoked honey and hot water to a tea cup, and stir.

Garnish with a rosemary sprig, lemon wheel and grated nutmeg.

*Smoked honey: Heat 1 cup of water to a boil, and slowly stir in 2 cups of honey. Heat 1 hardwood charcoal briquette to white-hot temperature over a flame, and submerge it into the honey water. Allow to cool. Remove the briquette, and run the mixture through a fine-mesh strainer. Makes 4â€"6 servings.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Big on flavor, these vegetarian tacos are simple, nutritious and wildly delicious.
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: 1 Green bell pepper, seeded and chopped
1.5 lb Sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2” cubes (about 5 cups chopped)
Corn tortillas warmed in an oven or grilled
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Heat oil in a Dutch oven or similar heavy-bottom pot over medium heat. Add the onion, bell pepper, poblano peppers and a pinch of salt, and saute until onions are translucent and peppers have become tender, for about 10 minutes.

Add the chili powder, cumin, jalapeño and garlic, and cook for another minute, until the spices become fragrant.

Add the stock, along with the sweet potatoes. Cover and simmer until the sweet potatoes are tender, for about 10 minutes.

Add the beans, cover and simmer, stirring occasionally, for about 30 minutes.

Assemble the tacos with a heaping spoonful of the beans, followed by avocado, sour cream, radishes and cilantro.

Author: Mount Gay
About: This rum-based drink takes less than five minutes to prepare.
Ingred: 2 oz Mount Gay Black Barrel Rum
Instructions:
Add the rum to a rocks glass filled with ice.

Top with ginger ale and bitters and garnish with a lime wedge.

.

Author: Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey
About: A set of international flavors livens up this bourbon cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Grapefruit peel and Thai basil leaf
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lemon and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit peel and Thai basil leaf.

About: This classic recipe is taken from “Trader Vic’s Book of Food and Drink” (Doubleday, 1946). As you may expect from its name, it features a drizzle of honey.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice cubes and crushed ice, and hard-shake until cold.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: Liquor.com
About:
Get all the flavor of a refreshing sipper minus the hangover with this easy-to-make mocktail.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “5 Essential Mocktails for the Best Kind of January Recovery.”
Instructions:
Gently muddle the basil, mint and simple syrup in a mixing tin, add ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: This classic gin drink is simple and refreshing.
Instructions:
Add the gin, lime juice and sour mix to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the club soda and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Chambord
About: The Kir Royale is a swanky Champagne and black raspberry cocktail that is sure to class up your night. The subtle twist on the fruity French Kir Royale combines Champagne and black raspberry liqueur, rather than the traditional creme de cassis. Whether you’re celebrating a special occasion or need a bubbly brunch drink, mix up this swanky recipe for the Kir Royale.
Instructions:
Add the Chambord to a flute and top with Champagne.

Garnish with a raspberry and a lemon twist.

Author: Martin Cate
About: An island paradise right in your glass.
Ingred: 1 oz Rich simple syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water)
2 oz Aged Barbados rum, such as Mount Gay
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a pinch of freshly grated nutmeg and a lime wheel.

Author: Camille Cavan
About: This cocktail by Camille Cavan, the bar manager at Portland Ore.’s Quaintrelle
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Tempus Fugit Gran Classico bitter 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the egg white to a shaker with ice and shake vigorously.

Fine-strain into a rocks glass over 1 large ice cube.

Add the egg white to an empty shaker and dry-shake for about 10 seconds, and pour over the cocktail.

Garnish with a few drops of black walnut bitters and 1 expressed lemon twist.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Mint and cucumber give this summery sipper a cooling sensation.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint leaves, cucumber slices and simple syrup.

Add the rum, lime juice and St-Germain, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda.

Garnish with a mint sprig poked through a cucumber slice.

About: Swearing off the sauce for a while? This surprising mocktail mimics the herbal quality of a Gin & Tonic minus the booze, with help from a simple syrup made with juniper berries, lemon peel and loose black tea.
Ingred: 4 fl oz High quality tonic water
Instructions:
Combine the juniper syrup and lemon juice in a Collins glass filled with ice.

Top with the tonic water and stir to combine. Garnish with a lemon wheel and serve.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: Sip on summer with this berry-and-juice cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄3 oz Noilly Prat Rouge Vermouth 1⁄3 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the berries.

Add the remaining ingredients and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and stir briefly.

Strain into a stemless wine glass and garnish with a raspberry, blackberry and cranberry on a skewer.

Author: Robert Ferrara
About: With strawberries and rhubarb syrup, this gin concoction just screams spring.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries.

Add the remaining ingredients and shake without ice.

Fill with ice and shake again for 20 seconds.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: Anthony Parks
About: Newly opened in December 2016 from Top Chef alum Ryan Scott, the cocktail menu at San Francisco’s Finn Town boasts plenty of fresh juices—cucumber, ginger, etc. But fennel’s not one you see on the drink menu very often. This drink by bartender Anthony Parks lends freshness and subtle anise to a tequila-forward sipper.
Ingred: .5 oz El Silencio espadín mezcal.5 oz
1.5 oz Fennel juice (juice of fennel bulbs)
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients except the soda water into a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.

Pour over fresh ice into a Collins glass, and top with the soda water.

Garnish with fennel fronds and fennel pollen.

Author: Virginia Miller
About: Arlington’s lively all-day cafe Baba
Ingred: .5 oz Honey syrup (1:1 or equal parts acacia honey and water).5 oz
1 tsp Plum preserves (Baba uses EuroGourmet plum jam)
Instructions:
Lightly muddle the basil leaves in a shaker, then add the remaining ingredients, and shake well until chilled.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a basil leaf and a few drops of Peychaud’s bitters.

About: Floral, herbaceous and beautiful to behold, the Stone Barn from Nathan O’Neill of The NoMad Bar in New York City showcases Elijah Craig bourbon accented with ginger liqueur, coconut, carrot and a hint of rum.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Cruzan black strap rum 1⁄4 oz
.5 oz Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with 3 Kold-draft ice cubes and shake (roughly 8 to 9 shakes).

Fine-strain into a pilsner glass over crushed ice.

Garnish with dill leaves and 1 straw.

*Coconut syrup: Toast 500g of coconut flakes until lightly browned under a grill, and remove from heat. Soak in 500 mL water, steep for 5 minutes, then blend ingredients with a hand mixer.

Allow to sit for 5 more minutes, then fine-strain through cheesecloth. Weigh remaining liquid, then add double the weight in white caster sugar, dissolve using the hand blender, bottle and refrigerate.

**Carrot juice: Juice 8 carrots and strain through a cheesecloth.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Whip up a pitcher of this bubbly, fruity concoction at your next party.
Ingred: 12.5 oz 12.5 oz (half a bottle) VeeV Açaí S­­pirit
Garnish: 1 Blueberries, sliced strawberries and orange wedges
Instructions:
Fill a pitcher three-quarters of the way with ice.

Add all the ingredients except the sparkling wine and stir well.

Top with sparkling wine and garnish with blueberries, sliced strawberries and orange wedges.

About: Have one for dessert.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Van Gogh Dutch Caramel Vodka
Instructions:
Drizzle thin lines of caramel and chocolate sauce on the inside of a rocks glass and chill in the refrigerator.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Author: Armando Zapata
About: This is what happens when Carrie and the gals go to Mexico.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake for 11 seconds and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: 42Below
About: Ginger ale is the perfect partner for a honey-flavored vodka.
Instructions:
Squeeze the lime wedges into a highball glass and add the mint sprig.

Muddle gently and fill with ice.

Add the vodka and top with ginger beer or ginger ale.

Garnish with a cucumber slice.

Author: Ultimat Vodka
About: Dill and cucumber add a savory note to this vodka-lime cocktail.

Author: Anna Archibald
About: Make a homemade sour mix with oleo saccharum and lemon juice to give this drink the punch it deserves.
Ingred: 2 oz Gin, vodka, rye whiskey, or tequila
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe glass.

About:
Sex on the Beach sports a provocative name for a harmless fruity cocktail. It’s easy to make and even easier to drink, so it’s perfect for your next tropical vacation or cocktail party.
No one can seem to agree on where the name Sex on the Beach originated, but many suggest the cocktail may have been invented when a bartender combined a Fuzzy Navel with a Cape Codder. The fruity sipper is served over ice in a Highball glass and garnished with an orange slice.
Ingred: .5 oz Chambord or crème de cassis (optional).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange wheel.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: St Patrick’s Day is around the corner. Start preparing now.
Ingred: 2 oz Michael Collins Blended Irish Whiskey
1⁄4 oz La Ina Fino Sherry 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

Author: Allen Katz
About: Named for one of the finest racehorses in history, this citrusy bourbon drink inspires.
Ingred: 1 oz Orange Curaçao or triple sec
Garnish: 1 Orange or lemon twist and brandied cherry
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange or lemon twist and a brandied cherry on a cocktail pick.

Author: Francesco Lafranconi
About: With rye whiskey, Belgian beer and a beef-jerky garnish, this is the manliest cocktail recipe we know of.
Ingred: Mesquite salt or your favorite barbecue dry rub spice mixture
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a pint or double Old Fashioned glass with mesquite salt or dry rub.

Fill halfway with ice and set aside.

Add the rye, lemon juice, maple syrup and egg white to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with the beer and bitters, and garnish with a piece of beef jerky.

About: Prepare to be hit with a wave of perfect spring refreshment.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the pea pods, tarragon and simple syrup.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine-strain into a frozen rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with 2 sugar snap pea pods.

Author: Enzo Cangemi
About: The spicy Mangapeño put Enzo Cangemi on the map. Inspired both by his early years in Los Angeles and his Italian heritage, the Mangapeño combines Grey Goose Vodka, Aperol, mango syrup, lemon juice and a slice of muddled jalapeño.
Instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a coupe.

Author: Jason Huffman
About: This cocktail by Jason Huffman, the bar manager at Coin-Op Game Room
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass.

Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: Master the all-time gin classic. The Tom Collins is essentially a sparkling lemonade spiked with a healthy dose of the juniper spirit. While there is a debate which side of the pond this drink was born, this cocktail lives up to his classic status with every sip.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part water, one part sugar) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the lemon juice, simple syrup and gin to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball or Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel and a cherry.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: This autumnal vodka cocktail contains both.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cider to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the cider and garnish with an apple slice and a sprinkle of grated nutmeg.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: Giving thanks has never been easier.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir for thirty seconds and strain into a chilled small cocktail glass.

Garnish with a broad slice of lemon peel.

Author: Vince Toscano
About: This cocktail is Vince Toscano’s ode to Miami’s Broken Shaker, where he was blown away by the high quality cocktail ingredients. Made with a combination of Bacardi Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron, cinnamon syrup, lime and pineapple juices and sweet vermouth, the Captain is a guaranteed crowd-pleaser.
Ingred: 2 oz Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker.

Shake and strain over fresh ice.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The secrets to making a great Irish Coffee are really so simple that they are often overlooked. This hot, creamy, classic Irish Coffee recipe from legendary bartender Dale DeGroff has all the right ingredients and will warm you to the bone.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and syrup to an Irish Coffee glass and fill two-thirds of the way with coffee.

Top with one inch of whipped cream.

About: Bea’s twist on an Old Fashioned hits sweet, tart, and chocolate-y notes.
Ingred: 1 dash Fee Brothers Aztec chocolate bitters
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.

Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel.

Author: Casey Elsass
About: The beautiful thing about shrubs is that there are only two rules: something sweet and something acidic. Typically some variety of sugar does the heavy lifting, but here maple syrup offers a perfect hit of character and complexity. And although the beets maybe seem like an odd or unnecessary addition, they actually keep the sweetness in check with a welcome earthiness, and the shrub makes a fantastic mixer in this riff on a Mint Julep.
Ingred: 1 Sprig Mint, plus more for garnish
Instructions:
In a rocks glass (or julep tin!), muddle the mint sprig. Add the maple beet shrub, the bourbon and a small scoop of crushed ice and stir.

Top with more crushed ice to fill the glass. Garnish with a festive straw and another mint sprig.

About: Green chile vodka adds a layer of heat to this lime-spiked cognac Swizzle.
Ingred: .5 oz St. George Green Chile vodka.5 oz
Instructions:
Line a rocks glass with a banana leaf.

Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and swizzle.

Strain into the rocks glass and top with crushed ice.

Garnish with an orchid.

Author: Jane Danger
About: This completely vegan cocktail takes Tiki to a dramatic level.
Instructions:
Whip the gin, aquavit, Laura’s mix, juices, syrup, tincture and bitters, pour into a metal nautilus shell (or similarly shaped vessel), top with crushed ice, and garnish with 6 orchids, 6 pineapple fronds, 3 cheetah-print (or plain) straws and a flaming lime shell.

*Laura's mix: Combine 1 oz of banana liqueur, 1 oz of dry curaçao and 2 oz of cinnamon syrup.

**Flaming lime shell: Scoop out half a lime (or use what’s left after juicing), then add a splash of overproof rum and light the flame when serving.

Author: Allen Katz
About: It’s not as famous as a Manhattan, but it’s just as tasty.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Gary Regan
About: This whiskey drink was invented in Paris while the US suffered through Prohibition.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Rich Ohtsuka
Instructions:
Pour all of the ingredients into a shaker, add ice, and shake briefly. Strain and serve over crushed ice in a double Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a single fresh rose petal, and mist rose water over top for aromatics.

About: A warmly spiced pineapple syrup adds extra dimension to an updated Sidecar.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Giffard Crème de Pêche de Vigne liqueur 1⁄4 oz
.5 oz Pineapple coriander allspice syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.

Garnish with a pineapple chunk and pineapple leaf.

*Pineapple coriander allspice syrup: Toast ½ tsp coriander and ¼ tsp allspice in a sauce pan until fragrant, making sure not to burn. In a saucepan, bring 46 oz pineapple juice and 16 oz white sugar to a boil until the sugar has dissolved. Add the toasted spices to the pineapple syrup.

About: This smoky, modern cocktail is stirred exactly 13.5 times to honor Japanese tradition.
Instructions: Fill a highball glass with large ice cubes. Pour the Hakushu over the ice. Gently stir the whisky with a bar spoon 13 and a half times. Pour the club soda over the back of the bar spoon and into the highball glass. Garnish with a mint sprig.

About: This twist on the New Orleans favorite goes down easy.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice 3⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Dark crème de cacao 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Prepare an Old Fashioned glass with a rim of smoked salt.

Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1 cup of cracked ice until smooth, and pour into the Old Fashioned glass.

Author: Matt Grippo
About: Tequila and verjus make fine bedfellows in this fragrant glass topped with bubbles.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except club soda in a wine glass.

Top with soda and garnish with lemongrass and mandarin peel.

Author: Will Thompson
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except for Champagne ahead of time and chill in refrigerator.

Pour into a flute and top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a lemon twirl or scrape of nutmeg.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: The secrets to making a great Irish Coffee are really so simple that they are often overlooked. This hot, creamy, classic Irish Coffee recipe from legendary bartender Dale DeGroff has all the right ingredients and will warm you to the bone.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and syrup to an Irish Coffee glass and fill two-thirds of the way with coffee.

Top with one inch of whipped cream.

Author: Bryan Dayton
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“Denver is known for these amazing orange-hued sunsets, so I wanted to incorporate that into this cocktail, says Bryan Dayton, the beverage director and co-owner of Denver’s Acorn
Ingred: .5 oz Ancho Reyes chile liqueur.5 oz
1⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the blue curaçao to the bottom of a rocks glass, and top with crushed ice.

Add all of the other ingredients into a shaker filled with ice and shake.

Slowly pour into the glass over crushed ice, and garnish with a blood orange slice.

Author: Herradura Tequila
About: The short trip from Cuba to Mexico makes for a drastic change in flavor for the classic Mojito. Blending mint and tequila, this warm weather drink is an excellent Cinco de Mayo cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint leaves.

Add the tequila, lime juice and agave nectar, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda.

Author: Theodore Kilpatrick
About: What do you get when you combine a Negroni and a Last Word? This unexpectedly delicious concoction.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a coupe glass.

Twist a slice of orange peel over the drink to express its oils and discard.

Author: Schuyler Hunton
About: Schuyler Hunton of Tiger Mama
Ingred: 2 dashes Salt solution (3:1 water to salt)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the coconut water soda to a shaker with ice and shake.

Add the soda, then strain into a Collins glass.

Garnish with speared maraschino cherries and lime wheels.

*Cherry shrub: 3 parts marasca syrup (the syrup left in a jar of maraschino cherries) to 1 part Champagne vinegar.

**Coconut water soda: Fill an iSi container with coconut water, and charge with a nitrogen cartridge.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: Keep the holidays classy with this seasonal tequila tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass. Garnish with a lemon wheel studded with cloves.

Author: Don Julio Tequila
About: Who says a Bloody Mary needs to be made with vodka? Try this tequila take on the classic.
Instructions:
Rub the lemon wedge along the rim of a highball glass and discard.

Coat the rim with black pepper.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and garnish with another lemon wedge and skewered cherry tomatoes.

Author: Sierra Zimei
About: Make an Aviation using all-American ingredients and you get this down-home cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with five brandied cherries and a mint leaf speared on a pick.

Author: Jerry Thomas
About: The Improved Holland Gin Cock-Tail is an old-school recipe from mixology legend Jerry Thomas.
Ingred: 3 dashes Rich simple syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with large, hard, cold ice cubes.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Neal Bodenheimer
About: At Cure
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into a slightly chilled coupe or Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Manny Hinojosa
About: The White Russian travels south of the border.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Junior Merino
About: This blended drink goes exotic, with cachaça, guava and rose syrup.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and blend for about 30 seconds.

Serve in a coupe glass.

Garnish with a rose petal.

About: This chocolate, cognac, coffee and berry cocktail hits all the best notes of the dessert course.
Instructions:
Dip the rim of a cocktail glass into simple syrup, then press into the crushed nuts to coat.

Drizzle chocolate syrup into the cocktail glass.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain carefully into the cocktail glass.

Garnish with a sliced strawberry.

Author: Camus Cognac
About: A little lemon elevates the sophisticated flavor of cognac.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a long strip of lemon peel.

About: RumChata + chocolate + mint = dessert in a glass.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Green crème de menthe 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with chocolate chips or chocolate shavings.

Author: Disaronno
About: This three-ingredient classic is a great way to highlight amaretto. The recipe dates back to the 1970s when this cocktail was a staple on cocktail menus and this version, made with Disaronno, will have you yearning for the days of bell bottoms and disco. Try this recipe for the Disaronno Sour.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist and a cherry.

Author: Sol Trece
About: One part inspiration from a Blood & Sand
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Ancho Reyes chile liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Author: Peter Vestinos
About: This Averna cocktail demands to be made immediately.
Garnish: 1 Basil leaf, lime wheel and lemon wheel
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime juice and basil.

Add the remaining ingredients except the club soda and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a highball glass.

Top with the soda and garnish with a basil leaf, lime wheel and lemon wheel.

Author: Kara Newman
About: This classic sherry cocktail recipe hails from Harry Craddock’s 1930 book, The Savoy Cocktail Book<.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir for 30 seconds.

Fine-strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: This spicy vodka and ginger cocktail bites back. The Moscow Mule marries the clear spirit with ginger for a spicy kick. Lime adds a citrusy touch for a taste that will keep you coming back for more.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About: You won’t find a simpler recipe for flavor-packed brandied cherries.
Instructions:
Drain the liquid from the contents of the jar of cherries by suspending a strainer over a container or bowl.

Dis­card the liquid (or save it to use in another drink) and return the cherries to the jar.

Add the cognac, amaretto and maraschino liqueur.

Reseal the jar and shake gently to combine the ingredients.

Add a label with the date and store the jar in the fridge for at least one month before using.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Forget that olde tyme English with this cocktail.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle all the ingredients except the gin.

Add the gin and fill with ice.

Shake well and double strain into a Martini or coupe glass.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Willy Shine
About: Respect your elders.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Pure cane simple syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, gently muddle the mint and lime juice.

Add the remaining ingredients except the Champagne and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with Champagne and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Wild Turkey Bourbon
About: A mint and ginger version of  the standard formula.
Instructions:
Muddle the ginger, mint, powdered sugar and bitters in a cocktail shaker.

Add the Wild Turkey Bourbon, both vermouths and ice.

Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a cherry.

About: This fruity drink from Spain has many variations, but sometimes tradition is the way to go.
Ingred: 1 bottle Dry red wine, like Rioja
Instructions:
In a large pitcher, add the sugar, oranges, apples and lemon and muddle for 30 seconds.

Add the brandy and orange juice and muddle again for 30 seconds.

Add the red wine, stir, add ice and serve in a red wine glass.

Author: David Wondrich
About: This early post-Prohibition concoction from Philadelphia is named for its creator’s wife, not the monarch.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: A sip of this concoction will convince you that red bell pepper deserves a place behind the bar.
Ingred: 1 oz Fresh red bell pepper juice
3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
