Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Combine all ingredients, except ginger beer, to a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into Collins glass with fresh ice, top with ginger beer and garnish.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Feel like you’re on permanent vacation with this refreshing vodka cocktail.
Ingred: 2 oz Grey Goose La Poire flavored vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the grenadine to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the grenadine and garnish with fresh mint.

Author: Emily Arden Wells
About: This cocktail is made with equal proportions of spirit and vermouth
Ingred: 2 oz La Quintinye Vermouth Royal Blanc
Instructions:
Stir with ice, and strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Lynette Marrero & Jim Kearns
About: A tribute to the actor’s Italian birthplace, this variation on the Negroni is a modern classic.
Ingred: 2 oz Vodka, gin or rye whiskey
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.This cocktail is on the menu at The Astor Room in Queens, New York.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: Don’t start a turf war over this lemony vodka cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz

About:
Eggnog, the creamy classic, is an essential part of the holidays. Combining eggs, sugar, milk and cream with  bourbon and  rum is the best version of Eggnog. The potency will put a little more cheer in your holidays.
Eggnog has a varied and rich history with a lot of competing claims of the origin of the drink that can get lost in an etymological debate. However, there are a few things to note. First, Eggnog is primarily imbibed in Canada and the USA during the holiday season. It can be consumed hot or cold depending on preference and how cold it is outside. The first printed mention of Eggnog was in 1788 in “The Jersey Journal” that referred to a young man drinking a glass of Eggnog. Second, there seems to be solid consensus that Eggnog as we know today is a culinary descendant of Posset.
Regardless of the origin, everyone can agree that Eggnog is universally delicious.
Instructions:
In a large bowl, beat together the egg yolks and half a cup of sugar until they turn light in color.

Stir in the milk, heavy cream, bourbon and rum.

In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites with the remaining quarter-cup of sugar until they form soft peaks.

Fold about a third of the egg whites into the yolk mixture.

Serve in punch or tea cups topped with freshly grated nutmeg, folding in more of the egg whites as desired.

Author: Mikey Barton
About: At Washington, D.C.â€™s Dram & Grain, the latest menu was dubbed Dram & Global, offering a series of drinks inspired from different cities across the world, including this Tokyo-style highball.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a highball glass with ice and stir to chill.

Garnish with a dried burdock root chip (or lemon wedge if burdock is unavailable).

*Golden delicious soda: Wash and cut 9â€"12 Fuji apples (enough for 36 oz of juice), avoiding the cores/seeds and juice in an extractor quickly (apples oxidize in seconds when sitting out). Halve 10 lemons (enough for 10 oz of juice) and juice. Pour each through a mesh strainer to remove solids. Once you have 36 oz apple juice and 10 oz lemon, combine the juices, and add 24 oz filtered water. Mix in 2 tbsp almond extract, and pour everything over 130 grams brown sugar in a separate container. Stir until dissolved, then carbonate with a SodaStream.

Author: Sandeman Port
About: Throw an autumn party with this port, cider and rye concoction.
Ingred: 2 Granny Smith apples, cored and sliced
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pitcher and refrigerate for at least 12 hours.

Serve in tumblers, garnished with apple or pear slices.

Author: Cody Pruitt
About: Beverage director Cody Pruitt melts De La Rosa peanut marzipan candies into a marzipan syrup to sweeten this mezcal– and tequila-based Old Fashioned. A touch of oloroso sherry echoes the nutty flavors from the peanut-studded candy.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.

*Marzipan syrup: Simmer 3 cups crushed De La Rosa peanut marzipan candies and 3 cups water until the sugar is dissolved and only the peanut pieces are left floating. Strain through a chinois and bottle. Keeps for up to 6 days refrigerated.

Author: Kevin Diedrich
About: Cognac, rye, a couple complex liqueurs and walnut orgeat combine in this extravagant cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass containing one large ice cube.

Garnish with an orange twist and a lemon twist.

About: Celebrate Halloween year-round.
Ingred: .5 oz Hiram Walker Pumpkin Spice Liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Matt Giarratano
About:
Matt Giarratano, the beverage director at Phoenixville, Pa.’s Bluebird Distilling, wanted to remove the endless sun-and-beach associations with his favorite tropical flavors—rum, coconut and pineapple—and added an element of what he calls everyday drinkability. Bourbon, rum and Tiki bitters balance the sweet, and the name is a nod to the Philadelphia suburb where the distillery and cocktail bar are located.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The 5 Recipe Variations Every Dark ’N’ Stormy Lover Should Know.”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Coconut-infused Bluebird Distilling Sugarcane rum
.5 oz Bluebird Distilling Four Grain bourbon.5 oz
Gosling's Stormy ginger beer, to top Gosling's Stormy ginger beer, to top
Instructions:
Add the rum, bourbon, juice, syrup and bitters into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer.

Garnish with 2 pineapple fronds and freshly grated nutmeg.

*Coconut-infused rum: Combine 1 750mL bottle of Bluebird Distilling Sugarcane rum and 4 cups flaked coconut in a nonreactive container like a large Mason jar. Let it set for 4 days, then strain out solids through a fine-mesh strainer.

Author: Morgan Schick
About: Try this modern and boozy twist on the classic Eggnog recipe.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into two punch cups.

Grate cinnamon on top and garnish with a slice of orange peel and a cinnamon stick.

Author: Alex Day
About: Mix tea with more than just hot water. Try this chamomile infused whiskey cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About: To make this cocktail served at The Circular
Instructions:
Partially freeze water in ice spheres for two hours.

Poke a hole in the sphere, and drain out the water.

Mix all of the ingredients, then add to the drained ice sphere using a syringe.

Freeze until needed or serve immediately. To serve, place the prepared ice sphere in a rocks glass, and crack it using a mallet.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Damian Windsor
About: After a couple of these spiced bourbon cocktails you’ll be hopping.
Ingred: .5 oz Star Anise and Black Tea Infused Simple Syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the syrup and ginger to a mixing glass.

Twist the lemon peel over the glass to extract the oils.

Drop the peel into the glass and muddle.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Casa Noble Tequila
About: Tequila, amaretto and OJ combine in this sweet treat.
Ingred: .5 oz Casa Noble Reposado Tequila.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

If desired, garnish with a lime wheel and a mint sprig.

Author: Tony Abou-Ganim
About: “The Ruby is a fruit-centric drink,” says bartender Tony Abou-Ganim. “I use a vodka with a good structure, rich mouthfeel and diverse fruit flavors. A potato-based vodka is ideal to help soften and moderate the drink’s bitter and floral elements.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed ruby red grapefruit juice 3⁄4 oz
3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, and shake with ice until well-mixed and the egg white is emulsified.

Strain into a chilled coupe, and garnish with the oils of a grapefruit twist.

Author: Chad Solomon & Christy Pope
About: Build some romance with this sophisticated take on the classic French 75  cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
.5 oz Honey syrup (2 parts honey, 1 part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne into a shaker filled with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a Champagne flute, and top with Champagne.

Author: Dan Watson
About:
This recipe may come from Cleveland, but it boasts the Tiki flavors you want from a Miami Vice cocktail. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Tiki Grows Up: Three Drinks That Will Win You Over.”
Ingred: .5 parts Giffard Crème de Fraise des Bois liqueur.5 parts
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the liqueur into a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a double rocks glass over pellet ice.

Drizzle the liqueur.

Garnish with a Luxardo cherry skewered with a cocktail umbrella, and an edible orchid.

Author: Matthew Tocco
About:
At The Patterson House in Nashville, Strategic Hospitality beverage director Matthew Tocco wanted to make a version of the Toronto cocktail that swapped out Canadian whisky for aged rum. “Rum is a product that comes from sugar, so pairing it with sugar makes sense,” he says. “A lot of people associate rum with sweet, fruity drinks, but there are a lot of different ways you can apply it.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “So You Love a Whiskey Old Fashioned. How About the Rise of the Rum Old Fashioned?”
Ingred: 1.5 oz Ron Zacapa Centenario Sistema Solera 23 rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain into a rocks glass over 1 large ice sphere.

Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: Every day is carnaval when you’re drinking the national cocktail of Brazil.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and sugar or simple syrup.

Fill with ice and add the cachaça.

Shake vigorously and pour (unstrained) into a rocks glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Neal Bodenheimer
About: At Cure
Ingred: 1 oz H&H; five-year-old special dry vermouth
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass and stir.

Strain into a slightly chilled coupe or Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Emilie Perrier
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Crème of choice (cassis, mure, abricot, framboise, fraises des bois) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions: Pour chilled Crémant into a wine glass, then slowly add the crème.

Author: Brian Means
About: After one sip of this pineapple-spiked drink from San Francisco’s Dirty Habit, you won’t need any more coaxing.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Tariquet Classique VS Armagnac 3⁄4 oz
Garnish: Compressed pineapple core or cube of pineapple.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.

Garnish with a compressed pineapple core or a cube of pineapple.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: Pear vodka and Disaronno make an elegant treat.
Ingred: 2 oz Grey Goose La Poire flavored vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a pear slice.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Rich and refreshing, Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron elevates the classic Tom Collins cocktail.
Ingred: 2 parts Bacardí Gran Reserva Maestro de Ron
Instructions:
Add the rum, lemon juice and sugar into a shaker with ice, and shake well.

Fine-strain into a Collins glass over ice.

Top with the soda.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Summer-Jane Bell
About: While this sophisticated tequila cocktail can’t actually see your future, it is delicious.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a rocks glass.

Garnish with a sprig of tarragon stuck through a small swatch of lemon peel.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: This old-school Martini goes heavy on the vermouth.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel and/or a small Spanish olive without pimento.

Author: Angus Winchester
About: The Pimm’s Cup is a classic British summertime drink that is filled with fruit.
Ingred: 1 Strawberry, hulled and cut into quarters
Instructions:
To make a Pimm's cup, first add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice and stir to combine.

(To mix things up a bit, you can replace the Sprite, 7Up or ginger ale with Champagne.).

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: Cocktail consultant Brian Van Flandern created this cocktail in honor of Casamigos creators and friends George Clooney and Rande Gerber.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously, and strain into a cocktail glass.

About: Pretend like you’re on your yacht when you mix this one up.
Instructions:
Add the vodka to a highball glass filled with ice.

Top with cranberry juice and stir until chilled.

Squeeze the lime wedge over the glass and drop it into the drink.

Author: Allen Katz
About: An old-timey name for a tasty fall gin-and-tea drink.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.

Garnish with thin apple slices.

Author: Robert Ferrara
About: The botanicals of Pimms No. 1 play ping-pong with hard cider and ZU Bison Grass Vodka’s notes of vanilla and coconut to make a refreshing cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients (except the cider) to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 20 seconds and strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Top with cider.

Garnish with a cucumber slice, a blackberry, a strawberry and a blade of bison grass.

About: This cocktail is the gin-based, day-drinking sipper of choice at Barcelona’s Polaroid Bar.
Instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, strain and serve in double rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with 2 bendy straws.

About: Two of Japan’s most famous beverages get cozy in this uplifting cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the whisky and tea to a Collins glass with an ice spear and stir.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with the maple leaf candy.

Add the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.

Strain into a Martini glass, and garnish with lemon zest.

Author: Liquor.com
About: When in Rome? How about when in New Orleans? The Hurricane powerful tropical drink will transport you to French Quarter during the first sip. Created in the 1940s, this super boozy rum-based concoction that will get the party started no matter where you are.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a large Hurricane glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a cherry..

Place the sugar into a rocks glass. Add the bitters and 1 oz of the scotch before filling the glass with ice.

Slowly stir, gradually adding the remaining scotch until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture is chilled.

Garnish with a twist of fresh orange zest and a cherry.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
About: This interchangeable eggnog recipe allows you to swap in your favorite base spirit or mix of spirits to create the perfect personalized punch. It’s easily multiplied to serve any size party, which means it’s the only ‘nog you need this season.
Ingred: 16 oz Dark rum (can substitute bourbon or brandy, or a mix)
Instructions:
In the bowl of a stand mixer or with a hand mixer, beat egg yolks at medium-high speed until thick and pale yellow.

Slowly add two-thirds of a cup of the powdered sugar (save one-third for later) and beat until fully dissolved.

Add the rum (or other spirits), milk, heavy cream, nutmeg and almond extract and stir to combine.In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites until they maintain soft peaks.

Gradually add the remaining one-third cup of powdered sugar and beat until incorporated and stiff peaks form.

Gently whisk the egg whites into the eggnog mixture.

Chill, and serve in a punch bowl.

Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg sprinkled on top.

Author: Abigail Gullo
About: New Orleans watering hole SoBou serves this subtle twist on the classic Brandy Milk Punch.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Old New Orleans Cajun Spice rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake vigorously.

Strain into a chilled Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a light dusting of freshly grated nutmeg and cinnamon.

Author: Jen Ackrill
About: Tequila shoulders out vodka in this south-of-the-border spin on the brunch-favorite Bloody Mary. Laced with two brands of hot sauce, the Bloody Maria gains extra kick from a hefty dose of horseradish and is generously garnished with a cucumber spear, jalapeño slices and queso fresco. Make your next brunch a fiesta with this tequila-spiked Bloody Mary.
Ingred: .5 tbsp Prepared horseradish, to taste.5 tbsp
Garnish: 1 Lime wedge, lemon wedge, cucumber spear, sweet pepper slices, jalapeño slices and queso fresco
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake briefly and strain into a pint glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lime wedge, a lemon wedge, a cucumber spear and a skewer of sweet pepper slices, jalapeño slices and queso fresco..

Author: Ted Allen
About: Get your morning off to the right start with this drink from Ted Allen.
Ingred: 16 oz Tangerine juice or orange juice (no pulp)
8 oz White rum or vodka, cold
Instructions:
The night before serving, stir together 8 ounces each of the tangerine and cranberry juices and divide between 2 small, uncovered food-storage containers.

Place 3 basil sprigs in each container and freeze overnight.

Pop the frozen juices out of their containers and place in a half-gallon pitcher.

Add the remaining 8 ounces each of tangerine and cranberry juices, along with the açai juice, rum or vodka and Campari.

(If you can't find açaí juice, substitute extra cranberry or tangerine juice.) Stir, and garnish with lime, orange and lemon wheels.

Serve in tall glasses filled with ice.

Stir all in mixing glass and serve on a large cube in Yarai rocks glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Want something spicy? Sweet? This cocktail gives you both.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Rim a double Old Fashioned glass with paprika sea salt.

Muddle the cilantro in a mixing glass, then add the jalapeño slice and gently muddle again.

Add the remaining ingredients to the mixing glass and shake well.

Double-strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

Author: Kathy Casey
About: Add a brand-new flavor to the classic aperitif.
Ingred: 1 Long, wide slice of grapefruit peel
2 Peeled ruby red grapefruit segments (or 1 oz fresh ruby red grapefruit juice)
Instructions:
Fill an Old Fashioned glass with ice, curl the grapefruit peel around the inside of the glass and set aside.

Squeeze the grapefruit segments into a shaker and drop in the fruit.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: This is one ride you’ll gladly give up the wheel for.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a cocktail glass with sugar and set aside.

(Do this a few minutes ahead of time so the sugar can dry and adhere well to the glass.) Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a piece of orange peel.

Author: Greg Lipari
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“My father and I have had New York Giants season tickets for at least 20 years, and we go to every home game,” says bartender Greg Lipari of New York City’s Bua. “We get there at 8 in the morning and make breakfast—bacon, egg and cheese sandwiches on English muffins, sometimes pancakes—and tailgate for hours before the game starts at 1 p.m. It’s a full-day affair, so you need a drink that it isn’t overpowering and won’t knock you over the head. If you start drinking with breakfast, you want something light and refreshing. 
“I just got back from the Giants–L.A. Rams game in London, so I was inspired to do a gin cocktail,” he says of this variation on a Tom Collins. “It’s named for Tom Coughlin, who was the Giants’ head coach for the 10 years, when they won two Super Bowls. He’s the most successful coach they’ve ever had. All Giants fans love Coughlin. The blueberries are for Big Blue, of course, and the prosecco is to anticipate imminent victory.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the blueberries, lemon juice and simple syrup.

Add the gin, fill with ice, and shake.

Pour, without straining, into a highball glass, top with the prosecco, and garnish with 8 blueberries.

Ingred: 2 oz Knappogue Castle Single Malt Irish Whiskey 12yr
Instructions:
Add dash of bitters, raspberries, orange slice & sugar syrup to shaker tin and muddle.

Add sherry, Knappogue Castle Single Malt Irish Whiskey castle 12yr and ice and shake.

Double strain into old fashioned glass and top with crushed ice.

Express orange oils from peel and discard.

Garnish with mint sprig and raspberry.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: The Old Fashioned cocktail is old-school but never out of fashion.
Ingred: 2 oz George Dickel No. 12 Tennessee Whisky (or any American Whiskey)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass.

Muddle to break down the sugar and stir briefly.

Fill with ice, stir again and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Twist slices of lemon and orange peel over the drink and drop them in.

Author: Andrew Schloss
About: Make your own hibiscus-rose liqueur for this bubbly refresher that’s perfect for an afternoon picnic.
Instructions:
Place one large ice cube in a wine glass and add all the ingredients.

Stir, and garnish with 3 rose petals or 6 pomegranate arils.

Author: Jonah Flicker
About: This take on the Whiskey Ginger (a.k.a the Irish Buck) adds a squeeze of lime and some bitters, which complement the slightly spicy but smooth Crown Royal Northern Harvest rye.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Crown Royal Northern Harvest rye
Instructions:
Combine the rye and lime juice in a shaker with ice, and shake well.

Strain into a highball glass over ice.

Add 2 dashes of Angostura bitters, and top with ginger beer.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and mint sprig.

Author: Alicia Leslie
About: A unique sherry-cask-mellowed gin adds depth and richness to this three-ingredient stunner.
Ingred: 1 oz Booth’s Finest Dry Gin Cask Mellowed
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Strain into a coupe.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: It won’t take much to warm up this refined take on the Hot Toddy. Great vodka and all the right garnishes add up to an unforgettable cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the hot water to a heated mug, and add the honey to melt, stirring.

Pour the vodka, liqueur and lemon juice into the mug and stir.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick, an orange wedge and freshly grated nutmeg. (Optional: Pierce an orange wedge with three cloves.).

Author: Randy Perez
About: Red bell pepper is an unusual ingredient, but it works well in this sweet-and-spicy tequila cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Cucumber and red bell pepper slices
Instructions:
Combine equal parts of chile de arbol and salt on a saucer and use to coat the rim of a Collins glass.

Fill with ice and set aside.

In a shaker, muddle the cucumber, bell pepper and lemon juice.

Add the tequila, agave nectar and bitters, and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Top with ginger beer and garnish with slices of cucumber and red bell pepper.

About: The simple, sweet and bubbly Gin Buck was a popular summer cooler during the Roaring ’20s.
Ingred: Juice of half a lemon or lime
Instructions:
Fill a Collins glass with ice and add the gin and lemon or lime juice.

Fill with ginger ale and stir briefly.

Garnish with a lemon or lime wedge.

About: You might be surprised by what a splash of soda can add to a premium single malt. Toss in a slice of red apple to enjoy this highball in style.
Ingred: 2 oz Aberlour 12 Year-Old Single Malt Scotch
Instructions:
Add the Aberlour 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch to an ice-filled highball glass.

Top with soda water and garnish with a slice of red apple.

Author: Hornitos Tequila
About: Swap out whiskey for tequila in this twist on the classic Hot Toddy.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mug.

Stir, and let steep for one minute.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: This savory concoction is the classic accompaniment to a shot of good tequila.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pitcher and stir until the salt dissolves.

Let stand for 15 to 30 minutes and then remove and discard the jalapeño.

(The longer the jalapeño infuses, the spicier the Sangrita will be.) Store in the refrigerator. Serve as an accompaniment to shots of tequila.

Author: Patrick Henaghan, Roka Akor
About: This cocktail was created by Patrick Henaghan at Roka Akor for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add the mint leaves, lemon juice, syrup and bitters to a shaking tin and muddle.

Add the cognac, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a Collins glass.

Fill with crushed ice and top with Champagne.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Victoria D'amato-Moran
About: Chase away the chills and find enlightenment.
Ingred: 1 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
Add the liqueur, whiskey and simple syrup to a coffee mug.

Stir and then add steamed milk.

Finish with a sprinkle of matcha and cocoa powders.

Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

Author: Adam Wilson
About: A cocktail that certainly lives up to its name.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the cranberries and pineapple.  Add the remaining ingredients except the club soda and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a pineapple chunk and/or three cranberries on a toothpick.

Author: Joy Perrine
About: You don’t have to be in Kentucky to enjoy this three-ingredient bourbon cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a large orange twist.

Author: Domaine de Canton
About: Start your next meal with this gingery aperitif.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the tonic to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a tall glass filled with fresh ice.

Fill with tonic and garnish with fresh mint.

Author: Lukas B .Smith
About:
This Rickey by herbalist and cocktail specialist Lukas B. Smith at Washington, D.C.’s Cotton & Reed showcases the rum distillery’s allspice dram. “The lime juice and soda water show off the lighter side of dram,” says Smith.


This recipe originally appeared as part of The Pioneering Return of the All-Important Allspice Dram.
Instructions:
Add the dram and juice to a Collins glass over ice.

Top with the soda water.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Gary Regan
About: Try this sultry cocktail invented at London’s Savoy Hotel.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Linnea Covington
About: Sexy and smooth, this tequila cocktail has a hint of lavender and a dash of sweet honey syrup. It’s spring in a cup, but since the floral flavors come from bitters, you can sip it all year round.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker and dry-shake (without ice).

Add ice and shake again to emulsify thoroughly.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with a lavender sprig.

*Honey syrup: Add .5 cup honey and .5 cup water to a small saucepan over medium heat. (You can experiment and decide how much of a honey flavor you want in your syrup. The more honey you use, the thicker the syrup and stronger in flavor it will be.) Stir until blended. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Will keep for 1 month in the refrigerator.

Author: Norma Beekman
About: No matter how much we fight it, as the weather turns cooler, imbibers turn to pumpkin spiced lattes. But instead of heading to the coffee shop for an overly sweet version, use the slow-cooker recipe by bartender Norma Beekman of Lexington, Ky.â€™s Lockbox
Ingred: 8 oz Dark rum, bourbon or Frangelico (optional)
Instructions:
Serves 10â€"12.

Add the liquor (rum, bourbon or Frangelico, optional), coffee, pumpkin puree, milk, sugar, vanilla extract, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon stick and .5 cup of heavy whipping cream into a slow cooker, and heat on high for at least 90 minutes.

Whip the remaining .5 cup of cream until thick.

Serve the slow-cooker mixture in a mug, top with some of the whipped cream, and garnish with grated cinnamon or nutmeg.

Author: Naren Young
About: With some homemade raspberry syrup and NOLET’S Finest Gin, you can take this classic to the next level.
Garnish: 1 Orange zest from a flamed orange peel
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine strain into a large coupe.

Garnish with zest from a flamed orange peel and a dehydrated orange wheel (a fresh orange wheel can also be used).

Author: Lucid Absinthe
About: Try this fizzy absinthe drink.
Instructions:
Squeeze the orange wedge into a shaker.

Add the absinthe and triple sec, and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and pour (unstrained) into a tall glass.

Top with the lemon-lime soda and garnish with a mint sprig and orange wheel.

Author: Francesco Amodeo
About: This riff on a Boulevardier
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir.

Pour into a rocks glass over ice, and garnish with an orange twist.

About: If you like a good Daiquiri, try this gingery upgrade from New Orleans’ Kingfish.
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into coupe, and garnish with a speared lime peel and cherry.

Author: David Slape
About: Named for the marmalade-loving bear, this drink gets a jolt of fruit flavor from orange preserves.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled coupe glass with absinthe.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: John Freeman
About: You don’t have to be rich to enjoy this plum cocktail.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Martini glass with lavender sugar and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a black plum half-wheel.

Author: Allison Kave
About: Good coffee, great whiskey and a little sweetness turns this Irish Coffee by Allison Kave of Butter & Scotch into something special.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and syrup into an Irish Coffee mug, then fill with the coffee.

Top with freshly whipped cream and a dusting of cocoa powd.

Author: Tim Wells
About: This gin cocktail from Tim Wells of Chicago’s Revival Social Club gets a seriously fruity twist with pomegranate syrup and raspberry liqueur.
Garnish: Lemon slice and fresh basil leaves
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake hard for 10 seconds, and strain into a Double Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon slice and fresh basil leaves.

Author: El Tesoro Tequila
About:
The Tequila Sunrise, with it’s bright striations of color, evokes a summer sunrise. This simple classic has only three ingredients—tequila, grenadine and orange juice—and is served unmixed to preserve the color of each layer.
The Tequila Sunrise was created by Bobby Lozoff and Billy Rice in Sausalito, Calif. The cocktail achieved notoriety after Mick Jagger began drinking it, and The Rolling Stones dubbed their 1972 tour “the cocaine and Tequila Sunrise tour.” The drink has been a part of the cocktail canon ever since.
Ingred: 1.5 oz El Tesoro Reposado Tequila, chilled
Instructions:
Add the tequila and then the orange juice to a chilled highball glass.

Float the grenadine on top and garnish with an orange slice and a cherry.

Author: Absolut Vodka
About: A fruity version of an old classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice.

Stir, and garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Candice Jae
About:
Behind lead bartender Candice Jae, San Francisco’s Mosto boasts more than 200 tequilas, 200 mezcals and even a vegan pechuga mezcal flight. The Sotolero drinks like a Martini made with sotol (Mexico’s desert spoon plant spirit) rather than gin. It’s earthy green notes are highlighted by Lillet blanc apéritif, Salers apéritif and orange bitters.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: April 2018.”
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir for 30 seconds.

Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

Express the oil from the lemon peel over the drink and discard.

Garnish with a dill sprig.

Drink Name: Grey Goose Le Citron Asian Mary
Author: Nick Mautone
About: Spice up this classic with a wasabi-spiked tomato mix.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Grey Goose Le Citron Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a large tumbler filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with shiso or cilantro leaves and a lemon wheel.

Author: Alexis Osborne
About:
Created by bartender Alexis Osborne of Acorn in Denver, this warming drink evokes campfire chats and cold days when you’re snuggled under a blanket with a good book. It’s bright and flavorful with a fruity undertone. The fennel—which is good for bones, treating heart disease and possibly fighting cancer—proves mild and slightly minty but helps give the cocktail body and a slight clarifying aftertaste.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “Everything You Need to Know About the Drinks That Could Save Your Morning.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz 291 Distillery The DECC citrus clove liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into rocks glass over fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon square studded with a whole clove.

*Fennel syrup: Toast 4 oz fennel seeds. Add the fennel seeds, 8 oz sugar and 8 oz water to a pot, and bring to boil. Simmer for 15 minutes and strain. Makes 16 oz.

Author: Dushan Zaric
About: It doesn’t get more elegant than a classic gin Martini.
Ingred: 2 1⁄4 oz No. 3 London Dry Gin, frozen
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Kristina Magro
About: A smoked honey syrup and spicy bitters lend subtle heat to this tequila-based party punch that serves eight to ten people.
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except sparkling wine in a punch bowl with two cups of ice.

Stir to combine and chill.

Top with sparkling wine and apple slices for garnish.

Add large chunks of punch ice to the bowl to keep it cold while minimizing dilution.

Author: Michelle Poteaux
About:
Michelle Poteaux’s aunt brought bundevara, a Croatian pie usually made with pumpkin, to Thanksgiving dinner every year, and she especially loved the slightly crispy, blackened top crust made by mixing bourbon with brown sugar and broiling the top. “With a cocktail tailored after a dessert, you get the flavors without the guilt,” says the owner and executive pastry chef of Alexandria, Va.’s Bastille. “You generally only need a little to satisfy your craving.”
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Right Drink. For Every Bit of the Thanksgiving Meal.”
Ingred: .5 oz Don Ciccio & Figli Mandarinetto liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Pour a splash of Tuaca liqueur into a Nick & Nora glass, swirl to coat, and pour out the remainder.

Add the bourbon, syrup and Don Ciccio & Figli liqueur to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with an orange peel wrapped around a cigarette wafer roll set across the rim of the glass.

*Sweet potato syrup: Add 4 tbsp organic sweet potato puree, 1/2 cup raw sugar, 1/2 tsp nutmeg and 1/4 tsp ground cloves to a bowl, and mix to combine. Stir in 1 cup hot water, whisking continuously until all ingredients are dissolved. Store in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

Author: Erick Castro
About: This red-tinged cocktail by Erick Castro at San Diego’s Polite Provisions
Instructions:
Add the Aperol and syrup to a cocktail shaker with iice and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a chilled flute glass, top with the sparkling wine and stir gently.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

*Rose petal syrup: Add 4 cups hot water to 1 cup rose petals, and steep 30 minutes. Squeeze out excess water from the rose petals, then strain out solids. Add 1 tsp rose water, top off with additional water to make 4 cups, and add equal parts white sugar.

Author: Juan Coronado
About:
Kick your feet up beside this winter-worthy cocktail, a cozy blend of BACARDÍ Ocho eight-year-old rum, cinnamon-star anise syrup and a trio of fresh fruit juices. Be sure to make extra syrup as it’s an easy way to winterize your favorite classic drinks. 
This recipe originally appeared as part of “3 BACARDÍ Cocktails to Keep You Warm This Winter.”
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Cinnamon and star anise syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a pot, and bring to a boil.

Remove from heat, and serve in a coffee mug.

Garnish with 2 apple slices and black pepper.

Author: Tad Carducci
About: Try this unusual frozen spin on the classic Sazerac.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a blender with just under 1 cup of ice.

Blend until smooth and pour into an Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
About: The creamsicle might have begun as a childhood sweet on a stick, but its base flavors can become a very adult beverage: Bright orangecello laced with vanilla beans.
Instructions:
Use a vegetable peeler or zester to remove the peels from all of the oranges, avoiding peeling the bitter white pith. Place the orange peels and vanilla beans in a large jar and cover with alcohol. Allow to steep for one week somewhere dark, like a closet or cabinet.

Strain the infused vodka into a large bowl and discard the orange peels and vanilla beans. Add one cup of simple syrup to the vodka and stir. Taste for sweetness, adding more simple syrup as desired. Use a funnel to bottle the vanilla-orangecello and set aside in a dark area for one more week for the flavor to mellow. Chill thoroughly in the freezer before serving.

Author: John Codd
About: Made with gin, pear puree, lime juice and a hint of absinthe, the Final Judgment is John Codd’s nod to an original recipe from The Savoy Cocktail Book, the first cocktail book he ever touched.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: Take a lesson in suave drinking with this classic Martini recipe.
Ingred: .5 oz Noilly Prat dry vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Martini glass.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Psychedelic marching garb not required.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the apple.

Add the blackcurrants, peppercorns, lime and sugar, and muddle again.

Add the gin and fill with ice.

Shake well and double strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Natasha David
About: The New Orleans classic Sazerac gets a clever upgrade with banana liqueur.
Ingred: .5 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur.5 oz
1 dash The Bitter Truth Old Time Aromatic Bitters
Instructions:
Pour a little absinthe into a chilled rocks glass.

Swirl to coat the inside, discard any excess and set the glass aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into the prepared glass.

Twist a swatch of lemon peel over the drink and discard.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Make the Cuban classic with a carbon-neutral spirit.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the lime and mint.

Add the VeeV and fill with ice.

Shake well and pour (unstrained) into an Old Fashioned glass.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Adam Wilson
About: A tasty mix of ginger vodka, lemon juice and maple syrup.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Luca Zanirato
About: This hot bourbon cocktail is perfect for Hanukkah or any wintertime celebration.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker (do not add ice).

Shake, and strain into a mug or Toddy glass.

Garnish with a lemon wheel and a cinnamon stick.

Author: The Bennett
About: The ideal nightcap for the coffee-inclined, the combination of cold brew and chinato in this cocktail by The Bennett in New York City make for the perfect balance of caffeinated zip and herbal calm.
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain over one rock into a rocks glass, and garnish with a dusting of ground nutmeg.

Author: Cavan
About: A coffee-flecked spin on the classic brunch cocktail the Bourbon Milk Punch, this drink has quickly become a weekend favorite at New Orleans’ Cavan. The chicory liqueur adds an extra special New Orleans flourish.
Instructions:
Pour the bourbon, Caffe Moka and chicory liqueur in a rocks glass filled with ice.

Top with the cream to fill glass.

Stir once, and sprinkle with freshly ground espresso to garnish.

About: This garden-fresh simple syrup recipe will add a hint of tarragon to your favorite cocktails.
Instructions:
Combine the sugar and boiling water.

Stir until the sugar is dissolved.

Add the tarragon leaves and steep in hot simple syrup for 20 minutes.

Strain into a clean jar, cover and refrigerate for up to two weeks.

Author: Leblon Cachaça
About: Try this recipe for an extra summery twist on the classic Caipirinha.
Instructions:
Muddle the pineapple, mint and sugar in a shaker.

Fill the shaker with ice and add Leblon Cachaça.

Shake vigorously.

Serve in a rocks glass.

Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

Author: Kelly Magyarics
About:
Named after the famed female pirate of the Caribbean, Jacquotte Delahaye, this Dark ’N’ Stormy riff adapted from The Bluffton Room at Hilton Head Island in Bluffton, S.C., has Redlock spiced rum from Hilton Head Distillery, a vanilla-forward spirit with tones of allspice and nutmeg.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The 5 Recipe Variations Every Dark ’N’ Stormy Lover Should Know.”
Instructions:
Add the rum, juice and syrup into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice, and stir gently.

Top with the ginger beer.

Garnish with a dill sprig.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Nothing like a little gin to rev your engine.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger ale to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with ginger ale and garnish with a lemon wedge.

Author: Owl's Brew
About: Craving gooey apple crisp? Create the drinkable version with a base of freshly-brewed English breakfast tea laced with lemon peel plus spicy ginger bourbon, apple slices and cinnamon.
Garnish: Fresh apple slices and a cinnamon stick
Instructions:
Combine Owl’s Brew, bourbon, bitters, cinnamon stick and two apple slices in a saucepan and heat until warm, but do not boil.

Pour into a mug and garnish with fresh apple slices and a cinnamon stick.

Author: Amanda Whitt
About: As El-Aurians, Star Trek: The Next Generation’s Guinan and her people are known for their talent as great listeners—just like those people who make nice things for you behind the stick. Inspired by that notion is this sprightly Negroni riff.
Ingred: 2 dashes Bittermens Orchard Street celery shrub
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass along with 1 2-inch-by-1-inch piece of lemon peel, and stir over ice.

Serve over a large piece of ice in a double rocks glass.

If you want an extra spacey touch, garnish with 3 cornflowers, express with an additional lemon peel, and serve.

Author: Somer Perez
About: It’s OK. You can hum “God Save The Queen” to yourself while sipping this cocktail. We won’t tell anyone.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the diced apple and lemon wedges.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Ryan Te
About: Soju and Genepy, the traditional herbal liqueur, meet with Cocchi Americano to produce this earthy yet refreshing cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a glass rinsed with mezcal and absinthe over a large ice cube.

Garnish with an edible flower.

Author: Erin Sullivan
About: You’ve never tasted a root beer float this good.
Ingred: 3 dashes Devil’s Larder Root Beer Bitters
Instructions: Spray a rocks glass with Yellow Chartreuse. Add the Jägermeister and root beer to the rocks glass. Add a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top. Dash the bitters on top of the ice cream. Express an orange peel over top and discard.

Author: Mike Di Tota
About:
The perfect Irish Coffee for a hot day, this light and refreshing cocktail by Mike Di Tota, the head bartender at The Bonnie in New York City, features the right balance of fruitiness and earthiness.

“As we’re moving into warmer weather, we wanted to create a drink that’s more light and refreshing than a traditional Irish Coffee,” says Di Tota. “It does contain actual cold brew, but it’s more focused on pulling out the flavors of coffee through the other ingredients: earthiness and salinity from the Teeling whiskey, fruitiness from the date syrup, smoke from the sea salt and spice from the cardamom. It’s light in body but full of flavor.”
Ingred: .5 oz Zirbenz Stone Pine Liqueur of the Alps.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to shaker and dry-shake (without ice) for 10 seconds.

Add 3 or 4 ice cubes and shake very well.

Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with cinnamon and alderwood-smoked sea salt.

*Spiced date syrup: Add 1 cup water and 1 cup turbinado sugar to a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Add 1 cup date molasses and stir until combined. Add 5 crushed cinnamon sticks and 5 crushed black cardamom pods, and simmer for five minutes. Strain into a jar and seal tightly with a lid. Keeps refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

Author: Katie Stipe
About: Bring some romance to your glass with this easy bubbly cocktail.
Ingred: Crémant d'Alsace rosé sparkling wine, to top
Instructions:
Add the bitters, lemon juice and simple syrup into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Top with the sparkling wine.

Garnish with red rose petals.

Author: Brian MacGregor
About: Spike a classic G&T with lime and bitters to create this simple but delicious concoction.
Instructions:
Add the gin, bitters and lime juice to a tall glass filled with ice.

Top with tonic water and stir briefly.

Author: Jeff Bell
About: This cocktail was created by Jeff Bell at PDT for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy V.S.O.P Privilège.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Rare Tea Cellar Champagne Peach Shrubbery 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a chilled coupe.

Top with the Champagne, and garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Larceny Kentucky Straight Bourbon
About: Don’t worry; you won’t be swindled out of a great night if you have this riff on the traditional Whiskey Sour in hand.
Instructions:
Add bourbon, simple syrup and fresh lemon juice to a Collins glass filled with crushed ice.

Top with bitters and garnish with mint. .

Author: Michael McIlroy
About: As hip as the Brooklyn neighborhood for which it’s named. The Greenpoint is variation on the Brooklyn, which was spawned from a classic Manhattan. Created at NYC’s legendary Milk & Honey, it was named after the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn and the greenish hue of the Chartreuse used to make it.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Tony Conigliaro
About: You’ll be saying “oh gosh” after you taste Tony Conigliaro’s extra-citrusy version of the Daiquiri.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake hard and double-strain into a large, chilled coupette.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Grey Goose Vodka
About: The enduring classic, without the pink hue.
Ingred: 3 oz Grey Goose L'Orange Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a slice of orange peel.

Author: Bobby Daglio
About:
This cocktail by Bobby Daglio, the beverage director at Emily West Village in New York, is a perfect daytime cocktail that goes savory but not treading the weary Bloody Mary route. Here, tequila, lime and cilantro are given tart, green roundness from a house-made fire-roasted tomatillo and jalapeno salsa, shaken and strained in the drink.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “11 Hottest Cocktails to Drink in Bars Now: January 2018.”
Ingred: .5 oz Fire-roasted jalapeño and tomatillo salsa.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Double-strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a cilantro leaf.

*Fire-roasted jalapeño and tomatillo salsa: Over a hot grill, cook 2 tomatillos and 1 jalapeño pepper (seeded and deveined). Roughly chop the peppers along with 1 garlic clove, 1 cilantro sprig and 1/2 Spanish onion. Blend the chopped ingredients in a bowl with 1 pinch sugar and 1 pinch salt to taste.

Author: Naren Young
About: In this cocktail from all-star New York mixologist Naren Young, ZU pairs wonderfully with pear brandy, cider, fresh lemon juice and honey syrup. You’ll crave this delightful drink on boiling hot afternoons.
Ingred: .5 oz Poire Williams Pear Brandy.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients (except the cider) to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

Top with hard apple cider and garnish with an apple fan and fresh grated cinnamon.

Author: Brian Van Flandern
About: If only the precipitation in the United States was this delicious
Instructions:
Add the tequila, sherry, lime juice and simple syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a shot glass.

Dip the orange zest in agave nectar and then in turbinado sugar.

Flame the zest over the glass to release its oils and rub along the rim.

Author: Jake Emen
About: This old timer’s whisky cocktail is shorthand for the Whisky Macdonald, so named for a Colonel Hector MacDonald, who first crafted the drink while serving during the British Raj in India. It’s a simple combination of blended scotch  and Stone’s Original Green Ginger Wine , a fortified wine described on the bottle as a “ginger flavored currant wine” with a 13.5 percent ABV.
Ingred: 1 oz Stone's Original Green Ginger Wine
Instructions: Pour the ingredients over ice into a rocks glass and stir lightly.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: This inspired chocolaty libation is for adults only.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until ice-cold and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a Luxardo Maraschino Cherry.

Author: Aisha Sharpe
About: This easy, fruity and bubbly cocktail will blow you away. It combines the Brazilian sugarcane liquor cachaça with a sweet and tart cherry liqueur. Try the recipe for the Cherry Bomb below.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a lime wheel and a cherry.

Author: Moon Mountain Vodka
About: A couple basil leaves add depth and complexity to a simple, lemony cocktail.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Moon Mountain Coastal Citrus Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel and/or basil sprig.

Author: Amanda Marsteller
Instructions:
Pulse hazelnuts in a food processor until finely ground. Combine the sugar and water in a pot over medium heat and stir until sugar dissolves completely. Boil the syrup for three minutes, then add in the ground hazelnuts. Turn the heat down to low and simmer for another three minutes, then slowly increase the temperature to medium high. Just before it starts to boil, remove it from the heat and cover with a lid.

Allow the covered nut mixture to infuse for at least 3 hours or up to 8 hours. Then, strain it through two layers of cheesecloth, discarding the ground hazelnuts for another use. Stir the orange flower water and brandy into the nutty syrup. Use a small funnel to portion the orgeat into bottles or a jar. Store in refrigerator for up to two weeks.

Author: Vincenzo Errico
About: Honor the hip Brooklyn neighborhood with this version of the Manhattan.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

Author: Brian Tasch
About: This Irish Coffee by Brian Tasch of Dusek’s Board and Beer in Chicago gets an iced makeover, along with some welcome additions and tweaks to the traditional recipes.
Instructions:
Add the whiskey, syrup and liqueur to a stainless steel cup, and fill 3/4 of the way with crushed ice.

Swizzle with a bar spoon, agitate the ice, and top with more crushed ice.

Add the bitters, and garnish with a few macadamia nuts and a mint sprig.

About: This Washington, D.C.–inspired cocktail has just the right amount of smoke and malt.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old scotch
.5 oz Rothman & Winter orchard apricot liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a couple glass, and garnish with star anise.

Author: Toby Maloney
About: Try this fresh spin on the Paloma.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Don Julio blanco tequila 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne.

Author: Kristin Alfandre
About: This spicy Bloody Mary recipe won Absolut’s 2013 America’s Best Bloody award.
Garnish: 1 Cocktail onions, spicy pickled green bean, celery stalk, pickled okra, bacon and beef straw
Instructions:
Dip the rim of a pint glass or Mason jar in Tabasco Chipotle Sauce and coat with sea salt.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake 3 or 4 times and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Garnish with cocktail onions, a spicy pickled green bean, a celery stalk, a pickled okra pod, a crispy strip of bacon and a beef straw.

Author: Eben Freeman
About: Go tropical with this exotic tequila and pomegranate cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into a highball glass.

Add a generous splash of ginger beer.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: An all-organic strawberry-and-mint cocktail.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Tea-Infused Square One Organic Vodka%
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the strawberries and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake for 10 seconds and double strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a strawberry.

Author: Stolichnaya
About: You decide exactly how to season this brunch-time classic.
Instructions:
Add the vodka, tomato juice, lemon juice and horseradish to a Collins glass filled with ice.

Add Worcestershire sauce, hot sauce, salt and pepper to taste.

Stir gently and garnish with celery and olives.

About:
The Scotch & Soda is a simple two-ingredient classic that’s easy to make and delicious to drink. 
In Japan, the Scotch & Soda has given birth to other Highball twists. Due to the simplicity of the cocktail, there are many competing claims about who invented the drink.
Instructions:
Add the Scotch to a highball or rocks glass filled with ice.

Top with soda and stir briefly.

There you have it, the perfect Scotch & Soda.

Author: Karin Stanley
About: You’ll find whisky, spice and everything nice inside this tall glass of Canadian whisky, ginger syrup and Chinese bitters.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker over ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a piece of crystallized ginger.

About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“Fifty years ago, the New Orleans Saints franchise was first announced right here at The Bayou Bar,” says Benton Bourgeois, a bartender at this Pontchartrain hotel bar. “Having been a Saints fan my entire life, one moment stands in my memory above all others: announcer Jim Henderson’s iconic call at the end of the 2010 NFC Championship game. ‘Pigs have flown! Hell has frozen over! The Saints are on their way to the Super Bowl!’ I’ll never forget driving home down St. Charles Avenue after the game, every horn in the city honking, high-fiving the wall of exuberant fans that lined both sides of the street, listening to local radio station WWL replay Jim’s call over and over. This drink is for you, sir.”
Instructions:
Add the bourbon, coffee, simple syrup and ginger brew to a mixing glass.

Open the charcoal tablet carefully, empty it into the glass, discard the capsule, and stir until the charcoal has dissolved, turning the drink black.

Pour the mix into a copper mug filled with ice.

Author: Michael Dietsch
About: This 1970s-era drink, named for the popular film The Godfather, is often made with equal parts, but this version from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, add the ingredients, and stir until chilled.

Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

Author: Joy Wilson
About: Joy Wilson, aka Joy the Baker, has created this perfectly springy and bubbly brunch drink found in her book Over Easy
Instructions:
Serves 8â€"10.

In a large punch bowl, gently stir together the Champagne, orange juice and ginger ale.

Add the orange sherbet in generous scoops. The sherbet will slowly melt into the punch.

Ladle into rocks glasses (which are easier to ladle into than Champagne flutes).

Author: Junior Merino
About: Try talented mixologist Junior Merino’s take on the classic tequila cocktail.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a Margarita or cocktail glass with salt.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a lime wheel.

Author: Julie Reiner
About: Blood orange and Champagne lend delicious elegance to this tequila cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a wine glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with a blood orange wheel.

Author: Oscar Olivares Takahashi
About: It’ll cure what ails you.
Ingred: .5 oz Star Anise-Infused Honey Syrup.5 oz
4 dashes Dr. Adam Elmegirab\'s Aphrodite Bitters
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the gin, lemon juice and rosemary.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a sprig of rosemary.

Author: Jerry Nevins
About: Give your Kentucky Derby party an extra kick with this smashing combination of small-batch Kentucky bourbon
Ingred: 8 3⁄4 oz Woodford Reserve Kentucky straight bourbon
Instructions:
Makes 4.

Add all the ingredients in a medium-size metal bowl and stir.

Pour the liquid into a large freezer bag, and place it in the freezer until frozen for approximately 4 hours.

When ready to drink, massage the freezer bag by hand until it’s a wet, slushy consistency. If it’s not breaking up, run the bag quickly under hot water, and massage some more.

Divide among four Old Fashioned or rocks glasses.

Garnish each glass with mint leaf and lemon wheel.

*Mint simple syrup: Place 1 ½ cups boiling water and 1 ½ cups pure cane sugar in a saucepan over medium heat and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to a simmer and stir the mixture, letting the sweetener dissolve, for about 3 minutes. Add 5 tbsp dried mint, and continue to heat, over medium heat, for an additional 12 minutes. Strain out the mint leaves with a fine-mesh strainer, then let the syrup cool. Place it in a sealed container, and store in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. Makes 2 ¼ cups.

Author: Phil Ward
About: Mix up a whole bunch of this fall-flavored punch for your Halloween party.
Ingred: 2 oz Flor de Caña 7-Year-Old Grand Reserve Rum
Garnish: 1 Apple slices, cinnamon sticks and pumpkin seeds
Instructions:
In a mixing glass, muddle the sugar cubes, cloves and 1 ounce of the soda until the sugar dissolves.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a punch cup.

Top with the remaining 2 ounces of club soda and garnish with apple slices, cinnamon sticks and pumpkin seeds.

(You can also multiply this recipe, stir and strain into a punch bowl. Top each individual portion with club soda when serving).

Author: Flor de Caña Rum
About: Named for a Central American bird, this fruity, tropical sipper was named the national drink of Nicaragua.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well for 20 to 30 seconds.

Strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange slice and a candied cherry.

About: This savory take on the Dark and Stormy has quite a punch—just like its namesake.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Jameson Black Barrel Irish Whiskey
.5 oz Connemara Cask Strength Peated Irish Whiskey.5 oz
3 dashes The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously, and strain into a highball glass containing with one large ice cube.

Top with vanilla soda and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Jamie Boudreau
About: Jamie Boudreau, the proprietor of Seattle’s Canon
Ingred: .5 oz Luxardo Bitter Bianco herbal liqueur.5 oz
Instructions:
Add the gin, apéritif wine, liqueur and syrup into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a bird glass (or coupe), and top with the Champagne.

Garnish with a flower.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: It’s like drinking a bouquet of flowers.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a mint sprig or edible flower.

Author: Ray Quinones, 48 Lounge
About: This cocktail was created by Ray Quinones at 48 Lounge for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Ingred: 3 dashes Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel-Aged bitters
1⁄4 oz Ardbeg Ten Years Old single-malt Scotch whisky 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the cognac, honey-ginger syrup, lemon juice and bitters to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into an Old Fashioned glass over fresh ice.

Top with the whisky, and garnish with the piece of candied ginger on a skewer.

Author: Maker's Mark
About: This delicious bourbon cocktail is what happens when a Manhattan and an Old Fashioned hang out together.
Instructions:
In a cocktail glass, lightly muddle the bitters, lime, lemon and orange.

Remove the fruit remnants and discard.

Add the bourbon and vermouth to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

Run a bar spoon around the inside of the glass to incorporate the bitters and fruit oils.

Garnish with a lightly crushed maraschino cherry.

Author: Jeffrey Morgenthaler
About: Mix up this tequila-and-sparkling-wine sipper and relax on a sunny spring day.
Ingred: .5 oz Rich simple syrup (two parts sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Add the tequila, lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker.

Fill with ice and shake.

Open the shaker and add the sparkling wine, then strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Matt Armato
About:
Sweet and citrusy, this innovative take on the classic Corpse Reviver could most certainly wake the dead. 
For more great Mexican-inspired drinks—and tacos, too!—head right this way.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Cazadores blanco tequila Buy Now 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in cocktail shaker filled with ice.

Shake and double strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Yuri Kato
About: Set sail on this whisky and pomegranate vessel.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Rick Paulger
About: Accentuate the subtle nuances of fine cognac in this boozy classic.
Instructions:
Fill a mixing glass with ice and stir briefly to chill.

With one pull from from the dropper of a 1 oz bitter bottle, carefully coat the inside of a chilled coupe glass with about 1/6 tsp absinthe, allowing the excess absinthe to remain in the bottom of the glass.

Strain excess water from mixing glass, adding fresh ice if needed, then add the cognac, syrup and bitters to the mixing glass.

Stir for 45 full rotations, then strain with a Hawthorne strainer into the prepared coupe.

To prepare the garnish, use a vegetable peeler to create a 2- to 3-inch-long and 1- to 1-1/2-inch-wide peel from a room-temperature lemon.

Express the lemon oils over the drink, paint the rim of the glass with the peel, and touch the stem of the glass once or twice with the peel.

Using a paring knife or kitchen shears, neatly trim the edges of the peel into an isosceles acute triangle, then cut a 1-inch slit in the center of the peel about 1/8 inch from the base of the triangle.

Starting from the tip of the triangle, roll the peel at an angle slightly off axis into a barrel shape.

Affix the rolled peel to the lip of the couple and release, which will cause the peel to unfurl into a swan-like shape.

*Demerara syrup: Combine equal parts demerara sugar and water in a saucepan. Heat and stir until the sugar dissolves. Let cool before using.

Author: Jon Harris, Virgin Hotels
About: This cocktail was created by Jon Harris at Virgin for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Ingred: 2 dashes Dr. Adam Elmegirab’s Teapot bitters
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Dale DeGroff
About: You’ll be claiming Angelo as your own relative after just one sip of this delightful Eggnog recipe.
Ingred: 4 oz Spiced rum (Captain Morgan or Sailor Jerry)
Instructions:
In a large bowl, beat together the egg yolks and half a cup of sugar until they turn light in color.

Stir in the milk, heavy cream, bourbon and rum.

In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites with the remaining quarter-cup of sugar until they form soft peaks.

Fold about a third of the egg whites into the yolk mixture.

Serve in punch or tea cups topped with freshly grated nutmeg, folding in more of the egg whites as desired.

Author: Jason Seele
Ingred: 8 oz Woodford Reserve Double Oaked bourbon
1 dash Bittercube cherry bark vanilla bitters
Garnish: Almond and orange extract aromatic smoke
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, stir and strain into a coupe.

Place the glass on an oak board with an oak barrel behind it.

Author: Ivy Mix
About: A fresh celery and sugar snap pea syrup brightens this tequila-based Highball, complete with an absinthe mist.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Celery and sugar snap pea syrup 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine Don Julio Blanco Tequila, sherry, fresh lemon juice, celery and sugar snap pea syrup into a shaker with ice. Shake well.

Strain contents into a highball glass over ice and top with seltzer. Garnish with mint sprig and absinthe mist.

Author: Maker's Mark
About: Try this Kentucky take on the Cuban classic.
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a tall glass with sugar and set aside.

In a mixing glass, muddle the simple syrup and mint.

Squeeze in the juice from the lime wedges and add the bourbon and triple sec.

Fill with ice and stir.

Pour (unstrained) into the prepared glass and top with the soda.

Garnish with an additional lime wedge.

Author: Bulleit
About: Cool down with this simple and classic whiskey drink.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, lemon, simple syrup and water.

Add the rye and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh crushed ice.

Garnish with a sprig of mint.

Author: Dan Q. Dao
About: Sometimes you want an expertly made and well-balanced cocktail. And sometimes you want some booze and artificial energy. Enter the Vodka Red Bull, once and arguably still quite popular at many city clubs and beyond.
Instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a highball glass over ice and stir.

Author: Moon Mountain Vodka
About: Overload on raspberry flavor with this gingery drink
Ingred: 1.5 oz Moon Mountain Wild Raspberry Flavored Vodka
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the raspberries.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with fresh raspberries and a lime twist.

Author: Jamie Gordon
About: The Gin & Tonic is the quintessential summer cocktail. The classic Gin & Tonic is both incredibly refreshing and easy to make.
Instructions:
Add the gin to a highball glass and fill with fresh ice.

Top with tonic water.

Squeeze the lemon and lime wedges into the drink, drop into the glass and stir.

Author: Andrew Call
About: For this cocktail at Portland Ore.’s Bacchus Bar
Instructions:
Add the gin, syrup, juices and bitters into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled flute.

Top with the chilled prosecco.

*Pineapple syrup: Peel and core 1 whole pineapple, then cut the meat into chunks. Add 1 cup white sugar, toss to coat in a glass bowl and store, covered, in the refrigerator overnight. Combine 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water in a saucepan, simmer until the sugar is dissolved, and remove from the heat. Blend the macerated pineapple in a blender, add the simple syrup, and stir to combine. Strain out solids using a cheesecloth, and store the syrup in the refrigerator.

Author: Toby Maloney
About: A really good tequila can make a really good Martini.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredient to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Jim Meehan
About: Much better than the grindstone.
Ingred: .5 oz Grade B maple syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and shake vigorously without ice for 10 seconds.

Fill with ice and shake for 10 seconds more.

Strain into a highball glass.

About: Try a citrusy take on the legendary cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and stir until well-chilled.

Strain over 1 large ice cube in a rocks glass filled with one large ice cube.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Wayne Curtis
About: This classic hot cocktail goes tropical with a slug of spiced rum.
Instructions:
Add the rum, lemon juice and syrup to a small mug.

Add the hot tea and bitters.

Stir, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
Add all the ingredients to a blender and blend to a uniform puree.

Author: Michael Page, Acanto
About: This cocktail was created by Michael Page at Acanto for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a shaker, and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a snifter, and garnish with a lemon peel.

Author: Skyy Vodka
About: Just because the holidays are technically over it doesn’t mean you can’t drink some Glögg.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a saucepan over medium heat.

Simmer very lightly for at least 30 minutes (do not boil).

Remove and discard the mulling spices.

Serve in mugs, garnishing each with a few raisins and blanched almonds.

Author: David Wondrich
About: Make any day a holiday by fixing a bowl of decadent Tom & Jerry.
Glass: Coffee mug or Tom & Jerry cup
Instructions:
Rinse a small coffee mug (or, indeed, a white ceramic Tom & Jerry cup) with boiling water to warm it and discard the water.

Add the batter, cognac and rum to the cup and fill with hot milk.

Garnish with a mixture of 2 parts freshly grated nutmeg to 1 part each ground clove and ground allspice.

About: Bring elegance to any brunch.
Instructions:
Add the orange juice to a Champagne flute.

Fill with sparkling wine.

About: Warm spices and sweet apricot make this cocktail suitable for any weather (storm or not).
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until properly diluted.

Strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with expressed citrus oils from an orange peel.

About: It’s a very simple drink on all fronts, yet very complexand some might say that’s the beauty of it.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Stir then strain into the glass.

Drink Name: Bacardí El Espresso de San Juan
Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Coffee-based rum cocktails are perfect for warming you up. This recipe was created for the coldest winters, using hot coffee, spicy Mayan chocolate, rum and a kick of chili.
Ingred: 3⁄4 parts Fine white sugar (caster sugar) 3⁄4 parts
Instructions:
Heat all the ingredients in a saucepan, and stir until the mixture boils. Let cool for 3-5 minutes before pouring into a cup or mug.

Garnish with coffee beans, chocolate shavings and 1 pinch of chili flakes.

Author: Erik Adkins
About: A slightly spicier version of the classic Presbyterian, this bourbon drink has a real ginger kick.
Instructions:
Fill a Collins glass with ice, add the club soda and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake briefly and double-strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a piece of candied ginger.

Author: Brian Lamberti
About: All the chocolate and rum craziness you can handle.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the whipped cream to a small saucepan and simmer over low to medium heat until hot.

Strain into a mug and top with whipped cream.

Garnish with grated pistachio.

About: Warm cinnamon syrup adds heat to this sweet-bitter cognac cocktail.
Ingred: .5 oz Luxardo bitter bianco vermouth.5 oz
3⁄4 oz Fresh red grapefruit juice 3⁄4 oz
Lemon Hart 151 demarara rum, to top
Instructions:
Combine the mint leaves, cinnamon simple syrup and absinthe in the bottom of a Collins glass and gently press the mint.

Add the remaining ingredients, fill the glass with crushed ice, and swizzle to combine.

Top off the cocktail with crushed ice, and garnish with a mint sprig and a wide grapefruit peel.

*Cinnamon simple syrup: Bring 2 cups water, 2 cups sugar and 6 crushed cinnamon sticks to a boil in a small saucepan. Reduce the heat, and simmer 10 minutes. Strain and cool.

Author: John Codd
About: Red wine gets a boost from raspberry brandy in this eau-de-vie cocktail from John Codd of San Francisco’s Tradition.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Small Hand Foods gum syrup 1⁄4 oz
1⁄4 oz Small Hand Foods grenadine 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except the Champagne water into mixing tin with ice, and shake briefly.

Strain into a Collins glass over ice, and top with the sparkling wine.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: This drink’s herb flavor is perfect for an autumn cocktail party.
Ingred: .5 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water).5 oz
Instructions:
Tear the sage leaves to release their oils and drop them into a shaker.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with a sage leaf.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: An orange twist on the classic fruity wine concoction.
Ingred: 1 cup Seedless red or black grapes
2 Apples, red and green, cored and cut into .5 inch wedges
Instructions:
Combine all the ingredients except the orange juice and wine in a punch bowl and let stand at least 1 hour.

Stir the orange juice and wine, and serve in ice-filled punch cups or wine glasses.

Author: Jillian Vose
About: White cacao and banana liqueur balance the dry, bitter duo of cocoa nibs and Campari in this elegant Irish whiskey cocktail from The Dead Rabbit.
Ingred: .5 oz White Cacao Marie Brizard.5 oz
.5 oz Giffard Banane du Brésil.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Nick & Nora glass.

About: Apple vodka gives the wine punch an autumnal feel.
Ingred: 2 2⁄3 oz Van Gogh Wild Appel Vodka
Instructions:
Combine the Van Gogh Wild Appel Vodka, orange liqueur, white wine and pineapple juice in a large pitcher.

Mix in the sugar until it's completely dissolved.

Add in all the fresh fruit and put the pitcher into the refrigerator for at least an hour.

Serve over ice.

Author: Kaitlyn Goalen
About: The hangover-smashing Black Magic cocktail combines beet juice with activated charcoal—the latest detox trend that claims to help dispel unwanted toxins. Don’t be turned off by the jet-black hue, the charcoal itself is tasteless.
Ingred: 1 oz Honey syrup (one part honey, one part water)
Instructions:
In a small bowl, break apart the charcoal capsules and discard the outer layer.

Whisk together the charcoal and honey syrup until combined (it will be jet black in color).

In a shaker, combine the charcoal-honey syrup with the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Author: Nic Christiansen
About: “I enjoy using grapefruit in a shrub because it allows the brightness and flavor of the grapefruit to come through and cuts down on the typical tartness of the grapefruit,” says Nic Christiansen, the beverage director at Lola. “Allowing the acid from the apple cider vinegar and the sugar to lift the grapefruit flavor [creates] a more complex grapefruit flavor.” Locally produced Copper & Kings Absinthe Superior
Instructions:
Add the aperol shrub and absinthe into a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled flute, and top with the chilled cava.

Garnish with an orange twist.

*Grapefruit shrub: Combine 2 cups sugar, 2 ½ cups grapefruit juice, 1 cup apple cider, a pinch of salt and the zest of the juiced grapefruits in a saucepan.
