Simmer ingredients over medium heat, stirring for about 20 minutes. Remove from the heat, strain out solids, let cool, and store in the refrigerator.

Author: Rob Giles
About: This cocktail by Rob Giles, the beverage director at Until Tomorrow in New York City, would still be a soothing and subtle Irish Coffee without it, but it’s not truly finished until you’ve added the whipped cream.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the cream to a shaker and dry-shake.

Add the vanilla-tahini whipped cream to top.

*Vanilla-tahini whipped cream: Add 1 barspoon of Giffard Vanille de Madagascar liqueur and 1 barspoon of tahini paste to 2 oz heavy whipping cream to a shaker, and shake for 30 seconds.

Author: Jonathan Pogash
About: Entertaining a crowd? This port-based punch will happily serve a group of 20.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a punch bowl with ice and stir well.

Garnish with sliced apples and lemons.

Author: Jay Zimmerman
About: You’ll enjoy the classic Gin & Tonic on a hot day, a cold day or really any day at all.
Instructions:
Fill a double rocks glass with ice.

Add the gin and fill with tonic.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Bols Genever
About: There’s nothing odorless or tasteless about this cocktail.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz White crème de cacao 1⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a Bols Genever-soaked cherry speared on a toothpick.

Author: Tim Laird
About: A little sour, a little sweet, a little fizzy and a lot of tequila.
Garnish: 1 Grapefruit wedge, lime wedge and mint sprig
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the grapefruit, lime and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with a grapefruit wedge, lime wedge and mint sprig.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: Our classic Caipirinha recipe instantly transports you to a beach in Rio.
Instructions:
To make a Caipirinha first, in a double Old Fashioned glass, muddle the sugar and lime.

Fill with ice and add the cachaça.

Stir briefly and garnish with a lime wheel if desired.

Author: Yuri Kato
About: The Land of the Rising Sun transforms this cognac classic.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Author: Kim Stodel
About: This drink by Kim Stodel of Providence
Ingred: .5 oz Pierre Ferrand dry curaçao.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with guava fruit leather (or piece of guava paste).

*Guava syrup: Slice 1 1/4 cup guava and macerate with 1 1/4 cup sugar and 3/4 cup water, mixing occasionally until the sugar is dissolved. Refrigerate the mixture until ready to strain. (Ideally, this can be done 1 day in advance and left overnight in the fridge.) Strain the syrup from the pulp, keeping the pulp for garnish if you wish.

**Guava fruit leather: Take the discarded guava pulp, and mix in a blender until smooth. Pour mixture through a large sieve and spread over a piece of parchment paper to make an even. Place sheet in an oven set at 135 degrees F for about 6 hours, checking periodically to prevent overdrying. Remove and cut into 1 x 2 inch slices.

Author: Baileys
About: Chill out with this simple, rich and fruity drink.
Instructions:
In a rocks glass, muddle the raspberries.

Add the Baileys and fill with crushed ice.

Garnish with 3 speared raspberries.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: The subtle botanicals in gin pair well with the fruit juices in this easy-to-make tipple.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a highball glass filled with ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: St. John Frizell
About:
Listed under the “Hot Helpers” category on the drinks menu at Fort Defiance in Brooklyn’s Red Hook neighborhood, this Irish Coffee by owner St. John Frizell was once dubbed “the best in the known world” by The New York Times.

This recipe originally appeared as part of “The Irish Coffee: 3 Delicious Ways to Reconsider the Famed Cocktail.”
Instructions:
Add the whiskey and simple syrup into a mixing tin.

Add a little boiling water to an Irish Coffee mug to heat it, and nestle the tin in the mug so that the tin heats as well.

Add the heavy cream to a separate mixing tin, and dry-shake (without ice) until the cream thickens.

Dump the water out of the mug, add the whiskey-sugar mixture, and fill with boiling water to about 1 inch below the rim.

Pour the espresso shot followed by the thickened cream on top, and grate cinnamon.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: It only takes one ingredient to make this classic a perfect ten. Tanqueray No. Ten is distilled with whole citrus instead of dried citrus peel, and includes grapefruit, orange and lime, along with juniper, coriander and a hint of chamomile. Don’t forget the perfect garnish to match: a grapefruit twist.
Instructions:
Add the gin to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish with a wide grapefruit twist.

Author: Charlotte Voisey
About: Whiskey and spiced rum spike this fresh-fruit punch.
Ingred: 12 oz Simple syrup (one part sugar, one part water)
Instructions:
In a small bowl, muddle the figs well and add the simple syrup.

Place a large block of ice in a punch bowl and add the fig mixture and the remaining ingredients.

Garnish with thinly cut lime wheels and freshly grated nutmeg.

Author: Aaron Ranf
About: This cocktail by Aaron Ranf of Santa Monica’s Rustic Canyon
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a Champagne flute.

Top off with prosecco.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

*Rose-geranium-infused beet juice: Slowly heat 1 qt beet juice, 1 cup sugar and 1 to 1 ½ cups dried rose geranium slowly in saucepan on low heat. Simmer for 10 minutes so the sugar is dissolved and the geranium can steep. Let cool and strain.

Author: Jonathan Howard
Ingred: 1.5 oz Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select bourbon
Instructions:
Grab a Lewis bag, and crack several pieces of large-format ice.

In a mixing glass, add the absinthe followed by the bitters, vermouth and bourbon.

Add the cracked ice and stir.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Patrón Tequila
About: What do you get when you mix tequila and espresso? One hell of a cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Patrón XO Café Liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a cocktail glass with sugar.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with powdered chocolate.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: Neil Diamond would surely approve of this gin, grape and mint cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Mint leaf and a grape cluster
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the grapes.

Add the remaining ingredients except the club soda and fill with ice.

Shake well and double strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mint leaf and a grape cluster.

Author: Philip Pepperdine
About: It’s strong, suave and sophisticated.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients, except the Champagne, to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into a chilled coupe or Martini glass.

Float the Champagne on top and garnish with a lime twist.

Author: Jerry Nevins
About: Lemon and lime start things up, with the herbal notes of fernet bringing up the rear, in this cocktail by Jerry Nevins from his book, Sloshies: 102 Boozy Cocktails Straight from the Freezer
Ingred: 3⁄4 tsp Fee Brothers lemon bitters 3⁄4 tsp
Instructions:
Makes 4.

Add all the ingredients in a medium-size metal bowl and stir.

Pour the liquid into a large freezer bag, and place it in the freezer until frozen for approximately 4 hours.

When ready to drink, massage the freezer bag by hand until it’s a wet, slushy consistency. If it’s not breaking up, run the bag quickly under hot water and massage some more.

Divide among four coupe glasses.

Author: Tony Abou-Ganim
About: The Canadian answer to the Bloody Mary
Ingred: .5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice, and roll the contents between mixing glass and a shaker tin until well-blended.

Rim the lip of a double Old Fashioned glass with lime, and dip it into a mixture of the pepper and salt.

Strain into a prepared ice-filled double Old Fashioned glass, and garnish with a carrot sliced lengthwise.

Author: Jamie Boudreau
About: Mix up a big bowl of this morally ambiguous punch.
Ingred: 3 oz Fat Bastard Pinot Noir Wine
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients and a large block of ice to a punch bowl.

Garnish with blood orange slices.

Author: Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey
About: Despite his tough reputation, Jack actually plays quite well with others.
Ingred: .5 oz Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur.5 oz
1 oz Sweetened lime juice (such as Rose’s)
Instructions:
Add the Jack Daniel's, Domaine de Canton and lime juice to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a tall glass.

Top with a splash of tonic water, stir briefly and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Tanqueray Gin
About: Refresh yourself with this fizzy gin tipple.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the mint, lime juice and simple syrup.

Add the gin and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with crushed ice.

Stir until frost appears on the outside of the glass.

Fill with club soda and garnish with another mint sprig.

Author: José Andrés
About: Despite its chilly temperature, this brandy cocktail offers warming notes of spice-infused vermouth, maple syrup and cardamom.
Ingred: .5 oz House-made syphoned blanc vermouth.5 oz
Instructions:
Add Concord grapes to a shaker and muddle.

Add remaining ingredients to the shaker with a small amount of crushed ice and whip shake.

Pour into a Julep glass and top with crushed ice.

Garnish with grated cinnamon and nutmeg, cinnamon stick, lavender and frozen Concord grapes.

Author: Joe Heron
Instructions:
In a chilled rocks glass, muddle the sugar, bitters, orange wedge and cherry into a thick paste, being careful not to work the orange peel.

Add brandy, stir and fill the glass with ice.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
Flaky grilled salmon only needs a simple mango salsa to tie it together into a perfect taco. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: Corn tortillas, warmed in the oven or grilled
Sour cream and lime wedges for serving
1 very ripe mango, peeled and diced (about ¾ cup)
1⁄3 cup lightly packed chopped cilantro 1⁄3 cup
Instructions:
Serves 6.

Combine the smoked paprika, cumin, chili powder, and a generous pinch of both salt and pepper in a small bowl. Lightly rub the spice mixture into the salmon filets on both sides to evenly coat.

Bring a grill or grill pan to high heat and brush with oil. Grill the salmon fillets for about four minutes on each side, aiming to get the center of the filets to medium rare. Transfer the salmon filets to a cutting board or plate. Use a spatula or fork to gently break the salmon into flaky pieces.

*Mango salsa: Combine 3/4 cup very ripe mango (peeled and diced), 1/3 cup lightly packed cilantro, 1 tbsp minced shallot, 1 tbsp minced jalapeño and 1/2 tbsp lime juice in a small mixing bowl.

Assemble tacos starting with the salmon, followed by the salsa, sour cream and a squeeze of lime.

Author: Somer Perez
About: Get away from it all with this fruity cocktail.
Garnish: 1 Mint leaf and a sliced grape
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the kiwi, grapes and mint.

Add the remaining ingredients, fill with ice and shake.

Strain into a Martini glass and garnish with a mint leaf and a sliced grape.

Author: Steve Schneider
About: This cocktail by Steve Schneider appears on the inaugural menu of Panama City’s The Strangers Club in honor of Panama’s national animal.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with a few large ice cubes and shake vigorously.

Strain in a chilled cocktail glass, and add a few drops of Angostura bitters.

*Falernum (by Bratislav Glisic):.

Place 1 1/2 cups peeled almonds into a glass jar. Add 1 quart filtered water and rinse. Discard the water and add another 1 quart filtered water. Leave the almonds in the jar for 4 hours, shaking them occasionally.

In a large pan, combine 3 tbsp allspice, 1 tbsp whole cloves and 4 star anise over medium heat, tossing for 1 minute. Then add the water and almonds from the jar to the pan, along with 2 quarts white sugar and 1/2 cup peeled and cut ginger, stirring continuously. When the mixture is about to boil, reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes, stirring frequently. Remove from heat and let the mixture to cool down, add the zest of 1 lime and stir. Pour the mixture back into jar and place in the refrigerator overnight.

The following day, strain the mixture over cheesecloth. In a fresh jar, combine the syrup and overproof rum: For every 5 oz syrup, add 1 oz overproof rum. Stir well and store up to 2 weeks.

Author: Liquor.com Staff
About: Actress Mary Pickford was known as America’s Sweetheart in the 1920s, when she landed in Cuba to shoot a film with husband Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin. As the story goes, Fred Kaufman, one of the many American bartenders who relocated to the island during Prohibition, dreamed up this BACARDÍ® rum-based concoction special for the silent-film star. Some recipes call for prepackaged juice only, but according to Basil Woon’s 1928 book, “When It’s Cocktail Time in Cuba,” it’s not a Mary Pickford without the addition of freshly squeezed pineapple juice. We tend to agree.
Instructions:
In a cocktail shaker, gently muddle the pineapple chunks.

Add the remaining ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.

Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a preserved cherry.

Author: Nate Dobson
About:
BlackTail, the Lower Manhattan retro Cuban bar from the team behind The Dead Rabbit, is known to modernize classics like the Rum & Coke. For its contemporary riff on the Dark ’N’ Stormy, bartender Nate Dobson added passion fruit, bitters and a blend of funky Jamaican spirits to the usual ginger and rum base.
This recipe originally appeared as part of “The 5 Recipe Variations Every Dark ’N’ Stormy Lover Should Know.”
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Wray & Nephew overproof rum 1⁄4 oz
Blenheim ginger ale, to top Blenheim ginger ale, to top
Instructions:
Pour the rum, rum blend, juice, puree and bitters into a Collins glass over ice.

Top with the ginger ale.

*DR rum blend: Combine 4 parts Bacardí Superior Heritage Limited Edition rum, 3 parts Caña Brava rum, 2 parts Barbancourt white rhum agricole and 1 part Banks 5 Island rum.

Author: Alex Day
About: Surprisingly, the vibrant white wine pairs nicely with bitter Aperol.
Ingred: 3 oz New Zealand sauvignon blanc wine
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with soda.

Author: Mike Steel
About: Tawny port and cognac are a match made in after-dinner heaven in this simple cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

Garnish with fresh grated nutmeg.

Author: Jordan Mackay
About: Our take on the lemon juice and maple syrup detox craze has a special spirited twist.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into 2 small tumblers or 2 large shot glasses.

Author: Dan Warner
About: This gin-and-Champagne cocktail is the perfect aperitif.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a wine glass and fill with ice.

Stir until cold.

Top with Champagne and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: This simple classic cocktail is the best way to improve a flute of bubbly.
Instructions:
Place the sugar cube on a spoon and douse with bitters.

Drop into a Champagne flute and fill with Champagne.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

Author: Beau Ciolino
About:
A little Cuban, these effortless beef tacos are modeled after the famed dish ropa vieja. 
Need a drink to go with those tacos? Try one of these great tequila drinks.
Ingred: 1 each yellow, red, and green bell pepper, seeded and thinly sliced
1⁄4 cup dry sherry or white wine 1⁄4 cup
.5 cup pitted green olives, halved.5 cup
Cotija or feta cheese for serving
Corn tortillas, warmed in the oven or grilled
Instructions:
Salt and pepper the chuck roast on all sides. Bring one tablespoon oil to almost smoking over medium-high heat in a Dutch oven or similarly sized heavy bottomed pot. Brown the roast on all four sides, about 3 minutes per side, and transfer to a plate.

Add the remaining oil to the pot, along with the bell peppers, onion, jalapeño and a pinch of salt. Cook over medium heat until the onions are translucent and it’s all just begun to caramelize, about 10 minutes. Add garlic, cumin, oregano, paprika and cloves and cook for another minute.

Add sherry and give a good stir, getting any crispy bits off the bottom of the pan. Add the diced tomatoes and the bay leaves and return the roast to the Dutch oven and the stovetop, reduce the heat to low and cover. Cook for 3 to 4 hours, until the roast has become tender and is easily broken up with a fork.

Remove the bay leaves from the pot. Shred the meat using two forks and add the olives, capers, and two tablespoons cilantro. Let simmer over medium heat for ten minutes before serving.

Assemble your tacos with a heaping spoonful of the shredded beef, followed by cotija, cilantro, and lime.

Author: Sother Teague
About: This Toddy recipe from New York bitters powerhouse Amor y Amargo
Instructions:
Brew the tea and pour it into a mug.

Add the rum and falernum, stir, then swirl in the butternut squash butter, steaming with a frothing wand if desired.

Add maple syrup to taste.

*Butternut squash butter: In a small mixing bowl, combine  2.5 oz of squash purée, 2.5 oz of room-temperature unsalted butter, .5 tsp of ground cinnamon, .5 tsp of ground nutmeg, .5 tsp of allspice, a pinch of ground cloves, .75 oz of dark brown sugar, .5 tsp of maple syrup and a pinch of salt; mix until smooth. Roll into a log in parchment or wax paper, and store in the refrigerator.

Author: Martin Cate
About:
The Mai Tai is perhaps the most famous Tiki cocktail for a good reason. Trader Vic’s is credited with inventing the drink, and the first person to try it was said to cry out “Mai Tai!” which means “the best—out of this world” in Tahitian. The Mai Tai took a star turn by earning a prominent role in the Elvis film Blue Hawaii.
The Mai Tai was created as a way to showcase the flavors of good-quality rum. It should never be neon-colored or overly sweet. A proper Mai Tai is a deep amber hue and allows the rum to shine through with the other ingredients. While some Mai Tai variants call for pineapple juice, this recipe omits it in favor of the more classic recipe favored by Martin Cate’s award-winning Tiki bar Smuggler’s Cove’s.
Ingred: 1⁄4 oz Rock candy syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part water) 1⁄4 oz
2 oz Premium aged rum (Appleton Estate 12-Year-Old, El Dorado 12- Year-Old)
Garnish: 1 Lime rind and fresh mint sprig
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with crushed ice.

Shake vigorously until the shaker is well-chilled and frosty on the outside.

Pour (unstrained) into a double Old Fashioned glass.

Garnish with half of a juiced lime and a fresh mint sprig.

Author: Liquor.com
About: A simple mixture of rum, citrus, sugar and spice, the Planter’s Punch has been gracing cocktail books and bar menus for well over a century.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously.

Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.

Top with a splash of soda water.

Garnish with a mint sprig.

Author: Purely Syrup
About: Vanilla bean, maple and bourbon compliment each other in this heart-warming concoction.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Purely Syrup Vanilla Bean 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake for approximately 12 seconds.

Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass and garnish with vanilla bean.

Author: Claire Smith
About: Celebrate a romantic night in with this festive sparkling drink recipe.
Instructions:
Add the vodka and peach puree into a shaker and fill with ice, and shake until chilled.

Strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

Top with Champagne.

Author: Van Gogh Vodka
About: Candy in a glass. Err, on a glass, with a real Peppermint Pattie as garnish.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Van Gogh Dutch Chocolate Vodka
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously and strain the mixture into a chilled Martini glass.

Garnish it with a Peppermint Pattie.

Author: Dylan Holcomb
About: Those who can’t resist a smoky cocktail or order the first drink on the menu promising a garnish of cured meat should stir up this four-ingredient bacon-flavored bourbon drink, by Dylan Holcomb of Denver’s Beatrice & Woodsley and Mario’s Double Daughter’s Salotto, served on some seriously meaty rocks.
Ingred: Osso Good bison bone broth ice cubes Osso Good bison bone broth ice cubes
Instructions:
Add all ingredients into a mixing glass.

Add the broth ice cubes, and stir approximately 30 times.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a baby back rib bone.

*Osso Good bison bone broth ice cubes: Combine the broth with equal parts water, chill in the refrigerator for 12 hours, skim off the fat layer that floats to the top, and place into large ice cube trays to freeze.

Author: Rael Petit
About: You don’t have to be vegan to appreciate this dairy-free spin on the Pisco Sour. The innovative use of aquafaba is enough to make it a can’t-miss cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a shaker, dry-shake and then hard-shake with ice.

Strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with ground cloves and a vegan chocolate marshmallow.

Author: VEEV Spirit
About: Go heavy on the antioxidants.
Ingred: VeeV Açaí Spirit VeeV Açaí Spirit
Instructions:
Fill a pitcher three-quarters of the way with ice.

Add all the ingredients and stir well.

Garnish with lime wheels.

Author: Theo Lieberman
About: Love apples? Try the Apple Business, an autumnal gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an apple slice.

Author: Jaime Salas
About: Put some chile fire in your Old Fashioned.
Ingred: 1 oz Ancho Reyes ancho chile liqueur
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir, and strain into a double Old Fashioned glass filled with one large ice block.

Cut long swatches of orange and lemon peels with a vegetable peeler.

Twist both over the drink, rub along the rim of the glass and roll together into a rosette to use as garnish.

Author: Beefeater Gin
About: Beefeater’s special Summer Edition Gin packs a heavy dose of floral flavor.
Instructions:
Add both ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.

Stir until well chilled and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a blackberry and a raspberry on a toothpick.

Author: Nazarene Garcia, Hudson Bar & Books
About: This cocktail was created by Nazarene Garcia at Hudson Bar & Books for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Instructions:
Rinse a chilled snifter glass with the whisky, discarding any excess, and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake and strain into the prepared glass over fresh cracked ice.

Garnish with an orange peel.

Drink Name: Tippy Cow Halloween Layered Shooters: Candy Corn
Instructions:
Layering trick: Pour first flavor into shot glass.

Shake second flavor vigorously for 10 seconds with ice then pour over spoon into glass.

Author: Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas
About: This rich drink should both revive you and settle your stomach after a big holiday meal.
Ingred: 1 3⁄4 oz Cinzano Bianco Vermouth (may substitute 1.5 oz of a different Italian dry vermouth)
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass.

Add large ice cubes and stir for 40 revolutions.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Garnish with the top of a mint stalk.

Author: Naren Young
About: This refreshing cocktail is low in alcohol and high in flavor.
Instructions:
Add all ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a stemmed cobbler glass filled with crushed ice.

Garnish with mixed berries, a mint sprig and powdered sugar.

Author: Jason Littrell
About: With orange juice, orange zest and orange liqueur, the vitamin C in this drink will last you for weeks. Not that you’ll want to wait that long to have another.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe or a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

Garnish with an orange twist.

Stir together bourbon, Cointreau and bitters in an ice-filled mixing glass.

Strain into a chilled CHampagne flute.

Top with cold champagne or sparkling wine, and garnish with twist.
Theme: Fall Holiday Season Romantic Spring Summer Winter

About: Mezcal
Ingred: .5 oz Tempus Fugit Alessio vermouth bianco.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly Squeezed Lime Juice.5 oz
.5 oz Freshly squeezed lemon juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Fine-strain into a coupe wrapped in a piece of a brown bag held together with a spear, and garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Jackson Cannon
About: This elegant, bubbly rum cocktail is good for the beach or the ballroom.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the Champagne to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

Top with the Champagne and garnish with an orange twist.

Author: Don Q Rum
About: Cupid would approve of this rum, fruit and basil recipe.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 5 seconds and strain into a chilled coupe glass.

Garnish with a basil leaf.

Author: Baileys
About: Enjoy a little crunch with the smooth taste of Baileys.
Ingred: 1.5 oz Baileys with a Hint of Caramel
Instructions:
Mix equal parts honey and warm water in a small bowl and stir until dissolved.

Place crushed almonds onto a small plate.

Dip the rim of a Martini glass into the honey water and then into the crushed almonds and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into the prepared glass.

About:
Irish Coffee may not be the first coffee drink with alcohol, but it has become one of the most famous. Combining coffee with Irish whiskey, brown sugar and lightly whipped cream, Irish Coffee is a hot, creamy classic. 
There are many tall tales about the Irish Coffee’s origins. The most credible version attributes the cocktail to Joe Sheridan, the head chef of the restaurant at the Foynes Flying Boat terminal in County Limerick in the early 1940s. Legend has it that when he first served it and was asked if it was Brazilian coffee, Sheridan cheekily replied that it was “Irish coffee.” 
The drink was later made famous by Staton Deplante, who worked at the
Buena Vista Cafe in San Francisco during the 1950s. Deplante wrote about the drink frequently in a travel column that was read widely across the States and piqued curiosity about Irish Coffee. 
Our version of the Irish Coffee is created by legendary bartender Dale DeGroff and has all of the right ingredients to warm you to the bone.
Ingred: 1 oz Brown sugar syrup (1:1 brown sugar to water, heated until dissolved)
Instructions:
Filling an Irish Coffee mug with hot water, let sit for 2 minutes, then discard the water.

Add the whiskey and syrup to the mug, and fill with the coffee.

Top with an inch of unsweetened lightly whipped cream.

Author: John Coltharp
About:
For football season, we had a bartender from each NFL team’s hometown provide the perfect cocktail to represent their team.
“The D line and the linebackers are the strongest group in the Ram’s current lineup,” says John Coltharp, the head bartender at Los Angeles’ Seven Grand. “This stiff cocktail is a tribute to those seven players; it also features the earthy flavors the Rams want the opposing running back to experience when they shove his face into the ground.”
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold.

Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

Express the oil from a lemon peel over top of the drink and garnish with the peel on the ice, skin up.

Author: Chopin Vodka
About: Get into an autumn mood.
Instructions:
In a shaker, muddle the pear and cardamom.

Add the remaining ingredients and fill with ice.

Shake, and double strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a pear fan.

Author: Nick Mautone
About: Island flair meets cocktail tradition.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the club soda to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well until the outside of the shaker is frosty and beaded with sweat.

Strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with club soda and garnish with a mango slice.

Author: H. Joseph Ehrmann
About: You can drink this blueberry cocktail in the city, too.
Instructions:
Place the thyme sprig in the palm of your hand and slap it to release its oils.

Twist it and place in the bottom of a 10-ounce highball or Old Fashioned glass.

Fill with ice and set aside.

In a shaker, muddle the blueberries and lemon. (If blueberries are out of season, use 2 teaspoons of high-quality blueberry preserves instead.

You'll have to adjust the amount of agave nectar depending on the sweetness of the preserves.) Add the vodka and agave nectar, and fill with ice.

Shake vigorously for 10 to 20 seconds and strain into the prepared glass.

Take a nice large, pretty sprig of thyme and slap it before using to garnish the drink.

About: This scotch drink at Edinburgh’s Bramble Bar
Instructions:
Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, express the oil of a lemon peel, and discard the peel.

Author: Angie O’Neil, Binny’s
About: This cocktail was created by Angie O’Neil at Binny’s for Cognac Classics Week, presented by Liquor.com and Hennessy VSOP Privilège.
Ingred: .5 oz Jo Snow tangerine lavender honey syrup.5 oz
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass, and fill with ice.

Stir and strain into a rocks glass with 1 fresh ice cube.

Garnish with the orange peel.

Author: Michael Waterhouse
About: The perfect summer cocktail.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake well and strain into a Martini glass.

Garnish with a strawberry.

About: This classic cooler can be made with vodka or gin and is perfect for a warm sunny day.
Instructions:
Rim a highball glass with salt.

Shake the vodka (or gin) and grapefruit juice, pour over ice in a highball glass.

Garnish with a grapefruit slice.

Author: Jeff "Beachbum" Berry
About: The Tiki mug is optional but come on, you know you want one.
Ingred: 1 1⁄4 oz Demerara rum (El Dorado or Lemon Hart)
Glass: Tiki mug or double Old Fashioned
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with crushed ice.

Shake, and pour (unstrained) into a Tiki mug or a double Old Fashioned glass.

Author: Mike Di Tota
About: Concord grape puree and a homemade basil syrup complete this fizzy gin cocktail.
Instructions:
Add the gin, grape puree, basil syrup and lime juice to a shaker filled with ice.

Shake, and pour into an Old Fashioned glass.

Top with club soda and garnish with Concord grapes and basil leaves.

Author: Benjamin Schiller
About: At The Sixth
Ingred: 2 oz El Dorado five-year-old gold rum
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients into a Highball glass or Tiki mug with crushed ice and swizzle.

Top with more crushed ice.

Garnish with a mint sprig and 2 twisty straws.

*Han’s mix: Combine 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, 3 cinnamon sticks, a few fresh grates of nutmeg and 3 and star anise in a small pot over medium heat. Simmer for 10 to 15 minutes. Allow to cool. Add 2 cups fresh orange juice, strain and store in a sealed glass container up to 1 week.

**Ginger syrup: Peel and juice 1 part ginger, and allow the juice to sit, preferably overnight. Gently pour the ginger juice into a new container, while leaving the sediment behind, and strain the remaining juice through a fine-mesh sieve. Measure the remaining juice and add an equal amount of granulated sugar by volume. Heat the mixture over medium heat, stirring until all the sugar is dissolved.

Author: Naren Young
About: Pear puree and pear liqueur add a double dose of fall flavor to this bubbly highball.
Garnish: Thin slice of pear and grated cinnamon
Instructions:
Add all ingredients except club soda to a shaker with ice.

Shake, and strain over fresh ice.

Top with club soda and stir.

Garnish with a slice of pear and grated cinnamon.

Author: Grand Marnier
About: Try this orange-liqueur spin on the classic Dark & Stormy.
Instructions:
Add all the ingredients except the ginger beer to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice.

Top with the ginger beer and swirl.

Garnish with a lime wedge.

Author: Kara Newman
About: Give this easy-drinking, low-alcohol sipper a spin. Made with equal parts sherry and vermouth, it pairs beautifully with tapas and other savory bites.
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.

Pour into a coupe glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

Author: Jacques Bezuidenhout
About: The Negroni is a classic Italian drink. Order a Negroni and you’ll be sure to Impress your bartender.
Ingred: 1 oz Sweet vermouth (Martini & Rossi Rosso or Cinzano Rosso)
Instructions:
Add all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and fill with ice.

Stir until cold, and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

Author: Ben Davidson
About: Blood orange juice and Campari transform the classic Margarita cocktail.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Combier triple sec orange liqueur 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Coat the rim of a rocks glass with salt, fill with ice and set aside.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with fresh ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with a blood orange slice.

Author: Robert Krueger
About: Shandies and other simple beer cocktails are popular in Germany, where they are called Biermischgetränke.
Ingred: 3⁄4 oz Honey syrup (2 parts honey, 1 part water) 3⁄4 oz
Instructions:
Add the cachaça, lemon juice and honey syrup to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into a Collins glass.

Add 5 or 6 ice cubes to the glass and top with beer, pouring gently so it doesn't foam over.

Stir briefly and garnish with a few grinds of pink peppercorn.

Author: Junior Merino
About: This tequila, apple, grapefruit juice and ginger cocktail is no runner-up.
Ingred: .5 oz Fresh pink grapefruit juice.5 oz
.5 oz Fresh Granny Smith apple juice.5 oz
Instructions:
Mix equal amounts of sugar and cinnamon on a small plate and use to coat the rim of a rocks glass.

Fill the glass with ice.

Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.

Shake, and strain into the prepared glass.

Garnish with Granny Smith apple slices.
